pdf:
BI, ML, and MP approaches for each individual locus and the concatenated sequences were used to identify
closely related taxa. Best-fit models of nucleotide substitution were selected using the Akaike information criterion
implemented in MrModeltest v.2.458 and run in PAUP v.4.059 (Supplementary Table S6). BI analyses were
performed using MrBayes v.3.2.660. Two independent analyses of four Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)
chains (3 heated, 1 cold) were run from a random tree for 2 × 106 (for the C. acutatum species complex), 4 × 106
(for the C. boninense species complex), and 6 × 106 (for the C. gloeosporioides species complex) generations or
until the average standard deviation of split frequencies was below 0.01. The analysis was sampled every 1,000
generations, and the first 25% of the generations were discarded as burn-in. The effective sample size and convergence
were monitored with Tracer v1.7.161. MP analyses were performed in PAUP v.4.059 using the heuristic
search option with Tree Bisection Reconnection branch swapping and 100 random sequence addition. Maxtrees
were set to 5,000 and bootstrap analysis was performed with 1,000 replicates. ML analyses were performed in
RAxML v8.2.1062 using the GTR-gamma substitution model with 1,000 bootstrap replicates. Phylogenetic trees
were visualized in FigTree v1.4.3. The concatenated alignments and phylogenetic trees were deposited in Tree-
BASE (www.treeb ase.org) with the study ID 26665.
txt: BI, ML, and MP approaches for each individual locus and the concatenated sequences were used to identify closely related taxa. Best-fit models of nucleotide substitution were selected using the Akaike Information Criterion implemented in MrModeltest v2.4 and run in PAUP v4.0. BI analyses were performed using MrBayes v3.2.6. Two independent analyses with four Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) chains (3 heated, 1 cold) were run from a random tree for 2 × 10^6 generations (for the C. acutatum species complex), 4 × 10^6 generations (for the C. boninense species complex), and 6 × 10^6 generations (for the C. gloeosporioides species complex), or until the average standard deviation of split frequencies was below 0.01. The analysis was sampled every 1,000 generations, with the first 25% of the generations discarded as burn-in. The effective sample size and convergence were monitored with Tracer v1.7.1. MP analyses were performed in PAUP v4.0 using the heuristic search option with Tree Bisection Reconnection branch swapping and 100 random sequence additions. Max-trees were set to 5,000, and bootstrap analysis was performed with 1,000 replicates. ML analyses were performed in RAxML v8.2.10 using the GTR-gamma substitution model with 1,000 bootstrap replicates. Phylogenetic trees were visualized in FigTree v1.4.3. The concatenated alignments and phylogenetic trees were deposited in TreeBASE (www.treebase.org) with the study ID 26665.
q1: What methods and tools were used for phylogenetic analysis of the Colletotrichum species, and how were the best-fit models of nucleotide substitution selected?
q2: How were the Bayesian Inference (BI), Maximum Likelihood (ML), and Maximum Parsimony (MP) analyses performed, and what parameters were used for each method?
q3: Where were the concatenated alignments and phylogenetic trees deposited for public access?
q4: Was the Akaike Information Criterion used to select the best-fit models of nucleotide substitution?
q5: Did the Bayesian Inference analyses use MrBayes with four MCMC chains and sampling every 1,000 generations?
q6: Were the concatenated alignments and phylogenetic trees deposited in TreeBASE with the study ID 26665?

pdf:
We applied the Genealogical Concordance Phylogenetic Species Recognition (GCPSR) method63,64
for species
delimitation of Colletotrichum taxa. A novel species was considered novel the clade was strongly supported as
monophyletic by BI (posterior probability ≥ 0.95), ML (bootstrap ≥ 70%), and MP (bootstrap ≥ 70%) analyses in
the multilocus phylogenetic tree and in the majority of individual gene trees.
txt: We applied the Genealogical Concordance Phylogenetic Species Recognition (GCPSR) method for species delimitation of Colletotrichum taxa. A novel species was considered novel if the clade was strongly supported as monophyletic by BI (posterior probability ≥ 0.95), ML (bootstrap ≥ 70%), and MP (bootstrap ≥ 70%) analyses in the multilocus phylogenetic tree and in the majority of individual gene trees.
q1: What criteria were used to determine if a Colletotrichum clade was considered a novel species using the GCPSR method?
q2: How was strong support for a monophyletic clade assessed in the multilocus phylogenetic tree and individual gene trees?
q3: What methods were employed for species delimitation in this study?
q4: Was a novel species considered novel if it was strongly supported as monophyletic by Bayesian Inference (BI), Maximum Likelihood (ML), and Maximum Parsimony (MP) analyses?
q5: Did the study use a posterior probability of ≥ 0.95 for BI and a bootstrap of ≥ 70% for ML and MP analyses to support novel species?
q6: Was the Genealogical Concordance Phylogenetic Species Recognition (GCPSR) method applied for species delimitation?

pdf:
Morphological characterization. Morphological characterization of one selected isolate from each Colletotrichum
species was conducted following the procedures of Weir et al. (2012) and Damm et al. (2012)12,13,21.
Cultures were grown on PDA and 1/4-strength PDA (1/4 PDA)65 for 2–3 weeks at 25 °C and 30 °C under a
12-h/12-h photoperiod. (Our preliminary tests showed that compared with PDA, the low nutrient medium
1/4 PDA could stimulate sporulation without affecting the size and shape of conidia.) The experiment was performed
in two independent trials, each consisting of two to three plates per isolate. Conidiomata were investigated
using a dissecting microscope (Leica M125). Conidia, conidiophores, setae, asci, ascomata and appressoria
were examined using a light microscope (Leica DM2500). To induce the formation of appressoria, 20–30 μl of
conidial suspension (prepared using sterile dH2O)
was dropped onto a microscope slide, covered with a cover
slip, then incubated in a moist chamber at 25 °C for 2–3 days39.
The lengths and widths of 55 conidiogenous cells,
100 conidia and 30 appressoria were measured using ImageJ software66.
txt: Morphological characterization: Morphological characterization of one selected isolate from each Colletotrichum species was conducted following the procedures of Weir et al. (2012) and Damm et al. (2012). Cultures were grown on PDA and 1/4-strength PDA (1/4 PDA) for 2–3 weeks at 25°C and 30°C under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod. Preliminary tests showed that compared with PDA, the low nutrient medium 1/4 PDA could stimulate sporulation without affecting the size and shape of conidia. The experiment was performed in two independent trials, each consisting of two to three plates per isolate. Conidiomata were investigated using a dissecting microscope (Leica M125). Conidia, conidiophores, setae, asci, ascomata, and appressoria were examined using a light microscope (Leica DM2500). To induce the formation of appressoria, 20–30 μl of conidial suspension (prepared using sterile dH₂O) was dropped onto a microscope slide, covered with a cover slip, and incubated in a moist chamber at 25°C for 2–3 days. The lengths and widths of 55 conidiogenous cells, 100 conidia, and 30 appressoria were measured using ImageJ software.
q1: How was morphological characterization of the Colletotrichum isolates performed, and what media were used for culturing?
q2: What methods and tools were used for examining and measuring the fungal structures such as conidia, conidiophores, and appressoria?
q3: How were the measurements of conidiogenous cells, conidia, and appressoria obtained and analyzed?
q4: Was the morphological characterization of Colletotrichum isolates conducted using PDA and 1/4-strength PDA media?
q5: Did the study use a dissecting microscope for investigating conidiomata and a light microscope for examining conidia, conidiophores, setae, asci, ascomata, and appressoria?
q6: Was ImageJ software used to measure the lengths and widths of conidiogenous cells, conidia, and appressoria?

pdf:
Effect of temperature on mycelial growth. Mycelium-agar discs (6 mm in diameter) were cut with a
sterilized cork borer from the advancing edge of 5- to 7-day-old Colletotrichum spp. colonies then placed (with
the mycelium-side down) onto the center of a 90 mm petri dish containing 25 ml PDA. Colony diameters were
measured after 7 days of incubation at different temperatures under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod in a growth chamber
(Firstek, GC-560H). The mycelial growth rate (mm/day) was calculated as “(the diameter of the colony—the
diameter of the mycelium-agar disc) / 7”. For one selected isolate from each Colletotrichum species, the mycelial
growth rates at 18 °C, 22 °C, 25 °C, 28 °C, 30 °C, and 32 °C were determined in two to three independent trials,
each consisting of three PDA plates per isolate per temperature. The optimum temperature for the mycelial
growth rate was estimated based on the Gaussian process (4 parameter) for nonlinear regression in SigmaPlot
14 (Systat Software, San Jose, CA). Growth of an additional two representative isolates of each Colletotrichum
species, selected from distinct subclades within the species based on the multilocus phylogenetic analysis, was
measured at 25 °C and 30 °C in two independent trials, each consisting of four PDA plates per isolate per temperature.
txt: Effect of temperature on mycelial growth: Mycelium-agar discs (6 mm in diameter) were cut with a sterilized cork borer from the advancing edge of 5- to 7-day-old Colletotrichum spp. colonies and then placed (with the mycelium-side down) onto the center of a 90 mm petri dish containing 25 ml PDA. Colony diameters were measured after 7 days of incubation at different temperatures under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod in a growth chamber (Firstek, GC-560H). The mycelial growth rate (mm/day) was calculated as “(the diameter of the colony—the diameter of the mycelium-agar disc) / 7”. For one selected isolate from each Colletotrichum species, the mycelial growth rates at 18°C, 22°C, 25°C, 28°C, 30°C, and 32°C were determined in two to three independent trials, each consisting of three PDA plates per isolate per temperature. The optimum temperature for the mycelial growth rate was estimated based on a Gaussian process (4 parameter) for nonlinear regression in SigmaPlot 14 (Systat Software, San Jose, CA). Growth of an additional two representative isolates of each Colletotrichum species, selected from distinct subclades within the species based on the multilocus phylogenetic analysis, was measured at 25°C and 30°C in two independent trials, each consisting of four PDA plates per isolate per temperature.
q1: How was the effect of temperature on mycelial growth rate determined for the Colletotrichum spp. isolates?
q2: What temperatures were tested for mycelial growth, and how were the mycelial growth rates calculated?
q3: How was the optimum temperature for mycelial growth estimated, and what additional isolates were tested?
q4: Was the mycelial growth rate calculated using the formula “(the diameter of the colony—the diameter of the mycelium-agar disc) / 7”?
q5: Were the temperatures tested for mycelial growth ranging from 18°C to 32°C?
q6: Was SigmaPlot 14 used for estimating the optimum temperature for mycelial growth based on a Gaussian process for nonlinear regression?

pdf:
Pathogenicity assay. The susceptible cultivar ‘Taoyuan No. 1’ was used for all inoculation tests in this
study. The pathogenicity of Colletotrichum spp. (one isolate from each Colletotrichum species) was examined via
Koch’s postulates. Strawberry seedlings at the four- to five-leaf stage were inoculated by spraying a spore suspension
on the leaves until runoff (
106 spores/ml), and also applying 1 ml of spore suspension (
106 spores/ml) on the
crown region after removal of one to two old leaves. After inoculation, the seedlings were covered with plastic
bags (> 90% relative humidity) for 3 days at 30 °C and then incubated in a growth chamber for 11 days at 30 °C
and 70% relative humidity under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod. The fungi were re-isolated from lesions of diseased
tissues (as mentioned above using the single hypha tip isolation method), then identified based on morphological
characteristics and ITS sequences as described above.
txt: Pathogenicity assay: The susceptible cultivar ‘Taoyuan No. 1’ was used for all inoculation tests in this study. The pathogenicity of Colletotrichum spp. (one isolate from each species) was examined using Koch’s postulates. Strawberry seedlings at the four- to five-leaf stage were inoculated by spraying a spore suspension (10^6 spores/ml) on the leaves until runoff and by applying 1 ml of spore suspension (10^6 spores/ml) on the crown region after removing one to two old leaves. After inoculation, the seedlings were covered with plastic bags (> 90% relative humidity) for 3 days at 30°C and then incubated in a growth chamber for 11 days at 30°C and 70% relative humidity under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod. The fungi were re-isolated from lesions on diseased tissues using the single hyphal tip isolation method and identified based on morphological characteristics and ITS sequences as described above.
q1: What methods were used to inoculate strawberry seedlings with Colletotrichum spp., and how were the seedlings treated post-inoculation?
q2: How was the pathogenicity of Colletotrichum spp. isolates assessed following Koch’s postulates?
q3: What conditions were maintained during the incubation period for the inoculated seedlings?
q4: Was the susceptible cultivar ‘Taoyuan No. 1’ used for all inoculation tests in this study?
q5: Did the inoculation procedure include spraying a spore suspension on the leaves and applying it directly to the crown region of the seedlings?
q6: Were the fungi re-isolated from lesions using the single hyphal tip isolation method and identified based on morphological characteristics and ITS sequences?
metadata: Diversity and pathogenicity of Colletotrichum species causing strawberry anthracnose in Taiwan and description of a new.pdf

pdf:
The virulence levels of different Colletotrichum spp. isolates were determined by inoculation of wounded and
non-wounded detached strawberry leaves. Fully expanded healthy leaves were collected from strawberry seedlings
at the four- to five-leaf stage. For inoculation of wounded leaves, each leaflet was punctured with a sterile
syringe needle on the left and right sides of the midrib, and 10 μl of a spore suspension (1 × 106 spores/ml) was
deposited on the left wound site, and sterile dH2O
was deposited on the right wound site as a control. Similarly,
inoculations of non-wounded leaves were performed in the same way as mentioned above. After inoculation,
the leaves were kept in a moist chamber (a plastic box with dH2O
at the bottom; the cut end of the petiole was
submerged in the water) at 25 °C or 30 °C under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod. Lesion size was measured at 7 and
14 days post inoculation (dpi). Lesions smaller than 0.1 cm in diameter were considered unsuccessful infections.
The same isolates for the “effect of temperature on mycelial growth” test were used for the pathogenicity assay.
For one selected isolate from each Colletotrichum species, inoculations of wounded and non-wounded leaves
were performed at 25 °C and 30 °C in three independent trials, each consisting of 12 leaflets (4 leaves from 4
seedlings) per isolate per treatment. An additional two representative isolates of each Colletotrichum species,
selected from distinct subclades within the species based on the multilocus phylogenetic analysis, were used for
wound inoculation at 30 °C. The experiment was performed in two independent trials, each consisting of 12
leaflets (4 leaves from 4 seedlings) per isolate per treatment.
txt: The virulence levels of different Colletotrichum spp. isolates were determined by inoculating wounded and non-wounded detached strawberry leaves. Fully expanded healthy leaves were collected from strawberry seedlings at the four- to five-leaf stage. For inoculation of wounded leaves, each leaflet was punctured with a sterile syringe needle on both sides of the midrib. Ten μl of a spore suspension (1 × 10^6 spores/ml) was deposited on one wound site, while sterile dH₂O was deposited on the other as a control. Similarly, non-wounded leaves were inoculated in the same manner. After inoculation, the leaves were kept in a moist chamber (a plastic box with dH₂O at the bottom, with the cut end of the petiole submerged in water) at 25°C or 30°C under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod. Lesion size was measured at 7 and 14 days post-inoculation (dpi). Lesions smaller than 0.1 cm in diameter were considered unsuccessful infections. The same isolates used for the “effect of temperature on mycelial growth” test were also used for the pathogenicity assay. For one selected isolate from each Colletotrichum species, inoculations of wounded and non-wounded leaves were performed at 25°C and 30°C in three independent trials, each consisting of 12 leaflets (4 leaves from 4 seedlings) per isolate per treatment. Additionally, two representative isolates of each Colletotrichum species, selected from distinct subclades based on the multilocus phylogenetic analysis, were used for wound inoculation at 30°C. This experiment was performed in two independent trials, each consisting of 12 leaflets (4 leaves from 4 seedlings) per isolate per treatment.
q1: How were the detached strawberry leaves inoculated in the virulence tests, and what controls were used?
q2: What conditions were maintained during the incubation of the inoculated leaves, and how were the lesions measured?
q3: How were the isolates selected for the virulence tests, and what was the experimental design for the inoculations?
q4: Were the detached strawberry leaves inoculated by puncturing them with a sterile syringe needle for wounded leaves, and by applying a spore suspension and water for the control?
q5: Did the incubation of the inoculated leaves occur in a moist chamber at 25°C or 30°C under a 12-h/12-h photoperiod?
q6: Were the same isolates used for the “effect of temperature on mycelial growth” test also used for the pathogenicity assay?

pdf:
Statistical analysis. Data were analyzed by analysis of variance (ANOVA) using the software SPSS v18.
Tukey’s range test or Student’s t-test was used to test for significant differences among or between different treatments
at a significance threshold of P < 0.05.
txt: Statistical analysis: Data were analyzed by analysis of variance (ANOVA) using SPSS v18. Tukey’s range test or Student’s t-test was used to test for significant differences among or between different treatments at a significance threshold of P < 0.05.

Acknowledgements
We acknowledge Dr. Dai-Rong Wu for sharing plant materials. We thank Ms. Feng-Ching Tu, Shih-Jhu Jiang,
and Mr. Ji-Feng Li (Miaoli District Agricultural Research and Extension Station, Taiwan) for help in the
inoculation trials. This research was funded by the Ministry of Science and Technology, Taiwan (grant no.
108-2321-B-002-023-).

pdf:
The effects of a range of concentrations of four nutrients – nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium and calcium – in fertilizer
solutions on the severity of anthracnose on strawberry cv. Nyoho cultivated under a noncirculation hydroponics system
were determined after inoculation with
Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
. Crop growth and tissue nitrogen, phosphorus,
potassium and calcium contents of the entire above-ground parts of the plant were also investigated. Elevated nitrogen
and potassium concentrations in the fertilizer solution increased disease severity in contrast to phosphorus and calcium.
Treatment with either NH
4
or NO
3
nitrogen was not significantly different. The dry weight of the strawberry plants
increased significantly with elevated concentrations of nitrogen (
R
2
= 0·9078) and phosphorus (
R
2
= 0·8842), but was
not influenced by the elevated amounts of potassium (
R
2
= 0·8587) and calcium (
R
2
= 0·6526) concentrations.
Keywords
:
Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
, disease severity, fertilizer, macronutrients, strawberry anthracnose
txt:
The effects of varying concentrations of four nutrients—nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and calcium—in fertilizer solutions on the severity of anthracnose in strawberry cv. Nyoho, cultivated under a non-circulation hydroponics system, were determined after inoculation with Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Crop growth and tissue contents of nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and calcium in the entire above-ground parts of the plant were also investigated. Elevated concentrations of nitrogen and potassium in the fertilizer solution increased disease severity, unlike phosphorus and calcium. There was no significant difference between treatments with NH₄ and NO₃ nitrogen. The dry weight of the strawberry plants increased significantly with higher concentrations of nitrogen (R² = 0.9078) and phosphorus (R² = 0.8842), but was not influenced by elevated amounts of potassium (R² = 0.8587) and calcium (R² = 0.6526).

Keywords: Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, disease severity, fertilizer, macronutrients, strawberry anthracnose
q1: How do different concentrations of nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and calcium in fertilizer solutions affect the severity of anthracnose in strawberry plants?
q2: What impact do varying levels of nitrogen and phosphorus have on the dry weight of strawberry plants compared to potassium and calcium?
q3: Is there a significant difference in disease severity between treatments using NH₄ and NO₃ nitrogen?
q4: Did elevated concentrations of nitrogen and potassium increase the severity of anthracnose?
q5: Was there a significant difference in the dry weight of strawberry plants between treatments with higher concentrations of potassium and calcium?
q6: Did the study find a significant impact of phosphorus on disease severity in strawberry plants?

pdf:
In Korea, strawberries (
Fragaria
×
ananassa
) are favoured
for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables
and fruits is relatively low. In 2003 strawberries
were planted on a total area of 7503 ha in Korea, with
plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7172 ha and
production for fresh market totalling 205 427 tonnes
(Anonymous, 2004). The use of forcing, where strawberries
are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September
and forced into fruiting in December (Oda, 1991), is
increasing in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang,
Akihime and Nyoho used for forcing have proven
difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose
(Nam
et al
., 1998; Kim & Nam, 1999). Anthracnose is
one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing
wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field.
The pathogen known to be responsible for the disease in
Korea is
Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
and was initially
reported in 1992 (Kim
et al
., 1992).
txt: In Korea, strawberries (Fragaria × ananassa) are favored for winter cultivation when the production of other vegetables and fruits is relatively low. In 2003, strawberries were planted on a total area of 7,503 hectares in Korea, with plastic greenhouse cultivation comprising 7,172 hectares and production for the fresh market totaling 205,427 tonnes. The use of forcing, where strawberries are transplanted into greenhouses in mid-September and forced into fruiting in December, is increasing in Korea. June-bearing cultivars such as Maehyang, Akihime, and Nyoho used for forcing have proven difficult to grow due to their susceptibility to anthracnose. Anthracnose is one of the most damaging diseases of strawberries, causing wilting and death of transplants in the nursery field. The pathogen responsible for the disease in Korea is Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, which was initially reported in 1992.

pdf:
The nutritional status of a plant has a major impact on
susceptibility to disease, and this has been exploited for
the reduction of disease severity (Huber & Watson, 1974;
Engelhard, 1989; Huber & McCay-Buis, 1993). In particular,
nitrogen, and the form of nitrogen used, can be
influential. For example, black root rot complex (
Rhizoctonia
fragariae
/
Pratylenchus penetrans
) of strawberries
was suppressed by application of (NH
4
)
2
SO
4
(Elmer &
LaMondia, 1999), and
C. phomoides
was controlled
using NH
4
-N fertilizer (Williams, 1965). However, the
severity of fusarium disease of tomato (Duffy & Dèfago,
1999) and anthracnose (
C. gossypii
) of cotton (Huber &
Watson, 1974) was elevated with NH
4
-N. Similarly, rice
blast disease (
Magnaporthe grisea
) is exacerbated in the
presence of excess nitrogen (Teng, 1994). In contrast,
when calcium was applied, tomato showed increased
resistance to fusarium wilt (Woltz
et al
., 1992).
txt: The nutritional status of a plant significantly impacts its susceptibility to disease, and this has been leveraged to reduce disease severity. In particular, nitrogen and its form can be influential. For instance, black root rot complex (Rhizoctonia fragariae/Pratylenchus penetrans) in strawberries was suppressed by applying (NH₄)₂SO₄, and C. phomoides was controlled using NH₄-N fertilizer. However, the severity of fusarium disease in tomatoes and anthracnose (C. gossypii) in cotton was increased with NH₄-N. Similarly, rice blast disease (Magnaporthe grisea) is exacerbated by excess nitrogen. In contrast, the application of calcium increased resistance to fusarium wilt in tomatoes.

q4: Did the application of (NH₄)₂SO₄ suppress black root rot complex in strawberries?

q6: Does excess nitrogen exacerbate rice blast disease?

Plant preparation
Tissue-cultured seedlings of strawberry cv. Nyoho at the
three-leaf stage were transplanted into 15 cm (1·6 L) plastic
pots containing perlite. Transplants were irrigated for
a month with distilled water to leach out nutrients contained
in the perlite. This also lowered the tissue nutrient
content of the strawberry plants. Following this, plants
were watered with the nutrient treatment solution every
2 days for 50 days.
txt:
Plant Preparation
Tissue-cultured seedlings of strawberry cv. Nyoho at the three-leaf stage were transplanted into 15 cm (1.6 L) plastic pots containing perlite. The transplants were irrigated with distilled water for a month to leach out the nutrients contained in the perlite and to lower the tissue nutrient content of the strawberry plants. Following this, the plants were watered with the nutrient treatment solution every 2 days for 50 days.

txt:
Nutrient Solutions
Hoagland nutrient solution (Hoagland & Arnon, 1950) was modified to create treatment solutions with the following concentrations: 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 30 mM nitrogen; 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 3 mM phosphorus; 0, 10, 20, and 30 mM potassium; and 0, 1.5, 3, 4.5, and 6.0 mM calcium. The composition and chemical sources of micronutrients are detailed in Table 1. The pH of all treatment solutions was adjusted to 6.5 using 1 N HCl or KOH. The effect of the form of nitrogen was tested by comparing 5, 10, and 15 mM nitrate and ammonium compounds.

Plant analysis
Plant tissue was sampled from shoots after 1 month of
nutrient solution treatments. Tissue samples were washed
with 0·2 N HCl for 1 min, rinsed with distilled water,
dried for 2 days at 70
°
C, and ground in a Wiley mill to pass
through the 1 mm particle size sieve. Total N was determined
by a modified Kjeldahl procedure which included
a salicylic acid pretreatment to aid in the reduction of NO
3
(Eastin, 1978). Tissue used for P, K and Ca analysis
was dry-ashed at 500
°
C, dehydrated in HCl and finally
dissolved in 0·5 N HCl. Analysis of K and Ca was done by
atomic absorption spectrometry, and colorimetric analysis
was performed for P (Chapman & Pratt, 1961).
txt:
Plant Analysis
Plant tissue was sampled from shoots after 1 month of nutrient solution treatments. Tissue samples were washed with 0.2 N HCl for 1 minute, rinsed with distilled water, dried for 2 days at 70°C, and ground in a Wiley mill to pass through a 1 mm particle size sieve. Total nitrogen was determined by a modified Kjeldahl procedure, which included a salicylic acid pretreatment to aid in the reduction of NO₃⁻. Tissue samples used for phosphorus, potassium, and calcium analysis were dry-ashed at 500°C, dehydrated in HCl, and finally dissolved in 0.5 N HCl. Potassium and calcium were analyzed by atomic absorption spectrometry, while phosphorus was determined by colorimetric analysis.

pdf:
Inoculation and disease assessment
Growth characteristics were determined for plants after
1 month of nutrient solution treatments. Inoculum of
C. gloeosporioides
(CGF43) was prepared at 10
6
conidia
mL
−
1
and sprayed on the plants. The inoculated plants
were incubated in dew chamber at 30
°
C and 100% RH
for 2 days and then moved to a glasshouse held between
24 and 28
°
C (Gupton & Smith, 1991). After 17 days, the
disease severity on each plant was rated. Disease severity
was rated as a disease index (DI) on a scale of 0–4, as
follows: 0, healthy; 1, < 50% of petioles affected; 2,
≥
50%
of petioles affected; 3, wilted; 4, necrosis formed on entire
plants (Ishikawa
et al
., 1989).
txt:
Inoculation and Disease Assessment
Growth characteristics were assessed for plants after 1 month of nutrient solution treatments. Inoculum of C. gloeosporioides (CGF43) was prepared at 10⁶ conidia/mL and sprayed on the plants. The inoculated plants were incubated in a dew chamber at 30°C and 100% relative humidity for 2 days, then moved to a glasshouse maintained at 24–28°C. After 17 days, disease severity on each plant was rated using a disease index (DI) scale of 0–4: 0 = healthy; 1 = < 50% of petioles affected; 2 = ≥ 50% of petioles affected; 3 = wilted; 4 = necrosis on entire plants.

Data analysis
Data from nutrient concentrations and different nitrogen
source trials were subjected to analysis of variance, and
treatment means were compared by Duncan’s multiple
range test at
P
= 0·05. The relationships between nutrient
concentrations and dry weight, and nutrient concentrations
and disease index, were evaluated using regression
analysis (Duffy & Dèfago, 1999; Choi
et al
., 2000). All
data analysis was performed using the SAS program (SAS
Institute, Inc., USA).
txt:
Data Analysis
Data from nutrient concentrations and different nitrogen source trials were subjected to analysis of variance, and treatment means were compared using Duncan’s multiple range test at P=0.05. The relationships between nutrient concentrations and dry weight, as well as between nutrient concentrations and disease index, were evaluated using regression analysis. All data analyses were performed using the SAS program (SAS Institute, Inc., USA).

pdf:
Anthracnose symptoms first appeared in the nitrogen
treatment approximately 2 weeks after inoculation. A
positive correlation (adjusted (Adj)
R
2
= 0·96) was found
between nitrogen concentration of treatment solution and
anthracnose disease (Fig. 1a). Disease was greatest (DI
∼
3) at a nitrogen concentration of 30 m
m
. Anthracnose
tended to be more severe in treatments receiving NH
4
than
NO
3
, but these differences were not significant according
to Duncan’s multiple range test (
P =
0·05) (Fig. 2). A similar
positive relationship (adjusted
R
2
= 0·84) between disease
and potassium concentration of treatment solution was
shown, with a maximum DI of
∼
3 at 30 m
m
potassium
(Fig. 1c). In contrast, neither increasing concentrations
of calcium (
P =
0·62) nor those of phosphorus (
P =
0·68)
had a patterned effect on disease (Fig. 1b and d). For all
treatments, the relative dry matter content of each nutrient
in the test plants increased with increasing concentration
in the treatment solution (Fig. 1).
txt: Anthracnose symptoms first appeared in the nitrogen treatment approximately 2 weeks after inoculation. A positive correlation (adjusted R2=0.96) was found between nitrogen concentration in the treatment solution and anthracnose severity (Fig. 1a). The disease was most severe (DI ≈ 3) at a nitrogen concentration of 30 mM. Anthracnose tended to be more severe in treatments receiving NH₄⁺ compared to NO₃⁻, but these differences were not significant according to Duncan’s multiple range test (P=0.05) (Fig. 2). A similar positive relationship (adjusted R2=0.84) between disease severity and potassium concentration was observed, with a maximum DI of ≈ 3 at 30 mM potassium (Fig. 1c). In contrast, increasing concentrations of calcium (P=0.62) and phosphorus (P=0.68) did not show a patterned effect on disease severity (Fig. 1b and d). For all treatments, the relative dry matter content of each nutrient in the test plants increased with increasing concentration in the treatment solution (Fig. 1).
q1: What was the relationship between nitrogen concentration and anthracnose severity?
q2: How did anthracnose severity in treatments with NH₄⁺ compare to those with NO₃⁻?
q3: Did increasing concentrations of calcium and phosphorus show a patterned effect on anthracnose severity?
q4: Was a positive correlation found between nitrogen concentration and anthracnose severity?
q5: Did the severity of anthracnose reach its maximum at a nitrogen concentration of 30 mM?

pdf:
Previous studies have shown correlations between
nitrogen concentration and severity of anthracnose, as in
the case of cotton (Huber & Watson, 1974). Previously,
Choi
et al
. (2000) showed that, as tissue nitrogen content
decreased, Ca and Mn contents, which have a direct role
in phenolic metabolism, increased in the strawberry. Manganese
may increase synthesis of host defence products
and thereby reduce disease incidence and/or severity
(Huber & McCay-Buis, 1993), whilst calcium has been
shown to inhibit anthracnose (caused by
C. gloeosporioides
or
C. acutatum
) in apples (Biggs, 1999) and decrease
postharvest disease development on strawberry (Cheour
et al
., 1990). Woltz
et al
. (1992) also found that treatment
with CaCO
3
(3·0 kg m
−
3
) in tomato reduced fusarium
crown rot disease. Calcium may be important for resistance
against certain cell-wall-degrading enzymes produced
by fungal pathogens (Conway & Sams, 1984; Biggs
& Peterson, 1990). However, in this study, no effect was
found of calcium content on anthracnose disease in strawberry.
As manganese content is increased under low nitrogen
conditions in plants, additional work is needed to
determine whether manganese levels are related to anthracnose
development. Phosphorus supplied as phosphite was
effective at reducing phytophthora root and crown rot
on tomato and pepper plants but also suppressed plant
growth (Förster
et al
., 1998). In the study reported here,
phosphorus concentration had no influence on anthracnose
development.
txt: Previous studies have shown correlations between nitrogen concentration and the severity of anthracnose, similar to observations in cotton (Huber & Watson, 1974). Choi et al. (2000) demonstrated that as tissue nitrogen content decreased, the contents of calcium (Ca) and manganese (Mn), which play a direct role in phenolic metabolism, increased in strawberries. Manganese may enhance the synthesis of host defense products and thereby reduce disease incidence and/or severity (Huber & McCay-Buis, 1993). Calcium has been shown to inhibit anthracnose caused by C. gloeosporioides or C. acutatum in apples (Biggs, 1999) and to decrease postharvest disease development in strawberries (Cheour et al., 1990). Woltz et al. (1992) also found that treatment with CaCO₃ (3.0 kg/m³) in tomatoes reduced fusarium crown rot disease. Calcium may be crucial for resistance against certain cell-wall-degrading enzymes produced by fungal pathogens (Conway & Sams, 1984; Biggs & Peterson, 1990). However, in this study, no effect of calcium content on anthracnose disease in strawberries was observed. As manganese content increases under low nitrogen conditions in plants, further research is needed to determine whether manganese levels are related to anthracnose development. Phosphorus supplied as phosphite was effective in reducing Phytophthora root and crown rot on tomato and pepper plants but also suppressed plant growth (Förster et al., 1998). In the study reported here, phosphorus concentration had no influence on anthracnose development.
q1: How does the study relate to previous research on nitrogen concentration and anthracnose severity?

pdf:
Strawberry prefers NH4 to NO3 nitrogen for optimal
growth (Park, 1990). Other studies have shown the use
of the former increases cotton anthracnose (Bollenbacher
& Fulton, 1971) and fusarium crown rot severity (Woltz
et al., 1992) more than the use of nitrate. It was found
on average that strawberry plants receiving ammonium
nitrogen had more disease than those receiving nitrate
treatments, but these differences were not significant.
txt: Strawberries prefer NH₄⁺ to NO₃⁻ nitrogen for optimal growth (Park, 1990). Other studies have shown that the use of NH₄⁺ increases anthracnose in cotton (Bollenbacher & Fulton, 1971) and fusarium crown rot severity (Woltz et al., 1992) more than the use of nitrate. In this study, strawberry plants receiving ammonium nitrogen generally had more disease than those receiving nitrate treatments, but these differences were not significant.

pdf:
It has been shown that increasing nitrogen and potassium
in nutrient solutions resulted in higher dry matter
percentages of both elements in strawberry but also
increased the severity of anthracnose. To decrease anthracnose
in strawberries, it is suggested that a minimum of
nitrogen and potassium should be present in any fertilizer
used and that this should not exceed 15 and 10 units of
nitrogen and potassium, respectively.
txt: Increasing nitrogen and potassium in nutrient solutions has been shown to result in higher dry matter percentages of both elements in strawberries but also increases the severity of anthracnose. To reduce anthracnose in strawberries, it is recommended that the minimum amounts of nitrogen and potassium in fertilizers should not exceed 15 mM and 10 mM, respectively.
q1: What is the effect of increasing nitrogen and potassium in nutrient solutions on dry matter percentages and anthracnose severity in strawberries?
q2: What are the recommended maximum concentrations of nitrogen and potassium in fertilizers to reduce anthracnose in strawberries?

q4: Does increasing nitrogen and potassium in nutrient solutions increase both the dry matter percentages and the severity of anthracnose in strawberries?
q5: Is it recommended to keep nitrogen concentrations in fertilizers below 15 mM to reduce anthracnose in strawberries?
q6: Should potassium concentrations in fertilizers not exceed 10 mM to help reduce anthracnose severity?

pdf:
Abstract. Three Colletotrichum species—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph Glomerella acutata J.C.
Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in
Penz. [teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk]—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria
·ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the
southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, may infect all aboveground plant parts;
however, the disease is most severe when the fungus infects the crown, causing crown rot, wilt, and death. Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides was responsible for an epidemic of anthracnose crown rot in strawberry nurseries in Arkansas and North
Carolina in the late 1970s. The anthracnose fruit rot pathogen, C. acutatum, was first reported in 1986 on strawberry in the
United States. Since the 1980s, increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots in the United States may be related
to changes in cultivars and to widespread use of annual plasticulture production rather than the matted-row production
system. Anthracnose investigations in the United States have concentrated on its epidemiology and differences among the
three causal Colletotrichum spp. in their cultural, morphological, and molecular characteristics; their infection processes;
and their pathogenicity. Results from these studies have resulted in a better understanding of the diseases and have led to
better disease control. Strawberries grown in soils with high nitrogen levels are more susceptible to anthracnose than are
those grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those amended with calcium nitrate. Anthracnose is spread more rapidly
in fields that have overhead irrigation and plastic mulch than in fields where drip irrigation and straw mulch are used.
Fungicide efficacy has been determined in in-vitro, greenhouse, and field studies, and pathogen resistance to some
fungicides has been detected. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars are a major objective of most strawberry breeding programs
in the southern United States.
txt: Abstract. Three Colletotrichum species—Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds (teleomorph Glomerella acutata J.C. Guerber & J.C. Correll), Colletotrichum fragariae A.N. Brooks, and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. in Penz. [teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk]—are major pathogens of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa). Strawberry anthracnose crown rot has been a destructive disease in commercial strawberry fields in the southeastern United States since the 1930s. The causal fungus, C. fragariae, can infect all aboveground plant parts; however, the disease is most severe when it infects the crown, causing crown rot, wilt, and death. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides was responsible for an epidemic of anthracnose crown rot in strawberry nurseries in Arkansas and North Carolina in the late 1970s. The anthracnose fruit rot pathogen, C. acutatum, was first reported on strawberry in the United States in 1986. Since the 1980s, increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots in the United States may be related to changes in cultivars and the widespread use of annual plasticulture production rather than the matted-row production system. Research on anthracnose in the United States has focused on its epidemiology, differences among the three causal Colletotrichum species in their cultural, morphological, and molecular characteristics; their infection processes; and their pathogenicity. These studies have led to a better understanding of the diseases and improved disease control. Strawberries grown in soils with high nitrogen levels are more susceptible to anthracnose than those grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those amended with calcium nitrate. Anthracnose spreads more rapidly in fields with overhead irrigation and plastic mulch than in fields with drip irrigation and straw mulch. Fungicide efficacy has been evaluated through in vitro, greenhouse, and field studies, with some pathogen resistance to fungicides detected. Developing anthracnose-resistant cultivars remains a major objective of strawberry breeding programs in the southern United States.
q1: What factors have contributed to the increased prevalence of anthracnose in U.S. strawberry crops since the 1980s?
q2: How do different Colletotrichum species vary in terms of their pathogenicity and infection processes in strawberries?
q3: What are some agricultural practices that increase the spread of anthracnose in strawberry fields?
q4: Has Colletotrichum fragariae been identified as a major cause of crown rot in strawberry plants?
q5: Did Colletotrichum gloeosporioides cause an epidemic of anthracnose crown rot in the late 1970s?
q6: Are strawberries grown in high nitrogen soils more susceptible to anthracnose infections than those grown with calcium nitrate amendments?

pdf:
Colletotrichum species cause serious diseases
of many fruit and vegetable crops
worldwide, and three species, C. fragariae,
C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides, cause
anthracnose diseases of strawberry (Smith
and Black, 1990). Since the 1930s, anthracnose
crown rot caused by C. fragariae and
C. gloeosporioides has been a destructive
disease in strawberry nurseries and fruitproduction
fields in the southeastern United
States (Brooks, 1931). In 1986, the presence
of the anthracnose fruit rot pathogen,
C. acutatum, was first reported on strawberry
in the United States (Smith and Black, 1986).
Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and
crown rots in the United States since the
1980s may be related to the shift from
matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture
production system, as well as to changes in
cultivars. Anthracnose diseases are increasing
in importance and resulting in major
economic losses to strawberry growers
worldwide. The objective of this report is to
summarize anthracnose related research from
the United States (excluding research from
California and Florida) so that we can better
understand these diseases and their control.
txt: Colletotrichum species cause serious diseases of many fruit and vegetable crops worldwide, with C. fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides being responsible for anthracnose diseases in strawberries (Smith and Black, 1990). Since the 1930s, anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides has been a significant problem in strawberry nurseries and fruit production fields in the southeastern United States (Brooks, 1931). The presence of the anthracnose fruit rot pathogen, C. acutatum, was first reported on strawberries in the United States in 1986 (Smith and Black, 1986). Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots since the 1980s may be attributed to the shift from matted-row culture to annual plasticulture production systems, as well as changes in cultivars. Anthracnose diseases are becoming increasingly important, leading to major economic losses for strawberry growers worldwide. This report aims to summarize anthracnose-related research from the United States (excluding California and Florida) to enhance our understanding of these diseases and their control.
q1: What impact has the shift from matted-row culture to annual plasticulture had on anthracnose disease outbreaks in strawberries?
q2: How has the emergence of Colletotrichum acutatum as a pathogen affected strawberry production since it was first reported in 1986?
q3: Why is anthracnose becoming a more significant issue for strawberry growers worldwide?
q4: Has anthracnose crown rot caused by Colletotrichum fragariae been a problem since the 1930s in the southeastern United States?
q5: Did changes in strawberry production systems contribute to increased anthracnose outbreaks since the 1980s?
q6: Is Colletotrichum acutatum responsible for anthracnose fruit rot in strawberries?

pdf:
Colletotrichum fragariae, C. acutatum,
and C. gloeosporioides (Howard et al.,
1992; Smith, 1998a, 1988b, 1988c) cause
anthracnose diseases of strawberries. C. fragariae
was assumed to be the causal agent of
strawberry anthracnose in the United States
until 1986 when Smith and Black (1986)
reported the presence of C. acutatum on
strawberry in the United States. This fungus
had previously been reported to cause
anthracnose fruit rot of strawberry in Queensland,
Australia (Simmonds, 1965); however,
it had probably been present in the United
States for some time under the name of
Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984). Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides causes anthracnose
crown rot, petiole lesions, and leaf spots
indistinguishable from those caused by
C. fragariae.
txt: Colletotrichum fragariae, C. acutatum, and C. gloeosporioides (Howard et al., 1992; Smith, 1998a, 1988b, 1988c) are responsible for anthracnose diseases in strawberries. Until 1986, C. fragariae was assumed to be the primary causal agent of strawberry anthracnose in the United States. However, Smith and Black (1986) reported the presence of C. acutatum on strawberries in the United States. This fungus had previously been identified as causing anthracnose fruit rot of strawberries in Queensland, Australia (Simmonds, 1965), but it had likely been present in the United States for some time under the name Gloeosporium spp. (Maas, 1984). Colletotrichum gloeosporioides causes anthracnose crown rot, petiole lesions, and leaf spots that are indistinguishable from those caused by C. fragariae.
q1: What discovery in 1986 changed the understanding of the primary causal agent of anthracnose in U.S. strawberries?
q2: How do the symptoms caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides compare to those caused by Colletotrichum fragariae in strawberries?
q3: Why was Colletotrichum acutatum previously misidentified as Gloeosporium spp. in the United States?
q4: Was Colletotrichum acutatum first identified in Australia as a cause of anthracnose fruit rot?
q5: Were the symptoms of anthracnose caused by C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae indistinguishable in strawberries?
q6: Did researchers initially assume Colletotrichum fragariae was the sole cause of anthracnose in U.S. strawberries before 1986?

pdf:
In a series of comparative studies of these
three major causal agents of strawberry
anthracnose, Smith and Black (1990) examined
the cultural characteristics, conidia,
appressoria, and setae of 24 Colletotrichum
isolates. Colletotrichum fragariae isolates
developed beige to olive to dark gray colonies,
did not form the ascigerous state in
culture, and their conidia were typically
cylindrical with one end sharply tapered
and the other end rounded. Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides isolates were very similar
except they formed the Glomerella cingulata
ascigerous state in culture and their conidia
usually were rounded on both ends. Isolates
of both C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides
produced dark black setae, visible with a
hand lens, in acervuli in culture and on
petiole, stolon, and fruit lesions. Colletotrichum
acutatum isolates produced fusiform
conidia tapered on both ends; developed
white, pink, orange, rose, or beige colonies;
and did not form setae or the ascigerous state
in culture. The growth rate of C. acutatum in
culture was slower than the other two species
at all temperatures tested with the greatest
difference being at 32 C.
txt: In a series of comparative studies on the three major causal agents of strawberry anthracnose, Smith and Black (1990) examined the cultural characteristics, conidia, appressoria, and setae of 24 Colletotrichum isolates. Colletotrichum fragariae isolates developed colonies ranging from beige to olive to dark gray, did not form the ascigerous state in culture, and produced cylindrical conidia with one end sharply tapered and the other end rounded. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides isolates were similar but formed the Glomerella cingulata ascigerous state in culture, and their conidia were typically rounded at both ends. Both C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides produced dark black setae, which were visible with a hand lens, in acervuli in culture as well as on petiole, stolon, and fruit lesions. Colletotrichum acutatum isolates produced fusiform conidia tapered at both ends, developed colonies in white, pink, orange, rose, or beige colors, and did not form setae or the ascigerous state in culture. Additionally, the growth rate of C. acutatum was slower than the other two species at all tested temperatures, with the most significant difference observed at 32°C.
q1: How do the conidia of Colletotrichum fragariae differ in shape from those of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides?
q2: What are the differences in colony color and growth rate between Colletotrichum acutatum and the other two species of Colletotrichum?
q3: What cultural or morphological traits distinguish Colletotrichum acutatum from Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides?
q4: Did Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides both produce dark black setae in culture?
q5: Did Colletotrichum acutatum develop colonies in a variety of colors, including white, pink, and beige?
q6: Was the growth rate of Colletotrichum acutatum slower than the other two species at 32°C?

pdf:
Colletotrichum fragariae, the ‘‘original’’
anthracnose fungus, was first identified in
Florida in 1931 (Brooks, 1931). It spread
throughout the southeastern United States
and was responsible for crown rot and death
of many plants in strawberry nurseries in the
1970s (Horn et al., 1972). It has a narrow host
range, infecting only strawberry and a few
weed hosts, and is rarely found outside the
southeastern United States. Colletotrichum
fragariae generally causes more severe petiole
and crown symptoms than C. acutatum,
and C. fragariae is considered by some to
be a host-specific or con-specific form of
C. gloeosporioides (Howard, 1983; Howard
et al., 1992; Sutton, 1992).
txt: Colletotrichum fragariae, the "original" anthracnose fungus, was first identified in Florida in 1931 (Brooks, 1931). It spread throughout the southeastern United States and was responsible for crown rot and death of many strawberry plants in nurseries during the 1970s (Horn et al., 1972). This species has a narrow host range, infecting only strawberries and a few weed hosts, and is rarely found outside the southeastern United States. C. fragariae generally causes more severe petiole and crown symptoms compared to C. acutatum, and is considered by some to be a host-specific or con-specific form of C. gloeosporioides (Howard, 1983; Howard et al., 1992; Sutton, 1992).
q1: Why is Colletotrichum fragariae considered to have a narrow host range compared to other Colletotrichum species?
q2: What factors contributed to the significant spread of Colletotrichum fragariae in strawberry nurseries during the 1970s?
q3: How does Colletotrichum fragariae differ in symptom severity from Colletotrichum acutatum when infecting strawberry plants?
q4: Was Colletotrichum fragariae first identified in Florida in 1931?
q5: Does Colletotrichum fragariae generally cause more severe crown rot than Colletotrichum acutatum in strawberries?
q6: Is Colletotrichum fragariae considered host-specific to strawberries and a few weed species?
