pdf:
In the late 1970s, C. gloeosporioides was
identified as the causal agent on plants
obtained from Arkansas and North Carolina
nurseries that died from a crown rot identical
to that caused by C. fragariae (Howard et al.,
1992). It has a wide host and geographic
range, causing diseases of many plant hosts
worldwide.
txt: In the late 1970s, C. gloeosporioides was identified as the causal agent of crown rot on plants from nurseries in Arkansas and North Carolina. This disease was identical to that caused by C. fragariae (Howard et al., 1992). C. gloeosporioides has a wide host and geographic range, causing diseases in many plant hosts worldwide.
q1: What similarities exist between the diseases caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and Colletotrichum fragariae in strawberry plants?
q2: How does the host range of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides compare to that of Colletotrichum fragariae?
q3: Why was Colletotrichum gloeosporioides identified as a causal agent of crown rot in Arkansas and North Carolina nurseries in the late 1970s?
q4: Was Colletotrichum gloeosporioides identified as the cause of crown rot in strawberry nurseries in Arkansas and North Carolina in the late 1970s?
q5: Does Colletotrichum gloeosporioides have a broader host range than Colletotrichum fragariae?
q6: Are the symptoms of crown rot caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides identical to those caused by Colletotrichum fragariae?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
The greatest economic losses due to
anthracnose on strawberry are from fruit rot
caused by C. acutatum, which also infects
many other fruit and vegetable crops, including
apples, tomatoes, peppers, peaches, blueberries,
blackberries, and grapes (Bernstein
et al., 1995; Howard et al., 1992; Smith,
2002). The presence of the pathogen has been
reported on strawberries in almost all areas
of the world where they are grown. Crown
infections of strawberry plants by C. acutatum
often result in stunted plants rather than
plant death. Infected plants usually do not
thrive after transplantation and produce few
berries at harvest.
txt: The greatest economic losses due to anthracnose on strawberries are attributed to fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. This pathogen also affects a wide range of fruit and vegetable crops, including apples, tomatoes, peppers, peaches, blueberries, blackberries, and grapes (Bernstein et al., 1995; Howard et al., 1992; Smith, 2002). C. acutatum has been reported on strawberries in nearly all regions where they are cultivated. While crown infections by C. acutatum often result in stunted plants rather than plant death, infected plants typically do not thrive after transplantation and yield few berries at harvest.
q1: Why does Colletotrichum acutatum cause the greatest economic losses among the Colletotrichum species affecting strawberries?
q2: How does the impact of Colletotrichum acutatum on strawberry crowns differ from its effect on fruit rot?
q3: What other fruit and vegetable crops are susceptible to infection by Colletotrichum acutatum?
q4: Is Colletotrichum acutatum responsible for fruit rot on strawberries in most regions where they are cultivated?
q5: Does Colletotrichum acutatum affect a wide range of crops, including apples, tomatoes, and blueberries?
q6: Do strawberry plants infected with Colletotrichum acutatum yield fewer berries after transplantation?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Historically, C. acutatum has been considered
to be the anthracnose fruit-rotting
pathogen, and C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides
have been associated with petiole and
stolon lesions and crown rot; however, all
three species may cause similar symptoms
and may be found to occur on the same plant
(Howard et al., 1992). Identification of these
pathogens should be based on classical taxonomic
characteristics or molecular techniques,
not symptoms.
txt: Historically, C. acutatum has been identified primarily as the pathogen responsible for anthracnose fruit rot, while C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides have been associated with petiole and stolon lesions as well as crown rot. However, all three species can cause similar symptoms and may even occur on the same plant (Howard et al., 1992). Accurate identification of these pathogens should rely on classical taxonomic characteristics or molecular techniques, rather than just symptoms.
q1: Why is it important to use classical taxonomic characteristics or molecular techniques to accurately identify Colletotrichum species on strawberries?
q2: How can the symptoms caused by Colletotrichum acutatum, C. fragariae, and C. gloeosporioides overlap on strawberry plants?
q3: What roles do Colletotrichum fragariae and C. gloeosporioides play in strawberry diseases compared to Colletotrichum acutatum?
q4: Can all three species of Colletotrichum cause similar symptoms on the same strawberry plant?
q5: Is Colletotrichum acutatum primarily responsible for anthracnose fruit rot in strawberries?
q6: Should identification of Colletotrichum species rely on molecular techniques for accuracy?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Results of several studies suggest that
C. acutatum may have evolved into a subgroup
that is highly virulent and host-specific
to strawberries. In one of these studies
(Denoyes-Rothan et al., 2002), 95 isolates
of Colletotrichum, including 81 isolates of
C. acutatum (62 from strawberry) and 14
isolates of C. gloeosporioides (13 from
strawberry), were characterized by various
molecular methods and pathogenicity tests.
Results based on random amplified polymorphic
DNA (RAPD) polymorphism and internal
transcribed spacer 2 (ITS2) sequence data
provided genetic evidence of two subgroups
within C. acutatum. The first subgroup,
characterized as CA-clonal, included only
isolates from strawberry and exhibited identical
RAPD patterns and nearly identical
ITS2 sequence analyses. A larger genetic
group, CA-variable, included isolates from
various hosts and exhibited variable RAPD
patterns and divergent ITS2 sequence analysis.
On the bases of these molecular data,
Denoyes-Rothan et al. (2002) proposed that
the CA-clonal subgroup contained closely
related, highly virulent C. acutatum isolates
that may have developed host specialization
to strawberry. Isolates of Colletotrichum spp.
have been disseminated worldwide, probably
through international plant exchanges, as
their genetic polymorphism and geographical
origins are not correlated (Denoyes-Rothan
et al., 2002; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas,
2005).
txt: Results from several studies suggest that C. acutatum may have evolved into a highly virulent, host-specific subgroup targeting strawberries. In one such study (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 2002), 95 Colletotrichum isolates were examined, including 81 isolates of C. acutatum (62 from strawberries) and 14 isolates of C. gloeosporioides (13 from strawberries). Using various molecular methods and pathogenicity tests, the study revealed genetic evidence of two subgroups within C. acutatum. The first subgroup, termed CA-clonal, comprised only strawberry isolates with identical RAPD patterns and nearly identical ITS2 sequences. In contrast, the CA-variable subgroup included isolates from diverse hosts, displaying variable RAPD patterns and divergent ITS2 sequences. Based on these molecular data, Denoyes-Rothan et al. (2002) proposed that the CA-clonal subgroup consists of closely related, highly virulent C. acutatum isolates that may have developed a specialization for strawberries. Additionally, Colletotrichum isolates have been spread globally, likely through international plant exchanges, as their genetic diversity and geographical distribution are not strongly correlated (Denoyes-Rothan et al., 2002; Sreenivasaprasad and Talhinhas, 2005).
q1: How did molecular methods in the Denoyes-Rothan et al. (2002) study reveal the presence of distinct subgroups within Colletotrichum acutatum?
q2: What evidence suggests that the CA-clonal subgroup of Colletotrichum acutatum has evolved to specialize in infecting strawberries?
q3: How has the global spread of Colletotrichum isolates been influenced by international plant exchanges?
q4: Did the Denoyes-Rothan et al. (2002) study identify two subgroups within Colletotrichum acutatum based on molecular data?
q5: Are isolates from the CA-clonal subgroup highly virulent and host-specific to strawberries?
q6: Is the global distribution of Colletotrichum isolates weakly correlated with their genetic diversity?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Anthracnose crown rot (Smith, 1998a),
caused by either C. fragariae or C. gloeosporioides,
is first apparent by the wilting of
the youngest leaves in the hottest part of the
day. The young wilted leaves may appear to
recover and become turgid in the evenings;
however, most will wilt and die after a few
days. Shortly after plants wilt, a red discoloration
appears within the crown tissue, and
the causal pathogen may be isolated from
discolored tissue. After the plants have been
dead for several days, the crown tissue will
turn dark brown to black, and then Colletotrichum
spp. is difficult to isolate. Colletotrichum
acutatum also may cause crown
death; however, typically a single side crown
is infected rather than the entire crown, and
infected plants are stunted but do not die.
Each of the three Colletotrichum spp. may
cause petiole and stolon lesions which are
dark brown or black and sunken and often
girdle the petiole or stolon. Pink masses of
conidia are usually visible near the center of
each lesion. All three species also cause leaf
spots (Howard et al., 1992; Maas and Palm,
1997; Smith, 1998c). Black leaf spot, typically
caused by C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides,
is characterized by gray or light
black spots, usually not necrotic, peppered
across the top surface of the strawberry leaflets.
C. acutatum more typically causes irregular
leaf spot, the primary symptom of which
is the appearance of necrotic black lesions
at the tip of the leaflets. All three Colletotrichum
spp. also cause flower blights and
fruit rots (Smith, 1998b). Fully open flowers
are much more susceptible than closed buds
(Smith, 1993). Infected green fruit are often
hard and brown and mummify rather than
ripen. Anthracnose lesions on ripe fruit are
firm, slightly sunken and covered with pink
spore masses. Colletotrichum acutatum also
causes root lesions.
txt: Anthracnose crown rot, caused by either C. fragariae or C. gloeosporioides (Smith, 1998a), is initially evident by the wilting of the youngest leaves during the hottest part of the day. Although the young wilted leaves may appear to recover and become turgid in the evenings, most will ultimately wilt and die within a few days. Shortly after wilting, a red discoloration appears in the crown tissue, and the pathogen can be isolated from these discolored areas. After several days, the crown tissue turns dark brown to black, making it difficult to isolate Colletotrichum spp. Colletotrichum acutatum can also cause crown death, but typically affects a single side of the crown rather than the entire crown, resulting in stunted plants that do not die. Each of the three Colletotrichum species can cause petiole and stolon lesions that are dark brown or black, sunken, and often girdle the petiole or stolon. Pink masses of conidia are usually visible near the center of each lesion. Additionally, all three species cause leaf spots (Howard et al., 1992; Maas and Palm, 1997; Smith, 1998c). Black leaf spots, typically caused by C. fragariae and C. gloeosporioides, appear as gray or light black spots, usually non-necrotic, on the top surface of strawberry leaflets. In contrast, C. acutatum more commonly causes irregular leaf spots characterized by necrotic black lesions at the tips of the leaflets. All three Colletotrichum spp. can also cause flower blights and fruit rots (Smith, 1998b). Fully open flowers are much more susceptible than closed buds (Smith, 1993). Infected green fruit often become hard, brown, and mummify instead of ripening. On ripe fruit, anthracnose lesions are firm, slightly sunken, and covered with pink spore masses. Colletotrichum acutatum also causes root lesions.
q1: What are the typical symptoms of anthracnose crown rot caused by Colletotrichum fragariae or Colletotrichum gloeosporioides?
q2: How does Colletotrichum acutatum differ in its effect on strawberry crowns compared to the other Colletotrichum species?
q3: What are the distinguishing characteristics of leaf spots caused by Colletotrichum acutatum compared to those caused by Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides?
q4: Do Colletotrichum fragariae and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides typically cause dark brown to black discoloration in the crown tissue?
q5: Can Colletotrichum acutatum cause root lesions in addition to fruit rot and crown disease?
q6: Are fully open strawberry flowers more susceptible to anthracnose than closed buds?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Curry et al. (2002) studied the infection
process of strawberry petioles and stolons by
C. acutatum and C. fragariae using light and
electron microscopy. Both fungal species
invaded the host tissue in a similar manner;
however, C. fragariae invaded the plants
more rapidly than did C. acutatum. Both
species penetrated the cuticle via an appressorium,
and their hyphae grew within the
cuticle and cell walls of epidermal, subepidermal,
and subtending cells. They began
invasion with a brief biotrophic phase, in
which they invaded living cells, before entering
an extended necrotrophic phase, in which
they proliferated among dead cells. Acervuli
formed once the cortical tissue had been
moderately disrupted and developed as a
stroma just beneath the outer periclinal epidermal
walls. Acervuli erupted through the
cuticle and released conidia. Invasion of the
vascular tissue typically occurred after acervuli
matured but remained minimal.
txt: Curry et al. (2002) investigated the infection process of strawberry petioles and stolons by C. acutatum and C. fragariae using light and electron microscopy. Both fungal species invaded the host tissue in a similar manner, but C. fragariae did so more rapidly than C. acutatum. Both species penetrated the cuticle via an appressorium, and their hyphae grew within the cuticle and cell walls of epidermal, subepidermal, and underlying cells. The infection process began with a brief biotrophic phase, where the fungi invaded living cells, followed by an extended necrotrophic phase, in which they proliferated among dead cells. Acervuli formed once the cortical tissue was moderately disrupted, developing as a stroma just beneath the outer periclinal epidermal walls. These acervuli erupted through the cuticle, releasing conidia. Invasion of the vascular tissue typically occurred after acervuli had matured but was generally minimal.
q1: How do Colletotrichum acutatum and Colletotrichum fragariae differ in the speed of their infection process on strawberry petioles and stolons?
q2: What are the stages of the infection process for both fungal species, and how do they progress from biotrophic to necrotrophic phases?
q3: What role do acervuli play in the infection process, and how do they develop and release conidia?
q4: Did Colletotrichum fragariae invade strawberry petioles and stolons more rapidly than Colletotrichum acutatum in the study by Curry et al. (2002)?
q5: Did both Colletotrichum species penetrate the host tissue via an appressorium and grow within the cuticle and cell walls?
q6: Was the invasion of vascular tissue significant after the acervuli had matured?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
The time from infection of the strawberry
by Colletotrichum spp. to first sporulation
(the latent period) is an important factor in
the speed at which anthracnose may spread
within a field. The latent period depends
on the temperature and ranges from 2–3 d at
25 C to 6–17 d at 5 C (King et al., 1997). At
5 and 10 C, the latent period was shorter for
C. acutatum than for C. gloeosporioides and
C. fragariae; however, at higher temperatures
the latent period for all species was
similar. Appressoria and secondary conidia
produced by C. acutatum on symptomless
foliage may be a significant source of inoculum
for fruit infections (Leandro et al.,
2001) and may also contribute to the availability
of inoculum throughout the growing
season (Leandro et al., 2003a). Conidial
germination, appressorial production, and
secondary conidiation are all favored by
longer periods of wetness than the 4 h
required for secondary conidia to form. Colletotrichum
acutatum survived up to 8 weeks
on leaves in greenhouse studies (Leandro
et al., 2003a) and up to 5 weeks on fabric
(Norman and Strandberg, 1997). More conidia
formed on leaves when exposed to flower
extracts than when exposed to leaf extracts or
water (Leandro et al., 2003b), suggesting that
C. acutatum inoculum levels on strawberry
foliage may increase during flowering.
txt: The time from infection of the strawberry by Colletotrichum spp. to the first sporulation, known as the latent period, significantly affects the rate at which anthracnose can spread within a field. This latent period is temperature-dependent, ranging from 2–3 days at 25°C to 6–17 days at 5°C (King et al., 1997). At 5 and 10°C, C. acutatum has a shorter latent period compared to C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae; however, at higher temperatures, the latent periods for all species are similar. Appressoria and secondary conidia produced by C. acutatum on symptomless foliage can be a significant source of inoculum for fruit infections (Leandro et al., 2001) and may also contribute to inoculum availability throughout the growing season (Leandro et al., 2003a). Conidial germination, appressorial production, and secondary conidiation are favored by longer wetness periods beyond the 4 hours required for secondary conidia formation. C. acutatum can survive up to 8 weeks on leaves in greenhouse studies (Leandro et al., 2003a) and up to 5 weeks on fabric (Norman and Strandberg, 1997). Additionally, more conidia form on leaves exposed to flower extracts compared to leaf extracts or water (Leandro et al., 2003b), suggesting that inoculum levels of C. acutatum on strawberry foliage may increase during flowering.
q1: How does the latent period of Colletotrichum species affect the spread of anthracnose within a field?
q2: How do temperature variations impact the latent period for different Colletotrichum species, specifically C. acutatum, C. gloeosporioides, and C. fragariae?
q3: What factors contribute to the availability of inoculum throughout the growing season, particularly for Colletotrichum acutatum?
q4: Is the latent period for anthracnose infection significantly shorter at 25°C compared to 5°C?
q5: Does Colletotrichum acutatum produce appressoria and secondary conidia on symptomless foliage that contribute to fruit infections?
q6: Can Colletotrichum acutatum survive for up to 8 weeks on leaves in greenhouse conditions?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Rain splash is the primary means by
which Colletotrichum spp. conidia are spread
from plant to plant in the field. Madden
and Boudreau (1997) found that anthracnose
fruit rot incidence generally declined as plant
density increased and concluded that plant
density reduced the amount of rain that
penetrated the plant canopy, thus reducing
the amount of splash. Most fruit infection
occurred in a 25-cm radius of the source of
the inoculum, an infected fruit (Madden and
Wilson, 1997). Ntahimpera et al. (1999)
studied splash dispersal of the conidia of the
three Colletotrichum spp. and found that
conidia of C. fragariae dispersed over the
shortest distance and those of C. acutatum
dispersed over the longest distance. This was
probably due to the greater amount of spores
produced on infected fruit by C. acutatum.
Colletotrichum acutatum conidia may survive
in soil and plant debris under dry
conditions for up to 12 months, but conidia
and sclerotia die rapidly under moist conditions,
i.e., soil moisture $12% (Norman
and Strandberg, 1997).
txt: Rain splash is the primary mechanism for spreading Colletotrichum spp. conidia from plant to plant in the field. Madden and Boudreau (1997) found that anthracnose fruit rot incidence generally decreased with increased plant density. They concluded that higher plant density reduces the amount of rain reaching the plant canopy, thereby reducing splash dispersal. Most fruit infections occurred within a 25-cm radius of the inoculum source, typically an infected fruit (Madden and Wilson, 1997). Ntahimpera et al. (1999) studied the splash dispersal of conidia from the three Colletotrichum spp. and found that conidia of C. fragariae dispersed the shortest distance, while C. acutatum conidia dispersed the farthest. This difference is likely due to the greater number of spores produced on infected fruit by C. acutatum. C. acutatum conidia can survive in soil and plant debris under dry conditions for up to 12 months, but they die rapidly under moist conditions, specifically in soil with moisture levels above 12% (Norman and Strandberg, 1997).
q1: How does plant density affect the spread of Colletotrichum spp. conidia in the field?
q2: What differences in splash dispersal distance exist among the Colletotrichum species, and what might account for these differences?
q3: How does moisture level influence the survival of Colletotrichum acutatum conidia in soil and plant debris?
q4: Does higher plant density reduce the amount of rain reaching the plant canopy, thereby decreasing splash dispersal of conidia?
q5: Did Colletotrichum acutatum conidia disperse farther than those of Colletotrichum fragariae in the studies by Ntahimpera et al. (1999)?
q6: Can Colletotrichum acutatum conidia survive for up to 12 months in soil and plant debris under dry conditions?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Because the primary source of infection in
most fruiting fields appeared to be infected
transplants, strawberry growers in the southeastern
United States were advised after the
anthracnose crown rot epidemics in the 1980s
to obtain their transplants from nurseries in
the northern United States, Canada, or California
that were believed to be outside the
range of C. fragariae. More recently, C.
acutatum has been found in some of the
nurseries in these areas. McInnes et al.
(1992a) demonstrated that anthracnose-free
transplants can be produced in the southeastern
United States by locating nurseries in
areas where strawberries are not grown commercially.
Disease-free transplants remain
the primary control of anthracnose crown
rot and fruit rot.
txt: Due to the primary source of infection in many fruiting fields being infected transplants, strawberry growers in the southeastern United States were advised after the anthracnose crown rot epidemics of the 1980s to source their transplants from nurseries located in the northern United States, Canada, or California, regions believed to be outside the range of C. fragariae. However, C. acutatum has since been detected in some nurseries in these areas. McInnes et al. (1992a) demonstrated that anthracnose-free transplants can be produced within the southeastern United States by locating nurseries in regions where strawberries are not grown commercially. Disease-free transplants continue to be the primary method for controlling anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot.
q1: Why were strawberry growers in the southeastern United States advised to source transplants from regions outside their area after the 1980s anthracnose crown rot epidemics?
q2: What change occurred with Colletotrichum acutatum's presence in nurseries from previously considered safe regions?
q3: How can anthracnose-free transplants be produced within the southeastern United States, according to McInnes et al. (1992a)?
q4: Were strawberry growers advised to source transplants from northern U.S., Canada, or California to avoid C. fragariae after the 1980s anthracnose epidemics?
q5: Has Colletotrichum acutatum been detected in some nurseries in regions previously considered free of this pathogen?
q6: Are disease-free transplants still a primary method for controlling anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot in strawberries?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Because Colletotrichum spp. may infect
many other hosts, primary infection in strawberry
fields sometimes is assumed to come
from these other hosts growing near the
strawberry field. To test the hypothesis that
Colletotrichum spp. may move from other
fruit or vegetable hosts to strawberry, 37
Colletotrichum isolates, representing nine
species collected from 12 hosts, were
wound-inoculated onto the leaves and stems
of strawberry, blueberry, blackberry, muscadine
grape, tomato, and pepper (Smith,
2002). Colletotrichum fragariae isolates
were the most aggressive and caused lesions
at an average of 38% of inoculation sites on
all hosts except pepper. Percentages of infection
for the other species were 25% Colletotrichum
capsici, 18%C. gloeosporioides, 15%
C. acutatum, 11% C. destructivum, 9% C.
truncatum, 8%C. coccodes, 6%C. higginsianun,
and 5% C. orbiculare. Strawberry was
the most susceptible host with 58% of petiole
and 14% of leaf inoculations of all isolates
resulting in lesion development. Pepper was
the most resistant host with no symptom
development on leaves or stems following
inoculation with any isolate. These results
suggest that primary anthracnose infections
in strawberry fields are most often from
infected strawberry transplants and only rarely
from other diseased fruit or vegetable hosts.
txt: Given that Colletotrichum species can infect a variety of hosts, it is sometimes assumed that primary infection in strawberry fields may originate from these other hosts growing nearby. To test this hypothesis, Smith (2002) conducted an experiment using 37 Colletotrichum isolates from nine species collected from 12 different hosts. These isolates were wound-inoculated onto the leaves and stems of strawberry, blueberry, blackberry, muscadine grape, tomato, and pepper. The study found that C. fragariae isolates were the most aggressive, causing lesions at an average of 38% of inoculation sites on all hosts except pepper. The infection percentages for the other species were: 25% for C. capsici, 18% for C. gloeosporioides, 15% for C. acutatum, 11% for C. destructivum, 9% for C. truncatum, 8% for C. coccodes, 6% for C. higginsianum, and 5% for C. orbiculare. Strawberry proved to be the most susceptible host, with 58% of petiole and 14% of leaf inoculations resulting in lesion development. In contrast, pepper was the most resistant host, showing no symptoms after inoculation with any isolate. These results indicate that primary anthracnose infections in strawberry fields are most commonly from infected strawberry transplants, with infections from other diseased fruit or vegetable hosts being relatively rare.
q1: What were the findings of Smith (2002) regarding the aggressiveness of Colletotrichum fragariae compared to other Colletotrichum species on various hosts?
q2: How did the susceptibility of strawberry compare to other hosts in the study, and which host was the most resistant?
q3: What do the results suggest about the primary source of anthracnose infections in strawberry fields?
q4: Was Colletotrichum fragariae found to be the most aggressive species in causing lesions on various hosts?
q5: Did the study find that strawberry was the most susceptible host for anthracnose infections?
q6: Were infections from other diseased fruit or vegetable hosts considered a relatively rare source of primary anthracnose infections in strawberry fields?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Anthracnose spreads within a field by
splashing water, and living mulches (such
as wheat, rye, or rye grass) in row middles
have been shown to reduce disease spread
within a field. Sublethal doses of grassspecific
herbicides such as sethoxydim, may
be used to prevent excessive growth of rye
grass (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such
as wheat straw or pine needles, will also
reduce splash and result in lower incidence
of anthracnose compared with rows mulched
with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and
Spiers, 1986). Anthracnose is less severe
when water is supplied to plants using drip
irrigation rather than overhead irrigation
(Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).
txt: Anthracnose spreads within a field primarily through splashing water. The use of living mulches, such as wheat, rye, or rye grass, in row middles has been shown to reduce disease spread within a field. To prevent excessive growth of rye grass, sublethal doses of grass-specific herbicides like sethoxydim may be applied (Gupton, 2000). Organic mulches, such as wheat straw or pine needles, also help reduce splash and result in a lower incidence of anthracnose compared to rows mulched with plastic (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986). Additionally, anthracnose is less severe when water is supplied using drip irrigation rather than overhead irrigation (Madden, 1992; Smith and Spiers, 1986).
q1: How does the use of living mulches affect the spread of anthracnose within a field?
q2: What are the benefits of using organic mulches like wheat straw or pine needles compared to plastic mulch in managing anthracnose?
q3: Why is drip irrigation preferred over overhead irrigation for reducing the severity of anthracnose?
q4: Does the use of living mulches such as wheat, rye, or rye grass help reduce the spread of anthracnose in strawberry fields?
q5: Are organic mulches more effective than plastic mulch in lowering the incidence of anthracnose?
q6: Is anthracnose less severe when using drip irrigation compared to overhead irrigation?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Anthracnose crown rot was observed to be
less severe in commercial fields when strawberries
were grown on soils with low nitrogen
fertility (Howard, et al., 1992). In greenhouse
studies, Smith (1987, 1989) determined that
strawberries grown in soils with high levels
of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources,
are more susceptible to anthracnose than
plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen
levels or those with high levels of calcium
nitrate. Anthracnose fruit rot caused by
C. acutatum was less severe on fruit from
greenhouse-grown plants receiving drench or
foliar applications of calcium sulfate than on
fruit from plants receiving water, calcium
chloride, or calcium nitrate treatments. Fruit
from plants receiving foliar applications of
CaCl2 developed less fruit rot than that from
plants receiving soil applications of CaCl2
(Smith and Gupton, 1993).
txt: Anthracnose crown rot has been observed to be less severe in commercial fields when strawberries are grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility (Howard et al., 1992). Greenhouse studies by Smith (1987, 1989) determined that strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, particularly from ammonium sources, are more susceptible to anthracnose compared to plants grown in soils with lower nitrogen levels or those amended with high levels of calcium nitrate. Anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum was less severe on fruit from greenhouse-grown plants that received drench or foliar applications of calcium sulfate, compared to fruit from plants treated with water, calcium chloride, or calcium nitrate. Additionally, fruit from plants receiving foliar applications of calcium chloride (CaCl₂) developed less fruit rot than that from plants receiving soil applications of CaCl₂ (Smith and Gupton, 1993).
q1: How does nitrogen fertility in the soil affect the severity of anthracnose crown rot in commercial strawberry fields?
q2: What impact does the source and level of nitrogen have on the susceptibility of strawberries to anthracnose in greenhouse studies?
q3: How do different calcium treatments, such as calcium sulfate and calcium chloride, influence the severity of anthracnose fruit rot?
q4: Is anthracnose crown rot less severe in strawberries grown in soils with low nitrogen fertility?
q5: Are strawberries grown in soils with high levels of nitrogen, especially from ammonium sources, more susceptible to anthracnose?
q6: Did calcium sulfate applications result in less anthracnose fruit rot compared to calcium chloride in the studies conducted by Smith and Gupton (1993)?

pdf:
The primary means to reduce the buildup
of anthracnose fruit rot in the field is to
harvest fruit frequently and remove all rotten
fruit from the field. Following severe infections
early in the fruiting season, all infected
fruit should be stripped from the plants and
removed from the field. Infected areas of a
field should be harvested last in the day, or
workers should wash up and change to clean
clothes when they must enter un-infected
areas of the field after they have harvested
areas where fruit rot is present.
txt: The primary method to reduce the buildup of anthracnose fruit rot in the field is to harvest fruit frequently and remove all rotten fruit from the field. After severe infections early in the fruiting season, all infected fruit should be stripped from the plants and removed from the field. Infected areas of the field should be harvested last in the day. Alternatively, workers should wash up and change into clean clothes before entering uninfected areas of the field after harvesting areas with fruit rot present.
q1: What is the primary method for reducing the buildup of anthracnose fruit rot in strawberry fields?
q2: What should be done with infected fruit and areas of the field after severe infections early in the fruiting season?
q3: How can workers minimize the risk of spreading anthracnose fruit rot to uninfected areas of the field?
q4: Is frequent harvesting and removal of rotten fruit the primary method to manage anthracnose fruit rot in the field?
q5: Should infected fruit be stripped from the plants and removed from the field after severe infections?
q6: Can workers reduce the risk of spreading anthracnose by washing up and changing into clean clothes before entering uninfected areas?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Until highly resistant cultivars are available,
growers must rely on chemical applications 
and cultural practices to reduce losses
due to anthracnose. Failure of fungicides
to control anthracnose epidemics may be
due to the development of fungicide resistance
in the Colletotrichum spp. population.
For example, benomyl was shown to effectively
reduce the incidence of anthracnose
crown rot (Horn et al., 1972; Howard, 1971)
and was used intensively by strawberry
growers for years to control anthracnose
and other diseases. However, the anthracnose
pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae,
developed resistance to it and other bendimidazole
fungicides (LaMondia, 1995;
McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black,
1992, 1993), and benomyl was no longer
effective for anthracnose control in strawberry
fields. In-vitro trials have been used to
screen fungicides for their ability to control
anthracnose (LaMondia, 1993; McInnes
et al., 1992b; Smith and Black, 1992). Smith
and Black (1993) reported that all 16 C.
acutatum, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae, and both
C. gloeosporioides isolates they tested in
vitro were resistant to benomyl and that all
benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant
to carbendazim, which is in the same class of
fungicides as benomyl. In a greenhouse
study, plants treated with propiconazole had
lower disease severity ratings than did plants
treated with captafol or benomyl (Smith and
Black, 1991). However, the propiconazoletreated
plants were shorter with dark green
leaves that appeared thicker than the leaves of
untreated plants.
txt: Until highly resistant cultivars become available, growers must rely on chemical applications and cultural practices to mitigate losses due to anthracnose. One challenge is the development of fungicide resistance in the Colletotrichum spp. population, which can lead to the failure of fungicides to control anthracnose epidemics. For instance, benomyl was initially effective in reducing the incidence of anthracnose crown rot and was extensively used by strawberry growers. However, resistance developed in the anthracnose pathogens, C. acutatum and C. fragariae, to benomyl and other benzimidazole fungicides, rendering them ineffective for anthracnose control (LaMondia, 1995; McInnes et al., 1992a; Smith and Black, 1992, 1993). In vitro trials have been used to evaluate fungicides for their effectiveness against anthracnose. Smith and Black (1993) found that all 16 C. acutatum isolates, 14 out of 18 C. fragariae isolates, and both C. gloeosporioides isolates tested were resistant to benomyl. Moreover, all benomyl-resistant isolates were also resistant to carbendazim, which belongs to the same class of fungicides. In a greenhouse study, plants treated with propiconazole exhibited lower disease severity compared to those treated with captafol or benomyl. However, the propiconazole-treated plants were shorter and had darker green leaves that appeared thicker than those of untreated plants (Smith and Black, 1991).
q1: What is a major challenge in controlling anthracnose in strawberries, and how has fungicide resistance affected control methods?
q2: How did the development of resistance to benomyl and other benzimidazole fungicides impact the effectiveness of these chemicals against Colletotrichum spp.?
q3: How did the effectiveness of propiconazole compare to other fungicides like captafol and benomyl in controlling anthracnose, according to the greenhouse study?
q4: Is fungicide resistance in Colletotrichum spp. a significant challenge for controlling anthracnose in strawberries?
q5: Did resistance to benomyl and other benzimidazole fungicides develop in C. acutatum and C. fragariae, making them ineffective for anthracnose control?
q6: Did propiconazole-treated plants show lower disease severity compared to those treated with captafol or benomyl in the greenhouse study by Smith and Black (1991)?

pdf:
Sixteen different fungicide treatments
were evaluated in five fungicide studies
conducted at Hammond, LA, and Poplarville,
MS, during the 2002, 2003, and 2005 fruiting
seasons (Wedge et al., 2007). Treatments
were applied at 7- to 10-d intervals to three
strawberry cultivars. The most frequent fruit
rots at harvest were anthracnose fruit rot
(caused by Colletotrichum spp.), stem end
rot (caused by Gnomonia comari P. Karst),
and Botrytis gray mold (caused by Botrytis
cinerea Pers.:Fr.). Compared with the
untreated control treatment, less anthracnose
fruit rot occurred on berries from the pyraclostrobin
+ boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil,
azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, captan +
fenhexamid, and captan treatments.
txt: In a series of studies conducted during the 2002, 2003, and 2005 fruiting seasons at Hammond, LA, and Poplarville, MS, sixteen different fungicide treatments were evaluated (Wedge et al., 2007). Treatments were applied at 7- to 10-day intervals across three strawberry cultivars. The primary fruit rots observed at harvest included anthracnose fruit rot (caused by Colletotrichum spp.), stem end rot (caused by Gnomonia comari P. Karst), and Botrytis gray mold (caused by Botrytis cinerea Pers.). Compared with the untreated control, the treatments with pyraclostrobin + boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil, azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, captan + fenhexamid, and captan resulted in a reduction in anthracnose fruit rot incidence.
q1: What were the primary fruit rots observed during the fungicide evaluation studies conducted in 2002, 2003, and 2005?
q2: Which fungicide treatments were found to reduce the incidence of anthracnose fruit rot compared to the untreated control?
q3: How many different fungicide treatments were evaluated across the strawberry cultivars in the studies conducted at Hammond, LA, and Poplarville, MS?
q4: Were anthracnose fruit rot, stem end rot, and Botrytis gray mold the primary fruit rots observed during the fungicide evaluation studies?
q5: Did treatments with pyraclostrobin + boscalid, cyprodinil + fludioxonil, azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin, captan + fenhexamid, and captan result in a reduction of anthracnose fruit rot incidence?
q6: Were sixteen different fungicide treatments evaluated in the studies conducted during the 2002, 2003, and 2005 fruiting seasons?

pdf:
In the early 1980s, when anthracnose
became a major disease of strawberries in
the southeastern United States, a breeding
program to develop anthracnose-resistant
cultivars adapted to the strawberry-growing
areas in the southeastern United States was
instituted by the USDA-ARS at the Small
Fruit Research Station, Poplarville, MS, and
the Fruit Laboratory, Beltsville, MD, with the
collaboration of state experiment stations
in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina
(Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers,
1982). From 1976 to 1995, over 160,000
progeny from 448 crosses made at Beltsville,
MD, primarily by G.J. Galletta, were screened
for anthracnose resistance in the greenhouse
at Poplarville, MS. Initially, parent lines were
eastern cultivars and advanced selections
from the breeding program at Beltsville. As
the program progressed, resistant selections
from the anthracnose program were crossed
with commercial cultivars to improve the
horticultural characteristics of the progeny.
Seed from the crosses made at Beltsville were
germinated at Poplarville, and resultant seedlings
were inoculated with a conidial suspension
of C. fragariae, incubated in a dew
chamber for 48 h, moved to a warm greenhouse,
and rated for anthracnose severity 30
d after inoculation. Resistant seedlings were
evaluated in the field in Florida, Louisiana,
Mississippi, Maryland, and North Carolina;
selections were made on the bases of yield,
fruit quality, plant habit, and resistance to leaf
scorch [caused by Diplocarpon earlianum
(Ellis & Everh.) F.A. Wolf], leaf spot [caused
by Mycosphaerella fragariae (Tul.) Lindau],
powdery mildew [caused by Sphaerotheca
macularis (Wallr.:Fr.) Jacz f. sp. fragariae
Peries], and two-spotted spider mites (Tetranychus
urticae Koch).
txt: In the early 1980s, a breeding program aimed at developing anthracnose-resistant strawberry cultivars for the southeastern United States was initiated by the USDA-ARS at the Small Fruit Research Station in Poplarville, MS, and the Fruit Laboratory in Beltsville, MD. This program was conducted in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina (Galletta et al., 1997; Smith and Spiers, 1982). Between 1976 and 1995, over 160,000 progeny from 448 crosses made at Beltsville, MD, primarily by G.J. Galletta, were screened for anthracnose resistance in a greenhouse setting at Poplarville, MS. Initially, the parent lines consisted of eastern cultivars and advanced selections from the Beltsville breeding program. As the program advanced, resistant selections from the anthracnose program were crossed with commercial cultivars to enhance the horticultural traits of the progeny. Seeds from the Beltsville crosses were germinated at Poplarville, and the seedlings were inoculated with a conidial suspension of C. fragariae. These were then incubated in a dew chamber for 48 hours, moved to a warm greenhouse, and rated for anthracnose severity 30 days post-inoculation. Resistant seedlings were further evaluated in field trials across Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, Maryland, and North Carolina. Selections were made based on yield, fruit quality, plant habit, and resistance to additional issues such as leaf scorch (caused by Diplocarpon earlianum), leaf spot (caused by Mycosphaerella fragariae), powdery mildew (caused by Sphaerotheca macularis f. sp. fragariae), and two-spotted spider mites (Tetranychus urticae Koch).
q1: What was the objective of the USDA-ARS breeding program initiated in the early 1980s for strawberries in the southeastern United States?
q2: How were the progeny from the breeding program screened for anthracnose resistance, and what were the subsequent steps for evaluating the resistant seedlings?
q3: What additional issues, aside from anthracnose, were considered when selecting resistant strawberry cultivars in the breeding program?
q4: Was the breeding program for developing anthracnose-resistant strawberry cultivars initiated by the USDA-ARS in collaboration with state experiment stations in Florida, Louisiana, and North Carolina?
q5: Were over 160,000 progeny from 448 crosses screened for anthracnose resistance between 1976 and 1995?
q6: Did the selection process for resistant seedlings also consider resistance to leaf scorch, leaf spot, powdery mildew, and two-spotted spider mites?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
Fifteen hundred fifteen (1515) anthracnose-
resistant selections were made from the
seedlings field-tested in Mississippi. Four of
these anthracnose-resistant strawberry clones
were released as breeding lines (Galletta
et al., 1993) and have been used as the source
of anthracnose resistance in several breeding
programs. Smith et al. (1998) released the
cultivar Pelican, which is highly resistant
to both anthracnose crown rot caused by
C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused
by C. acutatum. ‘Pelican’ is also resistant to
five races of red stele caused by Phytophthora
fragariae. Evaluation of strawberry seedlings
and advanced breeding lines from state and
private breeding programs is an ongoing
project. The USDA anthracnose-resistance
screening procedure has effectively identified
resistant genotypes in seedling progenies
from the North Carolina State University
breeding program, with >32,000 resistant
strawberry seedlings identified between
1998 and 1999 (Ballington et al., 2002).
txt: From the field-tested seedlings in Mississippi, 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections were identified. Four of these selections were released as breeding lines (Galletta et al., 1993) and have served as sources of anthracnose resistance in various breeding programs. The cultivar Pelican, released by Smith et al. (1998), is highly resistant to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum. Additionally, Pelican is resistant to five races of red stele caused by Phytophthora fragariae. Ongoing evaluation of strawberry seedlings and advanced breeding lines from state and private programs continues. The USDA’s anthracnose-resistance screening procedure has been successful in identifying resistant genotypes, including over 32,000 resistant seedlings from the North Carolina State University breeding program between 1998 and 1999 (Ballington et al., 2002).
q1: How many anthracnose-resistant selections were identified from the field-tested seedlings in Mississippi, and how many of these were released as breeding lines?
q2: Which strawberry cultivar, released by Smith et al. (1998), is noted for its high resistance to both anthracnose crown rot and anthracnose fruit rot, as well as to red stele?
q3: How successful was the USDA’s anthracnose-resistance screening procedure in identifying resistant genotypes from the North Carolina State University breeding program between 1998 and 1999?
q4: Were 1,515 anthracnose-resistant selections identified from the field-tested seedlings in Mississippi, with four of these being released as breeding lines?
q5: Is the cultivar Pelican resistant to both anthracnose crown rot caused by C. fragariae and anthracnose fruit rot caused by C. acutatum, as well as to five races of red stele?
q6: Did the USDA’s anthracnose-resistance screening procedure successfully identify over 32,000 resistant seedlings from the North Carolina State University breeding program between 1998 and 1999?

pdf:
Smith and Black (1987) found that resistance
to C. fragariae was influenced by
environmental conditions after inoculation
and that plants incubated at a high temperature
(35 C) for 48 h in a dew chamber
(relative humidity near 100%) had higher
disease severity ratings when compared with
plants incubated at 25 or 30 C. Plants
maintained in a greenhouse at 32 C after
dew chamber incubation developed more
severe symptoms than did those held in a
greenhouse at 25 C. Two- to 4-week-old
strawberry seedlings (age after transplanting
at the first true-leaf stage) were more susceptible
to C. fragariae than 14- to 18-weekold
seedlings when spray inoculated with a
conidial suspension (Smith et al., 1990).
txt: Smith and Black (1987) observed that resistance to C. fragariae in strawberries was affected by environmental conditions following inoculation. Plants incubated at a high temperature (35°C) with high humidity (near 100%) for 48 hours in a dew chamber showed higher disease severity compared to those incubated at lower temperatures (25°C or 30°C). Additionally, plants kept in a greenhouse at 32°C after dew chamber incubation developed more severe symptoms than those kept at 25°C. Furthermore, strawberry seedlings that were 2 to 4 weeks old after transplanting (at the first true-leaf stage) were more susceptible to C. fragariae than 14 to 18-week-old seedlings when spray-inoculated with a conidial suspension (Smith et al., 1990).
q1: How did high temperature and high humidity conditions affect disease severity in strawberries inoculated with C. fragariae, according to Smith and Black (1987)?
q2: What differences in symptom development were observed between strawberries incubated in a greenhouse at 32°C versus 25°C after dew chamber incubation?
q3: At what age of strawberry seedlings was susceptibility to C. fragariae found to be higher when inoculated with a conidial suspension?
q4: Did Smith and Black (1987) find that higher disease severity occurred in strawberries incubated at 35°C with high humidity compared to those at 25°C or 30°C?
q5: Were strawberry seedlings kept in a greenhouse at 32°C after dew chamber incubation found to develop more severe symptoms than those kept at 25°C?
q6: Were 2 to 4-week-old strawberry seedlings more susceptible to C. fragariae compared to 14 to 18-week-old seedlings when spray-inoculated?

pdf:
Tissue culture-induced (somaclonal) variation
is another strategy being pursued
for generating disease-resistant genotypes.
Hammerschlag et al. (2006) screened shoots
regenerated from leaf explants of six commercially
important cultivars for resistance to
a virulent isolate of C. acutatum. Somaclones
with higher levels of anthracnose resistance
were identified for all the cultivars, and the
greatest increases in disease resistance were
observed for somaclones of Chandler, Pelican,
and Sweet Charlie, where resistance
increased 12-fold. These studies provide
evidence that in-vitro screening can be used
to evaluate strawberry germplasm for anthracnose
resistance and that somaclonal variation
is influenced by strawberry genotype.
txt: Tissue culture-induced (somaclonal) variation is a strategy for developing disease-resistant strawberry genotypes. Hammerschlag et al. (2006) conducted a study where they screened shoots regenerated from leaf explants of six commercially important strawberry cultivars for resistance to a virulent isolate of C. acutatum. They identified somaclones with higher levels of anthracnose resistance for all cultivars tested. Notably, the greatest increases in resistance were observed in somaclones of ‘Chandler’, ‘Pelican’, and ‘Sweet Charlie’, with resistance levels increasing 12-fold. These findings demonstrate that in-vitro screening can be effective for evaluating strawberry germplasm for anthracnose resistance and that somaclonal variation is influenced by the strawberry genotype.
q1: What method did Hammerschlag et al. (2006) use to screen for anthracnose resistance in strawberry cultivars?
q2: Which strawberry cultivars showed the greatest increase in anthracnose resistance through somaclonal variation according to the study?
q3: What was the maximum observed increase in resistance levels for any of the strawberry cultivars tested?
q4: Did Hammerschlag et al. (2006) use shoots regenerated from leaf explants for screening strawberry genotypes for anthracnose resistance?
q5: Were somaclones of ‘Chandler’, ‘Pelican’, and ‘Sweet Charlie’ found to have 12-fold higher resistance levels to C. acutatum?
q6: Did the study indicate that somaclonal variation is influenced by the genotype of the strawberry?

pdf:
Gupton and Smith (1991) determined that
the estimates of dominance genetic variance
were six to 10 times higher than those for
additive genetic variance. The frequency distribution
of disease severity ratings was bimodal
suggesting major gene action. Narrowsense
heritability estimates of 0.37 and 0.26
were probably sufficient to produce gains
from recurrent selection, while gains from
selection of clonal value should be possible
because of the high (0.87 and 0.85) broadsense
heritability estimates. Gime´nez and
Ballington (2002) also found that nonadditive
effects were more important than additive
effects in the inheritance of resistance on
runners. The epistatic nature of anthracnose
resistance on runners appears to be supported
by results of crosses between susceptible
parents that result in up to 20% resistant
seedlings (Ballington et al., 2002). Gime´nez
and Ballington (2002) found that the frequency
distribution of lesion lengths within
progenies suggests that resistance to C. acutatum
on runners is quantitative. Results of
Garce´s et al. (2002) also support the theory
that inheritance of resistance to anthracnose is
quantitative in nature.
txt: Gupton and Smith determined that the estimates of dominance genetic variance were six to ten times higher than those for additive genetic variance. The frequency distribution of disease severity ratings was bimodal, suggesting major gene action. Narrow-sense heritability estimates of 0.37 and 0.26 were probably sufficient to produce gains from recurrent selection, while gains from selection of clonal value should be possible because of the high (0.87 and 0.85) broad-sense heritability estimates. Nonadditive effects were also found to be more important than additive effects in the inheritance of resistance on runners. The epistatic nature of anthracnose resistance on runners appears to be supported by results of crosses between susceptible parents that result in up to 20% resistant seedlings. The frequency distribution of lesion lengths within progenies suggests that resistance to C. acutatum on runners is quantitative. Results also support the theory that inheritance of resistance to anthracnose is quantitative in nature.
q1: What is the relationship between dominance genetic variance and additive genetic variance according to Gupton and Smith?
q2: What does the bimodal frequency distribution of disease severity ratings suggest about the genetic control of the disease?
q3: How do narrow-sense heritability estimates compare to broad-sense heritability estimates in terms of potential gains from selection?
q4: Were the estimates of dominance genetic variance higher than those for additive genetic variance?
q5: Is the resistance to C. acutatum on runners considered to be quantitative based on the frequency distribution of lesion lengths?
q6: Do the results of crosses between susceptible parents support the theory that inheritance of anthracnose resistance is quantitative?

pdf:
Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit
and crown rots may be related to the shift
from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture
production system in the United
States. Breeding for genetic resistance to
anthracnose and development of resistant
cultivars are primary means for reducing
economic loses due to this disease. This is
environmentally sound because it results in
reduced use of fungicides.
txt: Increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots may be related to the shift from matted-row culture to the annual plasticulture production system in the United States. Breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose and the development of resistant cultivars are primary means for reducing economic losses due to this disease. This approach is environmentally sound because it results in reduced use of fungicides.
q1: How might the shift from matted-row culture to annual plasticulture production affect losses due to anthracnose?
q2: What are the primary methods for reducing economic losses from anthracnose mentioned in the passage?
q3: Why is breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose considered environmentally sound?
q4: Is the shift to annual plasticulture production associated with increased losses due to anthracnose fruit and crown rots?
q5: Are breeding for genetic resistance and developing resistant cultivars considered primary methods for reducing economic losses from anthracnose?
q6: Does breeding for genetic resistance to anthracnose result in reduced use of fungicides?
metadata: Epidemiology and Pathology of Strawberry Anthracnose.pdf

pdf:
As our knowledge of the anthracnose
pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose
diseases has increased, so has our ability
to control these diseases. Changes in cultural
practices have resulted in reduced levels of
disease. At the same time, development of
more effective fungicides and their registration
for use on strawberries have greatly
reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown
rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars
also have reduced economic losses due
to these diseases. Even so, growers may
sustain severe losses when environmental
factors are highly favorable for anthracnose
development.
txt: As our knowledge of the anthracnose pathogens and the epidemiology of anthracnose diseases has increased, so has our ability to control these diseases. Changes in cultural practices have resulted in reduced levels of disease. At the same time, the development of more effective fungicides and their registration for use on strawberries have greatly reduced losses due to both anthracnose crown rot and fruit rot. Anthracnose-resistant cultivars have also reduced economic losses due to these diseases. Even so, growers may sustain severe losses when environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development.
q1: How has increased knowledge of anthracnose pathogens and epidemiology impacted disease control?
q2: What role have changes in cultural practices played in the management of anthracnose diseases?
q3: How have the development and registration of fungicides contributed to reducing losses from anthracnose?
q4: Has increased knowledge of anthracnose pathogens improved disease control?
q5: Have changes in cultural practices helped reduce levels of anthracnose disease?
q6: Can severe losses still occur if environmental factors are highly favorable for anthracnose development?

q2: How have different studies contributed to the understanding and management of strawberry anthracnose?

pdf:
Ontogeny of the invasion process by Colletotrichum acutatum and C.
fragariae was studied on petioles and stolons of the strawberry cultivar
Chandler using light and electron microscopy. The invasion of host tissue
by each fungal species was similar; however, each invasion event occurred
more rapidly with C. fragariae than with C. acutatum. Following
cuticular penetration via an appressorium, subsequent steps of invasion
involved hyphal growth within the cuticle and within the cell walls of
epidermal, subepidermal, and subtending cells. Both species of fungi
began invasion with a brief biotrophic phase before entering an extended
necrotrophic phase. Acervuli formed once the cortical tissue had been
moderately disrupted and began with the development of a stroma just
beneath the outer periclinal epidermal walls. Acervuli erupted through
the cuticle and released conidia. Invasion of the vascular tissue typically
occurred after acervulus maturation and remained minimal. Chitin distribution
in walls of C. fragariae was visualized with gold-labeled wheat
germ agglutinin. The outer layer of bilayered walls of conidia, germ tubes,
and appressoria contained less chitin than unilayered hyphae in planta.
Additional keywords: colloidal gold, hemibiotrophy, host–pathogen
interactions, lectin, ultrastructure.
txt: Ontogeny of the invasion process by Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae was studied on petioles and stolons of the strawberry cultivar Chandler using light and electron microscopy. The invasion of host tissue by each fungal species was similar; however, each invasion event occurred more rapidly with C. fragariae than with C. acutatum. Following cuticular penetration via an appressorium, subsequent steps of invasion involved hyphal growth within the cuticle and within the cell walls of epidermal, subepidermal, and subtending cells. Both species of fungi began invasion with a brief biotrophic phase before entering an extended necrotrophic phase. Acervuli formed once the cortical tissue had been moderately disrupted and began with the development of a stroma just beneath the outer periclinal epidermal walls. Acervuli erupted through the cuticle and released conidia. Invasion of the vascular tissue typically occurred after acervulus maturation and remained minimal. Chitin distribution in walls of C. fragariae was visualized with gold-labeled wheat germ agglutinin. The outer layer of bilayered walls of conidia, germ tubes, and appressoria contained less chitin than unilayered hyphae in planta. Additional keywords: colloidal gold, hemibiotrophy, host–pathogen interactions, lectin, ultrastructure.
q1: How do the invasion processes of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae differ in terms of speed?
q2: What is the role of appressoria in the invasion of C. acutatum and C. fragariae into strawberry plant tissue?
q3: How does chitin distribution differ between various fungal structures, such as conidia, germ tubes, and hyphae?
q4: Did C. fragariae invade strawberry tissue more quickly than C. acutatum?
q5: Do both C. acutatum and C. fragariae exhibit a biotrophic phase before transitioning to necrotrophy during the invasion?
q6: Was vascular tissue invasion minimal until after acervulus maturation?

pdf:
Anthracnose diseases of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa
Duch.) are caused by the fungal pathogens Colletotrichum
acutatum Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides
(Penz.) Penz. and Sacc. (teleomorph Glomerella cingulata
(Stonem.) Spauld. & Schrenk) (8,21–23,26). All three species incite
diseases, which cannot be distinguished in the field by symptoms
alone. Petiole and stolon lesions occur on plants grown
worldwide, but may go undetected in cool, dry areas where they
cause little injury to the plants. C. fragariae is most often associated
with anthracnose crown rot of strawberries grown in hot,
humid areas such as the southeastern United States. Its host range
is limited to strawberries and a few weeds (22). C. acutatum is the
primary causal agent of anthracnose fruit rot, has a broader
geographic and host range than C. fragariae (8,10,22), and is
increasing in importance as a cause of petiole, stolon, crown, and
root infections (7).
txt: Anthracnose diseases of strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.) are caused by the fungal pathogens Colletotrichum acutatum Simmonds, C. fragariae Brooks, and C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. and Sacc. (teleomorph Glomerella cingulata (Stonem.) Spauld. & Schrenk). All three species incite diseases that cannot be distinguished in the field by symptoms alone. Petiole and stolon lesions occur on plants grown worldwide but may go undetected in cool, dry areas where they cause little injury to the plants. C. fragariae is most often associated with anthracnose crown rot of strawberries grown in hot, humid areas such as the southeastern United States. Its host range is limited to strawberries and a few weeds. C. acutatum is the primary causal agent of anthracnose fruit rot, has a broader geographic and host range than C. fragariae, and is increasing in importance as a cause of petiole, stolon, crown, and root infections.
q1: Why is C. fragariae more commonly associated with anthracnose crown rot in hot, humid regions?
q2: How can the three Colletotrichum species that cause anthracnose diseases in strawberries be distinguished from each other if symptoms in the field are similar?
q3: What is the significance of C. acutatum in the increase of petiole, stolon, crown, and root infections in strawberries?
q4: Are anthracnose diseases of strawberries caused by three species of Colletotrichum fungi?
q5: Can C. fragariae affect plants in areas with cool, dry climates, causing only minimal injury?
q6: Does C. acutatum have a broader host and geographic range than C. fragariae?
metadata: Histopathology of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae.pdf

pdf:
A large number of light and electron microscopic studies describing
plant interactions with Colletotrichum species have been
published, but we have not found studies on the ultrastructure of
the C. acutatum– and C. fragariae–strawberry systems. A consideration
of the detailed natures of biotrophy, necrotrophy, and
hemibiotrophy is necessary in understanding the invasion mechanisms
of C. acutatum and C. fragariae. Biotrophy is the condition
in which the fungus maintains its host cells alive while removing
nutrients from them (9,16). Necrotrophy is the condition in which
the fungus approaches living host cells and kills them before
entering their lumina (9,12,16,28). Hemibiotrophy is a condition
in which the fungus initially enters a biotrophic phase and then
switches to a necrotrophic phase (9). The initial penetration and
invasion processes of a plant host by a fungal pathogen in the
absence of a significant plant resistant response ensure successful
colonization of host tissue and subsequent necrotrophic activities.
Bailey et al. (1) described two major invasion strategies, intracellular
hemibiotrophic invasion and subcuticular intramural invasion.
Early stages of invasion for both strategies include conidial
adhesion to the host surface, germination of conidia, production of
germ tubes, and penetration of the host cuticle via appressoria.
Subcuticular intramural pathogens grow within the cuticle and
within the cell walls of epidermal, subepidermal, and subtending
cells killing host cells prior to entering them (necrotrophic phase).
Intracellular hemibiotrophic pathogens invade living cells for a
short time, maintaining them apparently for nutritional advantage,
and then convert to a necrotrophic phase.
txt: A large number of light and electron microscopic studies describing plant interactions with Colletotrichum species have been published, but there are no studies on the ultrastructure of the C. acutatum– and C. fragariae–strawberry systems. Understanding the detailed natures of biotrophy, necrotrophy, and hemibiotrophy is necessary for comprehending the invasion mechanisms of C. acutatum and C. fragariae. Biotrophy is the condition in which the fungus maintains its host cells alive while removing nutrients from them. Necrotrophy is the condition in which the fungus kills host cells before entering their lumina. Hemibiotrophy is a condition in which the fungus initially enters a biotrophic phase and then switches to a necrotrophic phase. The initial penetration and invasion processes of a plant host by a fungal pathogen, in the absence of a significant plant resistant response, ensure successful colonization of host tissue and subsequent necrotrophic activities. Bailey et al. described two major invasion strategies: intracellular hemibiotrophic invasion and subcuticular intramural invasion. Early stages of invasion for both strategies include conidial adhesion to the host surface, germination of conidia, production of germ tubes, and penetration of the host cuticle via appressoria. Subcuticular intramural pathogens grow within the cuticle and within the cell walls of epidermal, subepidermal, and subtending cells, killing host cells prior to entering them (necrotrophic phase). Intracellular hemibiotrophic pathogens invade living cells for a short time, maintaining them apparently for nutritional advantage, and then convert to a necrotrophic phase.
q1: What is the significance of understanding biotrophy, necrotrophy, and hemibiotrophy in studying C. acutatum and C. fragariae invasion mechanisms?
q2: What are the differences between the intracellular hemibiotrophic invasion and subcuticular intramural invasion strategies in fungal pathogens?
q3: How do appressoria contribute to the early stages of host tissue invasion by Colletotrichum species?
q4: Are there currently no ultrastructural studies on the C. acutatum– and C. fragariae–strawberry systems?
q5: Does hemibiotrophy involve an initial biotrophic phase followed by a necrotrophic phase?
q6: Do subcuticular intramural pathogens kill host cells before entering them during the necrotrophic phase?
metadata: Histopathology of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae.pdf

pdf:
The role of chitin both as a host defense elicitor and as a target
for plant chitinases is well documented (3,18,20). Several fungi
are known to modify or mask chitin in structures involved in early
penetration presumably to avoid detection by the host or to avoid
the effects of host chitinases. A lectin probe, gold-labeled wheat
germ agglutinin, was chosen to study the distribution of chitin in
the walls of C. fragariae during the initial infection of the strawberry
host. The purpose of this study was to document the invasion
strategies of C. acutatum and C. fragariae in strawberry with
respect to strategies previously described by Bailey et al. (1), and
to examine the degree to which chitin was present in various
fungal infective structures.
txt: The role of chitin both as a host defense elicitor and as a target for plant chitinases is well documented. Several fungi are known to modify or mask chitin in structures involved in early penetration, presumably to avoid detection by the host or to evade the effects of host chitinases. A lectin probe, gold-labeled wheat germ agglutinin, was chosen to study the distribution of chitin in the walls of C. fragariae during the initial infection of the strawberry host. The purpose of this study was to document the invasion strategies of C. acutatum and C. fragariae in strawberry with respect to strategies previously described by Bailey et al., and to examine the degree to which chitin was present in various fungal infective structures.
q1: How do C. acutatum and C. fragariae modify or mask chitin during early penetration to evade host defenses?
q2: What was the purpose of using gold-labeled wheat germ agglutinin in the study of C. fragariae's infection of strawberry plants?
q3: How does the presence of chitin in fungal structures relate to the invasion strategies of C. acutatum and C. fragariae?
q4: Is chitin a target for plant chitinases as part of the plant's defense mechanism against fungal pathogens?
q5: Do C. fragariae and other fungi modify or mask chitin to avoid detection by the host?
q6: Was gold-labeled wheat germ agglutinin used to study the distribution of chitin in C. fragariae's cell walls during strawberry infection?
metadata: Histopathology of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae.pdf

pdf:
Propagation of strawberry plants. Strawberry plants (cv.
Chandler) were planted in 10- × 10-cm plastic pots containing a
1:1 (vol/vol) mixture of Jiffy-Mix (JPA, West Chicago, IL) and
pasteurized sand and grown for at least 6 weeks before inoculation
in a greenhouse maintained at 30°C day/18°C night 6°C with a
16-h photoperiod. Older leaves, runners, and flowers were
removed 1 to 7 days before inoculation, and three or four young
leaves remained on each plant at inoculation.
txt: Propagation of strawberry plants. Strawberry plants (cv. Chandler) were planted in 10 × 10 cm plastic pots containing a 1:1 (vol/vol) mixture of Jiffy-Mix (JPA, West Chicago, IL) and pasteurized sand and grown for at least 6 weeks before inoculation in a greenhouse maintained at 30°C day/18°C night ±6°C with a 16-hour photoperiod. Older leaves, runners, and flowers were removed 1 to 7 days before inoculation, leaving three or four young leaves on each plant at the time of inoculation.
q1: Why were older leaves, runners, and flowers removed from strawberry plants before inoculation?
q2: What was the significance of maintaining a specific temperature and photoperiod in the greenhouse during the propagation of strawberry plants?
q3: Why were strawberry plants grown for at least six weeks before inoculation?
q4: Were the strawberry plants grown in a mixture of Jiffy-Mix and pasteurized sand?
q5: Was the greenhouse temperature maintained at 30°C during the day and 18°C at night, with a 16-hour photoperiod?
q6: Were older leaves and runners removed 1 to 7 days before inoculating the strawberry plants?

pdf:
Inoculation of plants. Isolates of C. acutatum Goff and C.
fragariae CF-63 and CF-75 (26) were maintained on silica gel at
USDA-ARS in Poplarville, MS. These isolates were grown on
potato dextrose agar (PDA) for 14 to 21 days at 25°C under
fluorescent light at 14/10 h of light/dark intervals. The cultures
were located approximately 18 cm beneath four fluorescent tubes
(Sylvania Super Saver Lite White, 34 W, 16.7 μmolm2s–1;
OSRAM Sylvania, Danvers, MA). Conidial suspensions used for
inoculations were prepared by flooding each PDA culture plate
with sterile deionized water and gently scraping the agar surface
with a glass rod to remove conidia. The resulting conidial suspension
was filtered through cheesecloth and a final conidial suspension
of 1.5 × 106 conidia per ml was used to inoculate strawberry
plants.
txt: Inoculation of plants. Isolates of C. acutatum and C. fragariae CF-63 and CF-75 were maintained on silica gel at USDA-ARS in Poplarville, MS. These isolates were grown on potato dextrose agar (PDA) for 14 to 21 days at 25°C under fluorescent light with a 14/10-hour light/dark cycle. The cultures were positioned approximately 18 cm beneath four fluorescent tubes (Sylvania Super Saver Lite White, 34 W, 16.7 μmol·m²·s⁻¹; OSRAM Sylvania, Danvers, MA). Conidial suspensions used for inoculations were prepared by flooding each PDA culture plate with sterile deionized water and gently scraping the agar surface with a glass rod to remove conidia. The resulting conidial suspension was filtered through cheesecloth, and a final suspension of 1.5 × 10⁶ conidia per ml was used to inoculate strawberry plants.
q1: Why were conidial suspensions filtered through cheesecloth before inoculating strawberry plants?
q2: How were conidial suspensions of C. acutatum and C. fragariae prepared from potato dextrose agar cultures?
q3: What was the purpose of maintaining the fungal cultures at 25°C under fluorescent light with a 14/10-hour light/dark cycle?
q4: Were the fungal cultures grown on potato dextrose agar for 14 to 21 days before inoculation?
q5: Was a final conidial suspension concentration of 1.5 × 10⁶ conidia per ml used for inoculating the strawberry plants?
q6: Were the cultures positioned approximately 18 cm beneath fluorescent tubes for light exposure?

pdf:
Attached petioles and stolons were inoculated by misting to the
point of runoff or by spot inoculation. Plants were incubated in a
sealed 10-gallon tank at 100% relative humidity for 24 h and then
at reduced relative humidity by removing half of the plastic tank
cover for the remainder of the incubation time (25,26). Plants
inoculated with C. acutatum were incubated at 28°C; those inoculated
with C. fragariae were incubated at 32°C. Following inoculation,
petioles and stolons were examined microscopically at
8- to 10-h intervals for 96 h to document the morphology and time
required for germ tube development, appressorial formation, penetration
of the epidermis, subsequent invasion of tissue, development
of disease symptoms, and acervulus production.
txt: Attached petioles and stolons were inoculated by misting to the point of runoff or by spot inoculation. Plants were incubated in a sealed 10-gallon tank at 100% relative humidity for 24 hours, then at reduced relative humidity by removing half of the plastic tank cover for the remainder of the incubation period. Plants inoculated with C. acutatum were incubated at 28°C, while those inoculated with C. fragariae were incubated at 32°C. Following inoculation, petioles and stolons were examined microscopically at 8- to 10-hour intervals for 96 hours to document the morphology and timing of germ tube development, appressorial formation, epidermal penetration, subsequent tissue invasion, symptom development, and acervulus production.
q1: How did the incubation conditions differ between plants inoculated with C. acutatum and those inoculated with C. fragariae?
q2: What was the purpose of maintaining 100% relative humidity for 24 hours after inoculation?
q3: How was the progression of fungal infection, including germ tube development and appressorial formation, monitored over the 96-hour period?
q4: Were the inoculated plants initially incubated at 100% relative humidity for 24 hours?
q5: Were plants inoculated with C. acutatum incubated at a lower temperature (28°C) compared to those inoculated with C. fragariae (32°C)?
q6: Was the morphology and timing of fungal development documented every 8 to 10 hours for 96 hours after inoculation?
