pdf:
Fig. 1. Light micrographs of stolon inoculated with Colletotrichum spp. A and B, C. acutatum 24 h after inoculation. C and D, Cross sections showing C.
fragariae 48 and 72 h after inoculation. Bar = 25 μm. A, Septate (arrow) conidium (co) with a typical melanized appressorium (a) as a distinct swollen area
located at the end of a germ tube (g) and an immature, nonmelanized appressorium (n). The pore (arrowhead) from which the penetration peg develops is
visible. Bar = 5 μm. B, Cross section showing hypha (h) entering a stolon via an open stoma (arrow). Invading hyphae (arrowheads) in host apoplast. Bar =
25 μm. C, Colonization of cortical cells and periplastic spaces by fungal hyphae (h). Cortical cells show wall undulation (arrowhead) and plasmalemmal
disruption (arrow). D, Host walls showing increasing distortion (arrowhead) accompanied by disruption of the host plasmalemma (hp) and invasion of dead
cells by fungal hyphae (h).
txt:
Fig. 1. Light micrographs of stolon inoculated with Colletotrichum spp. A and B show C. acutatum 24 hours after inoculation. C and D show cross-sections with C. fragariae 48 and 72 hours after inoculation. Scale bar = 25 μm.

A: Septate conidium (co) with a typical melanized appressorium (a) as a distinct swollen area located at the end of a germ tube (g) and an immature, non-melanized appressorium (n). The pore (arrowhead) from which the penetration peg develops is visible. Scale bar = 5 μm.

B: Cross-section showing hypha (h) entering a stolon via an open stoma (arrow). Invading hyphae (arrowheads) in the host apoplast. Scale bar = 25 μm.

C: Colonization of cortical cells and periplastic spaces by fungal hyphae (h). Cortical cells show wall undulation (arrowhead) and plasmalemmal disruption (arrow).

D: Host walls showing increasing distortion (arrowhead) accompanied by disruption of the host plasmalemma (hp) and invasion of dead cells by fungal hyphae (h).
q1: How do the invasion structures of C. acutatum and C. fragariae differ at 24, 48, and 72 hours after inoculation?
q2: What is the significance of melanized appressoria in the infection process of C. acutatum?
q3: How does C. fragariae affect the host cell walls and plasmalemma during the colonization of stolon tissue?
q4: Does the light micrograph in panel A show a septate conidium with both melanized and non-melanized appressoria?
q5: Is there evidence of C. acutatum hyphae entering a stolon through an open stoma in panel B?
q6: Does panel D show disruption of the host plasmalemma and distortion of the host cell walls caused by fungal invasion?

pdf:
Tissue processing. Symptomatic tissue was fixed for 2 h in
0.1 M sodium cacodylate buffer (pH 7.0), 2.0% formaldehyde,
and 2.5% glutaraldehyde. Tissue was rinsed with distilled water
and postfixed 45 min in cacodylate buffered (pH 7.0) 1% osmium
tetroxide. Tissue was dehydrated with an ethanol series (50, 70,
85, 95, and 100%) followed by propylene oxide. Tissue was
then infiltrated in 50/50% by volume ERL 4206 resin (Spurr’s)/
propylene oxide for 4 h on a rotator, followed by 75/25%
by volume resin/propylene oxide change overnight on a rotator.
Tissue was infiltrated with two changes of 100% resin during
an 8-h period and cured at 70°C for 24 to 36 h. ERL 4206
resin contained nonenyl succinic anhydride (26 g), vinyl cyclohexene
dioxide (10 g), diglycidyl ether (6 g), and dimethylaminoethanol
(0.2 g).
txt:
Tissue Processing: Symptomatic tissue was fixed for 2 hours in 0.1 M sodium cacodylate buffer (pH 7.0) containing 2.0% formaldehyde and 2.5% glutaraldehyde. The tissue was then rinsed with distilled water and postfixed for 45 minutes in cacodylate-buffered (pH 7.0) 1% osmium tetroxide. Following fixation, the tissue was dehydrated through an ethanol series (50%, 70%, 85%, 95%, and 100%) and then transferred to propylene oxide.
The tissue was infiltrated with a 50/50% (by volume) mixture of ERL 4206 resin (Spurr’s) and propylene oxide for 4 hours on a rotator, followed by an overnight infiltration with a 75/25% (by volume) mixture of resin and propylene oxide. Two changes of 100% resin were performed over an 8-hour period, and the tissue was then cured at 70°C for 24 to 36 hours. ERL 4206 resin was composed of nonenyl succinic anhydride (26 g), vinyl cyclohexene dioxide (10 g), diglycidyl ether (6 g), and dimethylaminoethanol (0.2 g).
q1: What is the purpose of using sodium cacodylate buffer and formaldehyde for fixing the tissue samples?
q2: How does the process of infiltrating the tissue with ERL 4206 resin and propylene oxide contribute to the preparation of samples for microscopy?
q3: Why is the tissue cured at 70°C for 24 to 36 hours after resin infiltration?
q4: Was the tissue fixed in a solution containing both formaldehyde and glutaraldehyde?
q5: Did the tissue undergo dehydration through a series of increasing ethanol concentrations before infiltration with propylene oxide?
q6: Was the final resin used for infiltration ERL 4206, composed of a mixture of specific chemicals like nonenyl succinic anhydride and vinyl cyclohexene dioxide?
metadata: Histopathology of Colletotrichum acutatum and C. fragariae.pdf

pdf:
Slides with semithin sections (1 μm) were placed on a hotplate
at 55°C, stained for 1 to 2 min with 0.1% aqueous toluidine blue-
O, and examined with a light microscope. Ultrathin sections
(100 nm) were taken with a Porter-Blum MT-2B microtome (Ivan
Sorvall, Inc., Newton, CT) and a diamond knife (Diatome-U.S.,
Fort Washington, PA) and collected on 200-mesh copper grids.
Grids were stained with lead citrate (19) and 2% aqueous uranyl
acetate. Sections were viewed using a Zeiss EM 10-C transmission
electron microscope (Carl Zeiss, Inc., Thornwood, NY).
txt: Slide Preparation and Microscopy: Semithin sections (approximately 1 μm) were placed on a hotplate set to 55°C, stained for 1 to 2 minutes with 0.1% aqueous toluidine blue-O, and examined with a light microscope. Ultrathin sections (approximately 100 nm) were cut using a Porter-Blum MT-2B microtome (Ivan Sorvall, Inc., Newton, CT) with a diamond knife (Diatome-U.S., Fort Washington, PA) and collected on 200-mesh copper grids. The grids were then stained with lead citrate and 2% aqueous uranyl acetate. Sections were viewed using a Zeiss EM 10-C transmission electron microscope (Carl Zeiss, Inc., Thornwood, NY).
q1: Why are semithin sections stained with toluidine blue-O before being examined with a light microscope?
q2: What is the purpose of staining ultrathin sections with lead citrate and uranyl acetate?
q3: How does the use of a diamond knife in a Porter-Blum MT-2B microtome contribute to the preparation of ultrathin sections?
q4: Were the semithin sections stained for 1 to 2 minutes with 0.1% aqueous toluidine blue-O?
q5: Did ultrathin sections need to be cut to approximately 100 nm in thickness?
q6: Was the transmission electron microscope used for viewing ultrathin sections a Zeiss EM 10-C?

pdf:
We developed a procedure to aid in the location of appressoria
on fixed, embedded material. Slivers of epidermal tissue on which
appressoria had been seen with a compound microscope were flat
embedded in 2 to 3 mm of resin and cured at 70°C for 20 to 24 h.
Appressoria on the host tissue were identified through the thin
plastic with a compound microscope, and hand sections containing
appressoria were obtained. Those hand sections were then remounted
with Duco cement (Devcon, Danvers, MA) on prefaced
stubs (created by curing Spurr’s plastic in polyethylene Beem
capsules size “00” and trimmed with a 1 × 1 mm face) for ultrathin
sectioning.
txt: We developed a procedure to aid in locating appressoria on fixed, embedded material. Slivers of epidermal tissue, where appressoria had been observed with a compound microscope, were flat embedded in 2 to 3 mm of resin and cured at 70°C for 20 to 24 hours. Appressoria on the host tissue were identified through the thin plastic using a compound microscope, and hand sections containing appressoria were obtained. These hand sections were then remounted with Duco cement (Devcon, Danvers, MA) on prefaced stubs (created by curing Spurr’s plastic in polyethylene Beem capsules size “00” and trimmed with a 1 × 1 mm face) for ultrathin sectioning.
q1: What is the purpose of flat embedding slivers of epidermal tissue in resin before curing?
q2: How were appressoria identified through thin plastic using a compound microscope?
q3: Why were hand sections containing appressoria remounted with Duco cement on prefaced stubs?
q4: Was the epidermal tissue embedded in 2 to 3 mm of resin and cured at 70°C for 20 to 24 hours?
q5: Did the procedure involve using a compound microscope to locate appressoria before obtaining hand sections?
q6: Was Duco cement used to remount hand sections on prefaced stubs for ultrathin sectioning?

pdf:
Fig. 2. Light micrographs 72 h after inoculation with Colletotrichum spp. A, Petiole inoculated with C. acutatum. Bar = 50 μm. B, C, and D, Stolon inoculated
with C. fragariae. Bar = 25 μm. A, Advanced stage of invasion showing disrupted cortex and mature acervulus on intact epidermal and subepidermal layers.
Vascular tissue (phloem and xylem) remains intact at this point. B, Hyphae invading parenchyma cells (arrowhead) and vessel members (arrow). C, Expansion
of the host cuticle as the acervulus enlarges. D, The mature acervulus and stroma usually occupy the epidermal (e) and subepidermal (se) host layers while the
cortex experiences massive destruction. ac = acervulus; s = stroma; c = cuticle; cx = cortex; hw = host wall; p = phloem; x = xylem.
txt: Fig. 2. Light micrographs 72 hours after inoculation with Colletotrichum spp. A, Petiole inoculated with C. acutatum. Bar = 50 μm. B, C, and D, Stolon inoculated with C. fragariae. Bar = 25 μm. A, Advanced stage of invasion showing disrupted cortex and mature acervulus on intact epidermal and subepidermal layers. Vascular tissue (phloem and xylem) remains intact at this point. B, Hyphae invading parenchyma cells (arrowhead) and vessel members (arrow). C, Expansion of the host cuticle as the acervulus enlarges. D, The mature acervulus and stroma usually occupy the epidermal (e) and subepidermal (se) host layers while the cortex experiences massive destruction. ac = acervulus; s = stroma; c = cuticle; cx = cortex; hw = host wall; p = phloem; x = xylem.
q1: What stage of invasion is shown in light micrograph A for C. acutatum, and how does it affect the host tissue?
q2: How does the acervulus affect the host cuticle and underlying layers according to micrographs B, C, and D for C. fragariae?
q3: What structural features are indicated by the terms "acervulus," "stroma," "cuticle," "cortex," and "vascular tissue" in the context of fungal invasion?

pdf:
Application of wheat germ agglutinin lectin probe for
chitin. The application of the wheat germ agglutinin probe
(WGA; L-9640, Sigma, St. Louis) was modified from Benhamou
(2). The ultrathin sections on 200-mesh nickel grids were floated
on a drop of 0.01 M phosphate buffered saline (PBS; 40 ml of
0.02 M potassium hydroxide, 50 ml of 0.02 M potassium dihydrogen
phosphate, and 10 ml of distilled water), pH 7.4, in a
moist chamber for 1 h. Grids were subsequently incubated for 2 h
in a moist chamber in 15 μl of lectin-gold complex at the concentration
supplied by the manufacturer of 1.4 × 1013 particles per
ml. The probe was lectin from Triticum vulgaris conjugated to
10 nm colloidal gold particles. Each grid was then washed by
dipping repeatedly and gently for 10 s into PBS. Grids were air
dried and then stained with lead citrate and uranyl acetate as
described above.
txt: Application of wheat germ agglutinin lectin probe for chitin. The application of the wheat germ agglutinin probe (WGA; L-9640, Sigma, St. Louis) was modified from Benhamou. The ultrathin sections on 200-mesh nickel grids were floated on a drop of 0.01 M phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 40 ml of 0.02 M potassium hydroxide, 50 ml of 0.02 M potassium dihydrogen phosphate, and 10 ml of distilled water), pH 7.4, in a moist chamber for 1 hour. Grids were subsequently incubated for 2 hours in a moist chamber in 15 μl of lectin-gold complex at the concentration supplied by the manufacturer of 1.4 × 10¹³ particles per ml. The probe was lectin from Triticum vulgaris conjugated to 10 nm colloidal gold particles. Each grid was then washed by dipping repeatedly and gently for 10 seconds into PBS. Grids were air-dried and then stained with lead citrate and uranyl acetate as described above.
q1: How was the wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) lectin probe used to visualize chitin in ultrathin sections?
q2: Why was the lectin-gold complex applied at a specific concentration of 1.4 × 10¹³ particles per ml?
q3: What is the purpose of washing the grids with PBS after incubating them with the lectin-gold complex?
q4: Was the wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) probe used in conjunction with 10 nm colloidal gold particles for visualizing chitin?
q5: Were the ultrathin sections floated on a drop of 0.01 M phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) before incubation with the lectin-gold complex?
q6: Did the grids undergo staining with lead citrate and uranyl acetate after being air-dried?

pdf:
The specificity of the WGA lectin binding was determined by
the following tests used by Benhamou (2). These controls were
run simultaneously with the application of the normal probe on
symptomatic tissue. (1) The gold-labeled lectin was first preadsorbed
with poly-(1-4)--N-acetyl-D-glucosamine purified from
crab shells (C-9752, Sigma, St. Louis) at a concentration of 1 mg
per 2 ml of probe for 1 h and then applied as described above to
sections containing fungi from a strawberry petiole lesion 1 mm
or larger. (2) The ultrathin sections were floated on a drop of PBS
for 1 h and probed with wheat germ agglutinin without a gold
label for 1 h. The remainder of the probe application was as
described above.
txt: The specificity of the WGA lectin binding was determined by the following tests used by Benhamou. These controls were run simultaneously with the application of the normal probe on symptomatic tissue. (1) The gold-labeled lectin was first preadsorbed with poly-(1-4)-β-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine purified from crab shells (C-9752, Sigma, St. Louis) at a concentration of 1 mg per 2 ml of probe for 1 hour and then applied as described above to sections containing fungi from a strawberry petiole lesion 1 mm or larger. (2) The ultrathin sections were floated on a drop of PBS for 1 hour and probed with wheat germ agglutinin without a gold label for 1 hour. The remainder of the probe application was as described above.
q1: How was the specificity of the WGA lectin binding tested using poly-(1-4)-β-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine?
q2: What is the purpose of using wheat germ agglutinin without a gold label in one of the control tests?
q3: Why were the controls run simultaneously with the normal probe application on symptomatic tissue?
q4: Was the gold-labeled lectin preadsorbed with poly-(1-4)-β-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine before application to the sections?
q5: Were the ultrathin sections probed with wheat germ agglutinin without a gold label as part of the specificity test?
q6: Were the controls and normal probe applications run simultaneously to ensure accurate comparison?

pdf:
Light microscopy. The ontogeny of the infection processes
of C. acutatum and C. fragariae on inoculated plants were
similar (Table 1) at the light or electron microscopic levels.
Lesions most commonly developed on stolon tips and the upper
portion of the youngest petiole with fully expanded leaflets.
Lesions were first observed 2 days after inoculation as lenticular
brown spots that developed into the dark, sunken, and leathery
lesions typical of anthracnose that eventually girdled the stolon
or petiole.
txt: Light microscopy. The ontogeny of the infection processes of C. acutatum and C. fragariae on inoculated plants was similar (Table 1) at both the light and electron microscopic levels. Lesions most commonly developed on stolon tips and the upper portion of the youngest petiole with fully expanded leaflets. Lesions were first observed 2 days after inoculation as lenticular brown spots that developed into the dark, sunken, and leathery lesions typical of anthracnose, eventually girdling the stolon or petiole.
q1: How did the infection processes of C. acutatum and C. fragariae compare at both the light and electron microscopic levels?
q2: Where on the plant were lesions most commonly observed, and how did they progress over time?
q3: What were the initial and final appearances of the lesions caused by C. acutatum and C. fragariae?
q4: Were the infection processes of C. acutatum and C. fragariae similar when observed under light and electron microscopy?
q5: Did lesions initially appear as lenticular brown spots and later develop into dark, sunken, leathery lesions?
q6: Were lesions most commonly observed on stolon tips and the upper portion of the youngest petiole?

pdf:
Spore germination began as early as 16 h after inoculation, with
the germ tubes originating from either end of a conidium and
occasionally from both ends. Germ tubes generally spanned one
plant cell length or less, but occasionally grew across several
cells. Appressorial formation began as early as 20 h after inoculation.
Development of an appressorium began as a swelling of the
germ tube tip. Appressorial development could occur on such a
short germ tube as to appear sessile. Appressoria were initially
unmelanized, but by 24 h they were fully pigmented (Fig. 1A).
Small circular areas on the basal sides of appressoria, seen by
focusing through an appressorium with the light microscope, were
interpreted to be pores from which the penetration pegs developed
(Fig. 1A). The typical mature appressorium for either species was
globose and approximately 3 to 5 μm in diameter. Appressoria
frequently developed over anticlinal host walls, but occasionally,
were found over periclinal walls or near stomata. Appressoria and
their basal pores were found on the surface of both healthy and
diseased plant tissue.
txt: Spore germination began as early as 16 hours after inoculation, with germ tubes originating from either end of a conidium and occasionally from both ends. Germ tubes generally spanned one plant cell length or less but occasionally grew across several cells. Appressorial formation began as early as 20 hours after inoculation. Development of an appressorium started as a swelling of the germ tube tip. Appressorial development could occur on such a short germ tube that it appeared sessile. Appressoria were initially unmélanized, but by 24 hours they were fully pigmented (Fig. 1A). Small circular areas on the basal sides of appressoria, visible by focusing through an appressorium with the light microscope, were interpreted as pores from which the penetration pegs developed (Fig. 1A). The typical mature appressorium for either species was globose and approximately 3 to 5 μm in diameter. Appressoria frequently developed over anticlinal host walls but were occasionally found over periclinal walls or near stomata. Appressoria and their basal pores were found on the surface of both healthy and diseased plant tissue.
q1: How does the timing and development of spore germination and appressorial formation compare for the fungal species in the study?
q2: What are the observable characteristics and development stages of appressoria as described in the passage?
q3: Where on the host tissue are appressoria most commonly found, and how does their location vary?
q4: Did spore germination begin as early as 16 hours after inoculation?
q5: Were appressoria initially unmélanized and then fully pigmented by 24 hours?
q6: Are appressoria frequently found over anticlinal host walls but occasionally over periclinal walls or near stomata?

pdf:
The first signs of host cell distress appeared when the cell wall
contour became distorted, and the plasmalemma pulled away from
the cell wall (Fig. 1B to D). Hyphae during early stages of lesion
formation were less abundant in epidermal and subepidermal cells
than in cortical cells. A gradual increase of fungal hyphae in the
host cuticle, epidermis, and subepidermis was observed with
hyphae restricted to the apoplast in early stages of invasion and
then invading dead cells (Fig. 1B to D). As the infection progressed,
cell walls became increasingly distorted (Fig. 1D). In
contrast to disrupted cortical cell walls, epidermal and subepidermal
walls remained intact even though hyphae penetrated
their walls (Fig. 2A). Invasion of the vascular tissue and acervulus
formation occurred concurrently (Fig. 2A and B). The fungus was
seen in vessel elements (Fig. 2B) during this last phase of the
invasion process.
txt: The first signs of host cell distress appeared when the cell wall contour became distorted and the plasmalemma pulled away from the cell wall (Fig. 1B to D). During the early stages of lesion formation, hyphae were less abundant in epidermal and subepidermal cells than in cortical cells. A gradual increase of fungal hyphae in the host cuticle, epidermis, and subepidermis was observed, with hyphae initially restricted to the apoplast and then invading dead cells (Fig. 1B to D). As the infection progressed, cell walls became increasingly distorted (Fig. 1D). In contrast to disrupted cortical cell walls, epidermal and subepidermal walls remained intact even though hyphae penetrated their walls (Fig. 2A). Invasion of the vascular tissue and acervulus formation occurred concurrently (Fig. 2A and B). The fungus was seen in vessel elements (Fig. 2B) during this last phase of the invasion process.
q1: How does the abundance and distribution of fungal hyphae in different host tissues change during the infection process?
q2: What are the observable signs of host cell distress and how do they progress with infection?
q3: How does the invasion of vascular tissue and acervulus formation correlate with the overall progression of infection?
q4: Did the first signs of host cell distress include distorted cell wall contours and plasmalemma pulling away from the cell wall?
q5: Were hyphae initially less abundant in epidermal and subepidermal cells compared to cortical cells?
q6: Did the invasion of vascular tissue and acervulus formation occur concurrently during the final phase of the infection process?

Fig. 6. Electron micrographs showing later stages of invasion. A, Stolon 72 h after inoculation with Colletotrichum fragariae. B, Petiole 116 h after inoculation
with C. acutatum. A and B, Penetration of dead host cells. Some host cells were characterized by electron dense osmiophilic material associated with the
tonoplast (A), while others were not (B). C and D, Early development of a stroma in stolon 116 h after inoculation with C. fragariae. C, Hypha (h) growing

pdf:
Acervulus formation began with the development of a stroma
within the cuticle of epidermal cells. The cuticle expanded considerably
to accommodate the growing acervulus (Fig. 2C). The
maturing acervulus broke through the cuticle and eventually produced
conidia (Fig. 2D). The acervulus expanded radially with the
stroma also extending from the epidermis to the subepidermis.
Acervuli were produced over a disrupted cortex, or in extreme
cases, over a completely disintegrated cortex (Fig. 2D). In either
case, the epidermal and some of the subepidermal tissue remained
intact.
txt: Acervulus formation began with the development of a stroma within the cuticle of epidermal cells. The cuticle expanded considerably to accommodate the growing acervulus (Fig. 2C). The maturing acervulus broke through the cuticle and eventually produced conidia (Fig. 2D). The acervulus expanded radially with the stroma also extending from the epidermis to the subepidermis. Acervuli were produced over a disrupted cortex, or in extreme cases, over a completely disintegrated cortex (Fig. 2D). In either case, the epidermal and some of the subepidermal tissue remained intact.
q1: How does the formation and maturation of the acervulus progress in relation to the host tissue layers?
q2: What changes occur in the cuticle and underlying tissues during acervulus development and conidia production?
q3: How does the state of the cortex affect the production and expansion of the acervulus?
q4: Did acervulus formation begin with the development of a stroma within the cuticle of epidermal cells?
q5: Was the cuticle observed to expand significantly to accommodate the growing acervulus?
q6: Were acervuli produced over both disrupted and completely disintegrated cortex, while some epidermal and subepidermal tissue remained intact?

pdf:
The invasion of host tissue by C. fragariae and C. acutatum
was similar. However, each invasion event occurred more rapidly
with C. fragariae than with C. acutatum (Table 1). Lesions were
visible on petioles 3 days after inoculation with C. fragariae, but
were not visible until 4 days after inoculation with C. acutatum. A
similar delay in invasion events was observed between petiole and
stolen tissues following inoculation of either species. Most events
were observed a day sooner on the stolons than on the petioles
within species.
txt: The invasion of host tissue by C. fragariae and C. acutatum was similar. However, each invasion event occurred more rapidly with C. fragariae than with C. acutatum (Table 1). Lesions were visible on petioles 3 days after inoculation with C. fragariae, but were not visible until 4 days after inoculation with C. acutatum. A similar delay in invasion events was observed between petiole and stolon tissues following inoculation of either species. Most events were observed a day sooner on the stolons than on the petioles within species.
q1: How does the rate of invasion by C. fragariae compare to that of C. acutatum?
q2: What is the observed difference in the time it takes for lesions to become visible on petioles between the two fungal species?
q3: How does the timing of invasion events differ between petiole and stolon tissues for each fungal species?
q4: Did C. fragariae cause visible lesions on petioles 3 days after inoculation, while C. acutatum caused lesions 4 days after inoculation?
q5: Was there a consistent delay in invasion events between petiole and stolon tissues for both C. fragariae and C. acutatum?
q6: Were most invasion events observed a day sooner on stolons compared to petioles within each fungal species?

pdf:
Electron microscopy. The conidial and germ tube walls comprised
two layers, with the outer layer being thinner and more
electron dense than the inner layer. Only the inner conidial layer
was labeled by the WGA probe (Fig. 3). Upon germination, a
septum was laid down bisecting the conidium (Fig. 3), and one
also developed between the conidium and the germ tube. The
WGA probe was observed on the inner wall layers of the germ
tube and its septa. A few vesicles were present in the germ tube
after maturation of the appressorium, although no distinct organelles
were seen. The probe was not found in the cytoplasm of
germ tubes or appressoria.
txt: Electron microscopy. The conidial and germ tube walls comprised two layers, with the outer layer being thinner and more electron dense than the inner layer. Only the inner conidial layer was labeled by the WGA probe (Fig. 3). Upon germination, a septum was laid down bisecting the conidium (Fig. 3), and another developed between the conidium and the germ tube. The WGA probe was observed on the inner wall layers of the germ tube and its septa. A few vesicles were present in the germ tube after the maturation of the appressorium, although no distinct organelles were seen. The probe was not found in the cytoplasm of germ tubes or appressoria.
q1: What differences in wall layers are observed between the conidial and germ tube structures, and how are these layers labeled by the WGA probe?
q2: How does the WGA probe interact with the inner and outer layers of the conidial and germ tube walls?
q3: What observations were made regarding vesicles and organelles in the germ tube after appressorium maturation?
q4: Did the WGA probe label only the inner conidial layer and not the outer layer?
q5: Was a septum observed forming between the conidium and the germ tube after germination?
q6: Was the WGA probe found in the cytoplasm of germ tubes or appressoria?

pdf:
Appressoria were sometimes covered by an extracellular matrix
that was somewhat amorphous with dispersed fibrillar material.
The appressorial matrix was not labeled by the WGA probe (Fig.
4). The upper wall of the appressorium appeared to have two distinct
layers, with the probe being restricted to the inner layer (Fig.
4). The two layers became gradually indistinct as they approached
the basal side of the appressorium. The appressorial pore was
defined by the appressorial wall tapering toward a central area on
the basal side. The pore was usually occluded by a membrane
(Fig. 4). No evidence of labeling was found on either the host
cytoplasm or walls (Fig. 4).
txt: Appressoria were sometimes covered by an extracellular matrix that was somewhat amorphous with dispersed fibrillar material. The appressorial matrix was not labeled by the WGA probe (Fig. 4). The upper wall of the appressorium appeared to have two distinct layers, with the probe being restricted to the inner layer (Fig. 4). The two layers became gradually indistinct as they approached the basal side of the appressorium. The appressorial pore was defined by the appressorial wall tapering toward a central area on the basal side. The pore was usually occluded by a membrane (Fig. 4). No evidence of labeling was found on either the host cytoplasm or walls (Fig. 4).

q6: Was there no evidence of WGA probe labeling found on the host cytoplasm or walls?

pdf:
Some hyphae invaded the cuticle (Fig. 5A), outer epidermal
wall, and anticlinal walls of the epidermis (Fig. 5B). Some hyphae
initially penetrated what appeared to be living host cells (Fig. 5C
and D). The host plasmalemma invaginated to accommodate
hyphal penetration. The interface of the host membrane and
hyphal wall was frequently associated with a particular arrangement
of electron dense material (Fig. 5C and D). Several degrees
of disturbance and relaxation of the microfibrillar components of
cell walls were observed during penetration of host cells including
early penetration events (Fig. 5A). Death of fungal cells was a
rare occurrence.
txt: Some hyphae invaded the cuticle (Fig. 5A), outer epidermal wall, and anticlinal walls of the epidermis (Fig. 5B). Some hyphae initially penetrated what appeared to be living host cells (Fig. 5C and D). The host plasmalemma invaginated to accommodate hyphal penetration. The interface of the host membrane and hyphal wall was frequently associated with a particular arrangement of electron-dense material (Fig. 5C and D). Several degrees of disturbance and relaxation of the microfibrillar components of cell walls were observed during the penetration of host cells, including early penetration events (Fig. 5A). Death of fungal cells was a rare occurrence.
q1: Which structures did some hyphae invade during the infection process, and how did this affect the host cells?
q2: How did the host plasmalemma respond to the penetration of hyphae, and what was observed at the interface between the host membrane and hyphal wall?
q3: What changes were noted in the microfibrillar components of host cell walls during the hyphal penetration, and how common was fungal cell death?
q4: Did some hyphae invade the cuticle, outer epidermal wall, and anticlinal walls of the epidermis?
q5: Did the host plasmalemma invaginate to accommodate hyphal penetration, with the interface frequently showing electron-dense material?
q6: Was the death of fungal cells observed to be a rare occurrence during the infection process?

pdf:
Several dying host cells exhibited an amorphous, osmiophilic
material around the inside portion of the tonoplast (Fig. 6A, C,
and D); others did not (Fig. 6B). Some cortical fungal hyphae
appeared to be growing back to the epidermis in the stage prior to
acervulus formation (Fig. 6C). Acervulus formation involved the
development of a subcuticular stroma within and beneath the outer
host epidermal cell walls (Fig. 6D). A gradual vacuolation de-
veloped in stromatic cells (Fig. 6D). The stroma continued to develop
into the epidermal and adjacent subepidermal cells, finally
rupturing the cuticle (Fig. 7). Late development of the acervulus
included the extension of the host cuticle to accommodate the
expanding stroma, the rupture of the cuticle, and early development
of conidia (Fig. 7). C. acutatum and C. fragariae had a
pulvinate type of acervulus (27).
txt: Several dying host cells exhibited an amorphous, osmiophilic material around the inside portion of the tonoplast (Fig. 6A, C, and D); others did not (Fig. 6B). Some cortical fungal hyphae appeared to be growing back to the epidermis in the stage prior to acervulus formation (Fig. 6C). Acervulus formation involved the development of a subcuticular stroma within and beneath the outer host epidermal cell walls (Fig. 6D). A gradual vacuolation developed in stromatic cells (Fig. 6D). The stroma continued to develop into the epidermal and adjacent subepidermal cells, finally rupturing the cuticle (Fig. 7). Late development of the acervulus included the extension of the host cuticle to accommodate the expanding stroma, the rupture of the cuticle, and early development of conidia (Fig. 7). C. acutatum and C. fragariae had a pulvinate type of acervulus.
q1: What were the characteristics of the dying host cells and the surrounding amorphous osmiophilic material, and how did these features vary?
q2: How did fungal hyphae interact with the epidermis prior to acervulus formation, and what changes were observed in the stromatic cells?
q3: What were the key stages in the development of the acervulus, including its impact on the host cuticle and the formation of conidia?
q4: Did some dying host cells exhibit an amorphous, osmiophilic material around the inside portion of the tonoplast, while others did not?
q5: Were some fungal hyphae observed to be growing back to the epidermis before acervulus formation?
q6: Did the acervulus development include the extension of the host cuticle, rupture of the cuticle, and early development of conidia?

pdf:
C. acutatum and C. fragariae underwent a very brief biotrophic
phase (less than 12 h) before entering their extended necrotrophic
phase. Representatives of both species of fungi were observed
entering living host cells and developing a matrix comparable to
that described in reported biotrophic systems (4,11,13,15), but
they killed the host cells within a few hours. Previous descriptions
for other Colletotrichum species cite biotrophy at a minimum of
“less than 24 h” (14,29). But a situation in which a living cell is
entered and quickly killed might be considered a modification of
necrotrophy, rather than biotrophy or hemibiotrophy.
txt: C. acutatum and C. fragariae underwent a very brief biotrophic phase (less than 12 hours) before entering their extended necrotrophic phase. Representatives of both species of fungi were observed entering living host cells and developing a matrix comparable to that described in reported biotrophic systems, but they killed the host cells within a few hours. Previous descriptions for other Colletotrichum species cite biotrophy at a minimum of “less than 24 hours.” However, a situation in which a living cell is entered and quickly killed might be considered a modification of necrotrophy, rather than biotrophy or hemibiotrophy.
q1: How long does the biotrophic phase last for C. acutatum and C. fragariae before transitioning to necrotrophy?
q2: What characteristic distinguishes the behavior of C. acutatum and C. fragariae from other Colletotrichum species during the early infection stages?
q3: Why might the rapid killing of host cells by C. acutatum and C. fragariae be considered a modification of necrotrophy?
q4: Did C. acutatum and C. fragariae undergo a biotrophic phase for less than 12 hours?
q5: Are both C. acutatum and C. fragariae observed entering living host cells before killing them?
q6: Is the biotrophic phase for C. acutatum and C. fragariae shorter than 24 hours, as observed in other Colletotrichum species?

pdf:
Both intracellular hemibiotrophic and subcuticular intramural
Colletotrichum species avoid triggering resistance responses during
the symptomless phase (17). Species with an intracellular
hemibiotrophic strategy require an intimate cytoplasmic interaction
between the plant and the pathogen, while species with a subcuticular
intramural strategy do not require such intimacy. Since
the former species have a restricted host range, they are considered
specialists, while the latter species are considered generalists
(1). Regardless of the length of the biotrophic phase, all species
eventually revert to necrotrophic development. Since C. acutatum
is a generalist invader, only necrotrophic development was predicted,
while C. fragariae is a specialist invader (22) for which an
extended biotrophic phase was predicted to precede the necrotrophic
phase. The brevity of the biotrophic phase in C. acutatum
and C. fragariae leaves some uncertainty about calling these fungi
hemibiotrophs and comparing their initial infection strategies in
terms of previously described species.
txt: Both intracellular hemibiotrophic and subcuticular intramural Colletotrichum species avoid triggering resistance responses during the symptomless phase. Species with an intracellular hemibiotrophic strategy require an intimate cytoplasmic interaction between the plant and the pathogen, while species with a subcuticular intramural strategy do not require such intimacy. Since the former species have a restricted host range, they are considered specialists, while the latter species are considered generalists. Regardless of the length of the biotrophic phase, all species eventually revert to necrotrophic development. Since C. acutatum is a generalist invader, only necrotrophic development was predicted, while C. fragariae is a specialist invader for which an extended biotrophic phase was predicted to precede the necrotrophic phase. The brevity of the biotrophic phase in C. acutatum and C. fragariae leaves some uncertainty about calling these fungi hemibiotrophs and comparing their initial infection strategies in terms of previously described species.
q1: How do intracellular hemibiotrophic Colletotrichum species differ from subcuticular intramural species in terms of their interaction with the host plant?
q2: How do intracellular hemibiotrophic Colletotrichum species differ from subcuticular intramural species in terms of their interaction with the host plant?
q3: What uncertainty arises when attempting to classify C. acutatum and C. fragariae as hemibiotrophs?
q4: Do intracellular hemibiotrophic species require an intimate cytoplasmic interaction with the host plant?
q5: Are subcuticular intramural species considered generalists due to their broader host range?
q6: Was an extended biotrophic phase predicted for C. fragariae based on its specialist invader status?

pdf:
Penetration pegs were observed in our studies at the light
microscope level but not the ultrastructural level. Appressoria of
C. fragariae observed at the ultrastructural level may have been in
the process of forming a penetration peg or may have been arrested
just prior to formation of a penetration peg. Latent or quiescent
stages have been observed in fungal infections of fruits (30) where
the mature appressorium often will not produce a peg until the
fruit is at a particular stage of ripeness. This concept has not been
sufficiently studied in strawberry for the fungal penetration of
stolon, petioles, leaves, or roots. Strawberry petioles are often
more resistant to infection by C. fragariae while the plant is in
fruit (5,8). Development of appressoria of some species ceases
under the onset of unfavorable conditions, remains latent, and
resumes when the conditions are again favorable (6). The more
rapid invasion of host tissue by C. fragariae than by C. acutatum
is in agreement with previous reports that C. fragariae is more
aggressive than C. acutatum in inciting disease symptoms following
inoculation (24,26).
txt: Penetration pegs were observed in our studies at the light microscope level but not at the ultrastructural level. Appressoria of C. fragariae observed at the ultrastructural level may have been in the process of forming a penetration peg or may have been arrested just prior to its formation. Latent or quiescent stages have been observed in fungal infections of fruits, where the mature appressorium often will not produce a peg until the fruit reaches a particular stage of ripeness. This concept has not been sufficiently studied in strawberries for the fungal penetration of stolons, petioles, leaves, or roots. Strawberry petioles are often more resistant to infection by C. fragariae while the plant is in fruit. Development of appressoria of some species ceases under unfavorable conditions, remains latent, and resumes when conditions are again favorable. The more rapid invasion of host tissue by C. fragariae compared to C. acutatum is consistent with previous reports that C. fragariae is more aggressive than C. acutatum in inciting disease symptoms following inoculation.
q1: What might explain the absence of penetration pegs at the ultrastructural level during the observation of C. fragariae appressoria?
q2: How does fruit ripeness influence the development of penetration pegs in fungal infections, and why has this not been sufficiently studied in strawberries?
q3: What factors contribute to the more aggressive invasion of host tissue by C. fragariae compared to C. acutatum?
q4: Were penetration pegs observed at the light microscope level but not at the ultrastructural level in the study?
q5: Is C. fragariae more aggressive than C. acutatum in inciting disease symptoms after inoculation?
q6: Does the development of appressoria in some species cease and remain latent under unfavorable conditions?

pdf:
The distribution of chitin visualized by WGA gold probe in C.
lindemuthianum has been reported by O’Connell and Ride (15).
We found several similarities as well as some differences between
their findings and our results using the same probe to study C.
fragariae. The outer appressorial wall layer of C. lindemuthianum
was labeled more heavily by the probe than the inner layer. By
contrast, the outer appressorial wall layer of C. fragariae was
labeled less heavily by the probe than the inner layer. The matrices
of both C. lindemuthianum and C. fragariae were unlabeled.
The young intracellular hyphae of C. lindemuthianum were unlabeled,
but the invasive hyphal walls of C. fragariae and walls of
the comparable secondary hyphae of C. lindemuthianum were
labeled. The actively growing hyphal tips of either species labeled
with less intensity than the mature walls. The outer wall layers of
preinvasive structures of C. fragariae did not show chitin-gold
complex, but the single wall layers of invasive hyphae from the
earliest stages observed in planta contain chitin distribution comparable
to young hyphae observed in vitro. C. fragariae did not
appear to modify its chitin distribution during its very brief biotrophic
phase as does C. lindemuthianum. This supports O’Connell
and Ride’s (15) suggestion that chitin masking is necessary during
initial contact to establish a biotrophic relationship.
txt: The distribution of chitin visualized by the WGA gold probe in C. lindemuthianum has been reported by O’Connell and Ride. We found several similarities as well as some differences between their findings and our results using the same probe to study C. fragariae. The outer appressorial wall layer of C. lindemuthianum was labeled more heavily by the probe than the inner layer. By contrast, the outer appressorial wall layer of C. fragariae was labeled less heavily by the probe than the inner layer. The matrices of both C. lindemuthianum and C. fragariae were unlabeled. The young intracellular hyphae of C. lindemuthianum were unlabeled, but the invasive hyphal walls of C. fragariae and walls of the comparable secondary hyphae of C. lindemuthianum were labeled. The actively growing hyphal tips of either species were labeled with less intensity than the mature walls. The outer wall layers of preinvasive structures of C. fragariae did not show the chitin-gold complex, but the single wall layers of invasive hyphae from the earliest stages observed in planta contained chitin distribution comparable to young hyphae observed in vitro. C. fragariae did not appear to modify its chitin distribution during its very brief biotrophic phase as C. lindemuthianum does. This supports O’Connell and Ride’s suggestion that chitin masking is necessary during initial contact to establish a biotrophic relationship.
q1: How does the chitin distribution in the appressorial wall layers of C. lindemuthianum differ from that of C. fragariae?
q2: What similarities and differences were observed in the labeling of invasive hyphal walls between C. lindemuthianum and C. fragariae?
q3: Why is chitin masking considered necessary for establishing a biotrophic relationship, according to O'Connell and Ride?
q4: Was the outer appressorial wall of C. fragariae labeled less heavily by the WGA gold probe compared to the inner layer?
q5: Were the matrices of both C. lindemuthianum and C. fragariae unlabeled by the probe?
q6: Did C. fragariae fail to modify its chitin distribution during its brief biotrophic phase, unlike C. lindemuthianum?

pdf:
Fungi in the genus Colletotrichum cause serious pre- and post-harvest losses to
several agricultural crops worldwide. Through a systematic literature review, we
retrieved the published information on Colletotrichum anthracnose diseases on
different host plants and developed a mechanistic model incorporating the main
stages of the pathogen’s life cycle and the effect of weather. The model predicts
anthracnose progress during the growing season on the aerial organs of different
crops, and was parameterized for seven Colletotrichum clades (acutatum,
dematium, destructivum, gloeosporioides, graminicola, and orbiculare) and the
singleton species, C. coccodes. The model was evaluated for the anthracnose
diseases caused by fungi belonging to five clades on six hosts by using data from
17 epidemics that occurred in Italy, the USA, Canada, and Japan. A comparison of
observed versus predicted data showed a concordance correlation coefficient of
0.928 and an average distance between real data and the fitted line of 0.044.
After further validation, the model could be used to support decision-making for
crop protection.
KEYWORDS
epidemiology, disease modeling, glomerella, systematic literature review,
model validation
txt:
Fungi in the genus Colletotrichum cause significant pre- and post-harvest losses to several agricultural crops worldwide. Through a systematic literature review, we compiled published information on Colletotrichum anthracnose diseases across different host plants and developed a mechanistic model incorporating the main stages of the pathogen’s life cycle and the impact of weather. The model predicts anthracnose progress during the growing season on the aerial organs of various crops and was parameterized for seven Colletotrichum clades (acutatum, dematium, destructivum, gloeosporioides, graminicola, orbiculare) and the singleton species C. coccodes. The model was evaluated for anthracnose diseases caused by fungi from five clades on six hosts using data from 17 epidemics in Italy, the USA, Canada, and Japan. A comparison of observed versus predicted data showed a concordance correlation coefficient of 0.928 and an average distance between real data and the fitted line of 0.044. After further validation, the model could be used to support decision-making for crop protection.
KEYWORDS: epidemiology, disease modeling, Glomerella, systematic literature review, model validation
q1: How does the mechanistic model predict the progress of Colletotrichum anthracnose during the growing season across various crops?
q2: What factors were considered in parameterizing the model for different Colletotrichum clades and the species C. coccodes?
q3: How effective was the model in predicting anthracnose disease outcomes, based on its evaluation across multiple regions and hosts?
q4: Does the model incorporate weather factors to predict the progress of anthracnose diseases caused by Colletotrichum species?
q5: Was the model parameterized for seven Colletotrichum clades and the species C. coccodes?
q6: Did the model show a high concordance correlation coefficient of 0.928 when comparing observed and predicted data?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Fungi in the genus Colletotrichum (phylum: Ascomycota, class: Sordariomycetes) cause
pre- and post-harvest diseases in horticultural, ornamental, and fruit tree crops worldwide
(Hyde et al., 2009; Cannon et al., 2012). The genus Colletotrichum was ranked among the
top 10 fungal plant pathogens with scientific and economic importance (Dean et al., 2012).
This genus is widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions as well as in temperate
and Mediterranean areas. Common hosts range from high-value crops like strawberry,
olive, apple, and grape, to staple food crops grown by subsistence farmers in developing
countries like sorghum and cassava (Pastor-Corrales and Frederiksen, 1978; Peres et al.,
2005; Sangpueak et al., 2018). Many Colletotrichum species are primarily reported as causal
agents of anthracnose, which is also known by other names, like bitter rot on apple and ripe
rot on grape (Dowling et al., 2020). In addition to causing severe
yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can reduce the quality of the
produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). Blossom blight
and fruit rots are often the main economically damaging symptoms;
however, necrotic lesions can also appear on leaves, stems, and
twigs, leading to the deterioration of plants and a reduction in fruit
quality (Dowling et al., 2020).
txt: Fungi in the genus Colletotrichum (phylum: Ascomycota, class: Sordariomycetes) cause pre- and post-harvest diseases in horticultural, ornamental, and fruit tree crops worldwide (Hyde et al., 2009; Cannon et al., 2012). The genus Colletotrichum is ranked among the top 10 fungal plant pathogens with significant scientific and economic importance (Dean et al., 2012). It is widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions as well as in temperate and Mediterranean areas. Common hosts include high-value crops like strawberry, olive, apple, and grape, as well as staple food crops such as sorghum and cassava, which are grown by subsistence farmers in developing countries (Pastor-Corrales and Frederiksen, 1978; Peres et al., 2005; Sangpueak et al., 2018). Many Colletotrichum species are primarily reported as causal agents of anthracnose, which is also known by other names such as bitter rot on apple and ripe rot on grape (Dowling et al., 2020). In addition to causing severe yield losses, anthracnose epidemics can reduce the quality of the produce (Waller et al., 2002; Dowling et al., 2020). Blossom blight and fruit rots are often the main economically damaging symptoms; however, necrotic lesions can also appear on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration and reduced fruit quality (Dowling et al., 2020).
q1: What crops are most commonly affected by Colletotrichum species, and why is the genus considered scientifically and economically important?
q2: How do anthracnose epidemics caused by Colletotrichum affect crop yield and quality?
q3: What are the common symptoms of anthracnose disease on crops, and how do they impact plant health?
q4: Are Colletotrichum species ranked among the top 10 fungal plant pathogens of economic significance?
q5: Do Colletotrichum species affect both high-value and staple crops, such as strawberries and cassava?
q6: Can Colletotrichum infections cause symptoms like necrotic lesions on leaves, stems, and twigs, leading to plant deterioration?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Colletotrichum species are grouped into phylogenetic clades
(also called “species complexes”) on the basis of multilocus
molecular analysis. Species within a clade are closely related to
each other (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and
Baroncelli, 2021) and have similar temperature requirements
(Salotti et al., 2022). A recent systematic review of the taxonomy
and of the phylogenetic clades of the genus identified 15 major
clades and a number of small clusters and isolated species
(Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021). Detailed descriptions of major
phylogenetic clades and the list of species in each clade were
provided by Cannon et al. (2012); Vieira et al. (2020); Talhinhas
and Baroncelli (2021), Damm et al (2009; 2012; 2013; 2014), and
Weir et al. (2012).
txt: Colletotrichum species are grouped into phylogenetic clades (also called "species complexes") based on multilocus molecular analysis. Species within a clade are closely related to each other (Cannon et al., 2012; Vieira et al., 2020; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021) and share similar temperature requirements (Salotti et al., 2022). A recent systematic review of the taxonomy and phylogenetic clades of the genus identified 15 major clades as well as a number of small clusters and isolated species (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021). Detailed descriptions of the major phylogenetic clades and the species within each clade are provided by Cannon et al. (2012), Vieira et al. (2020), Talhinhas and Baroncelli (2021), Damm et al. (2009; 2012; 2013; 2014), and Weir et al. (2012).
q1: How are Colletotrichum species classified into phylogenetic clades, and what does this classification reveal about their relationships?
q2: What recent findings were reported in the systematic review of Colletotrichum taxonomy and phylogenetic clades?
q3: Which sources provide detailed descriptions of the major phylogenetic clades and their species?
q4: Are Colletotrichum species grouped into phylogenetic clades based on multilocus molecular analysis?
q5: Did the recent systematic review identify 15 major clades and some small clusters or isolated species of Colletotrichum?
q6: Are the major phylogenetic clades and species described in the works of Cannon et al. (2012) and Talhinhas and Baroncelli (2021)?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Colletotrichum species are primarily reported as causal agents of
anthracnose, occurring on plant leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits.
The disease cycles of anthracnose on different hosts have similar
components (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017); they are
generally polycyclic, with splash-borne asexual spores (conidia)
responsible for the initiation and spread of the epidemics. Other
Colletotrichum diseases have been described, causing crown rot of
strawberry and black dot on tomato and potato roots (Dillard and
Cobb, 1997; Dillard and Cobb, 1998; Waller et al., 2002).
Colletotrichum species can also cause post-harvest diseases,
especially on avocado, almond, and citrus fruit (Prusky, 1996;
Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013); in these cases, the
pathogens develop infection structures (appressoria) on the host,
but remain dormant inside the fruit until after harvest (i.e., during
storage, transportation, or sale of fruit), at which time symptoms
develop (Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). Several
studies reported that species within a clade show similar
colonization and infection behaviour, while the establishment of
quiescence is host- and tissue-specific (Sanders and Korsten, 2003;
Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013;
Jayawardena et al., 2016; Zakaria, 2021). Species within clades
also have similar temperature requirements for mycelial growth,
conidial germination and infection, and spore production (Salotti
et al., 2022). For example, C. gloeosporioides, C. fragarie, C. gossypii,
and C. musae belonging to the gloeosporioides clade show optimum
temperature for mycelial growth, sporulation, conidial germination
and infection between 25 and 32°C (Salotti et al., 2022).
txt:
Colletotrichum species are primarily reported as causal agents of anthracnose, affecting plant leaves, stems, flowers, and fruits. The disease cycles of anthracnose on different hosts share similar components (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017); they are generally polycyclic, with splash-borne asexual spores (conidia) responsible for initiating and spreading the epidemics. Other Colletotrichum diseases include crown rot of strawberry and black dot on tomato and potato roots (Dillard and Cobb, 1997; Dillard and Cobb, 1998; Waller et al., 2002).
Colletotrichum species can also cause post-harvest diseases, particularly on avocado, almond, and citrus fruits (Prusky, 1996; Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). In these cases, the pathogens form infection structures (appressoria) on the host but remain dormant inside the fruit until after harvest (i.e., during storage, transportation, or sale), at which point symptoms develop (Ismail and Zhang, 2004; Prusky et al., 2013). Several studies have reported that species within a clade exhibit similar colonization and infection behavior, though the establishment of quiescence is host- and tissue-specific (Sanders and Korsten, 2003; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013; Jayawardena et al., 2016; Zakaria, 2021). Additionally, species within clades have similar temperature requirements for mycelial growth, conidial germination, infection, and spore production (Salotti et al., 2022). For example, C. gloeosporioides, C. fragariae, C. gossypii, and C. musae, all belonging to the gloeosporioides clade, show optimal temperatures for mycelial growth, sporulation, conidial germination, and infection between 25 and 32°C (Salotti et al., 2022).
q1: What common features are shared in the disease cycles of anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum on different hosts?
q2: How do post-harvest diseases caused by Colletotrichum differ from pre-harvest diseases in terms of pathogen behavior and symptom development?
q3: How do temperature requirements for mycelial growth and infection vary among different Colletotrichum species within the gloeosporioides clade?
q4: Are the disease cycles of anthracnose generally polycyclic and initiated by splash-borne asexual spores?
q5: Do Colletotrichum species form infection structures that remain dormant in fruits until post-harvest?
q6: Do species within the gloeosporioides clade show similar temperature requirements for various stages of their lifecycle?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Integrated pest management (IPM) against Colletotrichum spp.
includes cultural, biological, and chemical control. Cultural control
includes producing disease-free propagating materials, avoiding the
use of overhead irrigation, limiting rain splashing by mulching, and
managing weeds (Coelho et al., 2008; Saxena et al., 2016). The
removal of infected crop residues and mummified or rotten fruits is
recommended to reduce the inoculum sources and the disease
pressure in the field (Samuelian et al., 2012; Saxena et al., 2016).
For instance, the removal of crop debris removal reduced by about
30% the anthracnose severity in Ethiopian sorghum fields (Aragaw
et al., 2021). The use of resistant cultivars could be an
environmentally friendly and cost-effective way to control the
disease (Saxena et al., 2016); however, available marketable
cultivars often do not provide enough resistance to eliminate the
need for fungicides (Dowling et al., 2020). Biological control agents
(BCAs), such as Trichoderma spp. and Bacillus subtilus, have been
considered (Saxena et al., 2016; Dowling et al., 2020), but most
farmers still prefer combining cultural practices and chemical
control methods because of the variable efficacy of BCAs under
field conditions (Dowling et al., 2020). Calendar-based
application of chemicals, therefore, remains the main tool for
controlling anthracnose diseases. This leads to intensive fungicide
sprays, which may involve needless applications that are not
economically or ecologically sustainable (Rossi et al., 2012).
txt: Integrated pest management (IPM) against Colletotrichum spp. involves cultural, biological, and chemical control methods. Cultural control includes practices such as using disease-free propagating materials, avoiding overhead irrigation, limiting rain splashing by mulching, and managing weeds (Coelho et al., 2008; Saxena et al., 2016). Removing infected crop residues and mummified or rotten fruits is recommended to reduce inoculum sources and disease pressure in the field (Samuelian et al., 2012; Saxena et al., 2016). For example, removing crop debris reduced anthracnose severity by about 30% in Ethiopian sorghum fields (Aragaw et al., 2021). Using resistant cultivars could be an environmentally friendly and cost-effective way to control the disease (Saxena et al., 2016); however, marketable cultivars often do not provide sufficient resistance to eliminate the need for fungicides (Dowling et al., 2020). Biological control agents (BCAs), such as Trichoderma spp. and Bacillus subtilis, have been considered (Saxena et al., 2016; Dowling et al., 2020), but most farmers still prefer combining cultural practices with chemical control methods due to the variable efficacy of BCAs under field conditions (Dowling et al., 2020). Calendar-based application of chemicals remains the primary method for controlling anthracnose diseases, leading to intensive fungicide sprays that may involve unnecessary applications, which are not economically or ecologically sustainable (Rossi et al., 2012).
q1: What cultural control methods are recommended for managing Colletotrichum spp. in integrated pest management (IPM)?
q2: How effective is removing infected crop residues and mummified fruits in reducing anthracnose severity, and what example demonstrates this?
q3: Why do marketable cultivars often require fungicides despite the use of resistant cultivars in controlling Colletotrichum diseases?
q4: Are cultural control practices like using disease-free materials, avoiding overhead irrigation, and managing weeds part of IPM strategies against Colletotrichum spp.?
q5: Do biological control agents (BCAs) like Trichoderma spp. and Bacillus subtilis show variable efficacy under field conditions?
q6: Is calendar-based application of chemicals the primary method for controlling anthracnose diseases, and does it lead to potentially unnecessary fungicide applications?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Mathematical models can help growers schedule fungicide
sprays (Pertot et al., 2017; Rossi et al., 2019; Fedele et al., 2022).
Models have been developed to understand the epidemiology of
anthracnose on specific crops and to support infection-risk-based
fungicide applications (Dodd et al., 1991; Park et al., 1992; Monroe
et al., 1997; Moral et al., 2012; Singh, 2020). Most of these models,
however, are simple and consider only one component of the
pathogen life cycle, mainly conidial infection, and only focus on a
single Colletotrichum species or crop. Furthermore, many of these
models have never been validated against independent data (i.e.,
data not used in model development). Contrary to these simple
models, mechanistic models have a flexible structure, a high
explanatory ability, and the possibility of making predictions over
a wide range of agricultural contexts; as a result, mechanistic models
are considered useful for decision-making in IPM (De Wolf and
Isard, 2007; Rossi et al., 2019). Recently, Ji et al. (2021) developed
and validated a mechanistic, weather-driven model for the ripe rot
of grapes caused by the Colletotrichum species.
txt: Mathematical models can assist growers in scheduling fungicide sprays (Pertot et al., 2017; Rossi et al., 2019; Fedele et al., 2022). Models have been developed to understand the epidemiology of anthracnose on specific crops and to support infection-risk-based fungicide applications (Dodd et al., 1991; Park et al., 1992; Monroe et al., 1997; Moral et al., 2012; Singh, 2020). However, many of these models are simplistic, focusing on only one component of the pathogen life cycle, primarily conidial infection, and often address only a single Colletotrichum species or crop. Additionally, many of these models have not been validated against independent data (i.e., data not used in model development). In contrast, mechanistic models offer a flexible structure, high explanatory capability, and the potential to make predictions across a broad range of agricultural contexts. Consequently, mechanistic models are considered valuable for decision-making in IPM (De Wolf and Isard, 2007; Rossi et al., 2019). Recently, Ji et al. (2021) developed and validated a mechanistic, weather-driven model for ripe rot of grapes caused by Colletotrichum species.
q1: What are the advantages of using mechanistic models over simplistic models in scheduling fungicide applications for managing Colletotrichum spp.?
q2: How do mechanistic models contribute to decision-making in integrated pest management (IPM) compared to simpler models?
q3: What recent development in mechanistic modeling is mentioned for managing ripe rot of grapes caused by Colletotrichum species?
q4: Do mathematical models assist growers in scheduling fungicide sprays and managing Colletotrichum diseases?
q5: Are many existing models simplistic, focusing primarily on conidial infection and often addressing only one species or crop?
q6: Has a recent mechanistic, weather-driven model been developed and validated for managing ripe rot of grapes caused by Colletotrichum?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Given that the pathogens causing different Colletotrichum
diseases affecting the aerial parts of host plants in the field (preharvest)
have similar life cycles, we developed a general, weatherdriven,
mechanistic model for anthracnose epidemics. The model is
“general” in that it has one conceptual structure that incorporates
the key epidemiological components and a set of equations that
account for the effect of external variables (both environmental and
host-related), which can be calibrated for single Colletotrichum
species, clades, and host plants. For model development and
calibration, we (i) conducted a systematic literature search to
retrieve the available information on Colletotrichum anthracnose
diseases; (ii) used this information to develop a conceptual model of
the diseases caused by Colletotrichum species based on systems
analysis; (iii) developed the mathematical equations describing the
system both quantitatively and dynamically; (iv) calibrated the
model for seven major clades and the singleton species C.
coccodes (which is referred to as the coccodes clade in this
report); and finally (v) evaluated the ability of the model to
represent the real system.
txt: Given that the pathogens causing various Colletotrichum diseases affecting the aerial parts of host plants in the field (preharvest) share similar life cycles, we developed a general, weather-driven, mechanistic model for anthracnose epidemics. The model is "general" in that it features a unified conceptual structure incorporating key epidemiological components and a set of equations accounting for external variables (both environmental and host-related). This model can be calibrated for specific Colletotrichum species, clades, and host plants. For model development and calibration, we: (i) conducted a systematic literature search to gather available information on Colletotrichum anthracnose diseases; (ii) used this information to develop a conceptual model of these diseases based on systems analysis; (iii) formulated mathematical equations to describe the system both quantitatively and dynamically; (iv) calibrated the model for seven major clades and the singleton species C. coccodes (referred to as the coccodes clade in this report); and (v) evaluated the model's ability to accurately represent the real system.
q1: What is the purpose of developing a general, weather-driven, mechanistic model for anthracnose epidemics affecting aerial parts of host plants?
q2: How does the model account for specific Colletotrichum species, clades, and host plants in its calibration process?
q3: What steps were involved in the development and calibration of the model for Colletotrichum anthracnose diseases?
q4: Does the general, weather-driven, mechanistic model feature a unified conceptual structure incorporating key epidemiological components and external variables?
q5: Was a systematic literature search conducted to gather information on Colletotrichum anthracnose diseases for model development?
q6: Did the calibration of the model include seven major clades and the singleton species C. coccodes?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
For developing the conceptual and mathematical structure of the
model, we conducted a systematic literature search (Okoli and
Schabram, 2010; Biesbroek et al., 2013; Candel, 2014) to collect
data on the biology, ecology, and epidemiology of Colletotrichum
spp. from academic articles, articles in the press, and conference
papers. Articles were searched by combining the following keywords:
(i) Colletotrichum; (ii) conidia OR spore OR acervuli OR primary
inoculum OR production OR development OR overwinter
OR dissemination OR release OR dispersion OR deposition
OR infection OR penetration OR germination OR incubation OR
lesion development OR lesion onset OR latency OR latent period, and
(iii) temperature OR wetness OR relative humidity OR rain OR
environment. Search strings are shown in Table 1 of the
Supplementary material. The literature search was carried out in
2022 in three bibliographical databases: Scopus (https://
www.scopus.com/ accessed on February 25), Web of Science
(https://www.webofscience.com/ accessed on February 28), and
CAB Abstracts (https://www.cabdirect.org/cabdirect/search/
accessed on March 1). Each article found was first reviewed on the
basis of the information in the title and abstract; articles of potential
interest were then read in full. Additional articles were retrieved from
the “References” section of the found articles; these articles were
also reviewed.
txt: For developing the conceptual and mathematical structure of the model, we conducted a systematic literature search to gather data on the biology, ecology, and epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp. from academic articles, press articles, and conference papers. We used the following keywords in our search: (i) Colletotrichum; (ii) conidia OR spore OR acervuli OR primary inoculum OR production OR development OR overwinter OR dissemination OR release OR dispersion OR deposition OR infection OR penetration OR germination OR incubation OR lesion development OR lesion onset OR latency OR latent period; and (iii) temperature OR wetness OR relative humidity OR rain OR environment. Search strings are shown in Table 1 of the Supplementary material. The literature search was conducted in 2022 across three bibliographical databases: Scopus (https://www.scopus.com/ accessed on February 25), Web of Science (https://www.webofscience.com/ accessed on February 28), and CAB Abstracts (https://www.cabdirect.org/cabdirect/search/ accessed on March 1). Each article was initially reviewed based on the title and abstract; articles of potential interest were then read in full. Additional articles were retrieved from the “References” sections of the identified articles and reviewed as well.
q1: What types of sources were included in the literature search for developing the conceptual and mathematical structure of the model?
q2: Which keywords were used in the literature search to gather data on the biology, ecology, and epidemiology of Colletotrichum spp.?
q3: How were articles reviewed and selected for inclusion in the systematic literature search?
q4: Was the literature search for the model development conducted using multiple bibliographical databases?
q5: Did the literature search include keywords related to pathogen biology, environmental factors, and infection processes?
q6: Were articles reviewed initially based on titles and abstracts before being read in full for potential inclusion?

pdf:
Although different life styles have been described for
Colletotrichum spp. (i.e., necrotrophic, biotrophic, hemibiotrophic,
quiescent, and endophytic life styles), the life cycles of these species
have some common attributes (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al.,
2017), which include both sexual and asexual reproduction. Because
the perithecial stage is rarely observed in the field (Dowling et al.,
2020), the asexual conidia are the most important stage for disease
development; ourmodel, therefore, focuses on the asexual life cycle. A
general, asexual life cycle for Colletotrichum spp. is shown in Figure 1.
txt: Although different lifestyles have been described for Colletotrichum spp. (i.e., necrotrophic, biotrophic, hemibiotrophic, quiescent, and endophytic), their life cycles share some common attributes (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017), including both sexual and asexual reproduction. Since the perithecial stage is rarely observed in the field (Dowling et al., 2020), the asexual conidia are the most critical stage for disease development. Consequently, our model focuses on the asexual life cycle. A general, asexual life cycle for Colletotrichum spp. is shown in Figure 1.
q1: What stages of reproduction are common in the life cycles of Colletotrichum spp.?
q2: Why is the asexual conidia stage considered critical for disease development in Colletotrichum spp.?
q3: What aspect of the Colletotrichum spp. life cycle is emphasized in the model described?
q4: Is the perithecial stage commonly observed in the field for Colletotrichum spp.?
q5: Does the model focus on both sexual and asexual reproduction?
q6: Is the asexual life cycle of Colletotrichum spp. illustrated in Figure 1?
