pdf:
Colletotrichum spp. overwinter as mycelium or sclerotia in crop
debris (Farley, 1976; Casela and Frederiksen, 1993; Yoshida et al.,
2002; Conner et al., 2019), fruit mummies (Moral and Trapero,
2012; Samuelian et al., 2012; McKay et al., 2014), and buds (Verma
et al., 2006; Stensvand et al., 2017; Everett et al., 2018). In some
hosts like strawberry and Citrus spp., the pathogen survives as
melanized appressoria on asymptomatic leaves (Denham and
Waller, 1981; Leandro et al., 2001). The pathogen can also be
introduced in the field with infected seeds (Thomas and
Sweetingham, 2004) or transplants (Howard et al., 1992); infected
seeds and transplants, however, are not considered as primary
inoculum sources in our model, because we assume that farmers
use pathogen-free propagating material.
txt: Colletotrichum spp. overwinter as mycelium or sclerotia in crop debris (Farley, 1976; Casela and Frederiksen, 1993; Yoshida et al., 2002; Conner et al., 2019), fruit mummies (Moral and Trapero, 2012; Samuelian et al., 2012; McKay et al., 2014), and buds (Verma et al., 2006; Stensvand et al., 2017; Everett et al., 2018). In some hosts, such as strawberry and Citrus spp., the pathogen survives as melanized appressoria on asymptomatic leaves (Denham and Waller, 1981; Leandro et al., 2001). Additionally, the pathogen can be introduced into the field with infected seeds (Thomas and Sweetingham, 2004) or transplants (Howard et al., 1992); however, infected seeds and transplants are not considered primary inoculum sources in our model, as we assume that farmers use pathogen-free propagating material.
q1: What are the different forms in which Colletotrichum spp. can overwinter?
q2: How does the pathogen survive in hosts like strawberry and Citrus spp.?
q3: Why are infected seeds and transplants not considered primary inoculum sources in the model?
q4: Can Colletotrichum spp. overwinter in crop debris?
q5: Is the pathogen capable of surviving as melanized appressoria on asymptomatic leaves?
q6: Does the model assume that farmers use pathogen-free propagating material?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Primary inoculum consists of fresh conidia produced in acervuli
under favorable conditions of temperature (10 to 30°C for most of
the clades) and moisture (e.g., wetness periods longer than 6 h) on
overwintered sources for the entire cropping season (Moral and
Trapero, 2012; Stensvand et al., 2017; Everett et al., 2018). Conidia
are splash-dispersed by rain (Denham and Waller, 1981;
Chakraborty and Billard, 1995; Madden et al., 1996; Madden,
1997; Guyot et al., 2005; Buirchell et al., 2006), are deposited on
plant surfaces, and germinate; the germ tubes then produce
appressoria that in turn produce infection pegs that penetrate the
host cuticle and epidermal cell walls (Perfect et al., 1999).
Penetration through stomata or wounds by germ tubes without
the formation of appressoria is rare (Zulfiqar et al., 1996). The
infection of epidermal and mesophyll cells occurs after a
symptomless biotrophic phase and results in a necrotic phase in
which host cells are killed and secondary hyphae grow intra- and
inter-cellularly (O'Connell et al., 2012). In some cases, the pathogen
has a quiescent phase (Peres et al., 2005; Prusky et al., 2013), and the
switch to the necrotrophic phase occurs only when host tissue and
environmental conditions become conducive to the continuation of
the infection cycle. Except for those few species that exist entirely as
endophytes, the majority of Colletotrichum species develop a
necrotrophic stage at some point in their life cycle (Prusky
et al., 2013).
txt: Primary inoculum consists of fresh conidia produced in acervuli under favorable conditions of temperature (10 to 30°C for most clades) and moisture (e.g., wetness periods longer than 6 hours) from overwintered sources throughout the cropping season (Moral and Trapero, 2012; Stensvand et al., 2017; Everett et al., 2018). Conidia are splash-dispersed by rain (Denham and Waller, 1981; Chakraborty and Billard, 1995; Madden et al., 1996; Madden, 1997; Guyot et al., 2005; Buirchell et al., 2006), deposited on plant surfaces, and germinate. The germ tubes produce appressoria, which in turn form infection pegs that penetrate the host cuticle and epidermal cell walls (Perfect et al., 1999). Penetration through stomata or wounds by germ tubes without appressoria formation is rare (Zulfiqar et al., 1996). Infection of epidermal and mesophyll cells occurs after a symptomless biotrophic phase, leading to a necrotic phase where host cells are killed and secondary hyphae grow intra- and inter-cellularly (O'Connell et al., 2012). In some cases, the pathogen enters a quiescent phase (Peres et al., 2005; Prusky et al., 2013), with the necrotrophic phase only occurring when host tissue and environmental conditions favor the continuation of the infection cycle. Except for a few species that exist entirely as endophytes, most Colletotrichum species develop a necrotrophic stage at some point in their life cycle (Prusky et al., 2013).
q1: What conditions are favorable for the production of primary inoculum in Colletotrichum spp.?
q2: How do conidia of Colletotrichum spp. lead to infection of the host?
q3: What are the different phases of infection and their effects on the host?
q4: Is the primary inoculum produced in acervuli?
q5: Do germ tubes of Colletotrichum spp. typically penetrate the host cuticle and epidermal cell walls through stomata or wounds?
q6: Do all Colletotrichum species develop a necrotrophic stage at some point in their life cycle?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Acervuli finally develop within lesions and produce masses of
conidia that serve as secondary inoculum for the repetition of
infection cycles and the further spread of the disease (Peres et al.,
2005; De Silva et al., 2017).
txt: Acervuli eventually develop within lesions and produce masses of conidia that act as secondary inoculum, enabling the repetition of infection cycles and further spread of the disease (Peres et al., 2005; De Silva et al., 2017).
q1: What role do acervuli play in the infection cycle of Colletotrichum spp.?
q2: How does secondary inoculum contribute to the spread of disease?
q3: At what stage do acervuli produce conidia?
q4: Do acervuli develop within lesions?
q5: Are the conidia produced by acervuli considered primary inoculum?
q6: Is the production of secondary inoculum facilitated by acervuli?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Information from the literature was organized in a relational
diagram representing the epidemic structure as developed by
Zadoks (1971) and by using the systems analysis syntax (Leffelaar
and Ferrari, 1989; Rossi et al., 2010; Rossi et al., 2015) (Figure 2 and
Table 1). In this structure, the crop is composed of a large but finite
number of sites that have equal dimensions and equal probability of
becoming infected; a site is defined as a fraction of the host tissues
where an infection may occur and where a lesion may develop
(Zadoks, 1971; Savary et al., 2015). During the epidemic, a site goes
through the following stages: healthy, infected without visible
lesions (latent infection), infected with visible lesions (i.e., disease
symptoms or signs), infected with fertile (i.e., sporulating) lesions,
and finally, infected with no-longer sporulating lesions (or removed
lesions). In the model, the site stages are state variables (boxes); the
flow from one stage to the next (solid arrows) is regulated by rates
(valves), which are in turn influenced by external and auxiliary
variables (short segments and circles, respectively). The external
variables include weather variables such as air temperature (T, in °
C), wetness duration (WD, in h), and rainfall (P, in mm).
Mathematical equations link (through dotted arrows) the external
variables to rates, and were developed by using the data extracted
from the literature; different parameterization was used for the
different phylogenetic clades of Colletotrichum (Salotti et al., 2022).
txt: Information from the literature was organized into a relational diagram representing the epidemic structure, as developed by Zadoks (1971) and using systems analysis syntax (Leffelaar and Ferrari, 1989; Rossi et al., 2010; Rossi et al., 2015) (see Figure 2 and Table 1). This structure models the crop as comprising a large but finite number of sites with equal dimensions and equal probability of becoming infected. A site is defined as a fraction of the host tissue where an infection may occur and where a lesion may develop (Zadoks, 1971; Savary et al., 2015). During the epidemic, a site progresses through the following stages: healthy, infected without visible lesions (latent infection), infected with visible lesions (i.e., disease symptoms or signs), infected with fertile (i.e., sporulating) lesions, and finally, infected with non-sporulating lesions (or removed lesions). In the model, site stages are represented as state variables (boxes), with transitions between stages (solid arrows) regulated by rates (valves). These rates are influenced by external and auxiliary variables (short segments and circles, respectively). External variables include weather factors such as air temperature (T, in °C), wetness duration (WD, in h), and rainfall (P, in mm). Mathematical equations link (through dotted arrows) the external variables to rates and were developed using data extracted from the literature; different parameterizations were applied for the various phylogenetic clades of Colletotrichum (Salotti et al., 2022).
q1: How is the epidemic structure of the crop modeled according to the relational diagram?
q2: What are the stages that a site progresses through during the epidemic in the model?
q3: What role do external variables play in the model of the epidemic structure?
q4: Does the relational diagram represent the epidemic structure using systems analysis syntax?
q5: Are site stages in the model represented as state variables?
q6: Do the mathematical equations linking external variables to rates use data extracted from the literature?

r	Apparent infection rate	N

Auxiliary Variables		
CON	Abundance of conidia (i.e., CON = CON’ + CON”)	N

CON”	Abundance of conidia on secondary inoculum sources	N
HS	Susceptibility of the host plant	0/1b
IP	Incubation period	N
iP	Infectious period	N
LP	Latency period	N
Computed Variables		
CF	Correction factor for diseased sites	0 to 1

pi	Hourly progress of IP depending on temperature	N
pl	Hourly progress of LP depending on temperature	N
Rc	Basic infection rate corrected for the removal	N
External Variables

Driving Functions		
f1(P)	Equation for the effect of rainfall on conidial dispersal and deposition on host tissues	0 to 1

pdf:
For equation development and parameterization, the original
data for each response (independent) variable collected in different
experiments were rescaled between 0 and 1 by dividing each value
by the maximum value obtained in each experiment. This was
necessary because the experiments often used different
measurement units (e.g., conidia production has been expressed
as the average number of conidia per lesion, the number of conidia
per cm2 of a lesion, or the number of conidia per Petri dish in
laboratory experiments, depending on the paper), fungal species or
strains, host plants, etc. As an example of rescaling, Wilson et al.
(1990) reported that 4 and 24 h of continuous wetness during
infection on strawberry fruits by C. acutatum gave a disease
incidence of 2 and 100%, respectively; therefore, the rescaled data
were x4h = 2/100 = 0.2, and x24h = 100/100 = 1.
txt:
For equation development and parameterization, the original data for each response (independent) variable collected from different experiments were rescaled between 0 and 1. This was done by dividing each value by the maximum value obtained in each experiment. The need for rescaling arose because experiments often used different measurement units (e.g., conidia production expressed as the average number of conidia per lesion, the number of conidia per cm² of a lesion, or the number of conidia per Petri dish in laboratory experiments), fungal species or strains, host plants, etc.
For example, Wilson et al. (1990) reported that 4 and 24 hours of continuous wetness during infection on strawberry fruits by Colletotrichum acutatum resulted in disease incidences of 2% and 100%, respectively. Therefore, the rescaled data were x4h​=1002​=0.02 and x24h​=100100​=1.
q1: Why was rescaling necessary for the data used in equation development and parameterization?
q2: How was rescaling performed on the data collected from different experiments?
q3: What was the effect of 4 hours and 24 hours of continuous wetness on disease incidence as reported by Wilson et al. (1990)?
q4: Was the original data for response variables rescaled between 0 and 1?
q5: Did the rescaling process involve dividing each value by the maximum value obtained in each experiment?
q6: Did Wilson et al. (1990) report different disease incidences based on varying durations of continuous wetness?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Rescaled data were regressed against the influencing
environmental factors (the independent variables). Different
nonlinear regression models were fit, and the goodness-of-fit was
compared based on the Akaike’s Information Criterion (AIC); the
model providing the smallest AIC value was considered the most
correct (Brunham and Anderson, 2002). Equation parameters were
estimated using the function nls of the “stats” package of R software
(Team, R Core. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical
Computing. 2019; available at https://www.r-project.org/). For
parameter estimation, the data obtained from different
experiments were considered to be replicates; the data concerning
the different species belonging to the same clade were also
considered to be replicates.
txt: Rescaled data were regressed against the influencing environmental factors (the independent variables). Various nonlinear regression models were fitted, and the goodness-of-fit was assessed using the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC); the model with the smallest AIC value was considered the most accurate (Brunham and Anderson, 2002). Equation parameters were estimated using the nls function from the “stats” package in R software (Team, R Core. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. 2019; available at R Project). For parameter estimation, data from different experiments were treated as replicates, and data concerning different species within the same clade were also treated as replicates.
q1: How were the rescaled data analyzed in relation to environmental factors?
q2: What criterion was used to assess the goodness-of-fit for the regression models?
q3: How were data from different experiments and species treated for parameter estimation?
q4: Were various nonlinear regression models fitted to the rescaled data?
q5: Was the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) used to determine the accuracy of the models?
q6: Did the parameter estimation use the nls function from the “stats” package in R software?

FIGURE 1
The general life cycle of Colletotrichum spp. as considered in the model: the pathogen overwinters as mycelia or sclerotia in different plant residues,
which produce acervuli that in turn produce primary conidia. Infections caused by rain-dispersed conidia develop into lesions, which develop
acervuli that produce conidia for secondary infection cycles
txt:
FIGURE 1
The general life cycle of Colletotrichum spp. as considered in the model: The pathogen overwinters as mycelia or sclerotia in various plant residues. These residues produce acervuli, which generate primary conidia. Rain-dispersed conidia cause infections that develop into lesions. These lesions then form acervuli that produce conidia for secondary infection cycles.

Relational diagram of the processes leading to infection by Colletotrichum spp. Acronyms for state variables, rates, and parameters are listed in
Table 1. The core structure of the model is based on Zadoks (1971), with sites evolving from healthy (H), to latent (L), to visible (V), to infectious (I),
and finally to removed (R).

pdf:
The goodness-of-fit of equations to original (rescaled) data was
evaluated based on the adjusted R2, the concordance correlation
coefficient (CCC), the root mean square error (RMSE), and the
coefficient of residual mass (CRM) (Nash and Sutcliffe, 1970; Lin,
1989). The adjusted R2 was estimated by conducting a linear
regression between the observed values and the model predicted
values; the linear regression was conducted with the lm function of
the R “stats” package (Wickham, 2019). CCC is an indication of the
difference between the best fitting line and the perfect agreement
line (if CCC = 1, the agreement is perfect) (Lin, 1989). CCC was
obtained using the CCC function of the R “DescTools” package
(Signorell, 2020). RMSE, which represents the average distance of
real data from the fitted line (Nash and Sutcliffe, 1970), was
obtained using the rmse function of the R “modeler” package
(Wickham, 2019). CRM was calculated as described in Manstretta
and Rossi (2015); CRM is a measure of the tendency of the equation
to overestimate or underestimate the observed values (a negative
CRM indicates a tendency of the model toward overestimation;
Nash and Sutcliffe, 1970).
txt: The goodness-of-fit of equations to original (rescaled) data was evaluated based on the adjusted R2, the concordance correlation coefficient (CCC), the root mean square error (RMSE), and the coefficient of residual mass (CRM). The adjusted R2 was estimated by conducting a linear regression between the observed values and the model-predicted values using the lm function in R. CCC indicates the difference between the best-fitting line and the perfect agreement line (with CCC = 1 indicating perfect agreement) and was obtained using the CCC function in the R “DescTools” package. RMSE, representing the average distance of real data from the fitted line, was obtained using the rmse function in the R “modeler” package. CRM, which measures the tendency of the equation to overestimate or underestimate the observed values (with a negative CRM indicating a tendency toward overestimation), was calculated as described by Manstretta and Rossi.
q1: What metrics were used to evaluate the goodness-of-fit of the equations to the rescaled data?
q2: How was the adjusted R2 estimated for the model evaluation?
q3: What does the coefficient of residual mass (CRM) measure in the context of model fitting?
q4: Was the adjusted R2 estimated using the lm function in R?
q5: Did the concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) indicate perfect agreement with a value of 1?
q6: Is the root mean square error (RMSE) calculated using the rmse function in the R “modeler” package?

validation are summarized in Table 2.

pdf:
In the validation, we assumed that each epidemic is triggered by
a potential quantity of inoculum sources (represented by the
parameter k in equation [1]), which are responsible for the
production of primary conidia. The values of k used to initialize
the model are reported in Table 2. Because there was no
information in the literature for an exact calculation of the
parameter k for each epidemic, the values in Table 2 were
estimated empirically, i.e., we selected the value of k that resulted
in the closest agreement between predicted and observed disease
severities by running the model with varying values of k (in the rage
0 to 1).
txt: In the validation, we assumed that each epidemic is triggered by a potential quantity of inoculum sources (represented by the parameter k in equation [1]), which are responsible for the production of primary conidia. The values of k used to initialize the model are reported in Table 2. Since there was no literature-based method for calculating the parameter k precisely for each epidemic, the values in Table 2 were estimated empirically. Specifically, we selected the value of k that resulted in the closest agreement between predicted and observed disease severities by running the model with varying values of k (in the range of 0 to 1).

q2: What role does the parameter k play in the model used for evaluating epidemics?

q6: Was there a literature-based method available for calculating the parameter k precisely?

pdf:
For epidemics resulting from natural inoculum, the model was
operated starting from January 1. For epidemics triggered by the
experimental placement of diseased plants (see epidemics MA-14
and MA-15 in Table 2) or diseased fruit (see epidemics OH-90 and
OH-91 in Table 2) in the crop or near the crop, the model was
operated starting from the day in which the diseased plants or fruit
were placed in the field. For MA-14 and MA-15, the inoculum was
introduced by the sowing of Colletotrichum-infested white bean
seeds (along with non-infested seeds), which developed into plants
that produced the primary conidia; the model was operated from
June 2 at MA-14 and from June 9 at MA-1. For OH-90 and OH-91,
the inoculum was provided by Colletotrichum-diseased strawberry
fruits that experimenters placed within the crop, and the model was
operated from July 16 at OH-90 and from August 7 at OH-91.
txt: For epidemics resulting from natural inoculum, the model was started on January 1. For epidemics triggered by the experimental placement of diseased plants (e.g., MA-14 and MA-15 in Table 2) or diseased fruit (e.g., OH-90 and OH-91 in Table 2) in or near the crop, the model was started on the day the diseased plants or fruit were placed in the field. For MA-14 and MA-15, inoculum was introduced by sowing Colletotrichum-infested white bean seeds (along with non-infested seeds), which developed into plants that produced primary conidia; the model was started on June 2 for MA-14 and June 9 for MA-15. For OH-90 and OH-91, inoculum was provided by Colletotrichum-diseased strawberry fruits placed within the crop, and the model was started on July 16 for OH-90 and August 7 for OH-91.
q1: When was the model started for epidemics resulting from natural inoculum?
q2: How did the start dates for the model vary between epidemics triggered by diseased plants and those triggered by diseased fruit?
q3: What were the start dates for the model in the experiments MA-14, MA-15, OH-90, and OH-91?
q4: Was the model started on January 1 for epidemics resulting from natural inoculum?
q5: Did the start dates for the model differ based on whether the inoculum was introduced by diseased plants or fruit?
q6: Were Colletotrichum-infested white bean seeds used as inoculum in the MA-14 and MA-15 experiments?

pdf:
Predicted disease severities (i.e., sum of visible, infectious, and
removed sites) and observed disease severities were compared, and
CCC, RMSE, and CRM (Nash and Sutcliffe, 1970; Lin, 1989), which
were used to evaluate the goodness-of-fit of predicted vs. observed
data, were calculated by using R software as described before. The
different sources of predictive errors in the model were identified by
calculating Theil’s partial inequality (Theil’s U statistic) coefficients
(Smith and Rose, 1995; Fall et al., 2016); among these coefficients,
Ubias indicates the mean difference between observed and
predicted disease; Uslope indicates the deviations from the 1:1
line; and Uerror indicates the unexplained variance.
txt: Predicted disease severities (i.e., the sum of visible, infectious, and removed sites) and observed disease severities were compared. The concordance correlation coefficient (CCC), root mean square error (RMSE), and coefficient of residual mass (CRM) were calculated using R software as previously described to evaluate the goodness-of-fit between predicted and observed data. The different sources of predictive errors in the model were identified by calculating Theil’s partial inequality (Theil’s U statistic) coefficients. Among these coefficients, Ubias​ indicates the mean difference between observed and predicted disease, Uslope​ indicates deviations from the 1:1 line, and Uerror​ indicates the unexplained variance.
q1: What metrics were used to evaluate the goodness-of-fit between predicted and observed disease severities?
q2: How were predictive errors in the model identified?
q3: What do the coefficients Ubias, Uslope, and Uerror represent in the context of Theil’s U statistic?
q4: Was the concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) used to evaluate the goodness-of-fit?
q5: Did the evaluation include calculating Theil’s partial inequality coefficients?
q6: Is Ubias used to indicate the mean difference between observed and predicted disease?

pdf:
The relational diagram of the processes leading to epidemics of
Colletotrichum spp. is shown in Figure 2; abbreviations are
explained in Table 1. The model is based on host sites, each of
which belongs to one of the following mutually exclusive
conditions: (i) healthy (H); (ii) latent (L), i.e., without disease
symptoms; (iii) visible (V), i.e., with visible lesions; (iv) infectious
(I), i.e., with visible lesions producing spores; and (iv) removed (R),
i.e., older and non-sporulating lesions removed from the system.
The model does not incorporate host growth and senescence and
does not account for lesion expansion.
txt: The relational diagram of the processes leading to epidemics of Colletotrichum spp. is shown in Figure 2, with abbreviations explained in Table 1. The model is based on host sites, each of which falls into one of the following mutually exclusive conditions: (i) healthy (H); (ii) latent (L), i.e., without disease symptoms; (iii) visible (V), i.e., with visible lesions; (iv) infectious (I), i.e., with visible lesions producing spores; and (v) removed (R), i.e., older and non-sporulating lesions removed from the system. The model does not incorporate host growth and senescence, nor does it account for lesion expansion.
q1: What are the five mutually exclusive conditions that a host site can fall into according to the model?
q2: What aspects are not accounted for in the model described?
q3: Where can the explanations for the abbreviations used in the relational diagram be found?
q4: Does the model incorporate host growth and senescence?
q5: Are lesion expansions included in the model?
q6: Are the abbreviations for the conditions in the model explained in Table 1?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Sites become infected (i.e., they change from healthy sites into
latent sites) at an infection rate (INFR), which depends on the
abundance of conidia (CON), which can be both primary (CON’)
and secondary (CON”) conidia, and on their rain-dependent
dispersal rate (DISR). Primary conidia (produced on k
overwintered inoculum sources at a sporulation rate of SPOR’)
and secondary conidia (produced on lesions on the host plant at a
sporulation rate of SPOR”) accumulate in CON’ and CON”,
respectively; SPOR’ depends on temperature and wetness
duration, and SPOR” depends only on temperature because the
moisture required for sporulation is provided by the host plant.
Infection rate also depends on a correction factor (CF) for diseased
sites (i.e., stages L, V, I, and R), a multiplication factor (Rc)
representing the proportion of daughter lesions generated per
mother lesion that depends on temperature (RcT) and wetness
duration (RcWD). Infection occurs during the period of host
susceptibility (HS), which is regulated by the plant growth stage
and varies with the host. Latent sites become visible at the end of an
incubation period (IP), and visible sites become infectious at the
end of a latency period (LP), both of which depend on temperature;
the progress of IP and LP depends on an incubation (INCR) and
latency (LATR) rate, respectively. Infectious sites produce
secondary conidia (CON”) during the infectious period (iP)
and finally become removed at a removal rate (REMR)
(Figure 2, Table 1).
txt: Sites become infected (i.e., they change from healthy to latent) at an infection rate (INFR), which depends on the abundance of conidia (CON), including both primary (CON’) and secondary (CON”) conidia, and their rain-dependent dispersal rate (DISR). Primary conidia, produced on k overwintered inoculum sources at a sporulation rate of SPOR’, and secondary conidia, produced on lesions on the host plant at a sporulation rate of SPOR”, accumulate in CON’ and CON”, respectively. SPOR’ depends on temperature and wetness duration, while SPOR” depends only on temperature, as the moisture required for sporulation is provided by the host plant. The infection rate also depends on a correction factor (CF) for diseased sites (i.e., stages L, V, I, and R), and a multiplication factor (Rc) representing the proportion of daughter lesions generated per mother lesion, which depends on temperature (RcT) and wetness duration (RcWD). Infection occurs during the period of host susceptibility (HS), which is regulated by the plant growth stage and varies with the host. Latent sites become visible at the end of an incubation period (IP), and visible sites become infectious at the end of a latency period (LP), both of which depend on temperature; the progress of IP and LP is governed by an incubation rate (INCR) and latency rate (LATR), respectively. Infectious sites produce secondary conidia (CON”) during the infectious period (iP) and eventually become removed at a removal rate (REMR) (Figure 2, Table 1).
q1: How does the infection rate (INFR) depend on the abundance and dispersal of conidia?
q2: What factors influence the sporulation rates (SPOR' and SPOR”) for primary and secondary conidia?
q3: How do the incubation period (IP) and latency period (LP) affect the progression of sites from latent to visible and from visible to infectious?
q4: Does the infection rate (INFR) depend on both primary and secondary conidia?
q5: Are the sporulation rates (SPOR') and (SPOR”) influenced by temperature?
q6: Is the progress of the incubation period (IP) and latency period (LP) governed by temperature?

pdf:
At the beginning of model calculations, H = 1 (i.e., the whole
crop is healthy), and the model represents the flow from one state to
the following one as a proportion of the H, i.e., on a 0 to 1 scale. The
model works at hourly time steps.
txt: At the beginning of model calculations, H=1 (i.e., the whole crop is healthy), and the model represents the flow from one state to the following one as a proportion of H, on a scale from 0 to 1. The model operates at hourly time steps.
q1: How does the model track the health of the crop over time?
q2: What is the significance of the initial value of H in the model?
q3: How does the model handle transitions between states of crop health?
q4: Does the model start with the entire crop in a healthy state (H=1)?
q5: Does the model operate on an hourly time step?
q6: Is the proportion of crop health measured on a scale from 0 to 1?

pdf:
The model considers that the primary inoculum consists of
conidia (CON’) produced by k inoculum sources at a sporulation
rate (SPOR’) that depends on temperature and wet periods. On any
ith hour, the model calculates SPOR’ as follows:
SPOR 0 = k  f(T)  f 0 (WD) (1)
where the parameter k (ranging from 0 to 1) represents the
abundance of primary inoculum sources; f(T) accounts for the effect
of temperature (T, °C) on the production of conidia; f’(WD)
accounts for the effect of wetness duration (WD, hours) on the
production of conidia, and is calculated as the first derivative of
equation (3). Values of SPOR’ accumulate in CON’.
txt:
The model considers that the primary inoculum consists of conidia (CON’) produced by k inoculum sources at a sporulation rate (SPOR’) that depends on temperature and wet periods. On any ith hour, the model calculates SPOR’ as follows:
SPOR′=k⋅f(T)⋅f′(WD)
where the parameter k (ranging from 0 to 1) represents the abundance of primary inoculum sources; f(T) accounts for the effect of temperature (T, °C) on the production of conidia; f′(WD) accounts for the effect of wetness duration (WD, hours) on the production of conidia and is calculated as the first derivative of the relevant equation. Values of SPOR’ accumulate in CON’.
q1: How do temperature and wetness duration influence the sporulation rate in the model?
q2: What role does the parameter k play in determining the abundance of primary inoculum sources?
q3: How is the wetness duration function, f′(WD), incorporated into the model for calculating conidia production?
q4: Does the model calculate the sporulation rate based on temperature and wet periods?
q5: Is the parameter k used to represent the abundance of inoculum sources in the model?
q6: Does the sporulation rate accumulate in the primary inoculum (CON’) over time?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
The effect of temperature is calculated by a BETE equation
(Analytis, 1977) in the following form:
f(T) = (a  Teqb  (1 – Teq))c (2)
where a to c = equation parameters, and Teq = temperature
equivalent in the form Teq = (T–Tmin)/(Tmax–Tmin). For the
latter equation, T = hourly temperature, and Tmin and Tmax =
minimum and maximum temperature for sporulation, respectively.
Tmin, Tmax, and equation parameters of each clade were derived
from Salotti et al. (2022).
txt:
The effect of temperature is calculated by a BETE equation in the following form:
f(T)=(a⋅Teqb​⋅(1−Teq​)c
where a, b, and c are equation parameters, and Teq​ is the temperature equivalent given by Teq​=Tmax​−Tmin​T−Tmin​​. In this equation, T is the hourly temperature, and Tmin​ and Tmax​ are the minimum and maximum temperatures for sporulation, respectively.
q1: What is the role of the BETE equation in calculating the effect of temperature on sporulation?
q2: How do the parameters a, b, and c influence the temperature effect in the BETE equation?
q3: How does the temperature equivalent (Teq) relate to the minimum and maximum temperatures for sporulation?
q4: Does the BETE equation calculate the effect of temperature on sporulation?
q5: Is the temperature equivalent (Teq) calculated based on the minimum and maximum sporulation temperatures?
q6: Are the parameters a, b, and c used to adjust the temperature effect in the BETE equation?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Whenever there are ≥ 3 continuous hours of wetness, the effect
of moisture is calculated as follows (Leandro et al., 2001):
if WD ≥ 3, then
f(WD) = exp ( – 5:947  exp ( – 0:067  WD)) (3)
otherwise, f(WD) = 0.
where WD refers to leaf wetness duration (for the hostpathogen
combinations in which the inoculum source is located
in the aerial part of the plant, e.g., hanging mummies or bud scales)
or ground wetness duration (when the source lays on the ground,
e.g., plant debris, leaf litter, or mummies in soil). In the model, the
ground is considered wet in hours when rainfall (P) > 0 mm or
vapour pressure deficit (VPD) ≤ 4.5 hPa; otherwise, the ground is
considered dry (Rossi et al., 2008); VPD is calculated from
temperature and relative humidity (RH, in %) following Buck
(1981). To calculate WD, wet hours are accumulated until a dry
hour occurs; if wetness is restored within 16 h, WD continues to
increase until the next dry hour; if the dry period persists for > 16 h,
the calculation of WD stops.
txt:
Whenever there are ≥ 3 continuous hours of wetness, the effect of moisture is calculated as follows:
If WD≥3, then
f(WD)=exp(−5.947⋅exp(−0.067⋅WD))
otherwise, f(WD)=0.
where WD refers to leaf wetness duration (for host-pathogen combinations where the inoculum source is located in the aerial part of the plant, e.g., hanging mummies or bud scales) or ground wetness duration (when the source is on the ground, e.g., plant debris, leaf litter, or mummies in soil). In the model, the ground is considered wet in hours when rainfall (P) > 0 mm or vapor pressure deficit (VPD) ≤ 4.5 hPa; otherwise, the ground is considered dry. VPD is calculated from temperature and relative humidity (RH, in %) using the relevant formulas. To calculate WD, wet hours are accumulated until a dry hour occurs; if wetness is restored within 16 hours, WD continues to increase until the next dry hour; if the dry period persists for > 16 hours, the calculation of WD stops.
q1: How does the model determine when moisture starts affecting sporulation based on wetness duration (WD)?
q2: How does the model distinguish between leaf wetness and ground wetness for different inoculum sources?
q3: What happens to the wetness duration (WD) calculation when a dry period lasts for more than 16 hours?
q4: Does the model calculate the effect of wetness only if the wetness duration (WD) is 3 or more continuous hours?
q5: Is the ground considered wet when rainfall is greater than 0 mm or vapor pressure deficit (VPD) is less than or equal to 4.5 hPa?
q6: Does the wetness duration (WD) stop accumulating if the dry period persists for more than 16 hours?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Equation (3) was developed and parameterized by fitting the
data from Leandro et al. (2003) and Moral and Trapero (2012),
which refer to the acutatum clade. Estimates and standard errors of
equation parameters were 5.947 ± 1.329 and 0.067 ± 0.009, with
adjusted R2 = 0.910, CCC = 0.953, RMSE = 0.116, and CRM = 0.041.
Because no information was found in the literature on the effect of
moisture on sporulation for the other Colletotrichum clades,
equation (2) was used for all clades.
txt: Equation (3) was developed and parameterized using data specific to the acutatum clade. The estimates and standard errors of the equation parameters were 5.947 ± 1.329 and 0.067 ± 0.009. The model fit was assessed with an adjusted R2=0.910, CCC = 0.953, RMSE = 0.116, and CRM = 0.041. Due to the lack of information on the effect of moisture on sporulation for other Colletotrichum clades, Equation (2) was used for all clades.
q1: How was the model parameterized for the acutatum clade using specific data?
q2: What are the key performance metrics (e.g., adjusted R², CCC, RMSE) used to assess the model fit for the acutatum clade?
q3: Why was Equation (2) applied to other Colletotrichum clades despite being developed for the acutatum clade?
q4: Was Equation (3) developed specifically for the acutatum clade?
q5: Did the model achieve a high adjusted R² (0.910) when assessing the fit for the acutatum clade?
q6: Was Equation (2) used for all Colletotrichum clades due to a lack of data on moisture effects for other clades?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
The model considers that conidia that accumulated (CON’ for
primary conidia and CON” for secondary conidia) are dispersed to
host plants at a dispersal rate (DISR) that depends on precipitation
(P, in mm h–1) (Madden et al., 1996; Madden, 1997; Ntahimpera
et al., 1999; Guyot et al., 2005), with a minimum of 0.3 mm of rain
h–1 (Guyot et al., 2005). On any ith hour, the model calculates DISR
as follows:
if P ≥ 0.3, then
DISR = f1(P)  (1 – f2(P)) (4)
otherwise, DISR = 0.
where f1(P) accounts for the dispersal of conidia and their
deposition on host tissues, and f2(P) accounts for the washing-off of
conidia from host tissues due to precipitation intensity > 15 mm h-1
(Madden et al., 1996). f1(P) is calculated as follows:
f1(P) = exp ( – 2:5  exp( – 0:15  P)) (5)
if P > 15, then
f2(P) = 1 = (1 + 966:9  exp ( – 0:133  P)) (6)
otherwise, f2(P) = 0.
Equation (5) was developed and parameterized by fitting the data
of Madden et al. (1996) and Ntahimpera et al. (1999); estimates and
standard errors of equation parameters were 2.5 ± 0.84 and 0.15 ±
0.04, with adjusted R2 = 0.895, CCC = 0.953, RMSE = 0.099, and
CRM = 0.002. Equation (6) was developed and parameterized by
fitting the data of Madden et al. (1996); estimates and standard errors
of equation parameters were 966.9 ± 16.4 and 0.133 ± 0.003, with
adjusted R2 = 0.999, CCC = 0.999, RMSE = 0.004, and CRM = 0.002.
txt:
The model considers that conidia, accumulated as CON’ (primary conidia) and CON” (secondary conidia), are dispersed to host plants at a dispersal rate (DISR) that depends on precipitation (P, in mm h−1) with a minimum of 0.3 mm h−1. On any ith hour, the model calculates DISR as follows:
If P≥0.3, then
DISR=f1​(P)⋅(1−f2​(P))
otherwise, DISR=0.
where f1​(P) accounts for the dispersal of conidia and their deposition on host tissues, and f2​(P) accounts for the washing-off of conidia from host tissues due to precipitation intensity > 15 mm h−1.
f1​(P)=exp(−2.5⋅exp(−0.15⋅P))
If P>15, then
f2​(P)=1+966.9⋅exp(−0.133⋅P)1​
otherwise, f2​(P)=0.
q1: How does the model account for conidia dispersal and deposition based on precipitation intensity?
q2: What happens to the dispersal rate (DISR) when precipitation exceeds 15 mm h⁻¹?
q3: How does the model distinguish between dispersal and washing-off of conidia based on different precipitation intensities?
q4: Does the model set the dispersal rate (DISR) to zero if precipitation is below 0.3 mm h⁻¹?
q5: Is the dispersal rate (DISR) reduced when precipitation intensity exceeds 15 mm h⁻¹ due to conidia washing off?
q6: Is the function f1(P) used to model the deposition of conidia on host plants?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Conidia on the plant surface cause infection according to an
infection rate (INFR), which modulates the transfer of sites from
healthy to latent. INFR is calculated as follows:
INFR = HS  CON  DISR  Rc  CF (7)
where HS defines whether the host plant is susceptible (HS=1)
or not (HS=0); CON is the sum of CON’ and CON”; Rc is a basic
infection rate (Vanderplank, 1963); and CF is a correction factor for
diseased sites, and is calculated as follows:
CF = 1 – (D = (D + H)) (8)
where D is the sum of disease sites (D = L + V + I + R) and H
represents healthy sites.
txt: Conidia on the plant surface cause infection based on an infection rate (INFR), which modulates the transfer of sites from healthy to latent. INFR is calculated as follows:INFR=HS×CON×DISR×Rc×CFwhere HS defines whether the host plant is susceptible (HS=1) or not (HS=0); CON is the sum of CON' and CON''; Rc is a basic infection rate; and CF is a correction factor for diseased sites, calculated as follows: CF=1−(D+HD​) where D is the sum of disease sites (D = L + V + I + R) and H represents healthy sites.
q1: How does the infection rate (INFR) depend on the susceptibility of the host plant (HS)?
q2: What is the role of the correction factor (CF) in adjusting the infection rate for diseased sites?
q3: How are the conidia (CON’ and CON”) and dispersal rate (DISR) combined to influence the infection rate?
q4: Is the infection rate (INFR) zero if the host plant is not susceptible (HS=0)?
q5: Does the infection rate (INFR) account for both primary and secondary conidia (CON' and CON'')?
q6: Is the correction factor (CF) used to reduce the infection rate based on the number of diseased sites?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
The model accounts for changes in the susceptibility of the host
to infection by introducing the correction factor HS into equation
(7). HS is defined for each host depending on the species and
growth stage. For epidemics occurring on green tissues (leaves,
stems, etc.), the model assumes that the plants are susceptible from
the appearance of the organ to the end of the season (i.e., harvest for
herbaceous hosts; leaf fall for trees and bushes). For epidemics
occurring on fruits, HS strictly depends on the reproductive growth
stage of the host. For instance, grapevine berries are susceptible
from fruit set (BBCH 71; Lorenz et al., 1994) to harvest (BBCH 89;
Lorenz et al., 1994; Cosseboom and Hu, 2022), and olive drupes are
susceptible from the beginning of flowering (BBCH 61; Sanz-Cortés
et al., 2002) to harvest (BBCH 89; Sanz-Cortés et al., 2002; Moral
et al., 2009).
txt: The model accounts for changes in the susceptibility of the host to infection by introducing the correction factor HS into the INFR equation. HS is defined for each host depending on the species and growth stage. For epidemics occurring on green tissues (leaves, stems, etc.), the model assumes that the plants are susceptible from the appearance of the organ to the end of the season (e.g., harvest for herbaceous hosts or leaf fall for trees and bushes). For epidemics occurring on fruits, HS depends strictly on the reproductive growth stage of the host. For instance, grapevine berries are susceptible from fruit set to harvest, and olive drupes are susceptible from the beginning of flowering to harvest.
q1: How does the model account for the varying susceptibility (HS) of different host plants at different growth stages?
q2: How does the model handle susceptibility for fruit epidemics versus those occurring on green tissues?
q3: What specific growth stages define the susceptibility of grapevine berries and olive drupes in the model?
q4: Does the model consider host susceptibility (HS) to vary based on species and growth stage?
q5: Are grapevine berries susceptible from fruit set to harvest according to the model?
q6: Does the model assume that plants are susceptible to infection for green tissues from the appearance of the organ to the end of the season?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
In equation (7), Rc represents the proportion of daughter
lesions generated per mother lesion. Following Savary et al.
(2015), Rc depends on the optimum corrected basic infection rate
(RcOPT), which is the basic infection rate under optimum
environmental conditions on a susceptible host, and on modifiers
for the effect of temperature (RcT) and wetness duration (RcWD)
(Loomis and Adams, 1983) as follows:
Rc = RcOPT  RcT  RcWD (9)
The value of RcOPT is estimated following Sun and Zeng (1994)
for each Colletotrichum clade from disease progress curves as
follows:
RcOPT = r = (exp ( – r  p) – exp ( – r  (i + p)))
(10)
where p is the latency period under favorable conditions, i is the
infectious period under favorable conditions, and r is the apparent
infection rate (Vanderplank, 1963; Vanderplank, 1975) and is
calculated as follows:
r = ln(x2= x1) = (t2 – t1) (11)
where x1 and x2 are disease fractions on two successive dates (t1
and t2) at the early stage of the epidemic under conditions
conducive to the disease. To calculate r, published disease
progress curves in susceptible and unprotected crops were used;
the first two non-zero severity values (expressed on a 0 to 1 scale)
were spotted from these curves and used for the calculation. For
each clade, values of RcOPT, p, i, r, and references for the disease
progress curves used to calculate r are summarized in Table 3. The
values of p were defined based on studies on latency reported in
Table 4. Irrespective of the clade, the value of i was set at 28 days
based on King et al. (1997).
txt: In the equation for INFR, Rc represents the proportion of daughter lesions generated per mother lesion. Following Savary et al., Rc depends on the optimum corrected basic infection rate (RcOPT), which is the basic infection rate under optimum environmental conditions on a susceptible host, and on modifiers for the effect of temperature (RcT) and wetness duration (RcWD) as follows:Rc=RcOPT×RcT×RcWD The value of RcOPT is estimated for each Colletotrichum clade from disease progress curves using the formula: RcOPT=r=pexp(−r×p) −exp(−r×(i+p))​ where p is the latency period under favorable conditions, i is the infectious period under favorable conditions, and r is the apparent infection rate, calculated as: r=t2−t1ln(x2/x1)​ where x1 and x2 are disease fractions on two successive dates (t1 and t2) at the early stage of the epidemic under conducive conditions. To calculate r, published disease progress curves in susceptible and unprotected crops were used; the first two non-zero severity values (expressed on a 0 to 1 scale) were taken from these curves. For each clade, values of RcOPT, p, i, r, and references for the disease progress curves used are summarized in Table 3. The values of p were defined based on studies reported in Table 4. Irrespective of the clade, the value of i was set at 28 days.
q1: How is the optimum corrected basic infection rate (RcOPT) calculated for each Colletotrichum clade?
q2: What factors influence the proportion of daughter lesions (Rc) in the model?
q3: How are the parameters p, i, and r used to estimate RcOPT, and where are these values sourced from?
q4: Is the value of RcOPT estimated from disease progress curves using the provided formula?
q5: Does the model use published disease progress curves to calculate the apparent infection rate (r)?
q6: Is the infectious period (i) consistently set to 28 days for all Colletotrichum clades in the model?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
The modifier RcT accounts for the effect of air temperature on
infection, and is calculated as a BETE equation (Analytis, 1977) in
the form of equation (3); Tmin and Tmax for infection by conidia
and equation parameters were derived from Salotti et al. (2022) for
each clade.
txt: The modifier RcT accounts for the effect of air temperature on infection and is calculated using a BETE equation in the form of equation (3). Tmin and Tmax for infection by conidia and the equation parameters were derived from Salotti et al. for each clade.
q1: How does the modifier RcT incorporate the effect of air temperature on infection?
q2: What source provides the Tmin and Tmax values used in the calculation of RcT for each clade?
q3: How are the BETE equation parameters for RcT determined for different Colletotrichum clades?
q4: Is the effect of air temperature on infection accounted for by the RcT modifier?
q5: Are Tmin and Tmax values for calculating RcT derived from Salotti et al.?
q6: Does the model use the BETE equation to calculate the temperature effect modifier (RcT)?

host variety used to calculate the apparent infection rate (r).
Clade RcOPT r p i References

txt:
TABLE 3 Estimates of the optimum corrected basic infection rate (RcOPT) for eight Colletotrichum clades, latency period under favorable conditions for epidemics (p), infectious period under favorable conditions for epidemics (i), and publications reporting disease progress curves on a susceptible host variety used to calculate the apparent infection rate (r).

Clade	RcOPT	r	p	i	References
acutatum	0.4	0.16	5	28	Moral and Trapero (2012); McKay et al. (2014); Nekoduka et al. (2018)
coccodes	0.2	0.06	14	28	Dillard and Cobb (1997)
dematium	0.1	0.05	6	28	Yoshida et al. (2002)
destructivum	0.2	0.09	8	28	Chongo et al. (1999)
gloeosporioides	0.5	0.19	5	28	Waller (1972); Sweetmore et al. (1994); de Medeiros and Peruch (2012); Berner et al. (2014)
graminicola	0.3	0.13	7	28	Li and TeBeest (2009); Moore et al. (2010); Hempfling et al. (2015)
orbiculare	0.3	0.12	7	28	Ntahimpera et al. (1996); Kumar et al. (1999)
truncatum	0.1	0.02	5	28	Saha and Bera (2021)
RcOPT and r were estimated following Sun and Zeng. Values of p were defined based on studies on latency reported in Table 5. Irrespective of the clade, the value of i was set at 28 days based on King et al.
q1: What references are used to estimate RcOPT and the apparent infection rate (r) for each Colletotrichum clade?
q2: How is the latency period (p) defined for each Colletotrichum clade, and where can this information be found?
q3: Why is the infectious period (i) consistently set to 28 days for all clades?
q4: Are the estimates of RcOPT and the apparent infection rate (r) provided in Table 3 specific to each Colletotrichum clade?
q5: Is the value of the infectious period (i) uniformly set at 28 days across all Colletotrichum clades in the model?
q6: Do the values of latency period (p) for the clades come from studies reported in Table 5?

pdf:
The modifier RcWD accounts for the effect of leaf wetness
duration and is calculated on any ith hour as the first derivative of
equations (12) to (15), depending on the Colletotrichum clade.
txt: The modifier RcWD accounts for the effect of leaf wetness duration and is calculated for any ith hour as the first derivative of equations (12) to (15), depending on the Colletotrichum clade.
q1: How is the modifier RcWD calculated for each Colletotrichum clade?
q2: What role do equations (12) to (15) play in determining the effect of leaf wetness duration on RcWD?
q3: How does the calculation of RcWD vary depending on the Colletotrichum clade?
q4: Is RcWD calculated as the first derivative of specific equations for each Colletotrichum clade?
q5: Do equations (12) to (15) determine the effect of leaf wetness duration on the modifier RcWD?
q6: Does the calculation of RcWD depend on the Colletotrichum clade being modeled?

pdf:
For the acutatum clade, equation (12) was developed and
parametreized by fitting the data of Wilson et al. (1990);
Turechek et al. (2006); Gillett and Schilder (2009); Bertetti et al.
(2009); Diéguez-Uribeondo et al. (2011); Moral et al. (2012); Miles
et al. (2013); Greer et al. (2014); Rodriguez-Salamanca et al. (2015),
and Gonçalves et al. (2021). For the coccodes clade, equation (12)
was developed and parameterized by fitting the data of Andersen
and Walker (1985); Dillard (1989); Byrne et al. (1998); Hong and
Hwang (1998); Sanogo et al. (2003), and Rodriguez-Salamanca et al.
(2018):
f(WD) = exp ( – d  exp( – e  WD)) (12)
txt: For the acutatum clade, equation (12) was developed and parameterized by fitting the data from Wilson et al. (1990), Turechek et al. (2006), Gillett and Schilder (2009), Bertetti et al. (2009), Diéguez-Uribeondo et al. (2011), Moral et al. (2012), Miles et al. (2013), Greer et al. (2014), Rodríguez-Salamanca et al. (2015), and Gonçalves et al. (2021). For the coccodes clade, equation (12) was developed and parameterized by fitting the data from Andersen and Walker (1985), Dillard (1989), Byrne et al. (1998), Hong and Hwang (1998), Sanogo et al. (2003), and Rodríguez-Salamanca et al. (2018): f(WD)=exp(−d×exp(−e×WD))
q1: How was equation (12) parameterized for the acutatum clade and what sources contributed to this parameterization?
q2: What data were used to develop and parameterize equation (12) for the coccodes clade?
q3: How does the form of the function f(WD) used in equation (12) represent the effect of leaf wetness duration?
q4: Was equation (12) parameterized using data from multiple studies for the acutatum clade?
q5: Is the function f(WD) for the coccodes clade represented as exp(−d×exp(−e×WD))?
q6: Did the development of equation (12) for the coccodes clade involve data from Rodríguez-Salamanca et al. (2018)?

pdf:
For the acutatum clade, equation parameters and their standard
errors were d = 5.491 ± 0.232, e = 0.207 ± 0.042, with adjusted
R2 = 0.894, CCC = 0.949, RMSE = 0.115, and CRM = –0.027. For the
coccodes clade, equation parameters and their standard errors were
d = 7.343 ± 0.696, e = 0.164 ± 0.028, with adjusted R2 = 0.956, CCC
= 0.979, RMSE = 0.083, and CRM = 0.008.
txt: For the acutatum clade, the equation parameters and their standard errors were d=5.491±0.232 and e=0.207±0.042, with an adjusted R2=0.894, CCC = 0.949, RMSE = 0.115, and CRM = -0.027. For the coccodes clade, the equation parameters and their standard errors were d=7.343±0.696 and e=0.164±0.028, with an adjusted R2=0.956, CCC = 0.979, RMSE = 0.083, and CRM = 0.008.
q1: What are the key performance metrics for equation (12) in modeling leaf wetness duration for the acutatum and coccodes clades?

q3: What are the standard errors of the parameters d and e for the coccodes clade, and how do they compare to those for the acutatum clade?
q4: Did the parameterization of equation (12) for the acutatum clade achieve an adjusted R² of 0.894?
q5: Is the value of d in equation (12) for the coccodes clade significantly higher than for the acutatum clade?

For the coccodes clade, the equation parameters and their standard errors were d=7.343±0.696 and e=0.164±0.028, with an adjusted R2=0.956, CCC = 0.979, RMSE = 0.083, and CRM = 0.008.

pdf:
For the destructivum clade, equation (14) was developed and
parametreized by fitting the data of Chongo and Bernier (2000). For
the gloeosporioides clade, equation (14) was developed and
parameterized by fitting the data of Griffin et al. (1987);
Chakraborty et al. (1990); Yun and Park (1990); Hildebrand and
Jensen (1991); Pandey et al. (1997); Luo and TeBeest (1999);
Monteiro et al. (2009); Guyader et al. (2013); Wang et al. (2015);
Zhao et al. (2020), and Gonçalves et al. (2021). For the orbiculare
clade, equation (14) was developed and parametreized by fitting the
data of Auld et al. (1989); Monroe et al. (1997), and Dalla Pria et al.
(2003):
f(WD) = (1 – f  exp ( – g  WD))(1 = (1 − h)) (14)
txt: For the destructivum clade, equation (14) was developed and parameterized by fitting the data from Chongo and Bernier (2000). For the gloeosporioides clade, equation (14) was developed and parameterized by fitting the data from Griffin et al. (1987), Chakraborty et al. (1990), Yun and Park (1990), Hildebrand and Jensen (1991), Pandey et al. (1997), Luo and TeBeest (1999), Monteiro et al. (2009), Guyader et al. (2013), Wang et al. (2015), Zhao et al. (2020), and Gonçalves et al. (2021). For the orbiculare clade, equation (14) was developed and parameterized by fitting the data from Auld et al. (1989), Monroe et al. (1997), and Dalla Pria et al. (2003): f(WD)=(1−f×exp(−g×WD))×(1−1−h1​)
q1: How was equation (14) parameterized for the destructivum, gloeosporioides, and orbiculare clades?
q2: What data sources were used to develop and parameterize equation (14) for the gloeosporioides clade?
q3: How does the function f(WD) for the orbiculare clade incorporate the effects of leaf wetness duration?
q4: Was equation (14) parameterized using data from Chongo and Bernier (2000) for the destructivum clade?
q5: Did the development of equation (14) for the gloeosporioides clade involve data from Gonçalves et al. (2021)?
q6: Is the function f(WD) for the orbiculare clade represented as f(WD)=(1−f×exp(−g×WD))×(1−1−h1​)?

For destructivum clade, equation parameters and their standard
errors were f = 1.0 ± 0.274, g = 0.201 ± 0.157, and h = 0.635 ± 0.162,
with adjusted R2 = 0.885, CCC = 0.952, RMSE = 0.105, and
CRM = 0.024. For gloeosporioides clade, equation parameters and
their standard errors were f = 1.0 ± 0.167, g = 0.157 ± 0.039, and h =
0.8 ± 0.064, with adjusted R2 = 0.939, CCC = 0.968, RMSE = 0.098,
and CRM = 0.041. For orbiculare clade, equation parameters and
their standard errors were f = 0.9 ± 0.157, g = 0.168 ± 0.061, and h =
0.738 ± 0.083, with adjusted R2 = 0.904, CCC = 0.954, RMSE =
0.107, and CRM = 0.019.
txt: For the destructivum clade, the equation parameters and their standard errors were f=1.0±0.274, g=0.201±0.157, and h=0.635±0.162, with an adjusted R2=0.885, CCC = 0.952, RMSE = 0.105, and CRM = 0.024. For the gloeosporioides clade, the equation parameters and their standard errors were f=1.0±0.167, g=0.157±0.039, and h=0.8±0.064, with an adjusted R2=0.939, CCC = 0.968, RMSE = 0.098, and CRM = 0.041. For the orbiculare clade, the equation parameters and their standard errors were f=0.9±0.157, g=0.168±0.061, and h=0.738±0.083, with an adjusted R2=0.904, CCC = 0.954, RMSE = 0.107, and CRM = 0.019.

pdf:
No information on the effect of WD on infection was retrieved
for the graminicola clade. The model assumes that there is a
similarity between the infection pattern of the graminicola and
destructivum clades on the basis of the inter-clade variability studies
of Salotti et al. (2022); the model therefore calculates RcWD for the
graminicola clade by using equation (14) as parameterized for the
destructivum clade.
txt: No information on the effect of WD on infection was retrieved for the graminicola clade. The model assumes that the infection pattern of the graminicola clade is similar to that of the destructivum clade, based on inter-clade variability studies by Salotti et al. (2022). Therefore, RcWD for the graminicola clade is calculated using equation (14) as parameterized for the destructivum clade.
q1: How does the model handle the calculation of RcWD for the graminicola clade in the absence of specific data?
q2: What is the basis for using the parameterization of equation (14) for the destructivum clade to estimate RcWD for the graminicola clade?
q3: What do inter-clade variability studies by Salotti et al. (2022) suggest about the similarity in infection patterns between the graminicola and destructivum clades?
q4: Does the model use the parameterization of equation (14) for the destructivum clade to estimate RcWD for the graminicola clade?
q5: Was no specific information on the effect of WD on infection available for the graminicola clade?
q6: Is the assumption that the infection pattern of the graminicola clade is similar to that of the destructivum clade based on Salotti et al. (2022)?

pdf:
Sites flow from L to V at an incubation rate (INCR, which
depends on IP, i.e., the incubation period), and then from V to I
with a latency rate (LATR, which depends on LP, i.e., the latency
period). In each ith hour, the model calculates the hourly progress of
both IP and LP as a function of temperature by using the equation
of Magarey et al. (2005) in the following form:
pi = f(T) = IPmin (16)
TABLE 3 Estimates of the optimum corrected basic infection rate (RcOPT) for eight Colletotrichum clades, latency period under favorable conditions
for epidemics (p), infectious period under favorable conditions for epidemics (i), and publications reporting disease progress curves on a susceptible
host variety used to calculate the apparent infection rate (r).
Clade RcOPT r p i References
acutatum 0.4 0.16 5 28 Moral and Trapero (2012); McKay et al. (2014); Nekoduka et al. (2018)
coccodes 0.2 0.06 14 28 Dillard and Cobb (1997)
dematium 0.1 0.05 6 28 Yoshida et al. (2002)
destructivum 0.2 0.09 8 28 Chongo et al. (1999)
gloeosporioides 0.5 0.19 5 28 Waller (1972); Sweetmore et al. (1994); de Medeiros and Peruch (2012); Berner et al. (2014)
graminicola 0.3 0.13 7 28 Li and TeBeest (2009); Moore et al. (2010); Hempfling et al. (2015)
orbiculare 0.3 0.12 7 28 Ntahimpera et al. (1996); Kumar et al. (1999)
truncatum 0.1 0.02 5 28 Saha and Bera (2021)
RcOPT and r were estimated following Sun and Zeng (1994). Values of p were defined based on studies on latency reported in Table 5. Irrespective of the clade, the value of i was set at 28 days
based on King et al. (1997).
Salotti et al. 10.3389/fpls.2023.1069092
Frontiers in Plant Science 10 frontiersin.org
pl = f(T) = LPmin (17)
where pi and pl represent the progression of incubation and
latency, respectively, on any ith hour; IPmin and LPmin are the
shortest duration of incubation and latency at the optimum
temperature; and f(T) is the equation accounting for the influence
of temperature. f(T) is calculated as follows:
f(T) =
(T − Tmin)
(Topt − Tmin)
 (
(Tmax − T)
(Tmax − Topt)
)
(Tmax − Topt)
(Topt − Tmin)
(18)
where Tmin and Tmax = minimal and maximal temperature for
incubation or latency, respectively; when T< Tmin or T > Tmax, f
(T) = 0. Equation parameters are shown for each clade in Table 4.
No information was available in the literature for the dematium
clade; based on between-clade similarities in temperature
requirements shown by Salotti et al. (2022), parameters estimated
for the acutatum clade were applied to the dematium clade.
txt:
Sites flow from L to V at an incubation rate (INCR), which depends on IP (incubation period), and then from V to I with a latency rate (LATR), which depends on LP (latency period). In each ith hour, the model calculates the hourly progress of both IP and LP as a function of temperature using the equation of Magarey et al. (2005) in the following form: pi​=f(T)=IPmin​
li​=f(T)=LPmin​
where pi​ and li​ represent the progression of incubation and latency, respectively, on any ith hour; IPmin​ and LPmin​ are the shortest durations of incubation and latency at the optimum temperature; and f(T) accounts for the influence of temperature. f(T) is calculated as follows: f(T)=(Topt​−Tmin​)(T−Tmin​)​×(Tmax​−Topt​)(Tmax​−T)​ where Tmin​ and Tmax​ are the minimal and maximal temperatures for incubation or latency, respectively; when T<Tmin​ or T>Tmax​, f(T)=0. Equation parameters are shown for each clade in Table 4.
No information was available in the literature for the dematium clade. Based on the similarities in temperature requirements shown by Salotti et al. (2022), parameters estimated for the acutatum clade were applied to the dematium clade.
q1: How does the model calculate the hourly progress of incubation and latency periods, and what role does temperature play in this calculation?
q2: What is the basis for applying the acutatum clade’s parameters to the dematium clade in the absence of specific literature data?
q3: How are incubation and latency periods (IP and LP) influenced by temperature according to the equation of Magarey et al. (2005)?
q4: Is the hourly progress of incubation and latency periods calculated as a function of temperature in the model?
q5: Were the parameters estimated for the acutatum clade used for the dematium clade based on similarities in temperature requirements?
q6: Is the influence of temperature on incubation and latency periods calculated using the equation f(T) = (Topt - Tmin) / (T - Tmin) × (Tmax - Topt) / (Tmax - T) when T falls between Tmin and Tmax?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
The model accumulates the hourly progress of incubation and
latency beginning with the hour when the infection has occurred;
when the sum of hourly progress results in IP ≥1, INCR = 1 and sites
flow from L to V; when the sum of hourly progress results in LP ≥1,
LATR = 1 and sites flow from V to I.
txt: The model accumulates the hourly progress of incubation and latency starting from the hour when the infection occurs. When the sum of the hourly progress results in IP≥1, INCR=1 and sites flow from L to V. When the sum of the hourly progress results in LP≥1, LATR=1 and sites flow from V to I.
q1: How does the model determine when sites flow from L to V and from V to I in terms of incubation and latency progress?
q2: What conditions must be met for INCR and LATR to equal 1 and allow site transitions in the model?
q3: How does the model handle the accumulation of hourly progress for incubation and latency?
q4: Does the model start accumulating the hourly progress of incubation and latency from the hour when infection occurs?
q5: Is INCR set to 1 when the sum of hourly progress results in IP ≥ 1?
q6: Does the model require LP ≥ 1 for LATR to be set to 1 and sites to flow from V to I?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Infectious sites (I) continue producing conidia for an infection
period (iP), and then flow from I to R according to a removal rate
(REMR). The model assumes that fertile lesions continue to
produce conidia for the entire epidemic, so that REMR = 0. The I
sites produce secondary conidia at a sporulation rate (SPOR”) that
depends on temperature according to equation (2); the secondary
conidia accumulate in CON”. Based on King et al. (1997), the model
assumes that the pathogen obtains sufficient moisture from the host
to produce conidia and does not require free surface moisture
for sporulation.
txt: Infectious sites (I) continue producing conidia throughout the infection period (iP), and then transition from I to R according to a removal rate (REMR). The model assumes that fertile lesions continue to produce conidia for the entire epidemic, so REMR = 0. The I sites produce secondary conidia at a sporulation rate (SPOR) that depends on temperature according to equation (2); the secondary conidia accumulate in CON. The model assumes that the pathogen obtains sufficient moisture from the host to produce conidia and does not require free surface moisture for sporulation.
q1: How does the model handle the production of conidia by infectious sites (I) during the infection period?
q2: What is the assumption regarding the removal rate (REMR) for infectious sites in the model?
q3: How is the sporulation rate (SPOR) for secondary conidia calculated, and what factors influence it?
q4: Does the model assume that infectious sites (I) produce conidia throughout the entire infection period (iP)?
q5: Is REMR set to 0 in the model for infectious sites, indicating that they continue producing conidia throughout the epidemic?
q6: Does the model assume that sufficient moisture is obtained from the host for conidia production, without requiring free surface moisture?

pdf:
The contribution of secondary inoculum to the progress of the
epidemic has been proved for some host-pathogen combinations
(Fitzell and Peak, 1984; Smith, 2008; Everett et al., 2018), but not for
others. In olive orchards, for instance, mummies are the main
source of inoculum all season long, and the contribution of conidia
produced within fruit lesions is negligible (Moral et al., 2012); when
lesions do not contribute to the progress of the epidemic, CON” = 0.
txt: The contribution of secondary inoculum to the progress of the epidemic has been demonstrated for some host-pathogen combinations, but not for others. In olive orchards, for instance, mummies are the main source of inoculum throughout the season, and the contribution of conidia produced within fruit lesions is negligible. When lesions do not contribute to the progress of the epidemic, CON = 0.
q1: Why are mummies considered the main source of inoculum in olive orchards?
q2: How does the contribution of secondary inoculum vary between different host-pathogen combinations?
q3: What role do fruit lesions play in the progress of epidemics in olive orchards?
q4: Can the contribution of secondary inoculum be significant in some host-pathogen combinations?
q5: Are mummies the primary source of inoculum in olive orchards throughout the season?
q6: Does CON = 0 when lesions do not contribute to the progress of the epidemic?

pdf:
The model calculates disease severity (DS) during the epidemic
as the sum of the proportion of sites with disease symptoms, i.e.,
visible, infectious, and removed sites, as follows:
DS = V + I + R (19)
txt: The model calculates disease severity (DS) during the epidemic as the sum of the proportion of sites with disease symptoms, which includes visible, infectious, and removed sites, as follows: DS = V + I + R.
q1: How is disease severity (DS) calculated during an epidemic?
q2: What factors contribute to the overall disease severity in the model?
q3: Why are visible, infectious, and removed sites included in the disease severity calculation?
q4: Does the model include removed sites in calculating disease severity?
q5: Is the sum of visible, infectious, and removed sites used to determine disease severity?
q6: Can disease severity (DS) be affected by the number of infectious sites during an epidemic?
