pdf:
The model was validated for the acutatum, dematium,
gloeosporioides, graminicola, and orbiculare clades. The model’s
ability to predict disease development throughout the season was
evaluated for 17 epidemics (Table 2) recorded between 1980 and 2019
in Italy, the USA, Canada, and Japan on six hosts, i.e., olive,
strawberry, mulberry, grape, bluegrass, and dry bean. In this
manuscript, only a few epidemics are described in detail; details on
the remaining epidemics are provided in the Supplementarymaterial.
txt: The model was validated for the acutatum, dematium, gloeosporioides, graminicola, and orbiculare clades. The model’s ability to predict disease development throughout the season was evaluated for 17 epidemics recorded between 1980 and 2019 in Italy, the USA, Canada, and Japan, covering six hosts: olive, strawberry, mulberry, grape, bluegrass, and dry bean. This manuscript describes only a few epidemics in detail; details on the remaining epidemics are provided in the Supplementary Material.
q1: How was the model validated across different clades and hosts?
q2: Why does the manuscript provide detailed descriptions of only a few epidemics?
q3: What geographical regions were considered when evaluating the model's predictive ability?
q4: Was the model evaluated for its ability to predict disease development in multiple countries, including Italy and the USA?
q5: Does the manuscript include information on six different host plants
q6: Are details for some of the epidemics covered in the Supplementary Material?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
For the acutatum clade, model validation was performed for 4
epidemics on drupes recorded in naturally infested olive orchards in
South Italy, and 2 epidemics in artificially infested strawberry fields
in Ohio, USA; in the latter case, researchers provided the inoculum
by placing affected fruit between the strawberry rows. Epidemics on
olive developed between August and December, with final disease
incidence on drupes ranging from 7% to 26% (Table 5); CCC
between predicted and observed disease ranged from 0.789 to 0.953,
and RMSE ranged from 0.022 to 0.047. Epidemics in the two
strawberry fields occurred in July to August in OH-90, and in
August to September in OH-91, with final disease incidences of 28%
and 45%, respectively; in the comparison of predicted and observed
disease, CCC = 0.874 and 0.898, and RMSE = 0.055 and 0.061,
respectively (Table 5). Across all 6 epidemics of the acutatum clade,
CCC = 0.895, RMSE = 0.048, and CRM = −0.099 (the latter
indicated a slight tendency of the model toward overestimation).
An example of model output for acutatum clade is shown in
Figure 3 for IT-17A. In the olive orchard, flowering (BBCH 61,
i.e., the beginning of host susceptibility) began on May 15, and
harvest occurred at the end of December. From mid-May to the end
of December, the average daily temperature was 20.3°C (min =
4.5°C, max = 31.1°C), with an average RH = 71%, a total of 365 mm
of rain on 69 rainy days, and a total of 1617 h of leaf wetness
(Figure 3A). Rains were frequent and intense between September
and November, with prolonged wetness periods that led to the
prediction of repeated infection periods (Figure 3B). Disease
outbreak occurred on August 17 (disease incidence 2%) and was
followed by a regular disease increase that resulted in a final disease
incidence of 18%, which was correctly predicted by the model
(Figure 3B). For IT-17A, CCC = 0.953, RMSE = 0.022, and CRM =
0.017 (the latter indicated no substantial underestimation).
txt: For the acutatum clade, model validation was performed for 4 epidemics on drupes recorded in naturally infested olive orchards in South Italy, and 2 epidemics in artificially infested strawberry fields in Ohio, USA. In the latter case, researchers provided the inoculum by placing affected fruit between the strawberry rows. Epidemics on olive developed between August and December, with final disease incidence on drupes ranging from 7% to 26%; the concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) between predicted and observed disease ranged from 0.789 to 0.953, and the root mean square error (RMSE) ranged from 0.022 to 0.047. In the two strawberry fields, epidemics occurred from July to August in OH-90 and from August to September in OH-91, with final disease incidences of 28% and 45%, respectively. For these fields, CCC values were 0.874 and 0.898, and RMSE values were 0.055 and 0.061, respectively. Across all 6 epidemics of the acutatum clade, CCC was 0.895, RMSE was 0.048, and the concordance correlation mean (CRM) was -0.099, indicating a slight tendency of the model toward overestimation. An example of model output for the acutatum clade is shown in Figure 3 for IT-17A. In the olive orchard, flowering (BBCH 61, the beginning of host susceptibility) began on May 15, and harvest occurred at the end of December. From mid-May to the end of December, the average daily temperature was 20.3°C (min = 4.5°C, max = 31.1°C), with an average relative humidity of 71%, a total of 365 mm of rain on 69 rainy days, and a total of 1617 hours of leaf wetness. Rains were frequent and intense between September and November, with prolonged wetness periods that led to the prediction of repeated infection periods. Disease outbreak occurred on August 17 (disease incidence 2%) and was followed by a regular disease increase, resulting in a final disease incidence of 18%, which was correctly predicted by the model. For IT-17A, CCC was 0.953, RMSE was 0.022, and CRM was 0.017, indicating no substantial underestimation.
q1: How did the model perform in predicting disease incidence for epidemics in olive orchards and strawberry fields?
q2: What environmental factors contributed to the disease outbreak in the olive orchard in IT-17A?
q3: Why does the concordance correlation mean (CRM) suggest a slight overestimation of the model's predictions across the acutatum clade epidemics?
q4: Were the final disease incidences in the strawberry fields higher than in the olive orchards for the acutatum clade epidemics?
q5: Did the model show high accuracy in predicting disease development, as indicated by the CCC and RMSE values?
q6: Was the model’s performance slightly biased toward overestimation, according to the CRM across the acutatum clade epidemics?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
For the dematium clade, 3 disease progress curves on mulberry
in Japan were used to validate the model (Table 2). Epidemics
developed on mulberry leaves between August and November, with
final disease incidence ranging from 13% to 37%. In the comparison
of observed and predicted disease progress curves, CCC ranged
from 0.862 to 0.991 and RMSE ranged from 0.014 to 0.055; across
all three epidemics, CCC = 0.95, RMSE = 0.036, and CRM = −0.023
(the latter indicated a slight tendency toward overestimation
(Table 5). An example of model output for the dematium clade is
shown in Figure 4 for JA-94. Disease assessment began in June after
the summer-pruning of mulberry trees, and ended in November.
During this period, the average daily temperature was 21.9°C (min
= 7.0°C, max = 30.1°C), with an average RH = 82%, a total of 625.5
mm of rain on 61 rainy days, and a total of 1688 h of leaf wetness
(Figure 4A). Regularly distributed rainfall ensured that the epidemic
would progress during the season, starting from the time of disease
onset in August until November when a sharp increase in disease
led to a 37% disease incidence (Figure 4B). The model correctly
predicted this dynamic; across all three epidemics, CCC = 0.991,
RMSE = 0.02, and CRM = 0.078.
txt: For the dematium clade, 3 disease progress curves on mulberry in Japan were used to validate the model. Epidemics developed on mulberry leaves between August and November, with final disease incidence ranging from 13% to 37%. In the comparison of observed and predicted disease progress curves, the concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) ranged from 0.862 to 0.991 and the root mean square error (RMSE) ranged from 0.014 to 0.055. Across all three epidemics, CCC was 0.95, RMSE was 0.036, and the concordance correlation mean (CRM) was -0.023, indicating a slight tendency toward overestimation. An example of model output for the dematium clade is shown in Figure 4 for JA-94. Disease assessment began in June after the summer pruning of mulberry trees and ended in November. During this period, the average daily temperature was 21.9°C (min = 7.0°C, max = 30.1°C), with an average relative humidity of 82%, a total of 625.5 mm of rain on 61 rainy days, and a total of 1688 hours of leaf wetness. Regularly distributed rainfall ensured that the epidemic progressed during the season, starting from the time of disease onset in August until November, when a sharp increase in disease led to a 37% disease incidence. The model correctly predicted this dynamic; across all three epidemics, CCC was 0.991, RMSE was 0.02, and CRM was 0.078.
q1: How did the model perform in predicting disease progression for mulberry epidemics in Japan?
q2: What climatic factors contributed to the disease development on mulberry leaves in the dematium clade epidemics?
q3: Why does the CRM value suggest a slight overestimation in the model’s predictions for the dematium clade?
q4: Were the final disease incidences in the mulberry epidemics in Japan correctly predicted by the model?
q5: Did regularly distributed rainfall contribute to the steady progression of the mulberry epidemic in the dematium clade?
q6: Did the model perform with a high level of accuracy, as indicated by the CCC and RMSE values for the dematium clade?

pdf:
Model validation for the gloeosporioides clade was performed
for 3 epidemics on grapevines in North Carolina, USA (Table 2).
These epidemics developed between June and September, with final
disease incidence on berries ranging from 24% to 54%. A small
average distance of real data from the fitted line was observed for
the three epidemics, with RMSE ranging from 0.012 to 0.101.
Concordance between observed and predicted values for NC-80
and NC-82 gave CCC = 0.843 and 0.993, respectively. The NC-81
epidemic is reported in Figure 5. Berries were susceptible between
June 9 (BBCH 71, i.e., fruit set) and October 1 (BBCH 89, i.e.,
berries ripe for harvest). During this period, the average daily
temperature was 24.6°C (min = 14.5°C, max = 29.8°C), with an
average RH = 77%, a total of 216.1 mm of rain on 31 rainy days, and
a total of 746 h of leaf wetness (Figure 5A). Disease incidence on
berries was assessed on September 17 and 24, and on October 1,
with a final disease incidence of 24%. Contrary to observations, the
model anticipated by some days the observed increase in disease at
the end of the season (Figure 5B), and CCC = 0.497, probably
because of an imprecise estimation of the incubation length in
relation to the berry growth stage at the time of infection. In the
comparison of predicted and observed disease progress curves for
the 3 epidemics of the gloeosporioides clade, CCC = 0.910, RMSE =
0.068, and CRM = −0.109 (the latter indicated a slight tendency of
the model toward overestimation).
txt: Model validation for the gloeosporioides clade was performed for 3 epidemics on grapevines in North Carolina, USA. These epidemics developed between June and September, with final disease incidence on berries ranging from 24% to 54%. A small average distance of real data from the fitted line was observed for the three epidemics, with root mean square error (RMSE) ranging from 0.012 to 0.101. Concordance between observed and predicted values for NC-80 and NC-82 was indicated by concordance correlation coefficients (CCC) of 0.843 and 0.993, respectively. The NC-81 epidemic is reported in Figure 5. Berries were susceptible between June 9 (BBCH 71, fruit set) and October 1 (BBCH 89, berries ripe for harvest). During this period, the average daily temperature was 24.6°C (min = 14.5°C, max = 29.8°C), with an average relative humidity of 77%, a total of 216.1 mm of rain on 31 rainy days, and a total of 746 hours of leaf wetness. Disease incidence on berries was assessed on September 17, September 24, and October 1, with a final disease incidence of 24%. Contrary to observations, the model anticipated the increase in disease at the end of the season by a few days (Figure 5B), with CCC = 0.497, probably due to imprecise estimation of the incubation length relative to the berry growth stage at the time of infection. In the comparison of predicted and observed disease progress curves for the 3 epidemics of the gloeosporioides clade, CCC was 0.910, RMSE was 0.068, and the concordance correlation mean (CRM) was -0.109, indicating a slight tendency of the model toward overestimation.
q1: How did the model perform in predicting disease progression for grapevine epidemics in North Carolina?
q2: What factors might have contributed to the model’s early prediction of disease increase in the NC-81 epidemic?
q3: Why does the CRM suggest a slight overestimation of disease incidence in the gloeosporioides clade epidemics?
q4: Did the gloeosporioides clade model slightly overestimate disease progression, as indicated by the CRM value?
q5: Was disease incidence on grape berries assessed multiple times in the NC-81 epidemic?
q6: Did the model's predicted and observed disease progression show high concordance for two of the three epidemics?

pdf:
Model validation for the graminicola clade was performed for 3
bluegrass epidemics in New Jersey, USA, in 2009 and 2010, and
Michigan, USA, in 1982 (Table 2). The epidemics were observed
between May and August, with final disease severity ranging from
16% to 41%. In the comparison of model output and observed data,
CCC ranged from 0.947 to 0.997, RMSE ranged from 0.006 to 0.037
(Table 5), and CRM ranged from −0.15 to 0.19 (the latter indicated
a slight over- or underestimation of observed disease progress
curves, depending on the epidemic). Across all three epidemics of
the graminicola clade, CCC = 0.973, RMSE = 0.026, and CRM =
0.018 (the latter indicated a slight tendency of the model toward
underestimation). An example of model output for the graminicola
clade is shown in Figure 6. At MI-82, the bluegrass field was
inspected at 10-day intervals for anthracnose symptoms from the
beginning of May to the end of July. During this period, the average
daily temperature was 18.9°C (min = 10.6°C, max = 26.7°C), with an
average RH = 75%, a total of 202.6 mm of rain on 31 rainy days, and
a total of 651 h of leaf wetness (Figure 6A). The disease outbreak at
MI-82 occurred on July 7 (disease severity 3%), and the disease
increased regularly to a final disease incidence of 25%, which was
correctly predicted by the model (Figure 6B), with CCC = 0.997,
RMSE = 0.006, and CRM = 0.050 (the latter indicated a slight
tendency of the model toward underestimation).
txt: Model validation for the graminicola clade was performed for 3 bluegrass epidemics in New Jersey, USA, in 2009 and 2010, and in Michigan, USA, in 1982. The epidemics were observed between May and August, with final disease severity ranging from 16% to 41%. In the comparison of model output and observed data, the concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) ranged from 0.947 to 0.997, and the root mean square error (RMSE) ranged from 0.006 to 0.037. The concordance correlation mean (CRM) ranged from -0.15 to 0.19, indicating a slight over- or underestimation of observed disease progress curves, depending on the epidemic. Across all three epidemics of the graminicola clade, CCC was 0.973, RMSE was 0.026, and CRM was 0.018, indicating a slight tendency of the model toward underestimation. An example of model output for the graminicola clade is shown in Figure 6. At MI-82, the bluegrass field was inspected at 10-day intervals for anthracnose symptoms from the beginning of May to the end of July. During this period, the average daily temperature was 18.9°C (min = 10.6°C, max = 26.7°C), with an average relative humidity of 75%, a total of 202.6 mm of rain on 31 rainy days, and a total of 651 hours of leaf wetness. The disease outbreak at MI-82 occurred on July 7 (disease severity 3%), and the disease increased regularly to a final disease incidence of 25%, which was correctly predicted by the model, with CCC = 0.997, RMSE = 0.006, and CRM = 0.050, indicating a slight tendency of the model toward underestimation.
q1: How did the model perform in predicting disease severity for bluegrass epidemics in the graminicola clade?
q2: What environmental factors influenced disease progression in the MI-82 bluegrass epidemic?
q3: Why does the CRM indicate a slight underestimation of disease severity across the graminicola clade epidemics?
q4: Did the model predict the final disease severity in the MI-82 bluegrass epidemic with high accuracy?
q5: Was there a slight tendency toward underestimation of disease severity in the graminicola clade, as indicated by the overall CRM value?
q6: Were the RMSE values for the graminicola clade epidemics generally low, indicating a small average error in the model's predictions?

pdf:
To validate the model for the orbiculare clade, 2 epidemics that
occurred on white bean in Manitoba, Canada were used (Table 2).
Crops were scouted for disease from the end of June, when artificial
inoculum was introduced into the field, to mid-August. At MA-14,
the disease was recorded only in traces (<1%), so that proper model
evaluation was impossible. At MA-15 (Figure 7), the average daily
temperature was 18.9°C (min = 10.6°C, max = 26.7°C), with an
average RH = 75%, a total of 202.6 mm of rain on 31 rainy days, and
a total of 651 h of leaf wetness (Figure 7A). Regularly distributed
rainfalls and prolonged wet periods ensured a progressive
development of the epidemic from the first third of July until
mid-August, with a final disease severity of 20%. The model slightly
overestimated the disease dynamics in the second half of July
(Figure 7B), with CCC = 0.896, RMSE = 0.035, and CRM = 0.19
(the latter indicated a tendency of the model toward
underestimation). Across both orbiculare clade epidemics, CCC =
0.931, RMSE = 0.027, and CRM = 0.158 (the latter indicated a
tendency of the model toward underestimation).
txt: To validate the model for the orbiculare clade, 2 epidemics that occurred on white bean in Manitoba, Canada, were used. Crops were scouted for disease from the end of June, when artificial inoculum was introduced into the field, to mid-August. At MA-14, the disease was recorded only in traces (<1%), making proper model evaluation impossible. At MA-15 (Figure 7), the average daily temperature was 18.9°C (min = 10.6°C, max = 26.7°C), with an average relative humidity of 75%, a total of 202.6 mm of rain on 31 rainy days, and a total of 651 hours of leaf wetness. Regularly distributed rainfall and prolonged wet periods ensured a progressive development of the epidemic from the first third of July until mid-August, with a final disease severity of 20%. The model slightly overestimated the disease dynamics in the second half of July (Figure 7B), with a concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) of 0.896, root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.035, and a concordance correlation mean (CRM) of 0.19, indicating a tendency of the model toward underestimation. Across both orbiculare clade epidemics, CCC was 0.931, RMSE was 0.027, and CRM was 0.158, also indicating a tendency of the model toward underestimation.
q1: How did the model perform in predicting disease progression for white bean epidemics in the orbiculare clade?
q2: Why was it impossible to properly evaluate the model for the MA-14 epidemic?
q3: What environmental conditions contributed to the disease progression at MA-15 in the orbiculare clade?
q4: Did the model slightly overestimate disease dynamics during the second half of July for the MA-15 epidemic?
q5: Was the final disease severity at MA-15 correctly predicted by the model within a small margin of error?
q6: Did the model show a tendency toward underestimation across both orbiculare clade epidemics, as indicated by the CRM values?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
In an overall comparison of predicted versus observed values for
the 17 epidemics listed in Table 5, CCC = 0.928 and RMSE = 0.044;
the similarity between the observed data and the fitted line indicated
that the model accurately represented the mechanisms leading to
Colletotrichum epidemics on different host plants. The model,
however, showed a slight tendency toward overestimation (CRM
= −0.052) when evaluated for the epidemics on different host plants.
The variance explained by the relationship of observed versus
predicted data was R2 = 0.866; based on Theils’ statistic, the
deviation from the unexplained variance was Uerror = 86%,
whereas the percentage of error associated with model bias and
deviation from the 1:1 line was Ubias = 2% and Uslope =
12%, respectively.
txt: In an overall comparison of predicted versus observed values for the 17 epidemics listed in Table 5, the concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) was 0.928 and the root mean square error (RMSE) was 0.044. The similarity between the observed data and the fitted line indicated that the model accurately represented the mechanisms leading to Colletotrichum epidemics on different host plants. However, the model showed a slight tendency toward overestimation, with a concordance correlation mean (CRM) of -0.052 when evaluated across the different host plants. The variance explained by the relationship between observed and predicted data was R² = 0.866. Based on Theil’s statistic, the deviation from the unexplained variance was Uerror = 86%, with the percentage of error associated with model bias (Ubias) being 2% and deviation from the 1:1 line (Uslope) being 12%.
q1: How well did the model represent the mechanisms leading to Colletotrichum epidemics across different host plants?
q2: What factors contributed to the model's slight tendency toward overestimation, as indicated by the CRM value?
q3: How did the model's performance compare in terms of variance explained and deviation from the 1:1 line?
q4: Was the overall concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) for the model higher than 0.9?
q5: Did the model show a slight tendency toward overestimation when evaluated across all 17 epidemics?
q6: Was the variance explained by the model (R²) 0.866, indicating a high level of explained variance?

pdf:
In this research, we developed a general, weather-driven,
mechanistic model for the prediction of anthracnose diseases
caused by Colletotrichum spp. on aerial plant parts of different
hosts in the field. Previous models for anthracnose diseases were
species- and crop-specific and considered only one component of
the pathogen life cycle, mainly conidial infection (Dodd et al., 1991;
Park et al., 1992; Monroe et al., 1997; Moral et al., 2012; Singh,
2020). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that this
kind of model has been developed, calibrated for different clades
and host plants, and evaluated to make predictions of anthracnose
patterns on multiple crops.
txt: In this research, we developed a general, weather-driven, mechanistic model for predicting anthracnose diseases caused by Colletotrichum spp. on aerial plant parts of various hosts in the field. Previous models for anthracnose diseases were species- and crop-specific, focusing primarily on conidial infection and considering only one component of the pathogen life cycle. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first model of its kind that has been developed, calibrated for different clades and host plants, and evaluated to predict anthracnose patterns across multiple crops.
q1: How does the new model differ from previous models for predicting anthracnose diseases caused by Colletotrichum spp.?
q2: What is the significance of developing a general, weather-driven model for predicting anthracnose diseases across multiple crops?
q3: What components of the pathogen life cycle does the new model consider that previous models did not?
q4: Is this model the first of its kind to be developed and calibrated for different clades and host plants?
q5: Did previous models for anthracnose diseases primarily focus on conidial infection?
q6: Does the new model consider multiple components of the pathogen life cycle?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Our model is “general” in that it has one conceptual structure
that incorporates the key epidemiological components of
anthracnose diseases. Even though Colletotrichum spp. exhibit
numerous lifestyles–which have been categorized as necrotrophic,
hemibiotrophic, latent or quiescent, and endophytic, with
hemibiotrophic being the most common (Peres et al., 2005; De
Silva et al., 2017)–all of the species have a necrotrophic stage
(Prusky et al., 2013), except for the few species that live entirely
as endophytes (e.g., some species in the gloeosporioides clade on
Salacia and Camellia; Bhagya et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2015). The
timing of the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy depends on the
host, its growth stage, and environmental conditions (Wharton
et al., 2001; Peres et al., 2005), as well as the phylogenetic clade (De
Silva et al., 2017). For instance, graminicola and destructivum
clades have a short biotrophic period, while acutatum and
gloeosporioides clades have a quiescent lifestyle on some fruit trees
like almond and guava (De Silva et al., 2017). Our model accounts
for the common attributes of the Colletotrichum lifestyles in terms
of (i) a reproductive (asexual) stage, which occurs on the host plant
or in plant debris; (ii) infection caused by conidia; (iii) an
asymptomatic (biotrophic) stage that can be short or extended
(depending on an incubation period); (iv) a necrotrophic stage in
which host cells are invaded and killed, with the appearance of
symptoms (lesions in our model); and (v) a sporulation stage, i.e.,
the production of secondary inoculum on lesions.
txt: Our model is "general" in that it has a unified conceptual structure incorporating the key epidemiological components of anthracnose diseases. Although Colletotrichum spp. exhibit various lifestyles—categorized as necrotrophic, hemibiotrophic, latent or quiescent, and endophytic, with hemibiotrophic being the most common—all species possess a necrotrophic stage, except for a few that live entirely as endophytes (e.g., some species in the gloeosporioides clade on Salacia and Camellia). The timing of the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy depends on the host, its growth stage, environmental conditions, and the phylogenetic clade. For instance, the graminicola and destructivum clades have a short biotrophic period, while the acutatum and gloeosporioides clades exhibit a quiescent lifestyle on certain fruit trees like almond and guava. Our model accounts for the common attributes of Colletotrichum lifestyles, including: (i) a reproductive (asexual) stage occurring on the host plant or in plant debris; (ii) infection caused by conidia; (iii) an asymptomatic (biotrophic) stage that can be either short or extended depending on the incubation period; (iv) a necrotrophic stage where host cells are invaded and killed, resulting in symptoms (lesions in our model); and (v) a sporulation stage, involving the production of secondary inoculum on lesions.
q1: How does the new model address the different lifestyles of Colletotrichum spp., including necrotrophic and biotrophic stages?
q2: What factors influence the timing of the transition from biotrophy to necrotrophy in Colletotrichum spp. according to the model?
q3: How does the model incorporate the various stages of the pathogen life cycle, such as reproduction, infection, asymptomatic phases, necrotrophy, and sporulation?
q4: Does the model account for both the asexual reproductive stage and the infection caused by conidia?
q5: Is the model designed to handle variations in biotrophic and necrotrophic stages depending on the host and environmental conditions?
q6: Does the model include a stage for sporulation and production of secondary inoculum on lesions?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Our model is weather driven in that it accounts for the effects of
temperature, wetness duration, and rain on the epidemiological
components leading to disease development. The model works with
an hourly time step to better account for fluctuations in
temperature, as well as in wetness duration and wetness
interruption that directly influence the epidemiological processes.
This ensures more accurate and robust predictions than provided
by models that work with a daily time step (Scherm and Van
Bruggen, 1994; Narouei-Khandan et al., 2020). To be incorporated
into our model, however, new information must have an hourly
time step.
txt: Our model is weather-driven, accounting for the effects of temperature, wetness duration, and rainfall on the epidemiological components leading to disease development. It operates with an hourly time step to better capture fluctuations in temperature, wetness duration, and interruptions, which directly influence the epidemiological processes. This approach ensures more accurate and robust predictions compared to models that use a daily time step. To be incorporated into our model, however, new information must also be provided at an hourly resolution.
q1: Why does the model use an hourly time step instead of a daily time step?
q2: How does the model incorporate weather variables such as temperature, wetness duration, and rainfall into its predictions?
q3: What is required to integrate new information into the model?
q4: Does the model account for fluctuations in weather variables by operating with an hourly time step?
q5: Is new information required to be provided at an hourly resolution for the model to function correctly?
q6: Does the use of an hourly time step improve the accuracy and robustness of the model compared to daily time steps?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
To design and calibrate the model, we performed a systematic
literature search in order to collect published information on the
biological processes involved in the development of epidemics and
the weather conditions affecting these processes. Locating and
assembling published knowledge by means of a systematic
approach reduces errors, limits search bias, and improves the
synthesis of research findings (Candel, 2014; Scherm et al., 2014),
facilitating the application of system analysis to the collected
information (Rossi et al., 2015). Organization of the available
knowledge on the basis of system analysis revealed incomplete
information for some biological processes or for some clades
(especially the dematium and graminicola clades); to deal with
this incomplete information, we made simplifications, made explicit
assumptions, and/or used data from related clades for both model
design and calibration.
txt: To design and calibrate the model, we conducted a systematic literature search to collect published information on the biological processes involved in epidemic development and the weather conditions affecting these processes. Using a systematic approach to locate and assemble published knowledge reduces errors, limits search bias, and improves the synthesis of research findings, facilitating the application of system analysis to the collected information. This organization of available knowledge revealed incomplete information for some biological processes or clades, particularly for the dematium and graminicola clades. To address these gaps, we made simplifications, explicit assumptions, and/or used data from related clades for model design and calibration.
q1: How did the systematic literature search contribute to the design and calibration of the model?
q2: What challenges were encountered in the literature search, particularly concerning the dematium and graminicola clades?
q3: What strategies were used to address gaps in the available information for certain biological processes or clades?
q4: Was a systematic literature search used to collect published information for model design and calibration?
q5: Did the literature search reveal incomplete information for some biological processes or clades?
q6: Were simplifications, explicit assumptions, or data from related clades used to address gaps in the model?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
The first simplification in the design of our model concerns the
role of sexual spores in the Colletotrichum life cycle. Sexual fruiting
bodies (perithecia) can be produced on artificial media by species in
the gloeosporioides, destructivum, and graminicola caldes (De Silva
et al., 2017). Perithecia, however, rarely occur in the field (Dowling
et al., 2020), and the asexual stage is considered the sole or main
kind of inoculum in disease development. The model therefore
focuses on the asexual stage of Colletotrichum, and asexual spores
(conidia) produced in acervuli are considered as the only inoculum
responsible for the development of anthracnose epidemics.
Exclusion of a possible (even though unlikely) ascosporic
inoculum could lead to an underestimation of the total inoculum
dose in the first phase of epidemics (the so-called lag phase; Schein,
1963), so delaying the epidemic growth (Schein, 1963) especially in
rainless periods, because ascospores are forcibly discharged from
perithecia even in the absence of rain if there is sufficient humidity
(Aylor and Anagnostakis, 1991; Manstretta and Rossi, 2016).
txt:
The first simplification in our model design concerns the role of sexual spores in the Colletotrichum life cycle. Sexual fruiting bodies (perithecia) can be produced on artificial media by species in the gloeosporioides, destructivum, and graminicola clades. However, perithecia rarely occur in the field, and the asexual stage is generally considered the primary or sole inoculum responsible for disease development. Consequently, our model focuses on the asexual stage of Colletotrichum, treating asexual spores (conidia) produced in acervuli as the only inoculum responsible for anthracnose epidemics.
Excluding a potential (though unlikely) ascosporic inoculum could lead to an underestimation of the total inoculum dose during the initial phase of epidemics, known as the lag phase. This might delay epidemic growth, especially during rainless periods, as ascospores can be discharged from perithecia even in the absence of rain if there is sufficient humidity.
q1: Why does the model focus exclusively on the asexual stage of Colletotrichum for predicting anthracnose epidemics?
q2: What impact could the exclusion of sexual spores (ascospores) have on the model's predictions, particularly during the initial phase of epidemics?
q3: How might the absence of rain affect the potential contribution of ascospores to disease development, according to the model?
q4: Does the model consider only asexual spores (conidia) as the inoculum responsible for anthracnose epidemics?
q5: Is the role of sexual spores (ascospores) excluded from the model due to their rarity in field conditions?
q6: Could excluding ascospores from the model lead to an underestimation of the total inoculum dose during the lag phase of epidemics?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
A second simplification concerns the model’s structure. The
model is based on the well-established framework designed by
Zadoks (1971), in which host sites go from healthy, to infected
with latent infection, to infected with visible lesions, to infectious,
and finally to removed (sites with sterile lesions). This structure has
been successfully applied to many pathosystems, under different
climates, and on cereals and dicotyledon crops (Djurle and Yuen,
1991; Rossi et al., 1997; Savary et al., 2015; Bove et al., 2020). This
model structure assumes that all sites have equal size, that healthy
sites have an equal probability to become diseased, and that diseased
sites are randomly distributed. For those anthracnose diseases in
which lesions enlarge, such as occurs on apple (Grammen et al.,
2019; Nita et al., 2019) and strawberry (Garrido et al., 2008), the
assumption that lesions are equal in size could lead to an
underestimation of both disease severity and the dose of
secondary conidia; a lesion expansion component (Berger et al.,
1997) could be easily integrated into the model for those cases.
Given that Colletotrichum conidia are splash-borne, with short
flight distances of splash droplets from the source, the
assumption that diseased sites are randomly distributed is likely
to be wrong, i.e., diseased sites are likely to be aggregated in space
(Madden, 1997); therefore, the assumptions that all sites have an
equal probability to become affected could result in an
overestimation of disease severity. The introduction of a diseaseaggregation
coefficient for the calculation of infection rate could
account for the spatial heterogeneity in disease distribution
(Waggoner and Rich, 1981).
txt:
A second simplification concerns the model’s structure. The model is based on the framework developed by Zadoks (1971), where host sites progress from healthy to infected with latent infection, to infected with visible lesions, to infectious, and finally to removed (sites with sterile lesions). This framework has been successfully applied to various pathosystems under different climates, and on both cereals and dicotyledon crops. It assumes that all sites are of equal size, that healthy sites have an equal probability of becoming diseased, and that diseased sites are randomly distributed.
For anthracnose diseases where lesions enlarge, such as on apple and strawberry, the assumption of equal lesion size could lead to an underestimation of both disease severity and the dose of secondary conidia. Integrating a lesion expansion component into the model could address this issue. Additionally, since Colletotrichum conidia are splash-borne with short flight distances, the assumption that diseased sites are randomly distributed may not be accurate. Diseased sites are likely to be spatially aggregated, which could result in an overestimation of disease severity. Introducing a disease-aggregation coefficient to account for spatial heterogeneity in disease distribution could improve the accuracy of infection rate calculations.
q1: How does the model’s reliance on the Zadoks (1971) framework influence its predictions for anthracnose diseases, particularly in terms of lesion size and disease severity?
q2: What are the potential consequences of assuming equal lesion size and random distribution of diseased sites in the model?
q3: How might introducing a lesion expansion component and a disease-aggregation coefficient improve the model’s accuracy for predicting anthracnose diseases?
q4: Does the model use the Zadoks (1971) framework, which assumes equal lesion size and random distribution of diseased sites?
q5: Could the assumption of equal lesion size lead to an underestimation of disease severity and conidial dose in the model?
q6: Is there potential for overestimation of disease severity due to the assumption that diseased sites are randomly distributed?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
A third simplification of model design refers to the host plant.
The model does not consider host growth and senescence, and only
uses the growth stage to determine the periods in which plants are
susceptible to infection or not. Crop growth and senescence cause
changes over time of the leaf area and, consequently, of healthy sites
(Bove et al., 2020). Our simplification could therefore lead to an
overestimation of healthy sites in the early season when the canopy
is growing, or in late season when sites become senescent, both of
which could both result in an overestimation of the disease severity.
As before, the model structure could be modified by inserting
components for host growth and senescence (Savary et al., 2015;
Bove et al., 2020). That the host can be either susceptible or not is
also a simplification in our model, because there are cases in which
fruits show various levels of susceptibility to infection, and in which
the switch from biotrophy to necrotrophy depends on physiological
and biochemical changes during the fruit ripening process (Moral
et al., 2009; Moral et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013; Nekoduka et al.,
2018; López-Moral et al., 2019).
txt:
A third simplification in the model design pertains to the host plant. The model does not account for host growth and senescence; it uses only the growth stage to determine periods of susceptibility to infection. However, crop growth and senescence affect leaf area and, consequently, the number of healthy sites. This simplification could lead to an overestimation of healthy sites early in the season when the canopy is expanding, or late in the season when sites become senescent, both of which could result in an overestimation of disease severity. The model structure could be improved by incorporating components for host growth and senescence.
Additionally, the model simplifies host susceptibility by categorizing it as either susceptible or not, while in reality, fruits may exhibit varying levels of susceptibility. The transition from biotrophy to necrotrophy often depends on physiological and biochemical changes during fruit ripening, which are not accounted for in this model (Moral et al., 2009; Moral et al., 2012; Prusky et al., 2013; Nekoduka et al., 2018; López-Moral et al., 2019). Integrating these aspects could enhance the model’s accuracy.
q1: How might the lack of consideration for host growth and senescence affect the model's predictions of disease severity?
q2: What are the potential consequences of simplifying host susceptibility to just susceptible or not, without accounting for varying levels of susceptibility?
q3: How could integrating host growth, senescence, and varying levels of susceptibility improve the accuracy of the model?
q4: Does the model currently simplify host plant factors by not accounting for growth and senescence?
q5: Could the exclusion of host growth and senescence lead to an overestimation of healthy sites and disease severity?
q6: Is host susceptibility in the model categorized as either susceptible or not, without considering varying levels of susceptibility?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
The model was calibrated for seven major clades (i.e., acutatum,
dematium, destructivum, gloeosporioides, graminicola, and
orbiculare) and the singleton species C. coccodes (considered as
the coccodes clade in the current research). Calibration was done at
the clade level because of the scarcity of information at the species
level; when there was no information for a specific clade, the model
was operated by using the parameterization of other clades. This
was the case for the effect of wetness on sporulation from primary
sources only for the acutatum clade on olive and strawberry
(Leandro et al., 2003; Moral and Trapero, 2012), and for the
seasonal availability of primary inoculum only for the acutatum
clade on olive (Moral and Trapero, 2012) only. Further studies are
needed to clarify the effect of wetness on primary inoculum
production and on the longevity of primary inoculum sources. A
lack of information was also found for the effect of wetness on
infection by the graminicola clade and the effect of temperature on
incubation and latency periods for the dematium clade. In the
validation, the model was operated by using equations from the
closest related clade, i.e., by using equations from the destructivum
clade for the graminicola clade and from the acutatum clade for the
dematium clade (Salotti et al., 2022).
txt:
The model was calibrated for seven major clades (acutatum, dematium, destructivum, gloeosporioides, graminicola, and orbiculare) as well as the singleton species C. coccodes (referred to as the coccodes clade in this research). Calibration was performed at the clade level due to limited information at the species level. When specific clade data was unavailable, parameterizations from related clades were used. For instance, information on the effect of wetness on sporulation from primary sources was only available for the acutatum clade on olive and strawberry (Leandro et al., 2003; Moral and Trapero, 2012), and seasonal availability of primary inoculum was only reported for the acutatum clade on olive (Moral and Trapero, 2012). Further research is needed to clarify the effects of wetness on primary inoculum production and longevity.
Additionally, there was insufficient information on the effect of wetness on infection for the graminicola clade and on temperature effects on incubation and latency periods for the dematium clade. During validation, the model used equations from the most closely related clades: equations from the destructivum clade for the graminicola clade and equations from the acutatum clade for the dematium clade (Salotti et al., 2022).
q1: Why was the model calibrated at the clade level instead of the species level?
q2: How were gaps in data for certain clades addressed during model calibration and validation?
q3: What are the specific data gaps identified for the graminicola and dematium clades, and how were they addressed?
q4: Was the model calibrated at the clade level due to limited information at the species level?
q5: Did the model use equations from related clades to fill in gaps for clades with insufficient data?
q6: Is there a need for further research to clarify the effects of wetness on primary inoculum production and longevity?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
A clade-based calibration has some limitations. For instance,
the acutatum clade, which affects strawberry, almond, olive, lupin,
etc., showed great variability in incubation and latency periods
depending on the host. At 15°C, the latency period was 5 days on
strawberry fruits (King et al., 1997), 19 days on olive fruits (Moral
et al., 2012), and about 10 days on lupin (Diggle et al., 2002).
Because of this variability, the equations developed for such
polyphagous clades had generally lower CCC values, higher
RMSE values, and CRM values more distant from zero (Table 4).
Effects of high within-clade variability were further reflected in the
model validation results (Table 5), which showed that predictions
were better for clades that had a small number of species and hosts.
The acutatum and gloeosporioides clades, which include multiple
species and hosts, had overall CCC values of 0.895 and 0.910,
respectively. In contrast, the graminicola clade, which is a welldefined
monophyletic clade encompassing Colletotrichum species
mainly associated with grasses (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021),
had the highest CCC value of 0.973.
txt:
A clade-based calibration has some limitations. For example, the acutatum clade, which affects a wide range of hosts such as strawberry, almond, olive, and lupin, exhibited significant variability in incubation and latency periods depending on the host. At 15°C, the latency period was 5 days on strawberry fruits (King et al., 1997), 19 days on olive fruits (Moral et al., 2012), and about 10 days on lupin (Diggle et al., 2002). This variability resulted in generally lower CCC values, higher RMSE values, and CRM values more distant from zero for equations developed for such polyphagous clades (Table 4).
The effects of high within-clade variability were further reflected in the model validation results (Table 5). Predictions were generally more accurate for clades with fewer species and hosts. For instance, the acutatum and gloeosporioides clades, which include multiple species and hosts, had overall CCC values of 0.895 and 0.910, respectively. In contrast, the graminicola clade, a well-defined monophyletic clade comprising Colletotrichum species mainly associated with grasses (Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021), achieved the highest CCC value of 0.973.
q1: What impact did variability within the acutatum clade have on model accuracy?
q2: How did the model's predictions differ between clades with high variability and those with fewer species and hosts?
q3: Which clade achieved the highest overall CCC value and why might that be?
q4: Did the acutatum clade show significant variability in incubation and latency periods depending on the host?
q5: Were predictions more accurate for clades with fewer species and hosts compared to polyphagous clades?
q6: Did the graminicola clade achieve the highest CCC value among the clades?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Clade-based calibration may also have advantages. Anthracnose
diseases have often been attributed to several Colletotrichum species
belonging to the same clade, depending on the region. For instance,
the main causal agents of olive anthracnose are in the acutatum
clade, with C. godetiae dominant in Spain, Italy, Greece, and
Tunisia; with C. nymphaeae dominant in Portugal; and with C.
fioriniae dominant in California (Moral et al., 2021). In addition,
proper identification of the Colletotrichum species requires
molecular analysis of multiple DNA regions (Damm et al., 2009;
Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2013; Damm
et al., 2014). Because the species belonging to the same clade show
similar environmental requirements (Salotti et al., 2022), a cladebased
calibration may be useful to overcome knowledge gaps for
single Colletotrichum species, to favor practical model usage when
the identification of species is not possible because of capacity or
economic limitations, and to make predictions for a wide range of
hosts and climatic conditions.
txt: Clade-based calibration offers several advantages. Many anthracnose diseases are attributed to various Colletotrichum species within the same clade, depending on the region. For example, in olive anthracnose, the acutatum clade includes C. godetiae, which is dominant in Spain, Italy, Greece, and Tunisia; C. nymphaeae in Portugal; and C. fioriniae in California (Moral et al., 2021). Molecular identification of Colletotrichum species requires analyzing multiple DNA regions (Damm et al., 2009; Damm et al., 2012; Weir et al., 2012; Damm et al., 2013; Damm et al., 2014). Since species within the same clade share similar environmental requirements (Salotti et al., 2022), clade-based calibration can help address knowledge gaps for individual species, facilitate practical model usage when species identification is challenging or economically unfeasible, and enable predictions across a wide range of hosts and climatic conditions.
q1: How does clade-based calibration help in managing anthracnose diseases caused by various Colletotrichum species?
q2: Why is molecular identification of Colletotrichum species often challenging and resource-intensive?
q3: What are some regional variations in the species of the acutatum clade responsible for olive anthracnose?
q4: Does clade-based calibration aid in predicting disease outbreaks across different climatic conditions?
q5: Is molecular identification of Colletotrichum species required to analyze multiple DNA regions?
q6: Can clade-based calibration be used when species identification is economically unfeasible?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Given that the model was validated against independent data
(i.e., data not used in model development) and provided accurate
and robust predictions of anthracnose epidemics, we conclude that
our assumptions and simplifications did not greatly reduce the
model’s ability to make correct predictions. Overall, high
concordance was shown between model predictions and reality
(CCC = 0.928), with few errors (RMSE = 0.044), and a slight
tendency of the model toward overestimation (CRM = –0.052).
Unfortunately, data enabling model validation were available for
only five of the eight clades for which the model was parameterized
(i.e., acutatum, dematium, gloeosporioides, graminicola, and
orbiculare clades). Except for the acutatum clade, which was
validated on strawberry and olive, each clade was validated on
only one host. More complete validation is needed for different
clades and hosts.
txt: The model's validation against independent data demonstrates its accuracy and robustness in predicting anthracnose epidemics. Despite the model's assumptions and simplifications, it showed high concordance with reality (CCC = 0.928), minimal errors (RMSE = 0.044), and a slight tendency towards overestimation (CRM = –0.052). However, validation data were only available for five of the eight clades for which the model was parameterized (acutatum, dematium, gloeosporioides, graminicola, and orbiculare). Except for the acutatum clade, which was validated on both strawberry and olive, each clade was validated on only one host. More comprehensive validation across different clades and hosts is needed to further assess the model's generalizability and accuracy.
q1: What statistical metrics were used to assess the model's accuracy and robustness?
q2: How many clades were not validated in the model’s evaluation?
q3: On how many different hosts was the acutatum clade validated?
q4: Did the model show high concordance with reality as indicated by the CCC value?
q5: Was the model validated on all eight clades it was parameterized for?
q6: Is further validation required to fully assess the model's generalizability across different clades and hosts?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
In our model validation, the k dose of primary conidia that can
develop from overwintering inoculum sources (crop debris, mummies,
and dormant buds) was estimated empirically from disease data; this
estimation may not greatly affect the reliability of the model to predict
disease progress because it modulates the final value of the disease
severity but not its progress. The real value of k in a field may depend
on many difficult-to-estimate factors, including the incidence and
severity of affected crops in the previous season and the proportion
of diseased tissues that remains in the field as an overwintering
inoculum source. Inappropriate estimation of k may result in underor
overestimation of infection risk during the season. Further studies
are therefore needed to improve the estimation of the abundance of
primary inoculum sources at the beginning of the cropping season.
txt: The model's validation involved empirically estimating the k dose of primary conidia from overwintering inoculum sources (e.g., crop debris, mummies, dormant buds). While this estimation mainly influences the final disease severity rather than its progression, it may affect the accuracy of infection risk predictions. The actual value of k is influenced by complex factors, such as the previous season's crop incidence and severity and the proportion of diseased tissues remaining in the field. Inaccurate estimation of k could lead to either underestimation or overestimation of infection risk. To enhance the model's reliability, further research is needed to improve the estimation of primary inoculum abundance at the start of the cropping season.
q1: What factors influence the estimation of the k dose of primary conidia in the model?
q2: How does the estimation of k affect the model's predictions of infection risk?
q3: Why is accurate estimation of the k dose crucial for predicting disease severity?
q4: Does the estimation of k primarily influence the final disease severity rather than its progression?
q5: Are complex factors such as previous season's crop incidence important for determining the value of k?
q6: Is further research needed to improve the estimation of primary inoculum abundance at the start of the cropping season?
metadata: Irene et al. (2023) Development of a model for Colletotrichum diseases with calibration for phylogenetic clades on diff.pdf

pdf:
Our model is flexible in both design and calibration. For instance,
the model can easily incorporate components for lesion expansion,
plant growth, senescence, or host susceptibility by integration of
additional model components (Loomis and Adams, 1983) and of
modifiers accounting for resistance components, as has been done
with similar models (Savary et al., 2015; Bove et al., 2021). Model
flexibility also enables easy incorporation of new information on
pathogen biology and epidemiology, so that inserting species-specific
or host-specific calibrations may improve the prediction accuracy
especially in hosts or in regions in which anthracnose disease is
caused by a dominant Colletotrichum species, or for clades not
considered in this work such as the boniense clade, which is
economically important on several Citrus spp. (Uysal and Kurt,
2019; Talhinhas and Baroncelli, 2021).
txt: Our model is flexible in both design and calibration. For instance, the model can easily incorporate components for lesion expansion, plant growth, senescence, or host susceptibility by integrating additional model components and modifiers accounting for resistance components, as has been done with similar models. Model flexibility also enables easy incorporation of new information on pathogen biology and epidemiology, so that inserting species-specific or host-specific calibrations may improve prediction accuracy, especially in hosts or regions where anthracnose disease is caused by a dominant Colletotrichum species, or for clades not considered in this work, such as the boniense clade, which is economically important on several Citrus species.
q1: How does the model's flexibility contribute to its ability to incorporate new information on pathogen biology and epidemiology?
q2: What are some examples of components that can be integrated into the model to enhance its functionality?
q3: Why is it important to include species-specific or host-specific calibrations in the model?
q4: Can the model easily integrate new components like lesion expansion or host susceptibility?
q5: Is the model adaptable to new information about pathogen biology and epidemiology?
q6: Are clades not considered in the current model, such as the boniense clade, economically important for certain crops?

pdf:
In spite of some shortcomings mainly related to its simplicity
and the scarcity of information available in the literature, our model
is promising. After further validation and evaluation of its ability to
support risk-based fungicide applications, the model could be used
for supporting decision-making in crop protection.
txt: In spite of some shortcomings mainly related to its simplicity and the scarcity of information available in the literature, our model is promising. After further validation and evaluation of its ability to support risk-based fungicide applications, the model could be used to support decision-making in crop protection.

q1: What are the specific advantages of clade-based calibration in modeling anthracnose diseases for Colletotrichum species?
q2: How does clade-based calibration facilitate practical applications when species identification is challenging?
q3: What are the potential economic impacts of using clade-based calibration compared to species-specific models?
q4: Does clade-based calibration improve the accuracy of disease models for different Colletotrichum species?
q5: Is it economically feasible to identify every Colletotrichum species in a clade for accurate modeling?
q6: Can clade-based calibration be applied effectively when direct species identification is not possible?

pdf:
Abstract: The limit of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex is defined genetically, based on a strongly supported clade within the Colletotrichum ITS gene tree.
All taxa accepted within this clade are morphologically more or less typical of the broadly defined C. gloeosporioides, as it has been applied in the literature for the past 50 years.
We accept 22 species plus one subspecies within the C. gloeosporioides complex. These include C. asianum, C. cordylinicola, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. horii, C.
kahawae subsp. kahawae, C. musae, C. nupharicola, C. psidii, C. siamense, C. theobromicola, C. tropicale, and C. xanthorrhoeae, along with the taxa described here as new,
C. aenigma, C. aeschynomenes, C. alatae, C. alienum, C. aotearoa, C. clidemiae, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, C. salsolae, and C. ti, plus the nom. nov. C. queenslandicum
(for C. gloeosporioides var. minus). All of the taxa are defined genetically on the basis of multi-gene phylogenies. Brief morphological descriptions are provided for species
where no modern description is available. Many of the species are unable to be reliably distinguished using ITS, the official barcoding gene for fungi. Particularly problematic
are a set of species genetically close to C. musae and another set of species genetically close to C. kahawae, referred to here as the Musae clade and the Kahawae clade,
respectively. Each clade contains several species that are phylogenetically well supported in multi-gene analyses, but within the clades branch lengths are short because of
the small number of phylogenetically informative characters, and in a few cases individual gene trees are incongruent. Some single genes or combinations of genes, such as
glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and glutamine synthetase, can be used to reliably distinguish most taxa and will need to be developed as secondary barcodes for
species level identification, which is important because many of these fungi are of biosecurity significance. In addition to the accepted species, notes are provided for names
where a possible close relationship with C. gloeosporioides sensu lato has been suggested in the recent literature, along with all subspecific taxa and formae speciales within
C. gloeosporioides and its putative teleomorph Glomerella cingulata.
txt: Abstract: The limit of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex is defined genetically, based on a strongly supported clade within the Colletotrichum ITS gene tree. All taxa accepted within this clade are morphologically similar to the broadly defined C. gloeosporioides, as it has been applied in the literature for the past 50 years. We accept 22 species plus one subspecies within the C. gloeosporioides complex. These include C. asianum, C. cordylinicola, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides, C. horii, C. kahawae subsp. kahawae, C. musae, C. nupharicola, C. psidii, C. siamense, C. theobromicola, C. tropicale, and C. xanthorrhoeae, along with the newly described taxa: C. aenigma, C. aeschynomenes, C. alatae, C. alienum, C. aotearoa, C. clidemiae, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, C. salsolae, and C. ti, plus the newly proposed C. queenslandicum (for C. gloeosporioides var. minus). All taxa are defined genetically based on multi-gene phylogenies. Brief morphological descriptions are provided for species lacking modern descriptions. Many species cannot be reliably distinguished using ITS, the official barcoding gene for fungi. Particularly problematic are species closely related to C. musae and C. kahawae, referred to as the Musae clade and the Kahawae clade, respectively. Each clade contains several phylogenetically well-supported species, but branch lengths within the clades are short due to the small number of phylogenetically informative characters, and some gene trees are incongruent. Single genes or combinations of genes, such as glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and glutamine synthetase, can reliably distinguish most taxa and should be developed as secondary barcodes for species-level identification, which is important because many of these fungi are of biosecurity significance. Notes are also provided for names suggesting a possible close relationship with C. gloeosporioides sensu lato, including all subspecific taxa and formae speciales within C. gloeosporioides and its putative teleomorph Glomerella cingulata.
q1: How has the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex been genetically defined in recent studies?
q2: What challenges exist in distinguishing species within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex using ITS gene sequences?
q3: Why is it important to develop secondary barcoding genes for species-level identification in the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q4: Are many species within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex morphologically similar to C. gloeosporioides?
q5: Can the ITS gene reliably distinguish all species within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex?
q6: Is the development of secondary barcoding genes suggested for better species identification in the C. gloeosporioides complex?

pdf:
The name Colletotrichum gloeosporioides was first proposed
in Penzig (1882), based on Vermicularia gloeosporioides, the
type specimen of which was collected from Citrus in Italy. Much
of the early literature used this name to refer to fungi associated
with various diseases of Citrus, with other species established for
morphologically similar fungi from other hosts. However, several
early papers discussed the morphological similarity between many
of the Colletotrichum spp. that had been described on the basis of
host preference, and used inoculation tests to question whether or
not the species were distinct. Some of these papers investigated
in culture the link between the various Colletotrichum species and
their sexual Glomerella state (e.g. Shear & Wood 1907, Ocfemia
& Agati 1925). Authors such as Shear & Wood (1907, 1913) and
Small (1926) concluded that many of the species described on the
basis of host preference were in fact the same, rejecting apparent
differences in host preference as a basis for taxonomic segregation.
Small (1926) concluded that the names Glomerella cingulata and
Colletotrichum gloeosporioides should be used for the sexual and
asexual morphs, respectively, of the many Colletotrichum spp.
they regarded as conspecific. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
was stated to be the earliest name with a proven link to what they
regarded as a biologically diverse G. cingulata. The studies of
von Arx & Müller (1954) and von Arx (1957, 1970) taxonomically
formalised this concept.
txt: The name Colletotrichum gloeosporioides was first proposed by Penzig (1882), based on Vermicularia gloeosporioides, with the type specimen collected from Citrus in Italy. Early literature commonly used this name to refer to fungi associated with various diseases of Citrus, while other species were established for morphologically similar fungi from different hosts. However, several early papers examined the morphological similarity among many Colletotrichum species described based on host preference and questioned whether these species were distinct. Some studies investigated the connection between various Colletotrichum species and their sexual state, Glomerella (e.g., Shear & Wood 1907, Ocfemia & Agati 1925). Authors like Shear & Wood (1907, 1913) and Small (1926) concluded that many species described based on host preference were actually the same, rejecting differences in host preference as a basis for taxonomic separation. Small (1926) proposed that the names Glomerella cingulata and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides should be used for the sexual and asexual morphs, respectively, of the many Colletotrichum species they considered conspecific. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides was identified as the earliest name with a proven link to what was regarded as a biologically diverse G. cingulata. The studies of von Arx & Müller (1954) and von Arx (1957, 1970) formally adopted this concept.
q1: How was the name Colletotrichum gloeosporioides first proposed, and what was its original association with citrus?
q2: What were the key findings of early studies regarding the morphological similarities among various Colletotrichum species?
q3: How did early researchers like Shear, Wood, and Small contribute to the understanding of the relationship between Colletotrichum and Glomerella?
q4: Was Colletotrichum gloeosporioides originally described from a specimen collected on citrus in Italy?
q5: Did Shear & Wood, and later Small, challenge the idea that host preference should be used for taxonomic separation of Colletotrichum species?
q6: Did von Arx & Müller support the use of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and Glomerella cingulata as names for the asexual and sexual morphs of the same species?

pdf:
The “von Arxian” taxonomic concept for Colletotrichum
saw large numbers of species synonymised with the names C.
graminicola (for grass-inhabiting species) and C. gloeosporioides
(for non-grass inhabiting species with straight conidia). The
genetic and biological diversity encompassed by these names
was so broad that they became of little practical use to plant
pathologists, conveying no information about pathogenicity, host
range, or other attributes. The von Arx & Müller (1954) and von
Arx (1957) studies were not based on direct examination of type
material of all species and some of the synonymy proposed
in these papers has subsequently been found to be incorrect.
Examples include the segregation of C. acutatum (Simmonds
1965) and C. boninense (Moriwaki et al. 2003) from C.
gloeosporioides sensu von Arx (1957). Other studies published
elsewhere in this volume (Damm et al. 2012a, b) show that
several species regarded as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides
by von Arx (1957) are members of the C. acutatum complex
(e.g. C. godetiae, Gloeosporium limetticola, G. lycopersici, and
G. phormii) or the C. boninense complex (e.g. C. dracaenae).
Recent molecular studies have resulted in a much better
understanding of phylogenetic relationships amongst the
grass-inhabiting species of the C. graminicola group and the
development of a more useful taxonomy for this group of fungi
(e.g. Hsiang & Goodwin 2001, Du et al. 2005, and Crouch et
al. 2006). This group is now recognised as comprising several
host-specialised, genetically well characterised species, but a
modern taxonomy for C. gloeosporioides has yet to be resolved.
txt: The “von Arxian” taxonomic concept for Colletotrichum led to the synonymization of many species under the names C. graminicola (for grass-inhabiting species) and C. gloeosporioides (for non-grass-inhabiting species with straight conidia). The genetic and biological diversity encompassed by these names was so extensive that they became of limited practical use to plant pathologists, providing little information about pathogenicity, host range, or other attributes. The studies by von Arx & Müller (1954) and von Arx (1957) were not based on the direct examination of type material for all species, and some of the synonymy proposed in these papers has been found to be incorrect. Examples include the segregation of C. acutatum (Simmonds 1965) and C. boninense (Moriwaki et al. 2003) from C. gloeosporioides sensu von Arx (1957). Other studies, such as those by Damm et al. (2012a, b), show that several species considered synonyms of C. gloeosporioides by von Arx (1957) are actually members of the C. acutatum complex (e.g., C. godetiae, Gloeosporium limetticola, G. lycopersici, and G. phormii) or the C. boninense complex (e.g., C. dracaenae). Recent molecular studies have greatly improved our understanding of the phylogenetic relationships among the grass-inhabiting species of the C. graminicola group and have led to a more useful taxonomy for this group of fungi (e.g., Hsiang & Goodwin 2001, Du et al. 2005, and Crouch et al. 2006). This group is now recognized as comprising several host-specialized, genetically well-characterized species, but a modern taxonomy for C. gloeosporioides is still to be resolved.
q1: How did the “von Arxian” concept of Colletotrichum affect the taxonomy of C. graminicola and C. gloeosporioides?
q2: What were some of the inaccuracies in von Arx's synonymization of Colletotrichum species, and how have modern studies corrected them?
q3: How have recent molecular studies improved the understanding of the taxonomy of grass-inhabiting Colletotrichum species?
q4: Did the "von Arxian" concept lead to the synonymization of many Colletotrichum species under C. graminicola and C. gloeosporioides?
q5: Have recent molecular studies revealed that some species previously considered synonyms of C. gloeosporioides are actually part of the C. acutatum and C. boninense complexes?
q6: Is the taxonomy of C. gloeosporioides still unresolved despite recent advances in molecular phylogenetics?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Von Arx (1970) and Sutton (1980) distinguished the C.
gloeosporioides group using conidial shape and size. A few apparently
host-specialised, C. gloeosporioides-like taxa were retained by these
authors, but the basis of their identification was often difficult to
understand. Prior to the availability of DNA sequence data, taxonomic
concepts within Colletotrichum were based on features such as host
species, substrate, conidial size and shape, shape of appressoria,
growth rate in culture, colour of cultures, presence or absence of
setae, whether or not the teleomorph develops, etc. Some studies
have found characters such as these useful for distinguishing
groups within C. gloeosporioides (e.g. Higgins 1926, Gorter 1956,
Hindorf 1973, and Johnston & Jones 1997). However, problems
arise because many of these morphological features change under
different conditions of growth (dependent upon growth media,
temperature, light regime, etc.), or can be lost or change with repeated
subculturing. Host preference is poorly controlled — even good, welldefined
pathogens causing a specific disease can be isolated by
chance from other substrates (e.g. Johnston 2000). Colletotrichum
conidia will germinate on most surfaces, form an appressorium,
remain attached to that surface as a viable propagule or perhaps as
a minor, endophytic or latent infection, and grow out from there into
senescing plant tissue or onto agar plates if given the opportunity.
In addition, the same disease can be caused by genetically distinct
sets of isolates, the shared pathogenicity presumably independently
evolved, e.g. the bitter rot disease of apple is caused by members
of both the C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides species complexes
(Johnston et al. 2005).
txt: Von Arx (1970) and Sutton (1980) distinguished the C. gloeosporioides group based on conidial shape and size. While a few apparently host-specialized C. gloeosporioides-like taxa were retained by these authors, the basis for their identification was often unclear. Before the advent of DNA sequence data, taxonomic concepts within Colletotrichum relied on features such as host species, substrate, conidial size and shape, shape of appressoria, growth rate in culture, color of cultures, presence or absence of setae, and whether the teleomorph develops. Some studies found these characters useful for distinguishing groups within C. gloeosporioides (e.g., Higgins 1926, Gorter 1956, Hindorf 1973, and Johnston & Jones 1997). However, problems arise because many of these morphological features can change under different growth conditions (dependent on growth media, temperature, light regime, etc.), or may be lost or altered with repeated subculturing. Host preference is poorly controlled—well-defined pathogens causing specific diseases can be isolated from other substrates by chance (e.g., Johnston 2000). Colletotrichum conidia can germinate on most surfaces, form an appressorium, remain attached as a viable propagule or minor endophyte, and grow into senescing plant tissue or onto agar plates if given the opportunity. Additionally, the same disease can be caused by genetically distinct sets of isolates, with shared pathogenicity presumably evolving independently. For example, the bitter rot disease of apple is caused by members of both the C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides species complexes (Johnston et al. 2005).
q1: How did von Arx and Sutton distinguish Colletotrichum gloeosporioides from other species, and what challenges arose from using conidial shape and size?
q2: What were some limitations of using morphological features for taxonomic identification of Colletotrichum species before the availability of DNA sequencing?
q3: How does the ability of Colletotrichum conidia to germinate on various surfaces complicate species identification and host specificity?
q4: Did early taxonomic concepts of Colletotrichum rely heavily on morphological features such as conidial size, appressoria shape, and growth rate in culture?
q5: Can the same plant disease, such as apple bitter rot, be caused by genetically distinct isolates from different Colletotrichum species complexes?
q6: Do morphological features of Colletotrichum species often change under varying growth conditions, complicating species identification?
