pdf:
Sutton (1992) commented on C. gloeosporioides that “No
progress in the systematics and identification of isolates belonging
to this complex is likely to be made based on morphology alone”.
A start was made towards a modern understanding of this name
with the designation of an epitype specimen with a culture derived
from it to stabilise the application of the name (Cannon et al. 2008).
Based on ITS sequences, the ex-epitype isolate belongs in a
strongly supported clade, distinct from other taxa that have been
confused with C. gloeosporioides in the past, such as C. acutatum
and C. boninense (e.g. Abang et al. 2002, Martinez-Culebras et
al. 2003, Johnston et al. 2005, Chung et al. 2006, Farr et al. 2006,
Than et al. 2008). However, biological and genetic relationships
within the broad C. gloeosporioides clade remain confused and ITS
sequences alone are insufficient to resolve them.
txt: Sutton (1992) remarked that "No progress in the systematics and identification of isolates belonging to this complex is likely to be made based on morphology alone." Progress toward a modern understanding of the name C. gloeosporioides began with the designation of an epitype specimen and a culture derived from it to stabilize the application of the name (Cannon et al. 2008). Based on ITS sequences, the ex-epitype isolate belongs to a strongly supported clade, distinct from other taxa that have historically been confused with C. gloeosporioides, such as C. acutatum and C. boninense (e.g., Abang et al. 2002, Martinez-Culebras et al. 2003, Johnston et al. 2005, Chung et al. 2006, Farr et al. 2006, Than et al. 2008). However, biological and genetic relationships within the broad C. gloeosporioides clade remain unclear, and ITS sequences alone are insufficient to resolve them.
q1: Why did Sutton (1992) believe that morphological data alone was insufficient for progress in the systematics of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex?
q2: How did the designation of an epitype specimen contribute to stabilizing the application of the name C. gloeosporioides?
q3: What challenges remain in understanding the biological and genetic relationships within the C. gloeosporioides clade despite the use of ITS sequences?
q4: Did Sutton (1992) argue that morphology alone is insufficient for identifying isolates in the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q5: Was an epitype specimen designated to stabilize the use of the name C. gloeosporioides?
q6: Are ITS sequences alone insufficient to fully resolve the relationships within the C. gloeosporioides clade?

pdf:
In this study we define the limits of the C. gloeosporioides
species complex on the basis of ITS sequences, the species we
accept within the complex forming a strongly supported clade
in the ITS gene tree (fig. 1 in Cannon et al. 2012, this issue). In
all cases the taxa we include in the C. gloeosporioides complex
would fit within the traditional morphological concept of the C.
gloeosporioides group (e.g. von Arx 1970, Mordue 1971, and
Sutton 1980). Commonly used species names within the C.
gloeosporioides complex include C. fragariae, C. musae, and C.
kahawae. Since the epitype paper (Cannon et al. 2008), several
new C. gloeosporioides-like species have been described in
regional studies, where multi-gene analyses have shown the new
species to be phylogenetically distinct from the ex-epitype strain of
C. gloeosporioides (e.g. Rojas et al. 2010, Phoulivong et al. 2011,
and Wikee et al. 2011).
txt: In this study, we define the limits of the C. gloeosporioides species complex based on ITS sequences, with the species we accept forming a strongly supported clade in the ITS gene tree (see fig. 1 in Cannon et al. 2012, this issue). All taxa included in the C. gloeosporioides complex fit within the traditional morphological concept of the C. gloeosporioides group (e.g., von Arx 1970, Mordue 1971, and Sutton 1980). Commonly used species names within the C. gloeosporioides complex include C. fragariae, C. musae, and C. kahawae. Since the epitype paper (Cannon et al. 2008), several new C. gloeosporioides-like species have been described in regional studies. Multi-gene analyses have shown these new species to be phylogenetically distinct from the ex-epitype strain of C. gloeosporioides (e.g., Rojas et al. 2010, Phoulivong et al. 2011, and Wikee et al. 2011).
q1: How is the C. gloeosporioides species complex defined in this study, and what is its relationship to traditional morphological concepts?
q2: What role do multi-gene analyses play in distinguishing newly described C. gloeosporioides-like species from the ex-epitype strain?
q3: What are some of the commonly used species names within the C. gloeosporioides complex, and how do they fit within the genetic and morphological framework?
q4: Are the limits of the C. gloeosporioides species complex based on ITS sequences in this study?
q5: Have new species been described since the designation of the C. gloeosporioides epitype in regional studies?
q6: Do multi-gene analyses show that some new C. gloeosporioides-like species are phylogenetically distinct from the ex-epitype strain?

pdf:
The regional nature of most of these studies, the often restricted
genetic sampling across the diversity of C. gloeosporioides globally,
and the minimal overlap between isolates treated and gene regions
targeted in the various studies, means that the relationship between
the newly described species is often poorly understood.
txt: The regional nature of most of these studies, coupled with often restricted genetic sampling across the global diversity of C. gloeosporioides, and minimal overlap between isolates studied and gene regions targeted, means that the relationships between the newly described species are often poorly understood.

q2: What challenges arise from limited genetic sampling and minimal overlap in gene regions when studying global diversity in C. gloeosporioides?

pdf:
While some authors have embraced a genetically highly
restricted concept for C. gloeosporioides, many applied researchers
continue to use the name in a broad, group-species concept (e.g.
Bogo et al. 2012, Deng et al. 2012, Kenny et al. 2012, Parvin et
al. 2012, and Zhang et al. 2012). In this paper we accept both
concepts as useful and valid. When used in a broad sense, we
refer to the taxon as the C. gloeosporioides species complex or C.
gloeosporioides s. lat.
txt: While some authors have adopted a genetically highly restricted concept for C. gloeosporioides, many applied researchers continue to use the name in a broad, group-species sense (e.g., Bogo et al. 2012, Deng et al. 2012, Kenny et al. 2012, Parvin et al. 2012, and Zhang et al. 2012). In this paper, we recognize both concepts as useful and valid. When used in a broad sense, we refer to the taxon as the C. gloeosporioides species complex or C. gloeosporioides s. lat.
q1: What are the differences between the genetically restricted and broad group-species concepts for C. gloeosporioides?
q2: Why do many applied researchers continue to use C. gloeosporioides in a broad, group-species sense despite the more restricted genetic concept?
q3: How does this paper reconcile the use of both the restricted and broad concepts for C. gloeosporioides?
q4: Do some authors adopt a genetically restricted concept for C. gloeosporioides?
q5: Do applied researchers often use C. gloeosporioides in a broad, group-species sense?
q6: Does this paper recognize both the genetically restricted and broad concepts of C. gloeosporioides as valid?

pdf:
This paper aims to clarify the genetic and taxonomic
relationships within the C. gloeosporioides species complex using
a set of isolates that widely samples its genetic, biological and
geographic diversity. Type specimens, or cultures derived from
type specimens, have been examined wherever possible. Although
we do not treat all of the names placed in synonymy with C.
gloeosporioides or Glomerella cingulata by von Arx & Müller (1954)
and von Arx (1957, 1970), we treat all names for which a possible
close relationship with C. gloeosporioides has been suggested in
the recent literature, along with all subspecific taxa and formae
speciales within C. gloeosporioides and G. cingulata.
txt: This paper aims to clarify the genetic and taxonomic relationships within the C. gloeosporioides species complex using a diverse set of isolates that represent its genetic, biological, and geographic diversity. Type specimens, or cultures derived from type specimens, have been examined whenever possible. Although we do not address all names placed in synonymy with C. gloeosporioides or Glomerella cingulata by von Arx & Müller (1954) and von Arx (1957, 1970), we consider all names suggested to have a possible close relationship with C. gloeosporioides in recent literature, as well as all subspecific taxa and formae speciales within C. gloeosporioides and G. cingulata.
q1: What is the primary goal of this paper regarding the C. gloeosporioides species complex?
q2: How does the paper approach the examination of type specimens or cultures derived from type specimens?
q3: Does the paper address all historical synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and Glomerella cingulata, or focus on a subset?
q4: Is the aim of this paper to clarify the genetic and taxonomic relationships within the C. gloeosporioides species complex?
q5: Are type specimens and cultures derived from type specimens examined whenever possible in this study?
q6: Does the paper consider names suggested in recent literature as potentially closely related to C. gloeosporioides, along with subspecific taxa and formae speciales?

pdf:
ITS sequences, the official barcoding gene for fungi (Seifert
2009, Schoch et al. 2012), do not reliably resolve relationships within
the C. gloeosporioides complex. We define species in the complex
genetically rather than morphologically, on the basis of phylogenetic
analyses of up to eight genes. Following Cannon et al. (2012, this
issue) the generic name Colletotrichum is used as the preferred
generic name for all species wherever possible throughout this
paper, whether or not a Glomerella state has been observed for that
fungus, and whether or not the Glomerella state has a formal name.
txt: ITS sequences, the official barcoding gene for fungi (Seifert 2009, Schoch et al. 2012), do not reliably resolve relationships within the C. gloeosporioides complex. We define species in the complex genetically rather than morphologically, based on phylogenetic analyses of up to eight genes. Following Cannon et al. (2012, this issue), the generic name Colletotrichum is used as the preferred generic name for all species throughout this paper, regardless of whether a Glomerella state has been observed or whether the Glomerella state has a formal name.
q1: Why are ITS sequences not reliable for resolving relationships within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q2: How does this paper define species within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q3: What naming convention does this paper use for the genus Colletotrichum, and why?
q4: Are ITS sequences insufficient for resolving relationships within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q5: Does the paper use phylogenetic analyses of up to eight genes to define species in the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q6: Is the name Colletotrichum used throughout the paper regardless of the presence or formal naming of the Glomerella state?

pdf:
An attempt was made to sample the genetic diversity across C.
gloeosporioides as widely as possible, with isolates from diverse
hosts from around the world selected for more intensive study. A
BLAST search of GenBank using the ITS sequence of the epitype
culture of C. gloeosporioides (Cannon et al. 2008) provided a
coarse estimate for the genetic limit of the C. gloeosporioides
complex and ITS diversity across the complex was used to
select a genetically diverse set of isolates. Voucher cultures were
obtained from the research groups who deposited the GenBank
records. To these were added isolates representing the known
genetic and morphological diversity of C. gloeosporioides from
New Zealand, isolated from rots of native and introduced fruits,
from diseased exotic weeds, and as endophytes from leaves of
native podocarps. Additional isolates representing ex-type and
authentic cultures of as many named taxa and formae speciales
within the C. gloeosporioides complex as possible were obtained
from international culture collections. Approximately 400 isolates
belonging to the C. gloeosporioides complex were obtained.
GAPDH gene sequences were generated for all isolates as an initial
measure of genetic diversity. A subset of 156 isolates, selected to
represent the range of genetic, geographic, and host plant diversity,
was used in this research (Table 1).
txt: An attempt was made to sample the genetic diversity of C. gloeosporioides as broadly as possible, with isolates from diverse hosts around the world selected for more intensive study. A BLAST search of GenBank using the ITS sequence of the epitype culture of C. gloeosporioides (Cannon et al. 2008) provided a preliminary estimate of the genetic boundaries of the C. gloeosporioides complex. ITS diversity across the complex was used to select a genetically diverse set of isolates. Voucher cultures were obtained from the research groups that deposited the GenBank records. Additional isolates representing the known genetic and morphological diversity of C. gloeosporioides from New Zealand were included, isolated from rots of native and introduced fruits, diseased exotic weeds, and as endophytes from native podocarps. Further isolates representing ex-type and authentic cultures of as many named taxa and formae speciales within the C. gloeosporioides complex as possible were obtained from international culture collections. Approximately 400 isolates belonging to the C. gloeosporioides complex were acquired. GAPDH gene sequences were generated for all isolates as an initial measure of genetic diversity. A subset of 156 isolates, selected to represent the range of genetic, geographic, and host plant diversity, was used in this research (see Table 1).
q1: How was the genetic diversity of C. gloeosporioides sampled for this study, and what was the scope of the isolates included?
q2: What method was used to estimate the genetic boundaries of the C. gloeosporioides complex, and how was ITS diversity utilized?
q3: How were the isolates selected for the research, and what was the total number of isolates acquired and used in the study?
q4: Was a BLAST search of GenBank used to estimate the genetic boundaries of the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q5: Did the study include isolates from a variety of hosts and geographical locations?
q6: Were GAPDH gene sequences generated for all isolates to assess initial genetic diversity?

pdf:
Most of the New Zealand isolates had been stored as conidial
suspensions made from single conidium or ascospore cultures and
then stored at -80 °C in a 5 % glycerol/water suspension. Additional
isolates from New Zealand were obtained from the ICMP culture
collection, where isolates are stored as lyophilised (freeze-dried)
ampoules or in a metabolically inactive state in liquid nitrogen
at -196 °C. The storage history of most of the isolates received
from other research groups is not known. Table 1 lists the isolates
studied. All those supplying cultures are acknowledged at the
end of this manuscript, and additional details on each culture are
available on the ICMP website (http://www.landcareresearch.co.nz/
resources/collections/icmp).
txt: Most of the New Zealand isolates had been stored as conidial suspensions made from single conidium or ascospore cultures, then preserved at -80 °C in a 5% glycerol/water suspension. Additional isolates from New Zealand were obtained from the ICMP culture collection, where they are stored either as lyophilized (freeze-dried) ampoules or in a metabolically inactive state in liquid nitrogen at -196 °C. The storage history of most isolates received from other research groups is not known. Table 1 lists the isolates studied. All those who supplied cultures are acknowledged at the end of this manuscript, and additional details on each culture are available on the ICMP website (http://www.landcareresearch.co.nz/resources/collections/icmp).

pdf:
Mycelium was collected from isolates grown on PDA agar, and
manually comminuted with a micropestle in 420 μL of Quiagen
DXT tissue digest buffer; 4.2 μL of proteinase K was added and
incubated at 55 °C for 1 h. After a brief centrifugation 220 μL of
the supernatant was placed in a Corbett X-tractorGene automated
nucleic acid extraction robot. The resulting 100 μL of pure DNA in
TE buffer was stored at -30 °C in 1.5 mL tubes until use.
txt: Mycelium was collected from isolates grown on PDA agar and manually comminuted with a micropestle in 420 μL of Qiagen DXT tissue digest buffer. To this, 4.2 μL of proteinase K was added and the mixture was incubated at 55 °C for 1 hour. After a brief centrifugation, 220 μL of the supernatant was transferred to a Corbett X-tractorGene automated nucleic acid extraction robot. The resulting 100 μL of pure DNA in TE buffer was stored at -30 °C in 1.5 mL tubes until use.

Gene sequences were obtained from eight nuclear gene regions,
actin (ACT) [316 bp], calmodulin (CAL) [756 bp], chitin synthase
(CHS-1) [229 bp], glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
(GAPDH) [308 bp], the ribosomal internal transcribed spacer
(ITS) [615 bp], glutamine synthetase (GS) [907 bp], manganesesuperoxide
dismutase (SOD2) [376 bp], and β-tubulin 2 (TUB2)
[716 bp].
txt: Gene sequences were obtained from eight nuclear gene regions: actin (ACT) [316 bp], calmodulin (CAL) [756 bp], chitin synthase (CHS-1) [229 bp], glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) [308 bp], the ribosomal internal transcribed spacer (ITS) [615 bp], glutamine synthetase (GS) [907 bp], manganese superoxide dismutase (SOD2) [376 bp], and β-tubulin 2 (TUB2) [716 bp].

pdf:
PCR Primers used during this study are shown in Table 2.
The standard CAL primers (O’Donnell et al. 2000) gave poor or
non-specific amplification for most isolates, thus new primers
(CL1C, CL2C) were designed for Colletotrichum based on the C.
graminicola M1.001 genome sequence. The standard GS primers
(Stephenson et al. 1997) sequenced poorly for some isolates due
to an approx. 9 bp homopolymer T run 71 bp in from the end of
the GSF1 primer binding site. A new primer, GSF3, was designed
41 bp downstream of this region to eliminate the homopolymer
slippage error from sequencing. The reverse primer GSR2 was
designed in the same location as GSR1 with one nucleotide
change. Both new GS primers were based on similarity with a
C. theobromicola UQ62 sequence (GenBank L78067, as C.
gloeosporioides).
txt: PCR primers used during this study are shown in Table 2. The standard CAL primers (O’Donnell et al. 2000) provided poor or non-specific amplification for most isolates, leading to the design of new primers (CL1C, CL2C) for Colletotrichum based on the C. graminicola M1.001 genome sequence. The standard GS primers (Stephenson et al. 1997) sequenced poorly for some isolates due to an approximately 9 bp homopolymer T run 71 bp from the end of the GSF1 primer binding site. A new primer, GSF3, was designed 41 bp downstream of this region to avoid the homopolymer slippage error in sequencing. The reverse primer GSR2 was designed similarly to GSR1, with one nucleotide change. Both new GS primers were based on similarity with a C. theobromicola UQ62 sequence (GenBank L78067, as C. gloeosporioides).

q3: How did the design of the new GS primers help resolve the sequencing issues encountered with the standard primers?
q4: Did the standard CAL primers provide poor or non-specific amplification for most isolates?
q5: Was a new primer, GSF3, designed to address a homopolymer slippage error in sequencing for the GS gene?
q6: Were the new GS primers based on similarity with a C. theobromicola sequence?

The PCRs were performed in an Applied Biosystems Veriti
Thermal Cycler in a total volume of 25 μL. The PCR mixtures
contained 15.8 μL of UV-sterilised ultra-filtered water, 2.5 μL of 10×
PCR buffer (with 20 mM MgCl2), 2.5 μL of dNTPs (each 20 μM), 1
μL of each primer (10 μM), 1 μL of BSA, 1 μL of genomic DNA, and
0.2 μL (1 U) of Roche FastStart Taq DNA Polymerase.

The PCR mixtures contained 15.8 μL of UV-sterilized ultra-filtered water, 2.5 μL of 10× PCR buffer (with 20 mM MgCl₂), 2.5 μL of dNTPs (each 20 μM), 1 μL of each primer (10 μM), 1 μL of BSA, 1 μL of genomic DNA, and 0.2 μL (1 U) of Roche FastStart Taq DNA Polymerase.

pdf:
The PCR conditions for ITS were 4 min at 95 °C, then 35
cycles of 95 °C for 30 s, 52 °C for 30 s, 72 °C for 45 s, and then
7 min at 72 °C. The annealing temperatures differed for the other
genes, with the optimum for each; ACT: 58 °C, CAL: 59 °C, CHS-
1: 58 °C, GAPDH: 60 °C, GS: 54 °C, SOD2: 54 °C, TUB2: 55
°C. Some isolates required altered temperatures and occasionally
gave multiple bands, which were excised separately from an
electrophoresis gel and purified. PCR Products were purified on a
Qiagen MinElute 96 UF PCR Purification Plate.
txt: The PCR conditions for ITS were as follows: 4 minutes at 95 °C, then 35 cycles of 95 °C for 30 seconds, 52 °C for 30 seconds, 72 °C for 45 seconds, followed by 7 minutes at 72 °C. The annealing temperatures for the other genes were optimized as follows: ACT at 58 °C, CAL at 59 °C, CHS-1 at 58 °C, GAPDH at 60 °C, GS at 54 °C, SOD2 at 54 °C, and TUB2 at 55 °C. Some isolates required adjusted temperatures and occasionally produced multiple bands, which were excised separately from an electrophoresis gel and purified. PCR products were purified using a Qiagen MinElute 96 UF PCR Purification Plate.

q2: How were the annealing temperatures optimized for the different genes, and what were the specific temperatures for ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, GS, SOD2, and TUB2?
q3: What steps were taken if some isolates produced multiple bands during PCR, and how were the PCR products purified?

pdf:
Multiple sequence alignments of each gene were made with
ClustalX v. 2.1 (Larkin et al. 2007), and manually adjusted where
necessary with Geneious Pro v. 5.5.6 (Drummond et al. 2011).
txt: Multiple sequence alignments of each gene were performed with ClustalX v. 2.1 (Larkin et al. 2007) and manually adjusted as necessary using Geneious Pro v. 5.5.6 (Drummond et al. 2011).
q1: Which software was used for performing multiple sequence alignments of each gene?
q2: How were the multiple sequence alignments adjusted after initial alignment with ClustalX?
q3: What version of Geneious Pro was used for manual adjustment of the sequence alignments?
q4: Was ClustalX v. 2.1 used for performing multiple sequence alignments?
q5: Were the alignments manually adjusted using Geneious Pro v. 5.5.6?
q6: Was Geneious Pro used in addition to ClustalX for sequence alignment adjustments?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Bayesian inference (BI) was used to reconstruct most of
the phylogenies using MrBayes v. 3.2.1 (Ronquist et al. 2012).
Bayesian inference has significant advantages over other methods
of analysis such as maximum likelihood and maximum parsimony
(Archibald et al. 2003) and provides measures of clade support as
posterior probabilities rather than random resampling bootstraps.
jModelTest v. 0.1.1 (Posada 2008) was used to carry out statistical
selection of best-fit models of nucleotide substitution using the
corrected Akaike information criteria (AICc) (Table 3). Initial
analyses showed that individual genes were broadly congruent,
thus nucleotide alignments of all genes were concatenated using
Geneious, and separate partitions created for each gene with
their own model of nucleotide substitution. Analyses on the full
data set were run twice for 5 x 107 generations, and twice for 2 x
107 generations for the clade trees. Samples were taken from the
posterior every 1000 generations. Convergence of all parameters
was checked using the internal diagnostics of the standard
deviation of split frequencies and performance scale reduction
factors (PSRF), and then externally with Tracer v. 1.5 (Rambaut
& Drummond 2007). On this basis the first 25 % of generations
were discarded as burn-in.
txt: Bayesian inference (BI) was used to reconstruct most of the phylogenies with MrBayes v. 3.2.1 (Ronquist et al. 2012). Bayesian inference offers significant advantages over other methods, such as maximum likelihood and maximum parsimony (Archibald et al. 2003), by providing clade support measures as posterior probabilities rather than random resampling bootstraps. jModelTest v. 0.1.1 (Posada 2008) was used for statistical selection of the best-fit models of nucleotide substitution using the corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc) (Table 3). Initial analyses showed broad congruence among individual genes, so nucleotide alignments of all genes were concatenated using Geneious, with separate partitions created for each gene and their respective models of nucleotide substitution. Analyses on the full dataset were conducted twice for 5 × 10⁷ generations and twice for 2 × 10⁷ generations for the clade trees. Samples were taken from the posterior every 1000 generations. Convergence of all parameters was checked using internal diagnostics of the standard deviation of split frequencies and performance scale reduction factors (PSRF), and externally with Tracer v. 1.5 (Rambaut & Drummond 2007). Based on these checks, the first 25% of generations were discarded as burn-in.
q1: Which software was used for Bayesian inference to reconstruct phylogenies, and what version was utilized?
q2: How did Bayesian inference provide clade support measures compared to other methods like maximum likelihood and maximum parsimony?
q3: What was the procedure for selecting the best-fit models of nucleotide substitution, and how were the nucleotide alignments managed?
q4: Was MrBayes v. 3.2.1 used for Bayesian inference in reconstructing phylogenies?
q5: Did Bayesian inference provide clade support as posterior probabilities rather than using bootstraps?
q6: Was jModelTest v. 0.1.1 used for selecting the best-fit models of nucleotide substitution?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
An initial BI analysis treated all 158 isolates using a concatenated
alignment for five of the genes, ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, and ITS.
Colletotrichum boninense and C. hippeastri were used as outgroups.
A second BI analysis, restricted to ex-type or authentic isolates
of each of the accepted species, was based on a concatenated
alignment of all eight genes. A third set of BI analyses treated
focussed on taxa within the Musae clade and the Kahawae clade.
For each clade, the ex-type or authentic isolates, together with 2–3
additional selected isolates of each accepted taxon where available,
were analysed using a concatenated alignment of all eight genes,
with C. gloeosporioides used as the outgroup for both analyses.
txt: An initial Bayesian inference (BI) analysis included all 158 isolates using a concatenated alignment of five genes: ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, and ITS. Colletotrichum boninense and C. hippeastri were used as outgroups. A second BI analysis, focusing on ex-type or authentic isolates of each accepted species, was based on a concatenated alignment of all eight genes. A third set of BI analyses focused on taxa within the Musae clade and the Kahawae clade. For each clade, the analyses included ex-type or authentic isolates, along with 2–3 additional selected isolates of each accepted taxon where available, using a concatenated alignment of all eight genes, with C. gloeosporioides as the outgroup for both analyses.
q1: What was included in the initial Bayesian inference (BI) analysis, and which outgroups were used?
q2: What was the focus of the second BI analysis, and which genes were used for the concatenated alignment?
q3: How were the third set of BI analyses structured, including the clades and outgroup used?
q4: Did the initial Bayesian inference analysis include a concatenated alignment of five genes with C. boninense and C. hippeastri as outgroups?
q5: Was the second Bayesian inference analysis based on a concatenated alignment of all eight genes, focusing on ex-type or authentic isolates of each accepted species?
q6: Were the third set of Bayesian inference analyses focused on the Musae and Kahawae clades, with C. gloeosporioides as the outgroup for both analyses?

pdf:
Several species-trees analyses were conducted using BEAST
v. 1.7.1 (Drummond et al. 2012). Species-trees combine multi-gene
and multiple isolate data to reconstruct the evolutionary history
of hypothesised species, rather than individual isolates. BEAST
does not use concatenation, but rather co-estimates the individual
gene trees embedded inside the summary species tree. It also
estimates the time since each species shared a common ancestor
(divergence times). For these analyses the species tree ancestral
reconstruction option was selected (Heled & Drummond 2010), the
gene data partitioned as for BI and the substitution model for each
gene was selected based on the models selected using jModelTest.
The individual isolates were grouped into sets of species by setting
species names as trait values. A strict clock was used for the
GAPDH gene (as an all intronic sequence it was assumed to be
accumulating mutations at a steady rate) and the other gene clock
rates were estimated relative to GAPDH, using an uncorrelated
lognormal relaxed clock. The species tree prior used for all genes
was the Yule process, with the ploidy type set to nuclear autosomal.
Uninformative priors were used for all parameters, and were
allowed to auto optimise.
txt: Several species-tree analyses were conducted using BEAST v. 1.7.1. Species-trees combine multi-gene and multiple isolate data to reconstruct the evolutionary history of hypothesized species, rather than individual isolates. BEAST does not use concatenation but rather co-estimates the individual gene trees embedded inside the summary species tree. It also estimates the time since each species shared a common ancestor (divergence times). For these analyses, the species tree ancestral reconstruction option was selected, the gene data partitioned as for BI, and the substitution model for each gene was selected based on models chosen using jModelTest. The individual isolates were grouped into species sets by setting species names as trait values. A strict clock was used for the GAPDH gene (as it is an all intronic sequence, it was assumed to be accumulating mutations at a steady rate), and the clock rates for other genes were estimated relative to GAPDH using an uncorrelated lognormal relaxed clock. The species tree prior for all genes was the Yule process, with the ploidy type set to nuclear autosomal. Uninformative priors were used for all parameters and were allowed to auto-optimize.
q1: How does BEAST estimate divergence times in species-tree analyses?
q2: What role does the GAPDH gene play in the molecular clock model used in this analysis?
q3: Why were individual isolates grouped into species sets for the BEAST analysis?
q4: Was the species tree prior for all genes based on the Yule process?
q5: Did BEAST co-estimate individual gene trees instead of concatenating them?
q6: Was the strict clock model applied to the GAPDH gene because it consists entirely of intronic sequences?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
The first species-tree analysis was conducted using the 158
isolate, five gene dataset, with C. boninense and C. hippeastri as
the outgroups. The MCMC chain was set to 1 × 108 generations
for the species complex tree and samples were taken from the
posterior every 1000 generations. The analysis was run twice
independently. The effective sample size (ESS) and traces of
all parameters and convergence of the two runs was checked
with Tracer and a summary maximum clade credibility species
tree was built with TreeAnnotator v. 1.7.1 (Drummond et al.
2012) using a 10 % burn-in and a posterior probability limit of
0.5, setting the heights of each node in the tree to the mean
height across the entire sample of trees for that clade. Separate
analyses were conducted using all eight genes and the same
restricted set of isolates chosen to represent taxa within the
Musae clade and the Kahawae clade as were used for the BI
analyses of the eight gene concatenated analyses outlined
above. For each of the Musae and Kahawae clade analyses,
the MCMC chain was set to 5 × 107 generations, but otherwise
run as for the five gene dataset.
txt:
The first species-tree analysis was performed using a dataset comprising 158 isolates and five genes, with C. boninense and C. hippeastri included as outgroups. The Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) chain was set to run for 1×108 generations for the species complex tree, with samples taken from the posterior every 1000 generations. This analysis was conducted independently in two runs. Convergence and effective sample size (ESS) for all parameters were evaluated using Tracer, and a maximum clade credibility species tree was generated with TreeAnnotator v. 1.7.1 (Drummond et al. 2012). The tree was constructed using a 10% burn-in and a posterior probability threshold of 0.5, with node heights set to the mean height across the entire sample of trees for each clade.
Separate analyses were conducted using all eight genes, focusing on a restricted set of isolates that represented taxa within the Musae and Kahawae clades, similar to those used in the Bayesian Inference (BI) analyses of the eight-gene concatenated dataset. For these analyses, the MCMC chain was set to 5×107 generations but otherwise followed the same procedures as the five-gene dataset.
q1: What outgroups were used in the first species-tree analysis?
q2: How was the maximum clade credibility species tree generated in this analysis?
q3: What was the purpose of using a restricted set of isolates in the eight-gene species-tree analysis?
q4: Was the species-tree analysis conducted with a dataset of 158 isolates and five genes?
q5: Were the MCMC chains for both the five-gene and eight-gene analyses set to sample the posterior every 1000 generations?
q6: Did the eight-gene analyses focus on isolates within the Musae and Kahawae clades?

pdf:
To illustrate the potential limitations of ITS to discriminate species
within the C. gloeosporioides complex, an UPGMA tree was built
of all 158 ITS sequences, using the Geneious tree builder tool. A
UPGMA tree visually approximates a BLAST search, which is based
on distances (and sequence length) rather than corrected nucleotide
substitutions of more sophisticated, model-based analyses.
txt: To highlight the potential limitations of ITS sequencing in discriminating species within the C. gloeosporioides complex, an UPGMA tree was constructed using all 158 ITS sequences with the Geneious tree builder tool. This UPGMA tree provides a visual approximation similar to a BLAST search, which relies on distance measures (and sequence length) rather than the corrected nucleotide substitutions used in more advanced, model-based analyses.
q1: What does the UPGMA tree reveal about the potential limitations of ITS sequencing in the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q2: How does the UPGMA tree compare to more advanced, model-based analyses in terms of the measures it uses?
q3: Why was the UPGMA tree constructed using all 158 ITS sequences?
q4: Was the UPGMA tree constructed with the Geneious tree builder tool?
q5: Does the UPGMA tree rely on distance measures rather than corrected nucleotide substitutions?
q6: Was the UPGMA tree used to highlight limitations of ITS sequencing for species discrimination within the C. gloeosporioides complex?

pdf:
Detailed morphological descriptions are provided only for those
species with no recently published description. Few specimens
were examined from infected host material; the descriptions
provided are mostly from agar cultures. Cultures were grown on
Difco PDA from single conidia, or from single hyphal tips for the few
specimens where no conidia were formed, with culture diameter
measured and appearance described after 10 d growth at 18–20 oC
under mixed white and UV fluorescent tubes, 12 h light/12 h dark.
Colour codes follow Kornerup & Wanscher (1963).
txt: Detailed morphological descriptions are provided only for species lacking recent descriptions. Few specimens were examined directly from infected host material; most descriptions are based on agar cultures. Cultures were grown on Difco PDA from single conidia or, for specimens that did not produce conidia, from single hyphal tips. Culture diameter and appearance were recorded after 10 days of growth at 18–20°C under mixed white and UV fluorescent lighting (12 hours light/12 hours dark). Color codes are based on Kornerup & Wanscher (1963).
q1: Why were detailed morphological descriptions only provided for certain species?
q2: How were cultures prepared for morphological examination in this study?
q3: What conditions were used to grow the cultures for description, and how was culture appearance recorded?
q4: Were most morphological descriptions based on observations from agar cultures?
q5: Were culture diameters recorded after 10 days of growth at 18–20°C?
q6: Did the study use Kornerup & Wanscher (1963) for color codes in describing cultures?

CAL	TIM1+G	TIM1+G	TrN+G
ACT	HKY+G	TrN	JC
CHS-1	TrNef+G	TrNef+G	K80
GS	TIM2+G	TIM3+G	-
SOD2	HKY+G	GTR+I+G	-
TUB2	TrN+G	HKY+G	-

pdf:
Species, subspecific taxa, and formae speciales within the C.
gloeosporioides species complex are treated alphabetically by
epithet. The names of formae speciales are not governed by the
International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (ICBN) (McNeill
et al. 2006, Art. 4, Note 4), and are hence enclosed in quotation
marks to indicate their invalid status. Other invalid names that
are governed by the ICBN are also enclosed in quotation marks.
Accepted names are marked with an asterisk (*). The breadth of
the taxonomic names treated includes:
all taxonomic names with DNA sequence data in GenBank
that place them in the C. gloeosporioides complex as it has been
defined here on the basis of the ITS gene tree. The sense that the
names were used in GenBank may have been misapplied;
names that have been used in the literature in recent years
for which a possible relationship to C. gloeosporioides has been
suggested;
all subspecific taxa and formae speciales within C.
gloeosporioides and Glomerella cingulata.
txt:
Species, subspecific taxa, and formae speciales within the C. gloeosporioides species complex are treated alphabetically by epithet. Names of formae speciales are not governed by the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (ICBN) (McNeill et al. 2006, Art. 4, Note 4) and are therefore enclosed in quotation marks to indicate their invalid status. Other invalid names governed by the ICBN are also enclosed in quotation marks. Accepted names are marked with an asterisk (*).

The breadth of the taxonomic names treated includes:

All taxonomic names with DNA sequence data in GenBank that place them in the C. gloeosporioides complex as defined here based on the ITS gene tree. Note that the sense in which names were used in GenBank may have been misapplied.
Names used in recent literature where a possible relationship to C. gloeosporioides has been suggested.
All subspecific taxa and formae speciales within C. gloeosporioides and Glomerella cingulata.

pdf:
DNA sequences of five genes were obtained from all 158 isolates
included in the study and concatenated to form a supermatrix of
2294 bp. The gene boundaries in the alignment were: ACT: 1–316,
CAL: 317–1072, CHS-1: 1073–1371, GAPDH: 1372–1679, ITS:
1680–2294. A BI analysis of the concatenated dataset is presented
in Fig.1. This tree is annotated with the species boundaries of the
taxa that we accept in the C. gloeosporioides complex, and the
clades representing these taxa formed the basis for investigating
the morphological and biological diversity of our species. Ex-type
and authentic isolates are highlighted in bold and labelled with the
names under which they were originally described. The posterior
probability (PP) support for the grouping of most species ranges
from 1 to 0.96, however support for deeper nodes is often lower,
e.g. 0.53 for the root of C. ti and C. aotearoa, indicating that the
branching may be uncertain for the root of these species. Branch
lengths and node PP are typically lower within a species than
between species.
txt: DNA sequences for five genes were obtained from all 158 isolates included in the study and concatenated to form a supermatrix of 2294 bp. The gene boundaries in the alignment were as follows: ACT: 1–316, CAL: 317–1072, CHS-1: 1073–1371, GAPDH: 1372–1679, and ITS: 1680–2294. A Bayesian inference (BI) analysis of the concatenated dataset is presented in Fig. 1. This tree is annotated with the species boundaries of the taxa accepted in the C. gloeosporioides complex, and the clades representing these taxa formed the basis for investigating the morphological and biological diversity of our species. Ex-type and authentic isolates are highlighted in bold and labeled with the names under which they were originally described. The posterior probability (PP) support for the grouping of most species ranges from 1 to 0.96; however, support for deeper nodes is often lower, e.g., 0.53 for the root of C. ti and C. aotearoa, indicating that the branching may be uncertain for the root of these species. Branch lengths and node PP are typically lower within a species compared to between species.
q1: How many genes were sequenced to create the supermatrix, and what is the total length of this supermatrix?
q2: What analysis method was used for the concatenated dataset, and what information does the resulting tree provide?
q3: How is the support for species grouping measured, and what variability is noted regarding deeper nodes?
q4: Were DNA sequences for five genes obtained from all 158 isolates in the study?
q5: Is the Bayesian inference analysis presented in a figure?
q6: Are ex-type and authentic isolates highlighted in bold in the tree?

pdf:
The large number of taxa in Fig. 1 makes it difficult to visualise
the interspecific genetic distance between the recognised species.
The unrooted tree in Fig. 2 represents the results of a BI analysis
based on a concatenation of all eight genes, but restricted to the
ex-type or authentic cultures from each of the accepted taxa. The
analysis was done without out-group taxa and clearly shows two
clusters of closely related species that we informally label the
Musae clade, and the Kahawae clade.
txt: The large number of taxa in Fig. 1 makes it challenging to visualize the interspecific genetic distances between the recognized species. To address this, Fig. 2 presents an unrooted tree based on a Bayesian inference (BI) analysis of all eight genes, but restricted to ex-type or authentic cultures from each of the accepted taxa. This analysis was conducted without out-group taxa and clearly delineates two clusters of closely related species, which we informally designate as the Musae clade and the Kahawae clade.
q1: What challenge is posed by the large number of taxa in Fig. 1 regarding the visualization of genetic distances?
q2: How does Fig. 2 differ from Fig. 1 in terms of the taxa included in the analysis?
q3: What informal names are given to the two clusters of closely related species identified in Fig. 2?
q4: Does Fig. 2 present an unrooted tree based on an analysis of all eight genes?
q5: Were out-group taxa included in the analysis for Fig. 2?
q6: Are the two clusters of closely related species referred to as the Musae clade and the Kahawae clade?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
To better resolve relationships within the Musae and Kahawae
clades a further set of BI analyses included eight genes and,
wherever possible, several representative isolates of each of the
accepted species. All eight gene sequences were concatenated
to form a supermatrix for each clade. For the Musae clade of
32 isolates the alignment was 4199 bp and the gene boundaries
were: ACT: 1–292, TUB2: 293–1008, CAL: 1009–1746, CHS-1:
1747–2045, GAPDH: 2046–2331, GS: 2332–3238, ITS: 3239–
3823, SOD2: 3824–4199. For the Kahawae clade of 30 isolates
the alignment was 4107 bp and the gene boundaries were: ACT:
1–281, TUB2: 282–988, CAL: 989–1728, CHS-1: 1729–2027,
GAPDH: 2028–2311, GS: 2312–3179, ITS: 3198–3733, SOD2:
3734–4107. The additional genes sequenced provided additional
support for our initial species delimitations with better resolution
for some closely related species. For example, the highly
pathogenic coffee berry isolates (referred to here as C. kahawae
subsp. kahawae) were distinguished from other C. kahawae
isolates.
txt: To better resolve relationships within the Musae and Kahawae clades, we conducted additional Bayesian inference (BI) analyses using all eight genes and, where possible, several representative isolates of each accepted species. The sequences from these eight genes were concatenated to form a supermatrix for each clade. For the Musae clade, which included 32 isolates, the alignment covered 4199 bp with the following gene boundaries: ACT: 1–292, TUB2: 293–1008, CAL: 1009–1746, CHS-1: 1747–2045, GAPDH: 2046–2331, GS: 2332–3238, ITS: 3239–3823, SOD2: 3824–4199. For the Kahawae clade, comprising 30 isolates, the alignment spanned 4107 bp with these gene boundaries: ACT: 1–281, TUB2: 282–988, CAL: 989–1728, CHS-1: 1729–2027, GAPDH: 2028–2311, GS: 2312–3179, ITS: 3198–3733, SOD2: 3734–4107. The additional genes sequenced provided enhanced support for our initial species delimitations and improved resolution for some closely related species. For instance, the highly pathogenic coffee berry isolates (designated here as C. kahawae subsp. kahawae) were effectively distinguished from other C. kahawae isolates.
q1: What was the purpose of conducting additional Bayesian inference analyses for the Musae and Kahawae clades?
q2: How many isolates were included in the Musae and Kahawae clades, and what were the respective lengths of their supermatrices?
q3: What specific advantage did the additional gene sequences provide regarding species delimitations?
q4: Were eight genes sequenced for both the Musae and Kahawae clades?
q5: Did the alignment for the Musae clade cover 4199 bp?
q6: Were highly pathogenic coffee berry isolates effectively distinguished from other C. kahawae isolates?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Analyses based on concatenated data sets can mask
incongruence between individual gene trees. The low levels of
support within some parts of the species-tree analysis (Fig. 3),
in part reflects incongruence between gene trees. The levels of
support for the Kahawae clade and for the Musae clade are strong
(PP=1) but the species that we accept within these clades have
lower levels of support than is shown between the other species
outside of the clades. The scale bar in Fig. 3 represents a time scale,
calibrated at zero for the present day, and at 1 for the last common
ancestor (LCA) of the C. gloeosporioides and C. boninense species
complexes. The separate species-tree analyses for the Musae and
Kahawae clades provide a finer resolution of evolutionary history
within each clade, the time scale based on the same calibration
as Fig. 3.
txt: Analyses based on concatenated datasets can obscure incongruences between individual gene trees. The low levels of support observed in certain areas of the species-tree analysis (Fig. 3) partly reflect such incongruence. While support for the Kahawae clade and the Musae clade is strong (PP=1), the species accepted within these clades exhibit lower support levels compared to the support between other species outside of the clades. The scale bar in Fig. 3 represents a time scale, with zero calibrated to the present day and one representing the last common ancestor (LCA) of the C. gloeosporioides and C. boninense species complexes. Separate species-tree analyses for the Musae and Kahawae clades offer more detailed resolution of evolutionary history within each clade, with the time scale calibrated similarly to Fig. 3.
q1: What issue can arise from analyses based on concatenated datasets concerning individual gene trees?
q2: How does the support level for species within the Kahawae and Musae clades compare to support levels for species outside of these clades?
q3: What does the scale bar in Fig. 3 represent regarding evolutionary time?
q4: Does the analysis in Fig. 3 show strong support (PP=1) for the Kahawae and Musae clades?
q5: Are the support levels for species within these clades lower than those for species outside the clades?
q6: Do separate species-tree analyses for the Musae and Kahawae clades provide a more detailed resolution of evolutionary history?

pdf:
The UPGMA-based ITS gene tree (Fig 6). shows that C.
theobromicola, C. horii, C. gloeosporioides, G. cingulata “f. sp.
camelliae”, C. asianum, C. musae, C. alatae, C. xanthorrhoeae all
form monophyletic clades and may be distinguished with ITS, but
many species are unable to be discriminated using this gene alone.
Note that C. cordylinicola and C. psidii are represented by a single
isolate, meaning that variation within ITS sequences across these
species has not been tested.
txt: The UPGMA-based ITS gene tree (Fig. 6) shows that species such as C. theobromicola, C. horii, C. gloeosporioides, G. cingulata “f. sp. camelliae”, C. asianum, C. musae, C. alatae, and C. xanthorrhoeae each form distinct monophyletic clades and can be distinguished using ITS sequences. However, many species cannot be reliably differentiated based on ITS alone. Additionally, C. cordylinicola and C. psidii are represented by only a single isolate each, so the variation within ITS sequences for these species has not been assessed.
q1: Which species form distinct monophyletic clades in the UPGMA-based ITS gene tree?

q4: Does the UPGMA-based ITS gene tree show that some species can be distinguished using ITS sequences?
q5: Are C. cordylinicola and C. psidii represented by more than one isolate each?
q6: Is it possible to reliably differentiate many species based solely on ITS sequences?

pdf:
Brief morphological descriptions, based on all specimens examined,
are provided for only those species with no recently published
description. Conidial sizes for all accepted species are summarised
in Fig. 7. Within a species, conidial sizes are reasonably consistent
across isolates, independent of geographic origin or host. However,
differences between species are often slight and size ranges often
overlap (Fig. 7). The shape of appressoria is generally consistent
within a species, some being simple in outline, others complex and
highly lobed.
txt: Brief morphological descriptions are provided for species lacking recent descriptions based on all specimens examined. Conidial sizes for all accepted species are summarized in Fig. 7. Within a species, conidial sizes are relatively consistent across isolates, regardless of geographic origin or host. However, differences between species are often subtle, and size ranges frequently overlap (Fig. 7). The shape of appressoria is generally consistent within a species, with some displaying a simple outline while others are complex and highly lobed.
q1: What type of descriptions are provided for species that lack recent morphological descriptions?
q2: How do conidial sizes vary within and between species, according to the passage?
q3: What variation is noted in the shape of appressoria among different species?
q4: Are conidial sizes summarized in Fig. 7?
q5: Is there consistency in conidial sizes within a species across different isolates?
q6: Do the shapes of appressoria vary significantly within a species?

pdf:
Several species are characterised in part by the development
of perithecia in culture. These include four species in the Musae
clade (C. alienum, C. fructicola, C. queenslandicum, and C.
salsolae) and three in the Kahawae clade (C. clidemiae, C.
kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C. ti). Ascospore size and shape
can be a useful species-level diagnostic feature (Fig. 8). In most
species the ascospores are strongly curved and typically tapering
towards the ends, but in C. clidemiae and C. ti, they are more or
less elliptic with broadly rounded ends and not, or only slightly,
curved. Individual isolates within any of these species may lose the
ability to form perithecia, perhaps associated with cultural changes
during storage.
txt: Several species are characterized by the development of perithecia in culture. These include four species in the Musae clade (C. alienum, C. fructicola, C. queenslandicum, and C. salsolae) and three in the Kahawae clade (C. clidemiae, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C. ti). Ascospore size and shape can be useful diagnostic features at the species level (Fig. 8). In most species, ascospores are strongly curved and typically taper towards the ends, while in C. clidemiae and C. ti, they are more or less elliptic with broadly rounded ends and are either not curved or only slightly so. Individual isolates within these species may lose the ability to form perithecia, potentially due to cultural changes during storage.
q1: Which species are noted for developing perithecia in culture, and how are they categorized?
q2: What diagnostic features of ascospores are mentioned as useful for distinguishing species?
q3: How can the ability to form perithecia vary among individual isolates within species?
q4: Are there four species in the Musae clade that develop perithecia in culture?
q5: Is ascospore size and shape considered a useful diagnostic feature at the species level?
q6: Can individual isolates lose the ability to form perithecia due to cultural changes during storage?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Large, dark-walled stromatic structures are present in the
cultures of some species not known to form perithecia. Often
embedded in agar, less commonly on the surface or amongst
the aerial mycelium, these structures differ from perithecia in
comprising a compact tissue of tightly tangled hyphae rather than
the pseudoparenchymatous, angular cells typical of perithecial
walls. They have a soft, leathery texture compared to the more
brittle perithecia. These stromatic structures sometimes develop
a conidiogenous layer internally, and following the production
of conidia they may split open irregularly, folding back to form a
stromatic, acervulus-like structure. These kind of structures are
also formed by some species in the C. boninense species complex
(Damm et al. 2012b, this issue).
txt: Large, dark-walled stromatic structures are present in the cultures of some species not known to form perithecia. Often embedded in agar, and less commonly on the surface or amongst the aerial mycelium, these structures differ from perithecia by consisting of a compact tissue of tightly tangled hyphae, rather than the pseudoparenchymatous, angular cells typical of perithecial walls. They have a soft, leathery texture, compared to the more brittle perithecia. These stromatic structures sometimes develop an internal conidiogenous layer; following conidia production, they may split open irregularly, folding back to form a stromatic, acervulus-like structure. Similar structures are also formed by some species in the C. boninense species complex (Damm et al. 2012b, this issue).
q1: How do the stromatic structures differ from perithecia in terms of their composition and texture?
q2: Under what conditions do stromatic structures typically develop, and what happens after conidia production?
q3: Which other species complex is mentioned as also forming similar stromatic structures?
q4: Are the stromatic structures embedded in agar or found on the surface of cultures?
q5: Do stromatic structures have a soft, leathery texture compared to the brittle texture of perithecia?
q6: Are similar structures formed by some species in the C. boninense species complex?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
The macroscopic appearance of the cultures is often highly
divergent within a species (e.g. C. fructicola and C. theobromicola),
in most cases probably reflecting different storage histories of the
isolates examined. Prolonged storage, especially with repeated
subculturing, results in staling of the cultures, the aerial mycelium
often becoming dense and uniform in appearance and colour, and
a loss of conidial and perithecial production, and variable in growth
rate (Fig. 9). In some species, individual single ascospore or single
conidial isolates show two markedly different cultural types, see
notes under C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro.
txt: The macroscopic appearance of cultures can vary significantly within a species (e.g., C. fructicola and C. theobromicola), often reflecting the different storage histories of the examined isolates. Prolonged storage, particularly with repeated subculturing, can lead to culture aging, with the aerial mycelium becoming dense and uniform in appearance and color. This can result in reduced conidial and perithecial production and variable growth rates (Fig. 9). In some species, individual single ascospore or single conidial isolates exhibit two distinctly different cultural types, as noted under C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro.
q1: How can the macroscopic appearance of cultures vary within a species, and what factors contribute to this variation?
q2: What effects can prolonged storage and repeated subculturing have on the appearance and productivity of cultures?
q3: In which species are two distinctly different cultural types observed in single ascospore or single conidial isolates?
q4: Does the macroscopic appearance of cultures vary significantly within species like C. fructicola and C. theobromicola?
q5: Can prolonged storage lead to reduced conidial and perithecial production?
q6: Are different cultural types observed in C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Some species appear to be host specialised, e.g. C. horii,
C. kahawae subsp. kahawae, C. nupharicola, C. salsolae, C. ti,
and C. xanthorrhoeae, but those most commonly isolated have
broad host and geographic ranges, e.g. C. fructicola, C. kahawae
subsp. ciggaro, C. siamense, and C. theobromicola. Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides s. str. is commonly isolated from Citrus in many
parts of the world, but has been isolated from other hosts as well,
such as Ficus, Mangifera, Pueraria, and Vitis. Not all of the species
with a broad host range are found everywhere, for example in New
Zealand C. alienum is commonly associated with cultivated fruits,
whereas species such as C. siamense and C. fructicola, common
on these same cultivated fruits in other parts of the world, have not
been reported from New Zealand.
txt: Some species appear to be host-specialized, such as C. horii, C. kahawae subsp. kahawae, C. nupharicola, C. salsolae, C. ti, and C. xanthorrhoeae. In contrast, those most commonly isolated tend to have broad host and geographic ranges, such as C. fructicola, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, C. siamense, and C. theobromicola. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu stricto is frequently isolated from Citrus in many parts of the world but has also been found on other hosts like Ficus, Mangifera, Pueraria, and Vitis. However, not all species with a broad host range are found globally. For instance, in New Zealand, C. alienum is commonly associated with cultivated fruits, while species such as C. siamense and C. fructicola, which are common on similar fruits elsewhere, have not been reported in New Zealand.
q1: Which species are mentioned as being host-specialized, and what is their characteristic?
q2: What types of species tend to have broad host and geographic ranges, and can you name a few examples?
q3: How does the distribution of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu stricto vary in relation to its host plants?
q4: Are some species of Colletotrichum considered host-specialized?
q5: Is Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu stricto frequently isolated from Citrus?
q6: Have species like C. siamense and C. fructicola been reported in New Zealand?

pdf:
Fig. 1. A Bayesian inference phylogenetic tree of 156 isolates in the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex. The tree was built using concatenated sequences of the
ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, and ITS genes each with a separate model of DNA evolution. Bayesian posterior probability values ≥ 0.5 are shown above nodes. Culture accession
numbers are listed along with host plant genus and country of origin. Ex-type and authentic cultures are emphasised in bold font, and include the taxonomic name as originally
described. Species delimitations are indicated with grey boxes. Colletotrichum boninense and C. hippeastri isolates are used as outgroups. The scale bar indicates the number
of expected changes per site.
txt: Fig. 1. Bayesian inference phylogenetic tree of 156 isolates in the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex. The tree was constructed using concatenated sequences of the ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, and ITS genes, each with its own model of DNA evolution. Bayesian posterior probability values ≥ 0.5 are shown above the nodes. Culture accession numbers are provided, along with the host plant genus and country of origin. Ex-type and authentic cultures are highlighted in bold font and include the taxonomic names as originally described. Species delimitations are indicated with grey boxes. Colletotrichum boninense and C. hippeastri isolates serve as outgroups. The scale bar represents the number of expected changes per site.
q1: What methods were used to construct the Bayesian inference phylogenetic tree for the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex?
q2: What information is provided alongside the nodes of the phylogenetic tree?
q3: How are ex-type and authentic cultures distinguished in the tree?
q4: Are Bayesian posterior probability values shown above the nodes in the tree?
q5: Do Colletotrichum boninense and C. hippeastri serve as outgroups in the analysis?
q6: Is the scale bar in the tree representative of the number of expected changes per site?

pdf:
Based on results of the multigene concatenated BI phylogenies,
we accept 22 species plus one subspecies within the C.
gloeosporioides complex. Isolates authentic for G. cingulata “f.
sp. camelliae” form a genetically distinct group, but this is not
formally named because of doubts over its relationship to C.
camelliae. Based on DNA sequence comparisons, a few other
isolates almost certainly represent additional unnamed species.
We do not formally describe them because most are known from
a single isolate, often stale, with little understanding of either their
morphological or biological diversity. In the Musae clade these
include ICMP 18614 and ICMP 18616, both from grape from
Japan, and ICMP 18726 from pawpaw from the Cook Islands,
and in the Kahawae clade ICMP 18699 from chestnut from Japan.
These isolates are not included in the phylogenies in this study,
but DNA sequences from these isolates have been accessioned
into GenBank (ITS: JX009423–JX009428, GAPDH: JX009416–
JX009422, ACT: JX009404–JX009407, CAL: JX009408–
JX009411, CHS-1: JX009412–JX009415).
txt: Based on the results of the multigene concatenated Bayesian inference (BI) phylogenies, we accept 22 species and one subspecies within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex. Isolates identified as Glomerella cingulata “f. sp. camelliae” form a genetically distinct group; however, this is not formally named due to uncertainties regarding its relationship to C. camelliae. DNA sequence comparisons suggest that a few other isolates likely represent additional unnamed species. These are not formally described because most are represented by a single, often stale isolate, and there is limited understanding of their morphological and biological diversity. In the Musae clade, these include ICMP 18614 and ICMP 18616 from grape in Japan, and ICMP 18726 from pawpaw in the Cook Islands. In the Kahawae clade, ICMP 18699 from chestnut in Japan is included. Although these isolates are not included in the phylogenies presented in this study, their DNA sequences have been accessioned into GenBank (ITS: JX009423–JX009428, GAPDH: JX009416–JX009422, ACT: JX009404–JX009407, CAL: JX009408–JX009411, CHS-1: JX009412–JX009415).
q1: How many species and subspecies are accepted within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex based on the multigene concatenated Bayesian inference phylogenies?
q2: Why are some isolates not formally described as new species despite being genetically distinct?
q3: Which specific isolates from the Musae and Kahawae clades are mentioned as likely representing additional unnamed species?
q4: Are isolates identified as Glomerella cingulata “f. sp. camelliae” considered a genetically distinct group?
q5: Are the DNA sequences of the unnamed isolates accessioned into GenBank?
q6: Do the isolates from Japan and the Cook Islands have limited understanding of their morphological and biological diversity?

Fig. 2. An unrooted Bayesian inference phylogenetic tree
of ex-type and authentic cultures of the 24 taxa within
the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex,
illustrating their relative genetic distances, as indicated by
branch lengths. There are two clusters within the species
complex, the ‘Musae clade’ and the ‘Kahawae clade’. The
tree was build using concatenated sequences of the ACT,
TUB2, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, GS, ITS, and SOD2 genes
each with a separate model of DNA evolution.
txt: Fig. 2. An unrooted Bayesian inference phylogenetic tree of ex-type and authentic cultures of the 24 taxa within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex, illustrating their relative genetic distances as indicated by branch lengths. The tree reveals two clusters within the species complex: the ‘Musae clade’ and the ‘Kahawae clade’. The analysis used concatenated sequences from the ACT, TUB2, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, GS, ITS, and SOD2 genes, each analyzed with a separate model of DNA evolution.

Fig. 3. A Bayesian inference species-tree of the C. gloeosporioides species complex. The tree was built by grouping all 158 isolates into species and simultaneously estimating
the individual five gene trees (ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, and ITS) and the summary species tree using BEAST. The scale is an uncalibrated clock set relative to the last
common ancestor of the C. gloeosporioides and C. boninense species complexes.
txt: Fig. 3. A Bayesian inference species-tree of the C. gloeosporioides species complex. The tree was constructed by grouping all 158 isolates into species and simultaneously estimating individual gene trees (ACT, CAL, CHS-1, GAPDH, and ITS) and the summary species tree using BEAST. The scale represents an uncalibrated clock, set relative to the last common ancestor of the C. gloeosporioides and C. boninense species complexes.

pdf:
Many of the species that we recognise fall into one of two
clades, the informally named Musae clade and Kahawae clade (Fig.
2). Each clade contains several species that are phylogenetically
well supported in multi-gene analyses, but within the clades branch
lengths are short because of the small number of phylogenetically
informative characters. This is reflected in the low support values in
the gene tree analyses for the species we accept within that clade
(Figs 3, 4). Both the Musae and Kahawae clades contain ex-type
or authentic cultures from several long accepted species. In this
work we have made a pragmatic decision to minimise taxonomic
disruption, so that monophyletic subclades within the Kahawae
and Musae clades are accepted as species where they include
ex-type or authentic cultures. The Musae clade thus includes C.
fructicola, C. musae, C. nupharicola, C. siamense, and C. tropicale;
and the Kahawae clade includes C. cordylinicola, C. psidii, and C.
kahawae. Also belonging in the latter is Glomerella cingulata “f.
sp. camelliae”. To provide a consistent taxonomic treatment of the
subclades resolved within the Musae and Kahawae clades, several
new species and one new subspecies are proposed. In the Musae
clade these are C. aenigma, C. aeschynomenes, C. alienum,
C. queenslandicum, and C. salsolae; in the Kahawae clade C.
aotearoa, C. clidemiae, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C. ti. The
other accepted species, well resolved in all of the gene trees, are C.
alatae, C. asianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. horii, C. theobromicola,
and C. xanthorrhoeae.
txt: Many of the species we recognize fall into one of two clades: the informally named Musae clade and the Kahawae clade (Fig. 2). Each clade contains several species that are phylogenetically well supported in multi-gene analyses, but within the clades, branch lengths are short due to the limited number of phylogenetically informative characters. This is reflected in the low support values in the gene tree analyses for the species accepted within these clades (Figs. 3, 4). Both the Musae and Kahawae clades include ex-type or authentic cultures from several long-accepted species. In this work, we have opted for a pragmatic approach to minimize taxonomic disruption, accepting monophyletic subclades within the Kahawae and Musae clades as species if they include ex-type or authentic cultures. Consequently, the Musae clade includes C. fructicola, C. musae, C. nupharicola, C. siamense, and C. tropicale; and the Kahawae clade includes C. cordylinicola, C. psidii, and C. kahawae. Also within the Kahawae clade is Glomerella cingulata “f. sp. camelliae”. To ensure a consistent taxonomic treatment of the subclades resolved within the Musae and Kahawae clades, several new species and one new subspecies are proposed: C. aenigma, C. aeschynomenes, C. alienum, C. queenslandicum, and C. salsolae in the Musae clade; and C. aotearoa, C. clidemiae, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C. ti in the Kahawae clade. Other accepted species, well resolved in all gene trees, include C. alatae, C. asianum, C. gloeosporioides, C. horii, C. theobromicola, and C. xanthorrhoeae.
q1: What criteria were used to accept species within the Musae and Kahawae clades?
q2: Which species are included in the Musae and Kahawae clades, and what new species or subspecies are proposed in this work?
q3: How do the branch lengths within the clades reflect the number of phylogenetically informative characters?
q4: Do the Musae and Kahawae clades contain several species that are phylogenetically well supported?
q5: Is Glomerella cingulata “f. sp. camelliae” included within the Kahawae clade?
q6: Are new species and a new subspecies proposed for both the Musae and Kahawae clades?

Fig. 6. An UPGMA tree of ITS sequences from 156 isolates in the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex. Isolate names have been replaced with species present
in each clade. Species that are in monophyletic clades are emphasised in bold font to indicate those for which ITS barcoding is likely to work well. B: A 50 % majority-rule
consensus Bayesian inference tree of the same data, showing the collapse of structure when analysed with a more robust method.
txt: Fig. 6. An UPGMA tree of ITS sequences from 156 isolates in the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex. Isolate names have been replaced with species present in each clade. Species that form monophyletic clades are emphasized in bold font to indicate those for which ITS barcoding is likely to work well. Panel B: A 50% majority-rule consensus Bayesian inference tree of the same data, illustrating the collapse of structure when analyzed with a more robust method.

pdf:
* Colletotrichum aenigma B. Weir & P.R. Johnst., sp. nov.
MycoBank MB563759. Fig. 10.
Etymology: from the Latin aenigma, based on the enigmatic
biological and geographic distribution of this species.
Holotype: Israel, on Persea americana, coll. S. Freeman Avo-37-
4B, PDD 102233; ex-holotype culture ICMP 18608.
Colonies grown from single conidia on Difco PDA 30–35 mm
diam after 10 d. Aerial mycelium sparse, cottony, white, surface
of agar uniformly pale orange (7A5) towards centre, more
or less colourless towards edge, conidia not associated with
well differentiated acervuli and no masses of conidial ooze. In
reverse pale orange towards centre. Conidiogenous cells arising
haphazardly from dense, tangled hyphae across agar surface,
short-cylindric with a poorly differentiated conidiogenous locus.
Conidia often germinating soon after release, sometimes forming
appressoria, so forming a thin, compact, layer of germinated,
septate conidia, germ tubes, and appressoria across the central
part of the colony surface. Conidia (12–)14–15(–16.5) × (5–)6–
6.5(–7.5) μm (av. 14.5 × 6.1 μm, n = 53), cylindric with broadly
rounded ends. Appressoria 6–10 μm diam, subglobose or with a
few broad lobes.
Geographic distribution and host range: known from only two
collections, one from Pyrus pyrifolia from Japan, the other from
Persea americana from Israel.
Genetic identification: ITS sequences are insufficient to separate C.
aenigma from C. alienum and some C. siamense isolates. These
taxa are best distinguished using TUB2 or GS.
Notes: Although the biology of this species is more or less unknown,
it has been found in two widely separate regions and is, therefore,
likely to be found to be geographically widespread in the future.
Genetically distinct within the Musae clade, this species has a
distinctive appearance in culture with sparse, pale aerial mycelium
and lacking differentiated acervuli.
Other specimen examined: Japan, on Pyrus pyrifolia, coll. H. Ishii Nashi-10 (ICMP
18686).
txt:
Colletotrichum aenigma B. Weir & P.R. Johnst., sp. nov.
MycoBank MB563759. Fig. 10.

Etymology: From the Latin aenigma, based on the enigmatic biological and geographic distribution of this species.

Holotype: Israel, on Persea americana, coll. S. Freeman Avo-37-4B, PDD 102233; ex-holotype culture ICMP 18608.

Colony Description: Colonies grown from single conidia on Difco PDA are 30–35 mm in diameter after 10 days. Aerial mycelium is sparse, cottony, and white, with the surface of the agar being uniformly pale orange (7A5) towards the center and more or less colorless towards the edge. Conidia are not associated with well-differentiated acervuli or masses of conidial ooze. In reverse, the color is pale orange towards the center. Conidiogenous cells arise haphazardly from dense, tangled hyphae across the agar surface, being short-cylindric with a poorly differentiated conidiogenous locus. Conidia often germinate soon after release, sometimes forming appressoria and a thin, compact layer of germinated, septate conidia, germ tubes, and appressoria across the central part of the colony surface. Conidia measure (12–)14–15(–16.5) × (5–)6–6.5(–7.5) μm (average 14.5 × 6.1 μm, n = 53), cylindric with broadly rounded ends. Appressoria are 6–10 μm in diameter, subglobose or with a few broad lobes.

Geographic Distribution and Host Range: Known from only two collections, one from Pyrus pyrifolia in Japan and the other from Persea americana in Israel.

Genetic Identification: ITS sequences are insufficient to separate C. aenigma from C. alienum and some C. siamense isolates. These taxa are best distinguished using TUB2 or GS.

Notes: Although the biology of this species is more or less unknown, it has been found in two widely separate regions and is likely to be found geographically widespread in the future. It is genetically distinct within the Musae clade and has a distinctive appearance in culture with sparse, pale aerial mycelium and lacking differentiated acervuli.

Other Specimen Examined: Japan, on Pyrus pyrifolia, coll. H. Ishii Nashi-10 (ICMP 18686).
q1: What are the key morphological characteristics of Colletotrichum aenigma as described in the passage?
q2: Why is the species named "aenigma," and what does this name suggest about its distribution?
q3: What molecular markers are suggested for distinguishing C. aenigma from other similar species?
q4: Is Colletotrichum aenigma known from only two collections?
q5: Are ITS sequences sufficient for distinguishing C. aenigma from C. alienum and some C. siamense isolates?
q6: Is the species described as having sparse, pale aerial mycelium and lacking differentiated acervuli?
