pdf:
Molecular tools are increasingly being used for day-to-day
identification by biosecurity officers and plant pathology researchers,
providing a need for both a taxonomy that closely reflects groups that
are resolved genetically, as well as simple and reliable protocols for
identifying those taxa. The internal transcribed spacer region (ITS)
has been proposed as the official fungal barcoding gene (Schoch
et al. 2012). Although ITS is useful at the species complex level, it
does a poor job of resolving species within the C. gloeosporioides
complex, resolving only 10 of 22 accepted species. This reflects
the low number of base changes in the ITS region across the C.
gloeosporioides complex; species often distinguished by only one
or two base changes. In some cases, chance variation in the ITS
sequence within or between species means that some species
cannot be distinguished (Fig. 6). Examples of taxa with identical
ITS sequences include C. clidemiae, C. tropicale, C. ti and some
C. siamense isolates; C. fructicola and some C. siamense isolates;
and C. alienum, C. aenigma and some C. siamense isolates.
txt: Molecular tools are becoming essential for daily identification tasks performed by biosecurity officers and plant pathology researchers. This necessitates a taxonomy that aligns closely with genetically resolved groups, as well as straightforward and reliable protocols for identifying those taxa. The internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region has been proposed as the official fungal barcoding gene (Schoch et al. 2012). While ITS is useful at the species complex level, it struggles to resolve species within the C. gloeosporioides complex, identifying only 10 out of 22 accepted species. This limitation is due to the low number of base changes in the ITS region across the complex, where species are often distinguished by just one or two base changes. Additionally, random variations in the ITS sequence within or between species can result in some species being indistinguishable. For example, taxa with identical ITS sequences include C. clidemiae, C. tropicale, C. ti, and some C. siamense isolates; as well as C. fructicola and some C. siamense isolates; and C. alienum, C. aenigma, along with certain C. siamense isolates.
q1: Why is the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region proposed as the official fungal barcoding gene?
q2: What challenges does the ITS region present for resolving species within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q3: Can you name some species that share identical ITS sequences, making them indistinguishable?
q4: Are molecular tools essential for biosecurity officers and plant pathology researchers?
q5: Does the ITS region effectively distinguish all species within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q6: Is the low number of base changes in the ITS region a contributing factor to the difficulty in identifying species within the complex?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Protein-coding genes and their introns often have more
variation than ITS, and the need for secondary barcodes based
on these kinds of genes has been discussed in relation to some
groups of fungi (Fitzpatrick et al. 2006, Aguileta et al. 2008, Weir
& Johnston 2011). Ideally, one of the seven protein coding genes
that were used in this study could be proposed as a secondary
barcode to obtain an accurate identification of species within the
C. gloeosporioides complex. A preliminary analysis of the genes
performance as barcodes was conducted as part of Cai et al.
(2009) with GAPDH, CAL, and ACT performing well, but CHS-
1, ITS, and TEF (EF1α) poorly. However, the analysis (Cai et al.
2009) included only five species within the C. gloeosporioides
complex, the Musae and Kahawae clades being treated at the level
of species. With the final classification presented here, none of
the genes we analysed provides an effective barcode ont its own
across the entire complex. Of the single genes, TUB2, GS, and
GAPDH are amongst the most effective at distinguishing species.
However, C. clidemiae is polyphyletic in the TUB2 gene tree and
GS sequences are needed to distinguish C. fructicola and C.
alienum. With GS, C. aotearoa, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C.
siamense are paraphyletic. GAPDH is the easiest of all the genes
tested to amplify and sequence, however when using this gene GS
sequences are needed to distinguish C. fructicola from C. alienum
and C. aeschynomenes from C. siamense, and C. tropicale is
paraphyletic. In the species descriptions we provide notes on which
genes are the best for genetic identifications, and in Table 4 these
are summarised for all species and genes. For species represented
by a single or only a few isolates the species boundaries may not
be accurate, we recommend two protein-coding genes in addition
to ITS for sequence-based identifications. A meta-analysis of
DNA barcodes across the whole genus will be required to find the
combination of genes that are effective for all species of the genus
that distinguish all Colletotrichum species.
txt:
Protein-coding genes and their introns typically exhibit greater variation than the ITS region, highlighting the need for secondary barcodes based on these genes, as discussed in various studies (Fitzpatrick et al. 2006, Aguileta et al. 2008, Weir & Johnston 2011). Ideally, one of the seven protein-coding genes used in this study could serve as a secondary barcode for accurate identification of species within the C. gloeosporioides complex. A preliminary analysis by Cai et al. (2009) assessed the barcoding potential of these genes, finding that GAPDH, CAL, and ACT performed well, whereas CHS-1, ITS, and TEF (EF1α) were less effective. However, this analysis included only five species from the complex, treating the Musae and Kahawae clades at the species level.

With the comprehensive classification presented here, none of the genes analyzed serve as effective standalone barcodes across the entire complex. Among the single genes, TUB2, GS, and GAPDH are identified as the most effective for distinguishing species. However, C. clidemiae appears polyphyletic in the TUB2 gene tree, and GS sequences are necessary to differentiate C. fructicola from C. alienum. The use of GS reveals that C. aotearoa, C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro, and C. siamense are paraphyletic.

GAPDH is noted as the easiest gene to amplify and sequence. However, it also requires GS sequences to distinguish C. fructicola from C. alienum and C. aeschynomenes from C. siamense, while C. tropicale shows paraphyly. The species descriptions include recommendations on the best genes for genetic identification, and Table 4 summarizes these recommendations for all species and genes. For species represented by only a single or a few isolates, species boundaries may be uncertain; therefore, it is recommended to use two protein-coding genes alongside ITS for sequence-based identifications. A meta-analysis of DNA barcodes across the genus is needed to identify the optimal gene combination effective for distinguishing all Colletotrichum species.
q1: Which protein-coding genes showed good barcoding potential according to the preliminary analysis by Cai et al. (2009)?
q2: What are the challenges in using TUB2 and GS sequences for distinguishing certain Colletotrichum species?
q3: Why is it recommended to use two protein-coding genes alongside ITS for identifying species represented by few isolates?
q4: Do protein-coding genes and their introns exhibit greater variation than the ITS region?
q5: Is GAPDH considered the easiest gene to amplify and sequence among those analyzed?
q6: Does the study suggest that none of the analyzed genes serve as effective standalone barcodes for the entire C. gloeosporioides complex?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Several studies have shown that cultural morphology can be
useful for grouping isolates when they are sampled at a local or
regional level (e.g. Johnston & Jones 1997, Prihastuti et al. 2009).
However, our experience is that such groups often break down
when the geographic sample within a clade is extended to a global
scale. Many of the species we accept have few or no diagnostic
morphological or cultural features that can be consistently and
reliably used to identify them. Our morphological examinations
were confined to cultures on Difco PDA agar plates, and we will
have missed any features that develop solely in association with
plant material. In addition, the cultures we used have been sourced
from different labs and collections from around the world, many
with no information on storage history. Storage history and method
has a major impact on the appearance of Colletotrichum in culture.
Cultures can become “stale” during storage, losing the ability to
produce pigments, the aerial mycelium often becoming very dense
and felted, and losing the ability to form well-differentiated acervuli,
conidia, or perithecia. In some clades, even freshly isolated cultures
are highly variable, forming distinct sectors with differences in the
production of pigment, aerial mycelium, acervuli, and conidia.
Some isolates form two very different cultural types from single
conidia or ascospores derived from colonies themselves started
from single ascospores. Figure 27F shows single ascospore
cultures from an isolate of C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro. One has
the typical appearance of cultures of this fungus isolated from the
field. The other, with a uniform, dense layer of conidia across the
colony surface without well differentiated acervuli and more or less
no aerial mycelium, is common from single ascospore isolates in
culture, but rarely found in cultures isolated directly from the field.
This kind of variation, and that revealed from sectoring during
colony growth, makes morphological variation difficult to interpret
for accurate identification.
txt: Several studies have shown that cultural morphology can be useful for grouping isolates when sampled at a local or regional level. However, our experience indicates that such groups often break down when the geographic sample within a clade is extended to a global scale. Many of the species we accept lack consistent and reliable diagnostic morphological or cultural features for identification. Our morphological examinations were confined to cultures on Difco PDA agar plates, which means we may have missed features that develop solely in association with plant material. Additionally, the cultures we used were sourced from different labs and collections worldwide, many of which had no information on storage history. Storage history and method significantly impact the appearance of Colletotrichum in culture. Cultures can become “stale” during storage, losing the ability to produce pigments, with the aerial mycelium often becoming very dense and felted, and they may lose the ability to form well-differentiated acervuli, conidia, or perithecia. In some clades, even freshly isolated cultures are highly variable, forming distinct sectors with differences in the production of pigment, aerial mycelium, acervuli, and conidia. Some isolates produce two very different cultural types from single conidia or ascospores derived from colonies started from single ascospores. One example shows single ascospore cultures from an isolate of C. kahawae subsp. ciggaro. One culture has the typical appearance of this fungus isolated from the field, while the other features a uniform, dense layer of conidia across the colony surface without well-differentiated acervuli and minimal aerial mycelium, which is common from single ascospore isolates but rarely found in cultures isolated directly from the field. This kind of variation, along with that revealed from sectoring during colony growth, complicates the interpretation of morphological variation for accurate identification.
q1: What factors contribute to the variability of Colletotrichum cultures when sampled from different geographic regions?
q2: How does the storage history of cultures affect their morphological features?
q3: What implications does the observed morphological variation have for the identification of Colletotrichum species?
q4: Do cultural morphology and geographic sampling influence the grouping of Colletotrichum isolates?
q5: Is it possible for a single isolate of Colletotrichum to produce different cultural types?
q6: Does the method of storage have an impact on the appearance of Colletotrichum in culture?

pdf:
Many of the species recognised in this work remain poorly
understood in terms of their pathogenicity and host preference.
This in part reflects a lack of certainty about the biological
relationship between the fungi and the plants from which they
were isolated. Species that are pathogenic on one host can
also be isolated from others following opportunistic colonisation
of senescing tissue, such as the C. salicis example discussed
by Johnston (2000, as Glomerella miyabeana). The multiple
Colletotrichum spp. associated with a single host are likely to
have a variety of life styles: primary pathogens of healthy tissue,
species with the ability to invade and cause minor disease
when the host plant is under stress, species that develop latent
infections and fruit only following senescence of the host tissue
or ripening of host fruit and endophytic species that sporulate
only following host tissue death. The combination of this range of
distinct life styles, the fact that several Colletotrichum spp. may
become established on a single host, and the ability of most of
these species to also establish on a range of other hosts, has
been a large part of the confusion surrounding species limits
within Colletotrichum.
txt: Many of the species recognized in this work remain poorly understood in terms of their pathogenicity and host preference. This partly reflects a lack of certainty about the biological relationship between the fungi and the plants from which they were isolated. Species that are pathogenic on one host can also be isolated from others following opportunistic colonization of senescing tissue, such as the example of C. salicis discussed by Johnston. The multiple Colletotrichum spp. associated with a single host are likely to exhibit a variety of lifestyles: primary pathogens of healthy tissue, species that can invade and cause minor disease when the host plant is under stress, species that develop latent infections and fruit only following senescence of the host tissue or ripening of host fruit, and endophytic species that sporulate only after host tissue death. The combination of this range of distinct lifestyles, the fact that several Colletotrichum spp. may establish on a single host, and the ability of most of these species to also thrive on a range of other hosts contributes significantly to the confusion surrounding species limits within Colletotrichum.
q1: What factors contribute to the confusion regarding species limits within the Colletotrichum genus?
q2: How do different lifestyles of Colletotrichum species affect their pathogenicity and host preferences?
q3: In what ways does opportunistic colonization complicate the understanding of Colletotrichum species?
q4: Are many Colletotrichum species poorly understood in terms of their pathogenicity and host preference?
q5: Can a single host plant be associated with multiple species of Colletotrichum?
q6: Do some Colletotrichum species only sporulate after the death of host tissue?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
In some cases, apparently clear differences in pathogenicity
of isolates in the C. gloeosporioides complex are not reflected
genetically. For example, the fungi referred to as C. gloeosporioides
f. stylosanthis “f. sp. guianensis” and C. gloeosporioides f.
stylosanthis “f. sp. stylosanthis”, are reportedly associated with two
distinct diseases of Stylosanthes (Irwin & Cameron 1978; Munaut
et al. 2002), but both taxa genetically match C. theobromicola and
are here placed in synonymy with C. theobromicola. It is possible
that screening additional genes across a set of isolates from
Stylosanthes with known pathogenicity will reveal one or more
genes that generate a phylogeny that correlates with pathogenicity.
This is the case with another specialised pathogen, C. kahawae.
Originally described as a pathogen of green coffee berries, almost
genetically identical isolates have subsequently been found on a
wide range of hosts (see notes under C. kahawae). The isolates
from other hosts are not pathogenic to coffee berries (Silva et al.
2012b). The difference in pathogenicity correlates with a genetic
difference in the GS gene, and we taxonomically recognise this
biologically specialised population at the subspecies level. A similar
approach could potentially be taken for other biologically distinct
populations within a genetically strongly supported species.
txt: In some cases, apparently clear differences in the pathogenicity of isolates in the C. gloeosporioides complex are not reflected genetically. For example, the fungi referred to as C. gloeosporioides f. stylosanthis “f. sp. guianensis” and C. gloeosporioides f. stylosanthis “f. sp. stylosanthis” are reportedly associated with two distinct diseases of Stylosanthes, but both taxa genetically match C. theobromicola and are placed in synonymy with it here. It is possible that screening additional genes across a set of isolates from Stylosanthes with known pathogenicity will reveal one or more genes that generate a phylogeny correlating with pathogenicity. This is also the case with another specialized pathogen, C. kahawae. Originally described as a pathogen of green coffee berries, almost genetically identical isolates have subsequently been found on a wide range of hosts. The isolates from other hosts are not pathogenic to coffee berries. The difference in pathogenicity correlates with a genetic difference in the GS gene, leading us to taxonomically recognize this biologically specialized population at the subspecies level. A similar approach could potentially be taken for other biologically distinct populations within a genetically strongly supported species.
q1: How do genetic similarities among isolates in the C. gloeosporioides complex complicate the understanding of their pathogenicity?
q2: What role do additional genetic screenings play in elucidating the relationship between pathogenicity and phylogeny?
q3: In what ways does the case of C. kahawae illustrate the importance of genetic differences in determining pathogenicity across different hosts?
q4: Do some isolates in the C. gloeosporioides complex exhibit clear differences in pathogenicity despite genetic similarities?
q5: Has the GS gene been linked to differences in pathogenicity for C. kahawae isolates?
q6: Could a similar genetic approach be useful for distinguishing other biologically distinct populations within a genetically supported species?

metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Despite the epitypification of C. gloeosporioides in 2008, web
search hits on the name C. gloeosporioides from papers published
over the past 12 mo show that many authors will continue to use
the name in the sense of the C. gloeosporioides species complex,
presumably regarding this level of identification as sufficient for their
research. All of the isolates that we accept in the C. gloeosporioides
complex share the string 5’–GGGCGGGT–3’ about 139–142 bases
after the ITS1F primer binding site. Based on a comparison with
GenBank data, this string appears to be specific to isolates that
we would accept as members of the C. gloeosporioides complex.
Several authors have developed PCR-based, rapid identification
tools for distinguishing members of the C. gloeosporioides complex
from members of the C. acutatum species complex. This has been
prompted because some members of the C. acutatum complex
have conidia without the acute ends characteristic of this species as
described by Simmonds (1965), and have at times been confused
with C. gloeosporioides (Damm et al. 2012, this issue). Primers
reportedly specific to C. gloeosporioides include the CgInt primer for
ITS (Mills et al. 1992). In our data set this primer sequence is found
in C. gloeosporioides s. str., C. fructicola, and C. siamense but all
of the other taxa that we recognise within the C. gloeosporioides
complex have one or more bases not matching the CgInt primer.
The practical impact of these differences will depend in part on
the position of the mismatch and stringency of the PCR reaction.
Talhinas et al. (2005) discussed the TBCG primer for β-tubulin,
and this is found within all of our taxa within the C. gloeosporioides
group except C. musae and C. asianum. Liu et al. (2011) describe
characteristic RFLP bands from glutamine synthetase using the
restriction enzyme Pst1. Based on our sequences, this method will
generate the characteristic C. gloeosporioides bands reported by Liu
et al. (2011) for C. aenigma, C. alienum, C. aotearoa, C. asianum,
C. clidemiae, C. cordylinicola, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides s.
str., C. horii, C. queenslandicum, C. salsolae, C. siamense, C. ti,
and C. tropicale. Different banding patterns will be produced by C.
aeschynomenes (band sizes 253, 316, 388), the two C. kahawae
subspp. (band sizes 112, 388, 457), G. cingulata “f. sp. camelliae”
(band sizes 51, 112, 337, 457), and C. musae (band sizes 388,
552), but none match the bands reported for C. acutatum by these
authors.
txt: Despite the epitypification of C. gloeosporioides in 2008, web search hits on the name C. gloeosporioides from papers published over the past 12 months show that many authors continue to use the name in the context of the C. gloeosporioides species complex, presumably regarding this level of identification as sufficient for their research. All the isolates we accept in the C. gloeosporioides complex share the sequence 5’–GGGCGGGT–3’ approximately 139–142 bases after the ITS1F primer binding site. Based on a comparison with GenBank data, this sequence appears to be specific to isolates we would recognize as members of the C. gloeosporioides complex. Several authors have developed PCR-based rapid identification tools for distinguishing members of the C. gloeosporioides complex from those of the C. acutatum species complex. This effort has been prompted by the fact that some members of the C. acutatum complex have conidia without the acute ends characteristic of this species, as described by Simmonds, and have occasionally been confused with C. gloeosporioides. Primers reportedly specific to C. gloeosporioides include the CgInt primer for ITS. In our dataset, this primer sequence is found in C. gloeosporioides s. str., C. fructicola, and C. siamense, but all other taxa we recognize within the C. gloeosporioides complex have one or more bases that do not match the CgInt primer. The practical impact of these differences will depend in part on the position of the mismatch and the stringency of the PCR reaction. Talhinas et al. discussed the TBCG primer for β-tubulin, which is found in all our taxa within the C. gloeosporioides group except C. musae and C. asianum. Liu et al. describe characteristic RFLP bands from glutamine synthetase using the restriction enzyme Pst1. Based on our sequences, this method will generate the characteristic C. gloeosporioides bands reported by Liu et al. for C. aenigma, C. alienum, C. aotearoa, C. asianum, C. clidemiae, C. cordylinicola, C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides s. str., C. horii, C. queenslandicum, C. salsolae, C. siamense, C. ti, and C. tropicale. Different banding patterns will be produced by C. aeschynomenes (band sizes 253, 316, 388), the two C. kahawae subspecies (band sizes 112, 388, 457), G. cingulata “f. sp. camelliae” (band sizes 51, 112, 337, 457), and C. musae (band sizes 388, 552), but none match the bands reported for C. acutatum by these authors.
q1: Why do many researchers continue to use the name C. gloeosporioides despite its epitypification in 2008?
q2: How do the sequence differences in the CgInt primer impact the identification of species within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q3: What role do PCR-based identification tools play in distinguishing members of the C. gloeosporioides complex from those of the C. acutatum complex?
q4: Is there a specific sequence that distinguishes isolates within the C. gloeosporioides complex from others in GenBank?
q5: Do all taxa within the C. gloeosporioides complex match the CgInt primer sequence?
q6: Can the TBCG primer for β-tubulin identify all taxa in the C. gloeosporioides group?
metadata: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex.pdf

pdf:
Comparison of our data with gene sequences reported as
C. gloeosporioides in recent papers allows most to be placed
with confidence in one of the species that we accept. There are
exceptions, such as the pecan-associated isolates from Liu et al.
(2011), and the pistachio-associated isolates reported by Yang et
al. (2011), both of which appear to represent undescribed species
within the C. gloeosporioides complex. Clearly, more species remain
to be described within the C. gloeosporioides complex. In addition,
taxonomic issues still to be resolved amongst the species discussed
in this paper include the relationship between G. cingulata “f. sp.
camelliae” and C. camelliae, the identity of the cotton pathogens
referred to C. gossypii, the identity of the cassava pathogens referred
to C. manihotis, the relationship between C. aeschynomenes and C.
gloeosporioides “f. sp. jussiaeae”, whether the various yam diseases
discussed in the literature are all caused by C. alatae, and whether
the isolates of C. aotearoa from Meryta leaf spots form a biologically
distinct population. A more general question relates to better
understanding the frequency of hybrids within the C. gloeosporioides
complex and the impact of this on the interpretation of the phylogenies
within the complex. The impact of hybridisation on the evolution of
disease specialised populations has barely been explored.
txt: Comparison of our data with gene sequences reported as C. gloeosporioides in recent papers allows most to be confidently placed in one of the species we accept. There are exceptions, such as the pecan-associated isolates from Liu et al. and the pistachio-associated isolates reported by Yang et al., both of which appear to represent undescribed species within the C. gloeosporioides complex. Clearly, more species remain to be described within this complex. Additionally, taxonomic issues still to be resolved among the species discussed in this paper include the relationship between G. cingulata “f. sp. camelliae” and C. camelliae, the identity of the cotton pathogens referred to as C. gossypii, the identity of the cassava pathogens referred to as C. manihotis, the relationship between C. aeschynomenes and C. gloeosporioides “f. sp. jussiaeae,” whether the various yam diseases discussed in the literature are all caused by C. alatae, and whether the isolates of C. aotearoa from Meryta leaf spots form a biologically distinct population. A broader question relates to better understanding the frequency of hybrids within the C. gloeosporioides complex and the impact of this on the interpretation of the phylogenies within the complex. The influence of hybridization on the evolution of disease-specialized populations has barely been explored.
q1: What challenges remain in classifying certain isolates within the C. gloeosporioides complex based on recent studies?
q2: Why is understanding the frequency of hybrids within the C. gloeosporioides complex important for interpreting phylogenies?
q3: What are some unresolved taxonomic issues mentioned regarding relationships between species within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q4: Are there isolates within the C. gloeosporioides complex that represent undescribed species?
q5: Is there uncertainty regarding the identity of cotton and cassava pathogens within the complex?
q6: Has the influence of hybridization on disease-specialized populations been extensively studied?

ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
This study was funded by AGMARDT (The Agricultural and Marketing Research
and Development Trust) grant no. 892, the New Zealand Ministry of Science and
Innovation through backbone funding of the “Defining New Zealand’s Land Biota”
programme, and the New Zealand Tertiary Education Commission through the
“Molecular diagnostics: capitalising on a million DNA barcodes” project. Shaun
Pennycook, Landcare Research, provided valuable nomenclatural advice, Duckchul
Park and Paula Wilkie, Landcare Research, provided valuable technical assistance.
Diogo Silva, Centro de Investigação das Ferrugens do Cafeeiro, Portugal, carried
out the C. kahawae pathogenicity tests. David Cleland, ATCC, provided DNA
sequences for ATCC 96723. This study has been possible only through the provision
of cultures by the DAR, ICMP, CBS, CABI, and MAFF culture collections, as well
as by many individual researchers — Matthew Abang, Deutsche Sammlung von
Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen, Braunschweig, Germany; Robert Barreto,
Universidade Federal de Viçosa, Brazil; George Carroll, University of Oregon,
USA; Dana Berner, Foreign Disease-Weed Science Research Unit, USDA-ARS, Ft.
Detrick, USA; Lindy Coates, Brad McNeil and Roger Shivas, Queensland Primary
Industries and Fisheries, Indooroopilly, Queensland, Australia; W.E. Copes, USDAARS
Small Fruit Research Unit, Poplarville, Massachusetts, USA; Kerry Everett
and Mike Manning, Plant and Food Research, Auckland, New Zealand; David Farr,
Gary Samuels and Steve Rehner, Systematic Mycology & Microbiology Laboratory
USDA, Beltsville, USA; Steve Ferriera and K. Pitz, University of Hawaii, USA; Stan
Freeman, Dept. of Plant Pathology and Weed Research, The Volcani Center, Israel;
Hideo Ishii, National Institute for Agro-Environmental Sciences, Tsukuba, Japan;
Sucheta Joshee and Nick Waipara, Landcare Research, Auckland, New Zealand;
Lisa Korsten, University of Pretoria, South Africa; Lei Cai, State Key Laboratory of
Mycology, Institute of Microbiology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China;
Frank Louws and Turner Sutton, North Carolina State University, USA; Stephen
Mackenzie and Natalia Peres, University of Florida, USA; Nelson Massola, Escola
Superior de Agricultura “Luiz de Queiroz”, Brazil; Jean-Yves Meyer, Department of

Po Than, Chinese Academy of Forestry, Kunming, China; Ramon Villanueva-Aroe,
University of València, Spain; Jing-Ze Zhang, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China.

q1: How do species within the Colletotrichum genus differ in their pathogenicity towards various host plants?
q2: Why is clade-based calibration beneficial when it comes to modeling diseases caused by closely related Colletotrichum species?
q3: What challenges arise from identifying specific species of Colletotrichum in practical or economic contexts?
q4: Is species identification of Colletotrichum sometimes impractical or too costly?
q5: Does clade-based calibration help model diseases when species identification is difficult?
q6: Are anthracnose diseases caused by different species of Colletotrichum within the same clade?

q1: What are the genetic and molecular methods used to distinguish between different species of Colletotrichum?
q2: How does Colletotrichum affect economically important crops like coffee, avocado, and mango?
q3: What are the host ranges and pathogenic diversity of Colletotrichum species across different regions?
q4: Did Rodrigues CJ et al. (1991) report strains of Colletotrichum coffeanum causing coffee berry disease with characteristics different from the Kenya strain?
q5: Was the nuclear ribosomal ITS region suggested as a universal DNA barcode marker for fungi in the work of Schoch CL et al. (2012)?
q6: Did Taylor JW & Berbee ML (2006) conduct studies related to dating divergences in the fungal tree of life?

pdf:
Take-all" root, crown, and foot rot
caused by the ubiquitous soilborne
fungus Gaeumannomyces graminfs
(Sacc.) Arx & D. Olivier var. tritici J.
Walker (syn. Ophiobolus graminis Sacc.)
is the most damaging root disease of
wheat ( Triricurn aesrfvum L.) worldwide
(3,8,17). Early symptoms of take-all are
subtle and easily overlooked. Dark
brown "runner" hyphae (ectotrophic
growth) of the fungus may or may not
be observed on the root surface, because
G, lprarninis frequently penetrates young
roots and grows between the cortex and
stele (38). The absence or presence of
runner hyphae is not a good diagnostic
character of disease because the fungus
grows epiphytically over the cortex of
resistant rye and oat roots without
causing disease.
txt: "Take-all" root, crown, and foot rot caused by the ubiquitous soilborne fungus Gaeumannomyces graminis (Sacc.) Arx & D. Olivier var. tritici J. Walker (syn. Ophiobolus graminis Sacc.) is the most damaging root disease of wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) worldwide. Early symptoms of take-all are subtle and easily overlooked. Dark brown "runner" hyphae (ectotrophic growth) of the fungus may or may not be observed on the root surface, as G. graminis frequently penetrates young roots and grows between the cortex and stele. The absence or presence of runner hyphae is not a reliable diagnostic characteristic of the disease because the fungus can grow epiphytically over the cortex of resistant rye and oat roots without causing disease.
q1: What factors contribute to the difficulty in diagnosing take-all disease in wheat?
q2: How does Gaeumannomyces graminis affect different plant species, such as rye and oats?
q3: What are the early symptoms of take-all disease in wheat, and why might they be overlooked?
q4: Is take-all disease caused by a soilborne fungus?
q5: Can the presence of dark brown runner hyphae reliably indicate the presence of take-all disease?
q6: Does Gaeumannomyces graminis cause disease in both resistant and susceptible plant species?

pdf:
Plants can be infected in all stages of
growth when environmental conditions
are favorable. Light to dark brown or
black lesions and necrotic tips are
characteristic root symptoms (Fig. 1).
Severe infection blackens and extensively
destroys the root system. A black
myceliaf mar of the fungus may farm on
the basal stem or "foot"area of the plant,
and most of the roots are heavily
melanized. On young plants, aboveground
symptoms are characteristic of
a general nutrient stress (Fig. 2) and are
frequently misdiagnosed as nitrogen
deficiency. A misdiagnosis of magnesium
deficiency in highly weathered soils, and
application of dolomitic lime (calcium
and magnesium carbonates) as a source
of magnesium, increases the severity of
take-all and exacerbates the nutrient
deficiency.
txt: Plants can be infected at all stages of growth when environmental conditions are favorable. Light to dark brown or black lesions and necrotic tips are characteristic root symptoms. Severe infections blacken and extensively destroy the root system. A black mycelial mat of the fungus may form on the basal stem or "foot" area of the plant, and most of the roots become heavily melanized. In young plants, aboveground symptoms are indicative of general nutrient stress and are frequently misdiagnosed as nitrogen deficiency. Misdiagnosis of magnesium deficiency in highly weathered soils, along with the application of dolomitic lime (calcium and magnesium carbonates) as a source of magnesium, can increase the severity of take-all and exacerbate the nutrient deficiency.
q1: What environmental conditions contribute to the infection of plants at various growth stages?
q2: How does the infection manifest differently in young plants compared to older plants?
q3: What role does soil composition play in the misdiagnosis of nutrient deficiencies in infected plants?
q4: Can plants be infected at any stage of growth?
q5: Do the symptoms of infection include dark lesions and necrotic tips?
q6: Does applying dolomitic lime worsen the severity of take-all disease?

pdf:
Grain losses of 10-1 5% from reduced
root absorptive capacity and killed or
aborted tillers may go undetected in the
field. Wheat fields severely infected with
the takeall fungus may have an uneven
appearance in height by heading, although
significant levels of infection frequently
go undetected (3,17,38). Whiteheads, i.e.,
prematurely ripened, poorly filled, or
empty seed heads, produced on severely
infected plants may be scattered thraughout
the plant population (Fig, 3) or occur
in circular to irregularly shaped areas in
the field. With adequate moisture, heads
of prematurely killed plants are generally
higher in soCuble carbohydrates and are
readily colonized by various saprophytic
fungi; they have a blackened appearance
by harvest time. Yield losses vary by soil
type, management, and climate for the
major wheat-producing areas of the
world, with estimates from I to 50% of
the potential yield and from 0.2 to 0.5
kg/ ha of wheat grain for each I % of the
plant population affected (3,8,17).
Estimated losses in Indiana aver a 10-
year period (1972-1981) ranged from 4
lo 25% of the potential wheat yield (20).
txt: Grain losses of 10-15% due to reduced root absorptive capacity and killed or aborted tillers may go undetected in the field. Wheat fields severely infected with the take-all fungus may exhibit uneven height by heading, although significant levels of infection often remain unnoticed. Whiteheads?rematurely ripened, poorly filled, or empty seed heads?roduced on severely infected plants may be scattered throughout the population or occur in circular to irregularly shaped areas in the field. With adequate moisture, heads of prematurely killed plants generally have higher soluble carbohydrates and are readily colonized by various saprophytic fungi, appearing blackened by harvest time. Yield losses vary by soil type, management, and climate across major wheat-producing areas, with estimates ranging from 1% to 50% of potential yield and from 0.2 to 0.5 kg/ha of wheat grain for each 1% of the plant population affected. Estimated losses in Indiana over a 10-year period (1972-1981) ranged from 4% to 25% of the potential wheat yield.
q1: What factors contribute to the undetected infection levels of the take-all fungus in wheat fields?
q2: How do soil type, management practices, and climate influence wheat yield losses due to infection?
q3: What is the significance of the appearance of whiteheads in assessing the health of wheat plants?
q4: Do wheat fields infected with the take-all fungus typically show an even height by heading?
q5: Are the yield losses from wheat infections consistent across all regions of the world?
q6: Is the presence of blackened heads on wheat plants an indicator of premature plant death?

The absence of genetic resistance and
effective chernicaI controls for take-all
imposes many constraints on management
practices and has given this disease
a notorious reputation among cereal
growers. Extensive research since the
initial description of take-all 150 years
ago in Australia has provided a wealth
of information on all aspects of the disease
1(3,17) and has made it an important
model for studying other soilborne
diseases. As with many soilborne diseases,
however, the vast pool of information
on take41 has frequently created
a greater frustration at its elusivecontrol.
Various hypotheses of the effects of cultural
practices on survival. pathogenicity,
and susceptibility have been promoted
to explain the mmy anomalies of
this disease.
txt: The absence of genetic resistance and effective chemical controls for take-all imposes significant constraints on management practices, giving this disease a notorious reputation among cereal growers. Extensive research since the initial description of take-all 150 years ago in Australia has provided a wealth of information on all aspects of the disease and has established it as an important model for studying other soilborne diseases. However, as with many soilborne diseases, the vast pool of information on take-all has frequently led to frustration due to the challenges of control. Various hypotheses regarding the effects of cultural practices on survival, pathogenicity, and susceptibility have been proposed to explain the many anomalies associated with this disease.
q1: What are the primary challenges cereal growers face due to take-all disease?
q2: How has the research on take-all disease contributed to the understanding of other soilborne diseases?
q3: What role do cultural practices play in the management of take-all disease?
q4: Has take-all disease been a subject of extensive research for over 150 years?
q5: Is there currently effective genetic resistance available for take-all disease?
q6: Do researchers often experience frustration with controlling take-all disease despite the available information?

pdf:
Take-all is primarily controlled by cultural
and management practices such as
crop sequence, pH adjustment (acidification),
and tillage. all of which have a
pronounced influence on the form and
abundance of essential plant nutrients in
the soil. Few diseases respond as
dramatically to nutrition as take-all, and
disease severity is increased by a deficiency
of any of the essential mineral
nutrients (3.12,14,19,22-24,39,40). Until
recently, major emphasis has been on the
effect of nitrogen. and a sufficiency of
nitrogen has been a standard recommendation
for many years to reduce the
severity of take-all. Specific forms of
nitrogen have different effects on takeall
(27,30,50): nitrate nitrogen increases,
and ammonium nitrogen decreases,
severity af take-all. There is a striking
positive correlation between the effect of
various cultural practices on nitrification
and the severity oftake-all (Table 1). The
use of a nitrification inhibitor with ammonium
and those conditions and crop
sequences that inhibit nitrification also
reduce take-all (21,22), and vice versa.
However, some practices, such as planting
oats before wheat in rotation, have
tittle apparent effect on nitrification but
provide some of the most effecfive control
of take-all (3.1 2.22). This suggests
that the form of nitrogen, as influenced
by the rate of nitrification, may act indirectly
or with other factors to influence
the severity of take-all.
txt: Take-all is primarily controlled by cultural and management practices such as crop sequence, pH adjustment (acidification), and tillage, all of which have a pronounced influence on the form and abundance of essential plant nutrients in the soil. Few diseases respond as dramatically to nutrition as take-all, and disease severity is increased by a deficiency of any essential mineral nutrients. Until recently, major emphasis has been placed on the effect of nitrogen, with a sufficiency of nitrogen being a standard recommendation for many years to reduce the severity of take-all. Specific forms of nitrogen have different effects on take-all: nitrate nitrogen increases severity, while ammonium nitrogen decreases it. There is a striking positive correlation between the effect of various cultural practices on nitrification and the severity of take-all. The use of a nitrification inhibitor with ammonium, along with conditions and crop sequences that inhibit nitrification, also reduces take-all. However, some practices, such as planting oats before wheat in rotation, have little apparent effect on nitrification but provide some of the most effective control of take-all. This suggests that the form of nitrogen, as influenced by the rate of nitrification, may act indirectly or with other factors to influence the severity of take-all.
q1: How do cultural practices impact the severity of take-all disease in crops?
q2: What role does the form of nitrogen play in managing take-all disease?
q3: Why might crop rotation with oats be an effective strategy for controlling take-all, despite its limited effect on nitrification?
q4: Does a deficiency of essential mineral nutrients increase the severity of take-all disease?
q5: Is nitrate nitrogen associated with an increase in take-all severity?
q6: Do all cultural practices have the same impact on nitrification and take-all disease?

pdf:
Colletotrichum is the causal agent of anthracnose and other diseases on leaves, stems and fruits of numerous plant
species, including several important crops. Accurate species identification is critical to understand the epidemiology and
to develop effective control of these diseases. Morphologically-based identification of Colletotrichum species has
always been problematic, because there are few reliable characters and many of these characters are plastic, dependent
upon methods and experimental conditions. Rapid progress in molecular phylogenetic methods is now making it
possible to recognise stable and well-resolved clades within Colletotrichum. How these should be reflected in a
classification system remains to be resolved. An important step in providing a stable taxonomy for the genus is to
epitypify existing names, and in so doing link them to genetically defined clades. We recommend a polyphasic
approach to the recognition and identification of species within Colletotrichum, matching genetic distinctness with
informative morphological and biological characters. This paper reviews various approaches in the study of
Colletotrichum complexes including morphology, pathogenicity, physiology, phylogenetics and secondary metabolite
production. A backbone phylogenetic tree using ITS sequence data from 42 ex-type specimens has been generated.
Phylogenetic analysis using ITS sequence data is a useful tool to give a preliminarily identification for Colletotrichum
species or place them in species complexes. However, caution must be taken here as the majority of the ITS sequences
deposited in GenBank are wrongly named. Multi-gene phylogenetic data provides much better understanding of the
relationships within Colletotrichum and should be employed where possible. We propose that an ideal approach for
Colletotrichum systematics should be based on a multi-gene phylogeny, with comparison made with type specimens,
and a well-defined phylogenetic lineage should be in conjunction with recognisable polyphasic characters, such as
morphology, physiology, pathogenicity, cultural characteristics and secondary metabolites. Finally a set of protocols
and methodologies is provided as a guideline for future studies, epitypification and the description of new species.
Key words: barcoding, epitypification, molecular phylogeny, morphology, pathogenicity, physiology, systematics
txt:
Colletotrichum is the causal agent of anthracnose and other diseases affecting the leaves, stems, and fruits of numerous plant species, including several important crops. Accurate species identification is critical for understanding the epidemiology and developing effective control measures for these diseases. Morphologically based identification of Colletotrichum species has always been problematic due to the limited reliable characters, many of which are plastic and dependent on methods and experimental conditions. However, rapid progress in molecular phylogenetic methods is now enabling the recognition of stable and well-resolved clades within Colletotrichum. The integration of these clades into a classification system remains to be addressed. A key step in providing a stable taxonomy for the genus is to epitypify existing names, linking them to genetically defined clades. We recommend a polyphasic approach for the recognition and identification of species within Colletotrichum, matching genetic distinctness with informative morphological and biological characteristics. This paper reviews various approaches in the study of Colletotrichum complexes, including morphology, pathogenicity, physiology, phylogenetics, and secondary metabolite production. A backbone phylogenetic tree using ITS sequence data from 42 ex-type specimens has been generated. Phylogenetic analysis with ITS sequence data is a useful tool for preliminary identification of Colletotrichum species or for placing them within species complexes. However, caution is advised, as many of the ITS sequences deposited in GenBank are incorrectly named. Multi-gene phylogenetic data provide a much better understanding of relationships within Colletotrichum and should be employed whenever possible. We propose that an ideal approach to Colletotrichum systematics should be based on a multi-gene phylogeny, with comparisons made to type specimens. A well-defined phylogenetic lineage should be coupled with recognizable polyphasic characters, such as morphology, physiology, pathogenicity, cultural characteristics, and secondary metabolites. Finally, a set of protocols and methodologies is provided as a guideline for future studies, epitypification, and the description of new species.
 Key words: barcoding, epitypification, molecular phylogeny, morphology, pathogenicity, physiology, systematics
q1: What challenges are associated with the morphological identification of Colletotrichum species?
q2: How does the use of molecular phylogenetic methods enhance the understanding of Colletotrichum classification?
q3: What is the significance of epitypification in developing a stable taxonomy for Colletotrichum?
q4: Is Colletotrichum responsible for diseases in multiple plant species?
q5: Does the passage suggest that morphological characteristics of Colletotrichum species are often unreliable?
q6: Should multi-gene phylogenetic data be used to better understand relationships within Colletotrichum?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Colletotrichum Corda is one of the economically
most important genera of fungi,
being responsible for anthracnose and other
diseases of a wide range of plant species
(Sutton, 1980; Hyde et al., 2009). The importance
of a rigid and stable taxonomy for the
determination of Colletotrichum species is,
therefore, a significant practical concern (Shenoy
et al., 2007). However, there has been
considerable difficulty surrounding Colletotrichum
systematics, due to the lack of reliable
morphological features, making species boundaries
ambiguous and confusing. Traditionally
many Colletotrichum species have been named
after their host, which suggests host specificity
amongst species. In what some considered a
drastic move, von Arx (1957) reduced the
number of Colletotrichum species from several
hundred to 11 based on morphological characters,
with many taxa treated as synonyms of C.
gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Several
additional species have been since accepted,
based on morphological criteria (Sutton, 1980;
1992).
txt: Colletotrichum Corda is one of the most economically important genera of fungi, responsible for anthracnose and other diseases affecting a wide range of plant species. The need for a rigid and stable taxonomy for determining Colletotrichum species is, therefore, a significant practical concern. However, there has been considerable difficulty surrounding Colletotrichum systematics due to the lack of reliable morphological features, leading to ambiguous and confusing species boundaries. Traditionally, many Colletotrichum species have been named after their hosts, suggesting host specificity among species. In what some considered a drastic move, von Arx reduced the number of Colletotrichum species from several hundred to 11 based on morphological characters, treating many taxa as synonyms of C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium. Since then, several additional species have been accepted based on morphological criteria.
q1: Why is the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species considered important for agricultural practices?
q2: What challenges exist in distinguishing between different species of Colletotrichum?
q3: How has the classification of Colletotrichum species changed over time?
q4: Has Colletotrichum been identified as a significant cause of diseases in plants?
q5: Did von Arx propose a reduction in the number of recognized Colletotrichum species?
q6: Are morphological features reliable for determining species boundaries within the Colletotrichum genus?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
The difficulty in recognising Colletotrichum
species has resulted from: 1) few and
variable morphological characters; 2) an extensive
host range and variability in pathogenicity
(Bailey and Jeger, 1992; Freeman et al., 2000;
Latunde-Dada, 2001; Du et al., 2005; Thaung,
2008); 3) type specimens are often missing or
in poor condition thus they can not be used for
molecular study and; 4) numerous rDNA ITS
(ITS) and other sequences of Colletotrichum
strains in NCBI are often erroneously named
(Crouch et al., 2009d; Damm et al., 2009). To
solve the problem of few morphologically
informative characters, researchers have
utilised other characters such as nucleic acid
sequence data, physiology, secondary metabolites
and pathogenicity, as part of a polyphasic
approach (Sutton, 1992; Cannon et al. 2000;
Than et al., 2008a,b; Crouch et al., 2009b;
Prihastuti et al., 2009). Phylogenetic analysis
based on nucleic acid sequences have been
successfully used to differentiate species in
other difficult genera or groups (e.g.
Fusarium—Shenoy et al., 2007; Kvas et al.,
2009; O’Donnell et al., 2009; Botryosphaeriaceae—
Slippers et al., 2004a,b; Crous et al.,
2006; Alves et al., 2006, 2008; Phillips et al.,
2007); although unsuccessfully in other genera
(e.g. Pestalotiopsis—Jeewon et al., 2002, 2003;
Lee et al., 2006; Hu et al., 2007; Tesjevi et al.,
2007). Such data is especially important in
species differentiation and understanding the
species relationships in Colletotrichum.
txt: The difficulty in recognizing Colletotrichum species arises from several factors: 1) limited and variable morphological characters; 2) a broad host range and variability in pathogenicity; 3) the absence or poor condition of type specimens, which hampers molecular studies; and 4) numerous rDNA ITS and other sequences of Colletotrichum strains in NCBI being often misidentified. To address the scarcity of morphologically informative characters, researchers have employed additional methods such as nucleic acid sequence data, physiology, secondary metabolites, and pathogenicity in a polyphasic approach. Phylogenetic analysis based on nucleic acid sequences has been effectively utilized to differentiate species in other challenging genera, although it has been less successful in some cases. Such data is crucial for species differentiation and understanding species relationships within Colletotrichum.
q1: What factors contribute to the difficulty in identifying Colletotrichum species?
q2: How do researchers address the challenge of limited morphological characters in Colletotrichum species identification?
q3: In what ways have phylogenetic analyses been successful or unsuccessful in differentiating species across various genera?
q4: Are morphological characters the only means of identifying Colletotrichum species?
q5: Is the issue of poorly preserved type specimens a common problem in the study of Colletotrichum?
q6: Have nucleic acid sequences been successfully used for species differentiation in any genera?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
One potential solution for poor type
material is to designate an epitype for the
species; this stabilises the species name and
should provide sequence data as well as living
specimens for future research (Hyde and Zhang,
2008). Thirteen species of Colletotrichum have
been epitypified and/or newly combined in the
genus (Crouch et al., 2006; Shenoy et al., 2007;
Cannon et al., 2008; Than et al., 2008a; Crouch
et al., 2009b; Damm et al., 2009; Weir and
Johnston, in press), while recently described
new species have ex-type cultures (Crouch et
al., 2009b; Damm et al., 2009; Prihastuti et al.,
2009; Shivas and Tan, 2009; Yang et al., 2009).
The use of sequences from type specimens is
essential when diagnosing Colletotrichum
species or studying their phylogenetic relationships.
Where possible, all previously designated
Colletotrichum gloeosporioides strains
should be compared against the recently designated
epitype of C. gloeosporioides (Cannon et
al., 2008) to establish if they are correctly
named.
txt: One potential solution for poor type material is to designate an epitype for the species; this stabilizes the species name and should provide sequence data as well as living specimens for future research. Thirteen species of Colletotrichum have been epitypified and/or newly combined in the genus, while recently described new species have ex-type cultures. The use of sequences from type specimens is essential when diagnosing Colletotrichum species or studying their phylogenetic relationships. Where possible, all previously designated Colletotrichum gloeosporioides strains should be compared against the recently designated epitype of C. gloeosporioides to establish if they are correctly named.
q1: Why is designating an epitype considered a beneficial approach for stabilizing species names?
q2: How many species of Colletotrichum have been epitypified according to the references provided?
q3: What role do sequences from type specimens play in diagnosing Colletotrichum species?
q4: Is the designation of an epitype meant to provide sequence data for future research?
q5: Have thirteen species of Colletotrichum been epitypified?
q6: Should previously designated Colletotrichum gloeosporioides strains be compared to the newly designated epitype?

pdf:
Colletotrichum taxonomy is presently
unsatisfactory and there is a pressing need for a
polyphasic approach for identification, which
reflects the natural classification of species and
subspecific taxa within the genus (Sutton,
1992; Cannon et al., 2000). In this paper a
taxonomic framework for describing Colletotrichum
epitypes and new species is proposed.
This utilises a multi-gene phylogeny based on
type specimens, and well-defined phylogenetic
lineages which correlate with recognisable
polyphasic characters such as morphology,
cultural characteristics, physiology and
pathogenicity. The various approaches that
have been used or could be incorporated in the
study of Colletotrichum species, with recommended
methodologies and discussion on
correlation of characters with phylogenetic
types are discussed. A phylogenetic analysis
based on the internal transcribed spacers and
the 5.8S ribosomal RNA gene (ITS) from
specimens including 42 ex-type strains is also
provided (Fig. 1).
txt: Colletotrichum taxonomy is currently unsatisfactory, highlighting the pressing need for a polyphasic approach to identification that reflects the natural classification of species and subspecific taxa within the genus. This paper proposes a taxonomic framework for describing Colletotrichum epitypes and new species, utilizing a multi-gene phylogeny based on type specimens and well-defined phylogenetic lineages that correlate with recognizable polyphasic characters such as morphology, cultural characteristics, physiology, and pathogenicity. Various approaches that have been used or could be incorporated in the study of Colletotrichum species are discussed, along with recommended methodologies and correlations of characters with phylogenetic types. Additionally, a phylogenetic analysis based on the internal transcribed spacers and the 5.8S ribosomal RNA gene (ITS) from specimens, including 42 ex-type strains, is provided.
q1: What challenges currently exist in the taxonomy of Colletotrichum species?
q2: How does the proposed taxonomic framework aim to improve the identification of Colletotrichum?
q3: What types of characters are suggested to correlate with the phylogenetic lineages in the study of Colletotrichum?
q4: Is there a need for a polyphasic approach for identifying Colletotrichum species?
q5: Does the proposed framework utilize a multi-gene phylogeny?
q6: Are internal transcribed spacers and the 5.8S ribosomal RNA gene used in the phylogenetic analysis of Colletotrichum?

pdf:
Traditional identification systems in
Colletotrichum have relied heavily on morphological
and cultural characteristics (von Arx,
1957; Sutton, 1980, 1992; Bailey and Jeger,
1992; Freeman et al., 1998). Sutton (1992)
noted that morphology alone does not provide
sufficient information for a precise identification,
especially for those species in the C.
gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes.
Crouch et al. (2009b) considered that conidial
size and shape, along with conidial appressoria
were taxonomically uninformative and of little
use for species diagnosis in graminicolous
Colletotrichum species. Species with similar
morphological characteristics may have considerable
variation at the physiological and
pathogenic levels. Recognition of this is
particularly important for biosecurity, plant
breeding and integrated disease management.
Taxonomy based on morphology alone is likely
to result in ambiguity. Recent studies have
shown that morphological characters should be
used in conjunction with other characters to
establish species relationships within Colletotrichum
(Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al.,
2009).
txt: Traditional identification systems in Colletotrichum have relied heavily on morphological and cultural characteristics. However, morphology alone does not provide sufficient information for precise identification, particularly for species in the C. gloeosporioides and C. dematium complexes. Conidial size and shape, along with conidial appressoria, are often uninformative for species diagnosis in graminicolous Colletotrichum species. Species with similar morphological traits may exhibit considerable variation in physiological and pathogenic levels, which is crucial for biosecurity, plant breeding, and integrated disease management. Relying solely on morphology can lead to ambiguity; thus, recent studies suggest that morphological characters should be combined with other attributes to establish species relationships within Colletotrichum.
q1: Why might relying solely on morphological characteristics be insufficient for identifying species in the Colletotrichum genus?
q2: What implications does the variation in physiological and pathogenic levels of similar-looking species have for agricultural practices?
q3: How have recent studies changed the approach to taxonomy in the Colletotrichum genus?
q4: Is morphology alone considered a reliable method for identifying Colletotrichum species?
q5: Have studies indicated that morphological characteristics should be used alongside other methods for species identification?
q6: Do species within the Colletotrichum genus exhibit significant variation despite having similar morphological traits?

pdf:
Available morphological characters of
Colletotrichum species include: 1) characters
on natural substrata, i.e. size and shape of
conidiomata (acervuli), conidia, conidiophores
and setae; 2) size and shape of conidia,
conidiophores and setae in culture; and 3) size
and shape of appressoria. Acervuli, setae and
conidial characters (shape and dimensions) on
natural substrata can vary due to environmental
factors, and conidia may be absent from
infected host tissues. Some species of Colletotrichum,
e.g. C. musae and C. gossypii, consistently
fail to produce setae in conidiomata
(Sutton and Waterston, 1970) and their
presence on natural hosts is often inconsistent
for species diagnosis (von Arx, 1957; Sutton,
1966).
txt: Available morphological characters of Colletotrichum species include: 1) characters on natural substrates, such as the size and shape of conidiomata (acervuli), conidia, conidiophores, and setae; 2) size and shape of conidia, conidiophores, and setae in culture; and 3) size and shape of appressoria. Acervuli, setae, and conidial characters (shape and dimensions) on natural substrates can vary due to environmental factors, and conidia may be absent from infected host tissues. Some species of Colletotrichum, such as C. musae and C. gossypii, consistently fail to produce setae in conidiomata, and their presence on natural hosts is often inconsistent for species diagnosis.
q1: How do environmental factors influence the morphological characteristics of Colletotrichum species?
q2: Why might the presence of setae be unreliable for diagnosing certain species of Colletotrichum?
q3: What are the main morphological characters used to identify different species of Colletotrichum?
q4: Do all species of Colletotrichum produce setae in their conidiomata?
q5: Can the size and shape of conidia vary in culture compared to natural substrates?
q6: Is the presence of conidia always detectable in infected host tissues?

pdf:
Morphological characters may vary with
environmental factors, and incubation conditions,
such as media and temperature, should
be standardized (Cannon et al., 2000) for
species comparison and identification. Unfortunately,
there is no recommended standard for
Colletotrichum cultivation. For example,
Baxter et al. (1983) described species of
Colletotrichum based on growth on MSA and
CDY at 20ºC; Sutton (1980) used potato
dextrose agar (PDA) under alternating 12 hours
near ultra violet irradiation / 12 hour dark at
25ºC; others have used PDA in the dark at
25ºC (Shivas et al., 1998; Nirenberg et al.,
2002) or; synthetic nutrient-poor agar (SNA)
medium and Anthriscus stems incubated under
permanent near ultra violet light at 20 ºC
(Damm et al., 2009). Thus, it is difficult to
compare morphological and cultural characters
due to variation and inconsistency in
methodology. To compare isolates/species, a
standardised protocol for cultivation of strains
should be applied.
txt: Morphological characters may vary with environmental factors, and incubation conditions, such as media and temperature, should be standardized for species comparison and identification. Unfortunately, there is no recommended standard for Colletotrichum cultivation. For example, some researchers have described species of Colletotrichum based on growth on MSA and CDY at 20繙C, while others have used potato dextrose agar (PDA) under alternating 12 hours of near ultraviolet irradiation and 12 hours of dark at 25繙C. Additional methods include using PDA in the dark at 25繙C or synthetic nutrient-poor agar (SNA) medium with Anthriscus stems incubated under permanent near ultraviolet light at 20繙C. Thus, it is difficult to compare morphological and cultural characters due to variation and inconsistency in methodology. To compare isolates and species, a standardized protocol for the cultivation of strains should be applied.
q1: What impact do environmental factors have on the morphological characteristics of Colletotrichum species?
q2: Why is it challenging to compare different species or isolates of Colletotrichum?
q3: What might be the benefits of establishing a standardized protocol for the cultivation of Colletotrichum strains?
q4: Is there a recommended standard for cultivating Colletotrichum species?
q5: Do different researchers use varying incubation conditions for Colletotrichum?
q6: Can inconsistency in methodology affect the comparison of morphological and cultural characters?

pdf:
Observations and measurements of conidial
size and shape have usually been made
using conidial masses mounted in water, cotton
blue, or lactic acid (Cannon et al., 2008). It
should be noted that many species of Colletotrichum
produce secondary conidia in culture
directly from germinated primary conidia;
these may vary morphologically when compared
to those produced in conidiomata
(Cannon et al., 2000).
txt: Observations and measurements of conidial size and shape have typically been made using conidial masses mounted in water, cotton blue, or lactic acid. It should be noted that many species of Colletotrichum produce secondary conidia in culture directly from germinated primary conidia; these may vary morphologically compared to those produced in conidiomata.

pdf:
Conidial and mycelial appressoria (also
referred to as hyphopodia) are often described
in Colletotrichum species. Sutton (1980)
characterised the mycelial appressoria formed
in potato-carrot agar (PCA) using a slide
culture technique, while others have used PDA
with incubation in the dark (Johnston and Jones,
1997; Malloch, 1981) or have observed
mycelial appressoria formed on the undersurface
of SNA cultures (Damm et al., 2009).
Conidial appressoria have been recorded when
conidia are germinated in drops of deionised
water on plastic cover slips in a moist chamber
(Johnson et al., 1997; Chaky et al., 2001).
Conidial appressoria are taxonomically uninformative
and of little use for species diagnosis
(Sutton, 1980, 1992). However, Du et al. (2005)
noted that the shape of appressoria can
differentiate C. acutatum (with rather smooth
appressoria) from C. gloeosporioides (with
more lobed appressoria). Crouch et al. (2009b)
found that appressoria shape and size are useful
for delimiting grass-associated Colletotrichum
species, but should be used in combination
with host range. Yang et al. (2009) found that
conidial appressoria can distinguish two
species of Colletotrichum from Amaryllidaceae.
The conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri are
larger than those of C. hymenocallidis and are
irregular, crenate or lobed, occasionally
becoming complex. In C. hymenocallidis they
are ovate or sometimes clavate
txt: Conidial and mycelial appressoria (also referred to as hyphopodia) are commonly described in Colletotrichum species. Sutton characterized the mycelial appressoria formed in potato-carrot agar (PCA) using a slide culture technique, while others have utilized PDA with incubation in the dark or observed mycelial appressoria on the undersurface of SNA cultures. Conidial appressoria have been recorded when conidia are germinated in drops of deionised water on plastic cover slips in a moist chamber. Although conidial appressoria are taxonomically uninformative and of limited use for species diagnosis, it has been noted that the shape of appressoria can differentiate C. acutatum (which has relatively smooth appressoria) from C. gloeosporioides (which has more lobed appressoria). Additionally, appressoria shape and size have proven useful for delimiting grass-associated Colletotrichum species, though they should be considered alongside host range. Conidial appressoria can distinguish two species of Colletotrichum from Amaryllidaceae, with the conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri being larger than those of C. hymenocallidis, and displaying irregular, crenate, or lobed forms, occasionally becoming complex. In contrast, the appressoria of C. hymenocallidis are ovate or sometimes clavate.
q1: What techniques have researchers used to study mycelial appressoria in Colletotrichum species?
q2: How do the shapes of conidial appressoria help in distinguishing between different Colletotrichum species?
q3: Why are conidial appressoria considered taxonomically uninformative?
q4: Have conidial appressoria been observed in moist chambers using deionised water?
q5: Is the shape of appressoria significant for differentiating certain Colletotrichum species?
q6: Are the conidial appressoria of C. hippeastri smaller than those of C. hymenocallidis?

pdf:
Cultural characteristics on agar media
have been applied for the diagnosis of some
Colletotrichum species (von Arx, 1957). The
conidial morphology of C. gloeosporioides and
C. lindemuthianum are similar, but their
cultural characters are distinctly different.
Colletotrichum lindemuthianum produces dark
pigmentation in media and grows consistently
slower than C. gloeosporioides (Baxter et al.,
1983; Sutton, 1992). Likewise, C. musae grows
relatively fast, forming effuse colonies and
glabrous conidiomata with many conidia, while
C. destructivum forms large conidiogenous
zones with scattered, relatively short setae and
has limited conidial production (Baxter et al.,
1983).
txt: Cultural characteristics on agar media have been applied for the diagnosis of some Colletotrichum species. The conidial morphology of C. gloeosporioides and C. lindemuthianum is similar, but their cultural characters are distinctly different. Colletotrichum lindemuthianum produces dark pigmentation in media and grows consistently slower than C. gloeosporioides. Likewise, C. musae grows relatively fast, forming effuse colonies and glabrous conidiomata with many conidia, while C. destructivum forms large conidiogenous zones with scattered, relatively short setae and has limited conidial production.
q1: What role do cultural characteristics play in distinguishing between different Colletotrichum species?
q2: How does the growth rate of C. gloeosporioides compare to that of C. lindemuthianum?
q3: What specific morphological features differentiate C. musae from C. destructivum?
q4: Does Colletotrichum lindemuthianum produce dark pigmentation in media?
q5: Is C. gloeosporioides characterized by a faster growth rate than C. lindemuthianum?
q6: Does C. destructivum have a high level of conidial production?
