pdf:
The shape and size of conidia and
appressoria, as well as cultural characters
should be evaluated and used with caution, as
these characters are highly dependent on the
growth conditions. Erroneous diagnosis can
largely be avoided if morphology is used in
conjunction with other characters such as
molecular sequence data, biochemical and
physiological characteristics and host range.
Crouch et al. (2009b) demonstrated that the
falcate-spored, grass-associated Colletotrichum
species could be distinguished by a combination
of molecular data, appressorial morphology
and host range. However, for most
Colletotrichum species host range has not been
determined and available information should
be considered with caution, as it is often based
on wrongly identified species (Damm et al.,
2009).
txt: The shape and size of conidia and appressoria, as well as cultural characteristics, should be evaluated and used with caution, as these traits are highly dependent on growth conditions. Erroneous diagnosis can largely be avoided if morphology is used alongside other factors such as molecular sequence data, biochemical and physiological characteristics, and host range. Research has demonstrated that the falcate-spored, grass-associated Colletotrichum species can be distinguished by a combination of molecular data, appressorial morphology, and host range. However, for most Colletotrichum species, host range has not been determined, and available information should be considered cautiously, as it is often based on incorrectly identified species.
q1: What factors can influence the morphology of conidia and appressoria?
q2: Why is it important to use a combination of diagnostic methods when identifying Colletotrichum species?
q3: What limitations exist regarding the determination of host range for most Colletotrichum species?
q4: Can cultural characters affect the evaluation of conidia and appressoria?
q5: Is there reliable information available on the host range of most Colletotrichum species?
q6: Did Crouch et al. (2009b) demonstrate a method to distinguish certain Colletotrichum species?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Due to the inadequacies and plasticity of
morphological characters, nucleic acid sequence
analysis has been regarded as more
reliable for Colletotrichum classification
(Sutton, 1992; Cannon et al., 2000; Crouch et
al., 2009a,b; Damm et al., 2009; Prihastuti et
al., 2009). A major drawback in the reliance on
a small proportion of the genome to understand
phylogenetic relationships amongst Colletotrichum
strains has been the risk of recreating
gene trees rather than species trees (Cannon et
al., 2000). Thus, multi-gene phylogenetics are
employed to systematically characterise Colletotrichum
species relationships and to serve
as a base for species diagnosis (Crouch et al.,
2006, 2009b; Farr et al., 2006; Damm et al.,
2009; Prihastuti et al., 2009). Prihastuti et al.
(2009) used six genes, the nuclear rDNA
internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region, partial
Actin (ACT), β-tubulin (TUB2), Calmodulin
(CAL), Glutamine synthetase (GS) and Glyceraldehyde
3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GPDH)
to study a few closely related Colletotrichum
species (C. gloeosporioides sensu lato) and
established that species relationships could be
well resolved. Multi-gene phylogenies were
also successfully applied to resolve the
relationships among Colletotrichum species
with curved conidia from graminicolous and
from herbaceous hosts (Crouch et al., 2009b;
Damm et al., 2009). Multi-gene phylogenetics
is an accurate and reliable way for the
diagnosis of Colletotrichum species, but is
neither very efficient nor economical. It is
currently impractical to apply multiple gene
phylogenetics to every Colletotrichum species,
as different research groups use different gene
regions. An international collaborative effort is
essential in order to standardise research being
carried out on the genus. Hyde et al. (2009)
listed all the multi-gene sequences derived
from the type or epitype cultures of Colletotrichum.
This provides an excellent platform
for data analysis that aims to study the natural
relationships among species.
txt: Due to the inadequacies and plasticity of morphological characters, nucleic acid sequence analysis has been regarded as more reliable for Colletotrichum classification. A major drawback in relying on a small proportion of the genome to understand phylogenetic relationships among Colletotrichum strains is the risk of recreating gene trees rather than species trees. Thus, multi-gene phylogenetics are employed to systematically characterize Colletotrichum species relationships and to serve as a basis for species diagnosis. Prihastuti et al. used six genes?he nuclear rDNA internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region, partial Actin (ACT), 帣-tubulin (TUB2), Calmodulin (CAL), Glutamine synthetase (GS), and Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GPDH)?o study a few closely related Colletotrichum species (C. gloeosporioides sensu lato) and established that species relationships could be well resolved. Multi-gene phylogenies were also successfully applied to clarify the relationships among Colletotrichum species with curved conidia from graminicolous and herbaceous hosts. While multi-gene phylogenetics is an accurate and reliable method for diagnosing Colletotrichum species, it is neither very efficient nor economical. Currently, it is impractical to apply multiple gene phylogenetics to every Colletotrichum species, as different research groups use various gene regions. An international collaborative effort is essential to standardize research on the genus. Hyde et al. listed all the multi-gene sequences derived from the type or epitype cultures of Colletotrichum, providing an excellent platform for data analysis aimed at studying the natural relationships among species.
q1: What are the advantages of using nucleic acid sequence analysis over morphological characters in classifying Colletotrichum?
q2: How do multi-gene phylogenetics improve the understanding of phylogenetic relationships among Colletotrichum species?
q3: Why is it important to standardize research efforts among different groups studying Colletotrichum?
q4: Is nucleic acid sequence analysis considered more reliable than morphological character analysis for Colletotrichum classification?
q5: Did Prihastuti et al. (2009) use six specific genes in their study of Colletotrichum species?
q6: Is it currently practical to apply multi-gene phylogenetics to every Colletotrichum species?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
The ITS region is the most widely
sequenced region but there are some concerns
as to whether ITS sequence data can provide
adequate resolution to determine and differentiate
Colletotrichum species. Crouch et al.
(2009d) have revealed a high error rate and
frequency of misidentification (86%) based on
ITS sequence similarity comparison within the
C. graminicola species complex. ITS sequence
data in the public domain can cause considerable
confusion to the end user; sequence
data were often entered under an incorrect
specific name and which may comprise several
cryptic species. Identical sequence data has
regularly been entered under different names.
We analysed 343 ITS sequences named “C.
gloeosporioides” (accessed on 6 Sept 2009)
and found that >86% had considerable
evolutionary divergence from the type specimen
of C. gloeosporioides (Cannon et al.,
2008), and most likely represent other Colletotrichum
species. It is paramount that
sequence data generated from type specimens
are used in species similarity comparisons and
phylogenetic analysis. Due to ease of acquisition
and an extensive library of existing
sequences, the ITS region is still useful in some
cases for reconstruction of interspecific relationships,
although it is not an ideal marker for
inferring infraspecific relationships. Currently,
ITS is also the only gene region that is
available from all the ex-type or ex-epitype
cultures of Colletotrichum species (Table 1).
We provide a phylogenetic tree based on ITS
sequence data, which includes sequences
originated from 42 ex-type or ex-epitype
cultures, in order to provide a backbone tree for
further diagnosis in Colletotrichum (Fig. 1).
Taxon names, GenBank accession numbers,
culture collection numbers, hosts and origins of
the strains are provided in Table 1. The
analysis was conducted following the methodology
outlined by Cai et al. (2008, 2009). The
backbone tree can be used to provide a rough,
quick identification guide to Colletotrichum
species.
txt: The ITS region is the most widely sequenced area, but concerns exist about its ability to adequately resolve and differentiate Colletotrichum species. High error rates and misidentifications (86%) have been reported within the C. graminicola species complex. Publicly available ITS sequence data often leads to confusion, as entries may be incorrectly labeled and may encompass several cryptic species, with identical sequences recorded under different names. Our analysis of 343 ITS sequences labeled ?. gloeosporioides??revealed that over 86% diverged significantly from the type specimen and likely represent other Colletotrichum species. It's essential to use sequence data from type specimens for accurate species comparisons and phylogenetic analysis. Despite its limitations as an ideal marker for infraspecific relationships, the ITS region remains valuable for reconstructing interspecific relationships due to its extensive existing library. Currently, it is the only gene region available from all ex-type or ex-epitype cultures of Colletotrichum species. We present a phylogenetic tree based on ITS sequence data from 42 ex-type or ex-epitype cultures, serving as a backbone for further diagnostics in Colletotrichum. Taxon names, accession numbers, culture collection numbers, hosts, and origins are detailed in the accompanying table. This backbone tree can provide a rough identification guide for Colletotrichum species.
q1: What are the limitations of using ITS sequence data for identifying Colletotrichum species?
q2: How does the error rate in ITS sequence identification impact the study of Colletotrichum?
q3: Why is it important to use sequence data from type specimens when conducting phylogenetic analyses of Colletotrichum species?
q4: Is the ITS region considered the most widely sequenced region for Colletotrichum species?
q5: Did the analysis reveal that more than 86% of the ITS sequences named ?. gloeosporioides??diverged significantly from the type specimen?
q6: Is the ITS region the only gene region available from all ex-type or ex-epitype cultures of Colletotrichum species?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Colletotrichum systematics should utilise
a multiple-gene phylogeny and a study of type
specimens to establish correlations between the
genotype and phenotype. The phenotype
should be expanded to a polyphasic sense
(morphology, physiology, pathogenicity, infection
processes, cultural characteristics and
secondary metabolites) (Frisvad, 2004; Samson
and Varga, 2007). The genotypes in Colletotrichum
appear to correlate with a combination
of characters but not with a single character.
These criteria are clearly demonstrated by
Crouch et al. (2009b), Damm et al. (2009) and
Prihastuti et al. (2009). Crouch et al. (2009b)
correlated the well-defined phylogenetic groupings
with combined characters of appressoria
and host ranges. Prihastuti et al. (2009)
established new taxa in the C. gloeosporioides
complex that form distinct phylogenetic
lineages with distinct morphological, cultural
and physiological characteristics. Taylor et al.
(2000) suggested that a genealogical concordance
method should be used to recognise a
phylogenetic species, with three criteria for
each lineage, i.e. monophyletic, statistically
supported and genealogically concordant (i.e.
no conflict among the single gene tree). Our
proposal is broader as we also emphasize the
importance of correlation with phenotypic
characters, so as to develop species concepts in
a systematic, biological sense.
txt: Colletotrichum systematics should utilize a multiple-gene phylogeny and a study of type specimens to establish correlations between genotype and phenotype. The phenotype should be expanded to include a polyphasic approach encompassing morphology, physiology, pathogenicity, infection processes, cultural characteristics, and secondary metabolites. The genotypes in Colletotrichum appear to correlate with a combination of characters rather than with a single character. These criteria are clearly demonstrated by various studies, which correlated well-defined phylogenetic groupings with combined characters such as appressoria and host ranges. Additionally, new taxa within the C. gloeosporioides complex have been established, forming distinct phylogenetic lineages with unique morphological, cultural, and physiological characteristics. A genealogical concordance method has been suggested to recognize phylogenetic species, employing three criteria for each lineage: monophyletic, statistically supported, and genealogically concordant (i.e., no conflict among the single gene trees). Our proposal is broader as it emphasizes the importance of correlating phenotypic characters to develop species concepts in a systematic, biological sense.
q1: What role do type specimens play in establishing correlations between genotype and phenotype in Colletotrichum?
q2: How do the morphological, cultural, and physiological characteristics contribute to the classification of new taxa in the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q3: What criteria are proposed for recognizing phylogenetic species beyond the genealogical concordance method?
q4: Should multiple-gene phylogeny be utilized in the systematics of Colletotrichum?
q5: Is it necessary for the genotype to correlate with multiple characters rather than a single character?
q6: Do the authors propose a broader approach to species concepts that includes phenotypic character correlation?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Physiology, carbon source utilization and
growth rate
Patterns of carbohydrate utilization have
been used to resolve the classification of
Penicillium species (Bridge, 1985) and this has
also been employed to differentiate Colletotrichum
species (Waller et al., 1993; Prihastuti et
al., 2009). Colletotrichum kahawae Waller &
Bridge is an economically important pathogen
causing coffee berry disease in Africa, which
could be distinguished from other Colletotrichum
species on coffee by its inability to utilize
citrate or tartrate as a sole carbon source
(Waller et al., 1993; Prihastuti et al., 2009).
There have been considerable controversies as
to whether Colletotrichum kahawae should be
a valid species or a sub-population of C.
gloeosporioides, as C. kahawae can only be
distinguished from C. gloeosporioides and
other close relatives by biochemical and physiological
characters (Correll et al., 2000;
Cannon et al., 2000). Recent phylogenetic
analysis using multi-gene data showed that C.
kahawae is genetically distinct from other close
related species in the complex (Prihastuti et al.,
2009). This serves as a good demonstration for
correlation between genotypes and phenotypes.
txt: Physiology, carbon source utilization, and growth rate patterns of carbohydrate utilization have been used to resolve the classification of Penicillium species and to differentiate Colletotrichum species. Colletotrichum kahawae is an economically important pathogen causing coffee berry disease in Africa, distinguished from other Colletotrichum species on coffee by its inability to utilize citrate or tartrate as a sole carbon source. There has been considerable controversy over whether C. kahawae should be considered a valid species or a sub-population of C. gloeosporioides, as it can only be distinguished from C. gloeosporioides and other close relatives by biochemical and physiological characteristics. Recent phylogenetic analysis using multi-gene data showed that C. kahawae is genetically distinct from other closely related species in the complex, demonstrating a correlation between genotypes and phenotypes.
q1: How does the carbohydrate utilization pattern help in the classification of fungal species?
q2: What biochemical characteristics differentiate Colletotrichum kahawae from C. gloeosporioides?
q3: What role does phylogenetic analysis play in establishing the classification of Colletotrichum kahawae?
q4: Is Colletotrichum kahawae known to cause coffee berry disease?
q5: Can Colletotrichum kahawae utilize citrate or tartrate as a sole carbon source?
q6: Did recent studies confirm that Colletotrichum kahawae is genetically distinct from other related species?

pdf:
Relative growth rates in culture is a
useful criterion for differentiating some
Aspergillus and Penicillium species (Frisvad,
2004; Frisvad et al., 2007; Samson and Varga,
2007) and this character has also been
employed in delimitating Colletotrichum
species. For example, Colletotrichum acutatum
grows significantly slower than C. gloeosporioides
and can be distinguished by growth
rate (Sutton, 1992). Than et al. (2008b) and
Prihastuti et al. (2009) showed a good
correlation between growth rate in culture and
multi-gene phylogeny in species causing chilli
anthracnose and coffee berry disease in
Thailand. Colletotrichum asianum could easily
be distinguished from C. fructicola and C.
siamense (all from coffee) by its much slower
growth rate (Prihastuti et al., 2009).
txt: Relative growth rates in culture are a useful criterion for differentiating some Aspergillus and Penicillium species, and this characteristic has also been employed in delineating Colletotrichum species. For example, Colletotrichum acutatum grows significantly slower than C. gloeosporioides and can be distinguished by its growth rate. Additionally, studies have shown a strong correlation between growth rate in culture and multi-gene phylogeny in species causing chilli anthracnose and coffee berry disease in Thailand. Colletotrichum asianum can be easily distinguished from C. fructicola and C. siamense (all from coffee) by its much slower growth rate.
q1: What specific criteria are used to differentiate between Aspergillus and Penicillium species?
q2: How does the growth rate of Colletotrichum acutatum compare to that of C. gloeosporioides?
q3: What correlation did Than et al. (2008b) and Prihastuti et al. (2009) find regarding growth rates and phylogeny in species causing diseases in Thailand?
q4: Is relative growth rate a significant criterion for differentiating species in the genus Colletotrichum?
q5: Can Colletotrichum asianum be distinguished from other Colletotrichum species by its growth rate?
q6: Did the studies conducted in Thailand find a correlation between growth rate and multi-gene phylogeny?

pdf:
Fig. 1. Phylogram generated from parsimony analysis based on rDNA ITS sequence data. Data was analysed with
random sequence addition, unweighted parsimony and by treating gaps as missing data. Bootstrap values ≥ 50% are
shown above or below branches. Thickened branches indicate Bayesian posterior probabilities ≥95%. The tree is rooted
with Fusarium oxysporum. (*Cultures derived from type specimens).
txt: Figure 1. Phylogram generated from parsimony analysis based on rDNA ITS sequence data. The data were analyzed using random sequence addition and unweighted parsimony, treating gaps as missing data. Bootstrap values of 50% or higher are shown above or below the branches. Thickened branches indicate Bayesian posterior probabilities of 95% or higher. The tree is rooted with Fusarium oxysporum. (*Cultures derived from type specimens).
q1: What type of analysis was performed to generate the phylogram, and what specific data was used?
q2: How does the use of bootstrap values contribute to the reliability of the phylogenetic tree presented?
q3: Why might Fusarium oxysporum have been chosen as the root for the phylogenetic tree?
q4: Was the analysis conducted using weighted parsimony methods?
q5: Are bootstrap values of 50% or higher indicated on the branches of the phylogram?
q6: Is the tree rooted with a species other than Fusarium oxysporum?

pdf:
The usefulness of physiological characters
in differentiating closely related species in
Colletotrichum has been well demonstrated in a
few species. Unfortunately, such physiological
characterizations have not been made for most
Colletotrichum species. In this paper, we
suggest that the carbohydrate utilization and
relative growth rate should be used as one of
the polyphasic characters to study Colletotrichum,
especially for those morphologically
indistinguishable species that bear phylogenetic
distinctiveness.
txt: The usefulness of physiological characters in differentiating closely related species in Colletotrichum has been well demonstrated in a few species. Unfortunately, such physiological characterizations have not been conducted for most Colletotrichum species. In this paper, we suggest that carbohydrate utilization and relative growth rate should be used as polyphasic characters to study Colletotrichum, particularly for morphologically indistinguishable species that exhibit phylogenetic distinctiveness.
q1: Why are physiological characters important in differentiating closely related species of Colletotrichum?
q2: What specific physiological characteristics does the paper suggest for studying Colletotrichum species?
q3: How might carbohydrate utilization and growth rate help in identifying morphologically indistinguishable Colletotrichum species?
q4: Have physiological characterizations been performed for all Colletotrichum species?
q5: Does the paper advocate for using carbohydrate utilization in the study of Colletotrichum?
q6: Are there species of Colletotrichum that are morphologically indistinguishable but phylogenetically distinct?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Pathogenicity testing
It is important to establish whether a
particular Colletotrichum species is hostspecific
or has a wide host range. Host-specific
taxa may have a limited distribution, which
may have important biosecurity implications. If
the taxon has a wide host range the species is
likely to be cosmopolitan and possibly an
opportunistic pathogen. Host range studies may
provide data useful in classification and future
delimitation of species. Koch’s postulates have
been completed to confirm the pathogenicity of
various Colletotrichum isolates. For example,
Vinnere et al. (2002) showed that Rhododendron
anthracnose was caused by C. acutatum;
Lee et al. (2005) re-infected Euonymus leaves
with C. boninense in moist chamber pathogenicity
tests; Tomioka et al. (2008) showed that a
species referred to as C. dematium (but see
Damm et al., 2009) was the causal agent of
severe spotting, blight and drop of leaves of
Polygonatum falcatum. Descriptions of new
species sometimes include data on pathogenicity
testing (Nakamura et al., 2006; Moriwaki
and Tsukiboshi 2009; Yang et al., 2009),
although this is not usually the case (e.g. Farr
et al., 2006). Crouch et al. (2009c) confirmed
that a new species, C. navitas, caused anthracnose
of Panicum virgatum. Much of the
pathogenicity work that has been carried out
needs repeating with verified Colletotrichum
species. For example, pathogenicity tests using
C. acutatum, C. capsici and C. gloeosporioides
isolates from chili were carried out on
susceptible and resistant varieties of chili (Than
et al., 2008b) but names of the Colletotrichum
species used need to be re-examined in light of
a re-assessment of some of these Colletotrichum
species (Shivas and Tan, 2009). Papers
epitypifying plant pathogenic taxa should
ideally include pathogenicity testing, but this
has not usually been done (e.g. Shenoy et al.,
2007; Cannon et al., 2008; Than et al., 2008a;
Crouch et al., 2009b; Weir and Johnston, in
press).
txt: It is important to establish whether a particular Colletotrichum species is host-specific or has a wide host range. Host-specific taxa may have a limited distribution, which can have significant biosecurity implications. If a taxon has a wide host range, the species is likely to be cosmopolitan and possibly an opportunistic pathogen. Host range studies may provide useful data for classification and future delimitation of species. Koch? postulates have been completed to confirm the pathogenicity of various Colletotrichum isolates. For example, it was shown that Rhododendron anthracnose was caused by C. acutatum; Euonymus leaves were re-infected with C. boninense in moist chamber pathogenicity tests; and a species referred to as C. dematium was identified as the causal agent of severe spotting, blight, and leaf drop in Polygonatum falcatum. Descriptions of new species sometimes include data on pathogenicity testing, although this is not usually the case. A new species, C. navitas, was confirmed to cause anthracnose in Panicum virgatum. Much of the pathogenicity work that has been carried out needs to be repeated with verified Colletotrichum species. For example, pathogenicity tests using C. acutatum, C. capsici, and C. gloeosporioides isolates from chili were conducted on susceptible and resistant varieties of chili, but the names of the Colletotrichum species used need to be re-examined in light of a reassessment of some of these species. Papers epitypifying plant pathogenic taxa should ideally include pathogenicity testing, but this has not usually been done.
q1: Why is it important to determine the host range of different Colletotrichum species?
q2: How does pathogenicity testing contribute to the classification and delimitation of Colletotrichum species?
q3: What are some of the implications of finding that a Colletotrichum species has a wide host range?
q4: Has Koch? postulates been completed for various Colletotrichum isolates?
q5: Are host-specific taxa of Colletotrichum likely to have a wide distribution?
q6: Is it common for descriptions of new Colletotrichum species to include data on pathogenicity testing?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Cross mating experiments
A cross mating test is an in vitro
experiment employed to recognise fungal
species based on the biological species concept
(Mayr, 1940; Taylor et al., 2000). In biological
species recognition, groups of mating compatible
individuals are regarded as the same
species (Taylor et al., 2000). There are major
obstacles that limit the application of this
theory to fungi including: 1) many fungi are
asexual (they may have permanently lost the
ability to reproduce sexually) and do not
produce ascospores (Reynolds, 1993); 2) some
species are able to produce ascospores without
a partner (homothallic), e.g. C. falcatum and C.
graminicola (von Arx and Müller, 1954; Politis,
1975; Vaillancourt and Hanaui, 1991); 3)
failure of some heterothallic fungi to mate in
artificial cultivation; and 4) there is much
evidence that groups of genetically isolated
fungi may retain the ancestral characters of
interbreeding. A common result is that mating
tests may define species that encompass more
than one genetically and phylogenetically isolated
groups (Perkins and Turner, 1988; Chase
and Ullrich, 1990; Vilgalys and Sun, 1994;
Petersen and Hughes, 1999).
txt: A cross mating test is an in vitro experiment used to identify fungal species based on the biological species concept. According to this concept, groups of mating-compatible individuals are considered the same species. However, several obstacles limit the application of this theory to fungi: 1) many fungi are asexual and may have permanently lost the ability to reproduce sexually, thus not producing ascospores; 2) some species can produce ascospores without a partner (homothallic), such as C. falcatum and C. graminicola; 3) some heterothallic fungi fail to mate in artificial cultivation; and 4) there is substantial evidence that groups of genetically isolated fungi may retain ancestral traits of interbreeding. Consequently, mating tests may define species that encompass multiple genetically and phylogenetically isolated groups.
q1: What challenges do researchers face when applying the biological species concept to fungal species?
q2: How does the reproductive strategy of some fungi complicate species identification?
q3: In what ways can cross mating tests lead to the classification of multiple genetically isolated groups as a single species?
q4: Are many fungi capable of reproducing sexually?
q5: Can some fungi produce ascospores without a mating partner?
q6: Do mating tests sometimes identify species that contain more than one genetically isolated group?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
There have been few studies using cross
mating tests to distinguish between Colletotrichum
species. Guerber et al. (2003) tested
isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato
and concluded that two phylogenetically isolated
clades have retained the ability to mate.
Genetic isolation appears to have occurred
before reproductive isolations in the C. acutatum
complex. In the case of the Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides complex, sexual compatibility
had been reported to be limited to individuals
that share the same host range (Brasier, 1987).
Cisar et al. (1994) discovered that some isolates
of C. gloeosporioides that are pathogenic
to distantly related hosts are also sexually
compatible. This result is in agreement with
studies on C. acuatum, i.e. genetically isolated
strains may retain the ability to mate. Similar
findings have been reported for Fusarium and
other fungi (Donoghue, 1985; Taylor et al.,
2000; Leslie et al., 2001; Amata et al., in press).
txt: There have been few studies using cross-mating tests to distinguish between Colletotrichum species. Guerber et al. tested isolates of Colletotrichum acutatum sensu lato and concluded that two phylogenetically isolated clades have retained the ability to mate. Genetic isolation appears to have occurred before reproductive isolation in the C. acutatum complex. In the case of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex, sexual compatibility has been reported to be limited to individuals that share the same host range. Some isolates of C. gloeosporioides that are pathogenic to distantly related hosts are also sexually compatible. This result aligns with studies on C. acutatum, suggesting that genetically isolated strains may retain the ability to mate. Similar findings have been reported for Fusarium and other fungi.
q1: What implications do the findings about sexual compatibility in Colletotrichum species have for understanding their evolutionary biology?
q2: How do the mating behaviors of Colletotrichum species compare to those of other fungi like Fusarium?
q3: What role does host range play in the sexual compatibility of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides isolates?
q4: Did Guerber et al. (2003) find that two clades of Colletotrichum acutatum retained the ability to mate?
q5: Is sexual compatibility in Colletotrichum gloeosporioides limited to individuals sharing the same host range?
q6: Have similar findings regarding genetic isolation and mating compatibility been reported in other fungal species?

pdf:
It is noteworthy that most Colletotrichum
species lack a sexual state (Hyde et al., 2009),
and many of the known teleomorphs, such as
those of C. graminicola and C. sublineolum
(Carvajal and Edgerton, 1944; Politis, 1975;
Vaillancourt and Hanau, 1992), are characterised
based on mating experiments in the
laboratory. In this sense, mating experiments
are important for a comprehensive understanding
of Colletotrichum species and should
be undertaken in studies on Colletotrichum.
txt: It is noteworthy that most Colletotrichum species lack a sexual state, and many of the known teleomorphs, such as those of C. graminicola and C. sublineolum, are characterized based on mating experiments in the laboratory. In this sense, mating experiments are important for a comprehensive understanding of Colletotrichum species and should be undertaken in studies on this genus.

q2: Why might the absence of a sexual state in most Colletotrichum species be significant for researchers?

q6: Have known teleomorphs of Colletotrichum species been characterised through laboratory experiments?

pdf:
There have been numerous publications
on secondary metabolite production by Colletotrichum
species and the chemical structures
of some of these metabolites have been
elucidated. However there have been few
attempts to use metabolite profiling as a source
of markers for identification and classification
purposes (O’Connell et al., 1998; Abang et al.,
2009), or to integrate chemotaxonomy within a
polyphasic framework for resolving natural
relationships of taxa within Colletotrichum.
Secondary metabolite production has been
extensively studied in putative strains of C.
capsici, C. dematium, C. fragariae, C. gloeosporioides,
C. lagenarium, C. nicotianae and C.
truncatum but was not linked to taxonomy
(García-Pajón and Collado, 2003). This is in
distinct contrast to Alternaria, Annulohypoxylon,
Aspergillus, Fusarium, Hypoxylon,
Penicillium, Stachybotrys, Stemphylium, and
Trichoderma species, where secondary metabolites
have been found to be valuable
taxonomic markers (Stadler et al., 2004;
Frisvad et al., 2007, 2008; Anderson et al.,
2008;).
txt: Numerous publications have addressed secondary metabolite production by Colletotrichum species, and the chemical structures of some of these metabolites have been elucidated. However, there have been few attempts to use metabolite profiling as a source of markers for identification and classification purposes or to integrate chemotaxonomy within a polyphasic framework for resolving the natural relationships of taxa within Colletotrichum. Secondary metabolite production has been extensively studied in putative strains of C. capsici, C. dematium, C. fragariae, C. gloeosporioides, C. lagenarium, C. nicotianae, and C. truncatum, but it was not linked to taxonomy. This stands in distinct contrast to Alternaria, Annulohypoxylon, Aspergillus, Fusarium, Hypoxylon, Penicillium, Stachybotrys, Stemphylium, and Trichoderma species, where secondary metabolites have been found to be valuable taxonomic markers.
q1: What are the potential benefits of using metabolite profiling in the identification and classification of Colletotrichum species?
q2: How do the secondary metabolites of Colletotrichum species compare to those of other fungal genera in terms of their role in taxonomy?
q3: Why might there have been limited attempts to integrate chemotaxonomy within Colletotrichum despite extensive studies on its secondary metabolites?
q4: Have there been many studies on secondary metabolite production by Colletotrichum species?
q5: Is there a clear link between secondary metabolites and taxonomy in Colletotrichum species?
q6: Are secondary metabolites considered valuable taxonomic markers in other fungal species, according to the passage?

pdf:
One of the few studies of secondary
metabolites as taxonomic markers for distinguishing
Colletotrichum spp. involved the
use of lectins - proteins or glycoproteins that
contain binding sites complementary in shape
to particular monosaccharides or oligosaccharides
(O’Connell et al., 1998). Although lectin
cytochemistry proved to be valuable as a
chemotaxonomic tool, the technique is limited
by the relatively small number of sugars that
are recognised by lectins. A further limitation
of this approach is the difficulty to interpret
assay results when lectins show affinity for
more than one sugar or when binding involves
non-specific hydrophobic or ionic interactions
(O’Connell et al., 1998). O’Connell et al.
(1998) proposed the use of monoclonal antibodies
(MAb) in studies of Colletotrichum
identification and chemotaxonomy because
they offer a much wider range of binding sites
than lectins. Although antibodies have been
used in identification of species such as C.
gloeosporioides (Peters et al., 1998) and in
taxonomic studies of zoosporic fungi (Hardham
et al., 1991), their wider applicability in
resolving Colletotrichum systematics remains
to be investigated.
txt: One of the few studies of secondary metabolites as taxonomic markers for distinguishing Colletotrichum spp. involved the use of lectins?roteins or glycoproteins that contain binding sites complementary in shape to particular monosaccharides or oligosaccharides. Although lectin cytochemistry proved to be valuable as a chemotaxonomic tool, the technique is limited by the relatively small number of sugars recognized by lectins. A further limitation of this approach is the difficulty in interpreting assay results when lectins show affinity for more than one sugar or when binding involves non-specific hydrophobic or ionic interactions. It has been proposed to use monoclonal antibodies (MAb) in studies of Colletotrichum identification and chemotaxonomy because they offer a much wider range of binding sites than lectins. Although antibodies have been used in the identification of species such as C. gloeosporioides and in taxonomic studies of zoosporic fungi, their wider applicability in resolving Colletotrichum systematics remains to be investigated.
q1: What are the main advantages of using monoclonal antibodies over lectins in the identification of Colletotrichum species?
q2: Why might the interpretation of results using lectins be challenging in chemotaxonomic studies?
q3: How have previous studies utilized monoclonal antibodies in the identification of fungal species?
q4: Did O?onnell et al. suggest using monoclonal antibodies for Colletotrichum identification?
q5: Are lectins limited by the number of sugars they can recognize?
q6: Has the effectiveness of monoclonal antibodies in Colletotrichum systematics been fully explored?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Morphotype, virulence phenotype, phylotype
and chemotype were recently used in a
polyphasic approach to clarify the taxonomic
status of Colletotrichum isolates associated
with anthracnose disease of yam (Dioscorea
spp.) (Abang et al., 2009). Four morphotypes
of C. gloeosporioides sensu lato were recognised
associated with foliar anthracnose of yam:
slow growing grey (SGG); fast growing salmon
(FGS); fast-growing grey (FGG); and fast
growing olive (FGO). The FGG morphotype
showed a greater divergence from the other
three morphotypes based on ITS sequence data.
Secondary metabolite profiles in high performance
TLC (HPTLC) and high performance
liquid chromatography (HPLC) showed that
the pathogenic SGG and FGS forms had a
chemotype (A or B) that was distinct from the
non-pathogenic FGG form (chemotype C). A
highly phytotoxic HPLC fraction was detected
in virulent FGS and SGG strains, but was not
detected in the FGG strains. It was not possible
to distinguish the pathogenic FGS from SGG
forms of Colletotrichum based on their ITSbased
phylotype; however, they could be
clearly distinguished based on their combined
ITS and metabolite profiles (Abang et al.,
2009), which corroborated a previous finding
that these strains represented two genetically
distinct populations of C. gloeosporioides
sensu lato on yam (Abang et al., 2005). The
presence of outliers stresses the necessity to
have a large number of correctly identified
strains of the same taxon for robust chemotaxonomic
analyses (Anderson et al., 2008).
txt: Morphotype, virulence phenotype, phylotype, and chemotype were recently used in a polyphasic approach to clarify the taxonomic status of Colletotrichum isolates associated with anthracnose disease of yam (Dioscorea spp.). Four morphotypes of C. gloeosporioides sensu lato were recognized in relation to foliar anthracnose of yam: slow growing grey (SGG), fast growing salmon (FGS), fast growing grey (FGG), and fast growing olive (FGO). The FGG morphotype showed greater divergence from the other three morphotypes based on ITS sequence data. Secondary metabolite profiles analyzed by high performance TLC (HPTLC) and high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) indicated that the pathogenic SGG and FGS forms had distinct chemotypes (A or B) from the non-pathogenic FGG form (chemotype C). A highly phytotoxic HPLC fraction was detected in virulent FGS and SGG strains, but not in FGG strains. While it was not possible to distinguish the pathogenic FGS from SGG forms of Colletotrichum based on their ITS-based phylotype, they could be clearly distinguished by their combined ITS and metabolite profiles, corroborating previous findings that these strains represented two genetically distinct populations of C. gloeosporioides sensu lato on yam. The presence of outliers emphasizes the need for a large number of correctly identified strains of the same taxon for robust chemotaxonomic analyses.
q1: What methods were used to clarify the taxonomic status of Colletotrichum isolates associated with yam anthracnose?
q2: How do the morphotypes of C. gloeosporioides sensu lato differ in their growth rates and pathogenicity?
q3: Why is it important to have a large number of correctly identified strains for chemotaxonomic analyses?
q4: Did the study identify four different morphotypes of C. gloeosporioides sensu lato associated with yam anthracnose?
q5: Was a highly phytotoxic HPLC fraction found in the virulent FGS and SGG strains?
q6: Could the pathogenic FGS and SGG forms of Colletotrichum be distinguished based solely on their ITS-based phylotype?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
elucidate the taxonomic status of Colletotrichum
from yam could be applied to resolve the
systematics of the genus as a whole. Frisad et
al. (2008) noted that, “the use of secondary
metabolite profiling seems to be of greatest
value in Ascomycetes…” which should
motivate those planning to apply this tool to
Glomerella/Colletotrichum taxonomy. There
are important methodological considerations
that should be borne in mind in chemotaxonomic
studies, many of which have been
discussed by Frivad et al. (2008) and Anderson
et al. (2008). For instance, fungal cultures used
in comparative chemotaxonomic analysis
should be grown on the same medium, incubated
together at the same temperature, and
extracted at the same time, to ensure that
differences reflected fungal diversity and not
environmental conditions (Frisad et al., 2008).
HPLC methods also need to be standardized
and the lack of standards for certain known
metabolites makes it difficult to identify many
peaks in HPLC-DAD chromatograms.
txt: Elucidating the taxonomic status of Colletotrichum from yam could be applied to resolve the systematics of the genus as a whole. It has been noted that ?he use of secondary metabolite profiling seems to be of greatest value in Ascomycetes,??which should motivate those planning to apply this tool to Glomerella/Colletotrichum taxonomy. There are important methodological considerations that should be kept in mind in chemotaxonomic studies, many of which have been discussed in previous works. For instance, fungal cultures used in comparative chemotaxonomic analysis should be grown on the same medium, incubated together at the same temperature, and extracted at the same time to ensure that differences reflect fungal diversity and not environmental conditions. HPLC methods also need to be standardized, and the lack of standards for certain known metabolites makes it difficult to identify many peaks in HPLC-DAD chromatograms.
q1: How might secondary metabolite profiling enhance our understanding of Colletotrichum taxonomy?
q2: What are some key methodological considerations mentioned for conducting chemotaxonomic studies on fungi?
q3: Why is it important for fungal cultures to be grown under the same conditions in comparative analyses?
q4: Is the use of secondary metabolite profiling considered valuable for Ascomycetes?
q5: Should fungal cultures in chemotaxonomic studies be incubated at different temperatures?
q6: Are there known standards available for all metabolites in HPLC-DAD chromatograms?

pdf:
A new approach to Colletotrichum
systematics, which utilizes metabolite profiling
(thus bringing functional characters to the fore),
may help provide a better understanding of
species relationships in this genus. The correct
identification of a species and its strains using
ITS and other sequence data, is, however,
essential before such studies can take place.
Research in chemotaxonomy in Colletotrichum
is at an early stage and recommendations are
not made here.
txt: A new approach to Colletotrichum systematics, utilizing metabolite profiling to emphasize functional characters, may enhance our understanding of species relationships in this genus. However, the correct identification of a species and its strains using ITS and other sequence data is essential before such studies can occur. Research in chemotaxonomy within Colletotrichum is still in its early stages, and no recommendations are made at this time.
q1: How does metabolite profiling improve the understanding of species relationships in Colletotrichum?
q2: What role does ITS and sequence data play in identifying species and their strains in Colletotrichum?
q3: Why are recommendations not provided in the current research on chemotaxonomy in Colletotrichum?
q4: Is metabolite profiling a new approach to studying Colletotrichum systematics?
q5: Is the identification of species and their strains important for further research in this area?
q6: Is chemotaxonomy in Colletotrichum considered to be at an advanced stage?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Infraspecific groups within Colletotrichum
species are poorly understood and have
been mostly avoided in the paper on current
names (Hyde et al., 2009). The current Code of
Botanical Nomenclature provides a few formal
infraspecific categories: subspecies, variety and
form. Categories such as forma specialis and
pathotype have also been used by plant pathologists
for infraspecific groups with distinct
host specializations or behaviours (Cannon,
2000).
txt: Infraspecific groups within Colletotrichum species are poorly understood and have mostly been overlooked in the literature on current names. The current Code of Botanical Nomenclature provides a few formal infraspecific categories: subspecies, variety, and form. Additional categories, such as forma specialis and pathotype, have also been used by plant pathologists for infraspecific groups with distinct host specializations or behaviors.
q1: Why are infraspecific groups within Colletotrichum species considered poorly understood?
q2: What are the formal infraspecific categories recognized by the current Code of Botanical Nomenclature?
q3: How do plant pathologists differentiate infraspecific groups based on host specialization or behavior?
q4: Does the current Code of Botanical Nomenclature recognize multiple formal infraspecific categories?
q5: Have infraspecific groups within Colletotrichum species been the focus of research in the past?
q6: Is the term "pathotype" used exclusively in the context of Colletotrichum species?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
The use of subspecies, varieties and
forms within Colletotrichum have been variously
used with 33 introductions between
1940 and 2000. The fact that forma species or
varieties were intermittently used appear to
have depended as much on individual authors
as on any rules and until a clear understanding
of what constitutes a Colletotrichum species it
may be unwise to consider subspecies, forms
and varieties any further. From a pathology
view point there has been more recent use of
forma specialis and pathotype, with pathotypes
being most frequently used in the genus (Lubbe
et al., 2004; Suman et al., 2005; Moore et al.,
2008).
txt: The use of subspecies, varieties, and forms within Colletotrichum has varied, with 33 introductions between 1940 and 2000. The intermittent use of forma species or varieties seems to have depended more on individual authors than on established rules. Until there is a clear understanding of what constitutes a Colletotrichum species, it may be unwise to consider subspecies, forms, and varieties further. From a pathology viewpoint, there has been more recent use of forma specialis and pathotype, with pathotypes being the most frequently used in the genus.
q1: How has the classification of Colletotrichum species changed over time?
q2: What factors have influenced the use of subspecies, varieties, and forms in Colletotrichum research?
q3: Why might it be considered unwise to further categorize Colletotrichum into subspecies, forms, and varieties at this time?
q4: Have there been 33 introductions of Colletotrichum between 1940 and 2000?
q5: Is the classification of Colletotrichum species dependent on individual authors?
q6: Has there been an increase in the use of pathotypes in the study of Colletotrichum?

pdf:
For true pathotype differences there must
be a qualitative or phenotypic difference in
infection (virulence) between isolates on a set
of differential genotypes (Taylor and Ford,
2007). A quantitative difference in severity of
infection based on lesion size is simply a
reflection of the variation of aggressiveness of
isolates and does not constitute a true
pathotype difference (Taylor and Ford, 2007).
txt: For true pathotype differences, there must be a qualitative or phenotypic difference in infection (virulence) between isolates on a set of differential genotypes. A quantitative difference in the severity of infection based on lesion size is merely a reflection of the variation in aggressiveness of isolates and does not constitute a true pathotype difference.
q1: What criteria must be met to determine true pathotype differences between isolates?
q2: How do qualitative differences in infection differ from quantitative differences in lesion size?
q3: Why is lesion size not considered a true pathotype difference?
q4: Is a qualitative difference in virulence necessary to identify true pathotype differences?
q5: Does a variation in lesion size indicate a true pathotype difference?
q6: Can differences in aggressiveness among isolates be classified as true pathotype differences?

pdf:
Identification of pathotypes of Colletotrichum
species has been based on both qualitative
differences in infection, e.g. C. trifolii in
lucerne (Mackie et al., 2003); C. lindemuthianum
in bean (Gonzalez-Chavira et al., 2004); C.
acutatum in citrus (You et al., 2007); C.
sublineolum in sorghum (Moore et al., 2008);
C. capsici in chili pepper (Montri et al., 2009);
C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides in chili
pepper (Monkolporn et al., 2010) and
quantitative differences in severity (C. capsici
in chili pepper, Sharma et al. 2005; C. falcatum
in sugarcane, Suman et al., 2005) between
isolates on specific host genotypes.
txt: Identification of pathotypes of Colletotrichum species has been based on both qualitative differences in infection, such as C. trifolii in lucerne, C. lindemuthianum in bean, C. acutatum in citrus, C. sublineolum in sorghum, and C. capsici in chili pepper. Additionally, there are quantitative differences in severity, exemplified by C. capsici in chili pepper and C. falcatum in sugarcane, observed between isolates on specific host genotypes.
q1: How do the infection patterns of different Colletotrichum species vary across various host plants?
q2: What methods are used to identify different pathotypes of Colletotrichum species?
q3: Are there specific host genotypes that show varying levels of susceptibility to different Colletotrichum species?
q4: Is C. trifolii associated with lucerne?
q5: Does the passage mention quantitative differences in infection severity for C. capsici in chili pepper?
q6: Are C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides both found in chili pepper?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
There have been some reports of races of
Colletotrichum species; however, races of a
fungal pathogen only occur where differences
in isolates are determined by differences in
virulence genes and corresponding host resistance
genes, i.e. a gene for gene relationship as
occurs in rust diseases. Mackie et al. (2007)
linked races 1, 2 and 4 of C. trifolii to quantitative
trait loci (QTL) conferring resistance to
C. trifolii in lucerne. However, since the
relationship between specific genes for
avirulence in the pathogen and resistance genes
in the host has not been established, these
variations in the pathogen should be referred to
as pathotypes as described by Irwin et al.
(2006).
txt: There have been reports of races of Colletotrichum species; however, races of a fungal pathogen occur only when differences among isolates are determined by variations in virulence genes and corresponding host resistance genes, indicating a gene-for-gene relationship, similar to that observed in rust diseases. Mackie et al. linked races 1, 2, and 4 of C. trifolii to quantitative trait loci (QTL) conferring resistance to C. trifolii in lucerne. However, since the relationship between specific avirulence genes in the pathogen and resistance genes in the host has not been established, these variations in the pathogen should be referred to as pathotypes.
q1: What criteria determine the classification of races in Colletotrichum species?
q2: How do the findings of Mackie et al. (2007) relate to resistance in lucerne?
q3: Why should variations in the pathogen be referred to as pathotypes instead of races?
q4: Do reports of Colletotrichum species indicate the presence of races?
q5: Has the relationship between avirulence genes in pathogens and resistance genes in hosts been established?
q6: Are variations in the pathogen described by Irwin et al. (2006) classified as pathotypes?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
The identification of pathotypes is not
only important as a taxonomic tool at the
infraspecific level of a Colletotrichum species,
but has implications for plant breeders trying to
develop new improved genotypes with durable
resistance to a pathogen. Pathotypic differences
actually help to relate the infraspecific taxonomy
back to the biological interaction of the
pathogen to specific genotypes of a host.
txt: The identification of pathotypes is important as a taxonomic tool at the infraspecific level of Colletotrichum species and has implications for plant breeders aiming to develop new, improved genotypes with durable resistance to pathogens. Pathotypic differences help relate infraspecific taxonomy to the biological interactions between the pathogen and specific host genotypes.
q1: Why is identifying pathotypes important for plant breeders?
q2: How do pathotypic differences contribute to understanding the relationship between pathogens and host plants?
q3: In what ways might the classification of pathotypes affect the development of new plant varieties?
q4: Is the identification of pathotypes considered a taxonomic tool?
q5: Do pathotypic differences have any relevance to plant breeding?
q6: Can understanding pathotypes help in developing plants with durable resistance to pathogens?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
The identification of Colletotrichum
species needs to be simple and quick as it has
important implications for biosecurity, disease
control and plant breeding. There is now a
major effort to establish species concepts and
formalise names in current use. It is unlikely
that morphology will solve many problems in
species delineation, but a polyphasic approach
can be used to establish species boundaries, for
epitypification of existing names and for the
introduction of new species. Ideally, a single
gene will be found that can be used for
barcode-like identification of species in a quick
and simple way.
txt: The identification of Colletotrichum species needs to be simple and quick, as it has important implications for biosecurity, disease control, and plant breeding. There is now a major effort to establish species concepts and formalize names currently in use. While morphology is unlikely to resolve many issues in species delineation, a polyphasic approach can effectively establish species boundaries, facilitate epitypification of existing names, and introduce new species. Ideally, a single gene will be identified for quick and simple barcode-like species identification.
q1: Why is it important to identify Colletotrichum species quickly?
q2: What challenges are associated with using morphology for species delineation?
q3: What is the goal of the ongoing efforts related to Colletotrichum species identification?
q4: Is there a current effort to formalize species names for Colletotrichum?
q5: Does the passage suggest that morphology alone is sufficient for identifying these species?
q6: Is the identification of Colletotrichum species considered important for biosecurity?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
DNA barcoding aims to establish an
accurate, rapid, cost-effective and universally
accessible identification system for organisms
by using short and standardised segments of
the genome (Herbert et al., 2003, 2004;
Summerbell et al., 2005). It is particularly
important to establish a DNA barcoding system
for Colletotrichum species, as they have very
simple morphologies and the current taxonomy
is very confused. The success of Colletotrichum
barcoding relies on highly reliable
sequences from the type or verified strains and
the selection of most appropriate of gene(s).
txt: DNA barcoding aims to establish an accurate, rapid, cost-effective, and universally accessible identification system for organisms by using short, standardized segments of the genome. It is particularly important to develop a DNA barcoding system for Colletotrichum species, as their simple morphologies have led to a confused taxonomy. The success of Colletotrichum barcoding depends on highly reliable sequences from type or verified strains and the selection of the most appropriate gene(s).
q1: Why is DNA barcoding considered particularly important for identifying Colletotrichum species?
q2: What challenges does the current taxonomy of Colletotrichum species present?
q3: How does the success of DNA barcoding for Colletotrichum species depend on the quality of the sequences used?
q4: Is DNA barcoding intended to be a universally accessible identification system for organisms?
q5: Are Colletotrichum species characterized by complex morphologies?
q6: Does the effectiveness of DNA barcoding for Colletotrichum depend on the selection of appropriate genes?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species
complex contains taxa with significant
biological, morphological, and genetic diversity
(Sutton, 1992; Hyde et al., 2009). Some of
these taxa have been named as separate species
e.g. C. fragariae (Johnston et al., 2008). ITS
region has a poor ability to discriminate clades
within this group, hence a more appropriate
biomarker is required for use in barcoding. The
ideal locus for use in barcoding has low
heterogeneity within species, yet enough variation
to allow maximum separation of different
species. The first requirement allows strains of
the same species to be easily grouped and
identified. The second requirement ensures that
misidentifications are minimised. It is also
important, that the gene can be easily sequenced
for all species and does not require
specific primers for each group (Seifert, 2009;
Gilmore et al., 2009; Chen et al., 2009).
txt: The Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex contains taxa with significant biological, morphological, and genetic diversity. Some of these taxa have been named as separate species, such as C. fragariae. The ITS region has a poor ability to discriminate clades within this group, necessitating a more appropriate biomarker for use in barcoding. The ideal locus for barcoding should exhibit low heterogeneity within species while providing enough variation to maximize separation between different species. This ensures that strains of the same species can be easily grouped and identified, minimizing misidentifications. Additionally, it is crucial that the gene can be easily sequenced for all species without requiring specific primers for each group.
q1: What are the implications of the biological, morphological, and genetic diversity within the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex for species identification?
q2: Why is the ITS region considered a poor biomarker for barcoding within this group?
q3: What characteristics define the ideal locus for barcoding in fungal species?
q4: Does the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides species complex include taxa that have been classified as separate species?
q5: Is the ITS region recommended for use in barcoding for all taxa within this species complex?
q6: Should the ideal barcoding locus be easy to sequence without requiring specific primers for different groups?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
We used a diverse set of 64 Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides sensu lato isolates
(and two C. boninense strains as outgroups)
previously analysed by Johnston et al. (2008).
Each isolate was sequenced with six genes: ITS,
GPDH (glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase),
CAL (calmodulin), ACT (actin), CHS (chitin
synthase), and EF1α (elongation factor 1α).
The 64 taxa were assigned to five groups on
the basis of a multigene phylogeny (Johnston et
al., 2008). Two groups represented named
species (C. fragariae and C. horii) and one
group represented Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
sensu stricto. The remaining two
groups A and B (sensu Johnston and Jones,
1997) consisted of diverse mostly unnamed
isolates, although C. musae is in Group A, and
C. kahawae is in Group B. A similarity matrix
was generated for each gene, and results were
analysed in TaxonGap 2.4.1 (Slabbinck et al.,
2008).
txt: We used a diverse set of 64 Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu lato isolates, along with two C. boninense strains as outgroups, previously analyzed by Johnston et al. Each isolate was sequenced for six genes: ITS, GPDH (glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase), CAL (calmodulin), ACT (actin), CHS (chitin synthase), and EF1帢 (elongation factor 1帢). The 64 taxa were assigned to five groups based on a multigene phylogeny. Two groups represented named species (C. fragariae and C. horii), while one group represented Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu stricto. The remaining two groups, A and B, consisted of diverse mostly unnamed isolates; however, C. musae is in Group A, and C. kahawae is in Group B. A similarity matrix was generated for each gene, and results were analyzed using TaxonGap 2.4.1.
q1: What criteria were used to classify the 64 Colletotrichum isolates into different groups?
q2: How many genes were sequenced for each isolate, and what are their names?
q3: What role did the outgroup strains play in the analysis of the Colletotrichum isolates?
q4: Were two strains of C. boninense used as outgroups in the study?
q5: Did the analysis involve a total of six genes for sequencing?
q6: Is C. musae included in Group A of the diverse isolates?

The results (Fig. 2) graphically summarise
the heterogeneity within each of the
assigned groups (light grey bar), and the separability
of species (dark grey bar). Separability
represents the ability of the gene to distinguish
between groups, the minimum separability of
GPDH, CAL, ACT, and EF1α is good at 12.2,
11.7, 9.5, and 9.9, respectively. In contrast ITS
and CHS have low minimum separability
values of 3.9 and 0.3, respectively.
txt: The results graphically summarize the heterogeneity within each of the assigned groups (light grey bar) and the separability of species (dark grey bar). Separability reflects the ability of the gene to distinguish between groups. The minimum separability for GPDH, CAL, ACT, and EF1帢 is relatively good at 12.2, 11.7, 9.5, and 9.9, respectively. In contrast, ITS and CHS show low minimum separability values of 3.9 and 0.3, respectively.

pdf:
The heterogeneity values (intra-species
variation) ideally should be low, certainly less
than the respective separability value. In most
cases this is true, with the notable exception of
EF1α in Groups A, B, sensu stricto, and C.
boninense. This is likely the result of the high
variability of introns in EF1α sequences of
Colletotrichum species, which is likely to be
more useful in population level studies, rather
than systematics or barcoding. Across all the
genes the heterogeneity values for Groups A
and B are high, this may imply that these
groups consist of several different taxa, and
should be subdivided further. It can be
concluded from this analysis that within
Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu lato
GPDH, CAL, and ACT are good candidates for
barcodes; whilst ITS, CHS, and EF1α are poor
candidates.
txt: The heterogeneity values (intra-species variation) should ideally be low, certainly less than the respective separability value. In most cases, this holds true, with notable exceptions in EF1帢 for Groups A, B, sensu stricto, and C. This is likely due to the high variability of introns in EF1帢 sequences of Colletotrichum species, making it more useful for population-level studies rather than for systematics or barcoding. Across all genes, the heterogeneity values for Groups A and B are high, suggesting these groups may consist of several different taxa and should be subdivided further. This analysis concludes that within Colletotrichum gloeosporioides sensu lato, GPDH, CAL, and ACT are good candidates for barcodes, while ITS, CHS, and EF1帢 are poor candidates.
q1: Why are heterogeneity values important in the analysis of Colletotrichum species?
q2: What does the high variability of introns in EF1帢 suggest about its utility in studies?
q3: How might the findings about Groups A and B influence future taxonomic classifications?
q4: Are the heterogeneity values for Groups A and B considered low?
q5: Is EF1帢 identified as a poor candidate for barcoding in this analysis?
q6: Does the analysis suggest that GPDH, CAL, and ACT are suitable for use as barcodes?

A similar set of six genes (ITS, ACT,

species with curved conidia from
herbaceous hosts, which included six different
clades. The separability of the species was best
with both GPDH and histone 3 genes, which
are superior to ITS, ACT, CHS and betatubulin.

pdf:
The most appropriate gene for barcoding
Colletotrichum must be selected in the process
of species delimitation, since we can only
decide for one or more barcoding gene(s) when
we know which taxa need to be distinguished
by it. A good approach would be to test and
establish a selection of loci used by the
different groups involved in Colletotrichum
systematics in order to work towards the best
barcoding gene.
txt: The most appropriate gene for barcoding Colletotrichum must be selected during the species delimitation process, as we can only choose one or more barcoding genes when we identify the taxa that need distinction. A good approach would be to test and establish a selection of loci used by the various groups involved in Colletotrichum systematics to work towards identifying the ultimate barcoding gene.

q5: Should different groups in Colletotrichum systematics work together on gene selection?
q6: Can a single barcoding gene suffice for all species of Colletotrichum?

pdf:
Endophytes and pathogens without
visible sporulation: Plant tissues are cut into
small pieces, surface sterilized by dipping in
1% sodium hypochlorite for 1 minute, in 70%
ethanol for 1 minute and rinsed three times
with sterilized water and finally dried on
sterilized tissue paper. The plant tissues are
then placed onto potato dextrose agar (PDA)
containing 100 μg/ml streptomycin and 50
μg/ml tetracycline to allow fungal growth. The
mycelia growing from pieces of plant tissues
are transferred onto a new PDA plate for
morphological or molecular study (Than et al.,
2008b).
txt: Endophytes and pathogens without visible sporulation: Plant tissues are cut into small pieces and surface sterilized by dipping in 1% sodium hypochlorite for 1 minute, followed by 70% ethanol for 1 minute. They are then rinsed three times with sterilized water and dried on sterilized tissue paper. The plant tissues are placed onto potato dextrose agar (PDA) containing 100 弮g/ml streptomycin and 50 弮g/ml tetracycline to promote fungal growth. The mycelia growing from the pieces of plant tissue are transferred onto a new PDA plate for morphological or molecular study.

q2: Why are specific antibiotics like streptomycin and tetracycline used in the agar?
q3: What types of studies can be conducted with the transferred mycelia?
q4: Are the plant tissues rinsed with sterilized water after the ethanol treatment?
q5: Is potato dextrose agar (PDA) used for promoting fungal growth?
q6: Are endophytes and pathogens being distinguished in this method?

pdf:
Pathogens or epiphytes with visible
sporulation: A single spore isolation technique
should be applied to plant tissues where spore
masses are formed. Spore masses are transferred
with a sterilized wire loop or fine
forceps and suspended in sterilized water. The
spore suspension is diluted to a reasonable
concentration and spread onto the surface of
PDA agar, followed by incubation overnight at
25°C. Single germinated spores are picked up
with a sterilised needle and transferred onto
new PDA plate for further study (Goh et al.,
1999).
txt: Pathogens or epiphytes with visible sporulation require a single spore isolation technique for plant tissues where spore masses are formed. Spore masses should be transferred using a sterilized wire loop or fine forceps and suspended in sterilized water. The spore suspension is then diluted to a reasonable concentration and spread onto the surface of PDA agar, followed by overnight incubation at 25簞C. Single germinated spores are picked up with a sterilized needle and transferred onto a new PDA plate for further study.

q3: What role does temperature play in the incubation of spore masses?

pdf:
There is a need to standardise incubation
parameters for Colletotrichum species as it is
difficult or impossible to compare the morphology
of species that have been grown under
different conditions. For inoculation, it is
suggested to aseptically punch and transfer a
mycelial disc (about 4 mm diam.) from the
actively growing edge of a 5 day old single
conidium derived culture onto PDA. Cultures
are incubated at 20, 25 and 30°C under
constant fluorescent light. We do not suggest
Sutton’s protocol as we think the switch of
ultra violet irradiation and dark is not always
practical and may bring in many more factors
that might impact the growth of fungus. Three
replicate cultures of each isolate should be
investigated. After 7 days, conidial size and
shape from >25 conidia should be measured
and recorded, while colony characters can be
recorded and photographed (Than et al., 2008a).
Observation and measurements (e.g. conidial
size, appressoria size and conidiogenous cells)
should be made in water mounts.
txt: There is a need to standardize incubation parameters for Colletotrichum species, as it is difficult or impossible to compare the morphology of species grown under different conditions. For inoculation, it is suggested to aseptically punch and transfer a mycelial disc (about 4 mm in diameter) from the actively growing edge of a 5-day-old single-conidium-derived culture onto PDA. Cultures are incubated at 20, 25, and 30簞C under constant fluorescent light. We do not recommend Sutton? protocol, as the switch between ultraviolet irradiation and darkness is not always practical and may introduce additional factors that could impact fungal growth. Three replicate cultures of each isolate should be investigated. After 7 days, conidial size and shape from more than 25 conidia should be measured and recorded, while colony characteristics can be documented and photographed. Observations and measurements (e.g., conidial size, appressoria size, and conidiogenous cells) should be made in water mounts.
q1: Why is it important to standardize incubation parameters for Colletotrichum species?
q2: What alternative inoculation method is suggested instead of Sutton? protocol?
q3: What specific measurements are recommended to be taken after incubating the cultures for 7 days?
q4: Is it recommended to use constant fluorescent light during the incubation of Colletotrichum species?
q5: Should three replicate cultures of each isolate be investigated?
q6: Is Sutton? protocol suggested for the inoculation process?

pdf:
Appressoria should be produced using a
slide culture technique, in which 10 mm2 plugs
of PDA are placed in an empty Petri dish. The
edge of the agar is inoculated with spores taken
from a sporulating culture and a sterile cover
slip is placed over the inoculated agar (Johnston
and Jones, 1997). After 7 days, the shape
and size of the appressoria formed on the
underside of the cover slip could be recorded
(Fig. 3).
txt: Appressoria should be produced using a slide culture technique, in which 10 mm簡 plugs of PDA are placed in an empty Petri dish. The edge of the agar is inoculated with spores taken from a sporulating culture, and a sterile cover slip is placed over the inoculated agar. After 7 days, the shape and size of the appressoria formed on the underside of the cover slip can be recorded.
q1: What role do the 10 mm簡 plugs of PDA play in the slide culture technique for producing appressoria?
q2: Why is a sterile cover slip used in the slide culture technique?
q3: What observations can be made after the 7-day incubation period regarding the appressoria?
q4: Is the slide culture technique used to produce appressoria?
q5: Does the passage mention that the appressoria should be recorded after 7 days?
q6: Are spores taken from a sporulating culture used to inoculate the agar?

pdf:
Multi-locus phylogeny is a powerful tool
to diagnose Colletotrichum species and has
been widely employed (Johnston et al., 2008;
Crouch et al., 2009b; Prihastuti et al., 2009;
Yang et al., 2009). Unfortunately, dif-ferent
research groups have been utilizing different
gene regions. For example Crouch et al.
(2009b) used ITS, Apn2, Sod2 and Mat1-2
gene regions; Prihastuti et al. (2009) used ITS,
CAL, GS, GPDH, ACT and TUB2 gene
regions; Johnston et al. (2008) employed
additional gene regions such as EF1α and CHS.
To facilitate future study and comprehensive
comparison of Colletotrichum species, it is
important that an agreement should be formed
on how many and which genes should be
sequenced. An even more important issue is the
interpretation of phylogenetic groups in terms
of classification. Currently there is no consensus
over what constitutes a species,
although researchers started to adopt “genealogical
concordance” to recognise phylogenetic
species (Taylor et al., 2000). In this paper we
suggest that species rank should be given to
well defined phylogenetic lineages that are in
conjunction with recognisable phenotypic
characters.
txt: Multi-locus phylogeny is a powerful tool for diagnosing Colletotrichum species and has been widely employed. Unfortunately, different research groups have utilized varying gene regions. For example, some used ITS, Apn2, Sod2, and Mat1-2, while others used ITS, CAL, GS, GPDH, ACT, and TUB2. Additional gene regions such as EF1帢 and CHS have also been employed. To facilitate future studies and comprehensive comparisons of Colletotrichum species, it is crucial to reach an agreement on which genes should be sequenced. An even more pressing issue is the interpretation of phylogenetic groups concerning classification. Currently, there is no consensus on what constitutes a species, although researchers have begun adopting "genealogical concordance" to recognize phylogenetic species. In this paper, we suggest that species rank should be assigned to well-defined phylogenetic lineages that correspond with recognizable phenotypic characters.
q1: What are some of the specific gene regions that different research groups have used for diagnosing Colletotrichum species?
q2: Why is it important to reach an agreement on the gene regions used in multi-locus phylogeny for Colletotrichum species?
q3: How does the lack of consensus on species classification affect research in phylogenetic studies of Colletotrichum?
q4: Have different research groups used the same gene regions for diagnosing Colletotrichum species?
q5: Is there currently a consensus on what constitutes a species in the context of Colletotrichum?
q6: Should species rank be based solely on genetic data according to the authors of the paper?

pdf:
Punch and aseptically transfer a mycelial
disc (about 4 mm diam.) from the actively
growing edge of a 5 day old single conidium
derived culture onto PDA. Cultures are
incubated at 25°C under constant fluorescent
light. Three replicate cultures of each isolate
should be investigated. Colony diameter of the
culture is measured daily for 7 days. Growth
rate can be calculated as the 7 day average of
mean daily growth (mm per day). After 7 days,
colony size and colour of the conidial masses
and zonation should be recorded.
txt: Punch and aseptically transfer a mycelial disc (about 4 mm in diameter) from the actively growing edge of a 5-day-old single conidium-derived culture onto PDA. Cultures should be incubated at 25簞C under constant fluorescent light. Three replicate cultures of each isolate should be investigated. Measure the colony diameter of the culture daily for 7 days. The growth rate can be calculated as the 7-day average of mean daily growth (mm per day). After 7 days, record the colony size, color of the conidial masses, and zonation.

q2: Why are three replicate cultures investigated for each isolate?
q3: How is the growth rate of the culture determined?
q4: Is the mycelial disc taken from a single conidium derived culture?
q5: Are the cultures incubated at a temperature other than 25簞C?
q6: Is colony diameter measured daily for a period longer than 7 days?
