pdf:
Biochemical testing can also be utilized
as it has been reported in several studies that
biochemical characters, especially the ability to
utilize citrate or tartrate as a sole carbon source
could be used to differentiate some closely
related species (Bridge et al., 2008; Prihastuti
et al., 2009). The biochemical test based on
substrate utilization could be assessed in agar
plates according to the method of Bridge et al.
(2008). Utilization of citrate and tartrate as a
carbon source are assayed on agar plates.
Medium B (contains NH3H2PO4 1.0g/L; KCl
0.2 g/L; MgSO4.7H2O 0.2g/L in distilled water)
with 1.2% (w/v) agar is supplemented with 1%
(w/v) citric acid or ammonium tartrate and
0.005% (w/v) bromocresol purple (Waller et al.,
1993; Bridge et al., 2008). Positive and negative
controls containing, respectively, glucose
or no additional carbon source are included for
each isolate.
txt: Biochemical testing can be utilized, as several studies have reported that biochemical characteristics, particularly the ability to utilize citrate or tartrate as a sole carbon source, can differentiate closely related species. The biochemical test based on substrate utilization can be assessed on agar plates. Medium B (containing NH3H2PO4 1.0 g/L; KCl 0.2 g/L; MgSO4繚7H2O 0.2 g/L in distilled water) with 1.2% (w/v) agar is supplemented with 1% (w/v) citric acid or ammonium tartrate and 0.005% (w/v) bromocresol purple. Positive and negative controls containing glucose or no additional carbon source, respectively, are included for each isolate.

q3: What role do positive and negative controls play in the biochemical testing process?
q4: Is citrate used as a carbon source in the testing method?
q5: Does the testing method involve agar plates?
q6: Are glucose and no additional carbon source used as controls in the experiment?

pdf:
All media should be adjusted to pH 4.5
with NaOH or HCl prior to sterilization
(Waller et al., 1993; Bridge et al., 2008). Test
media are inoculated with agar plugs (4 mm
diam) taken from 5 day old single conidium
derived cultures. Utilization is assessed by
visual comparison of growth and a rise in the
pH of the medium adequate to produce a dark
blue to purple colour of bromocresol purple
(Waller et al., 1993; Bridge et al., 2008).
txt: All media should be adjusted to pH 4.5 with NaOH or HCl prior to sterilization. Test media are inoculated with agar plugs (4 mm diam) taken from 5-day-old single-conidium derived cultures. Utilization is assessed by visual comparison of growth and a rise in the pH of the medium sufficient to produce a dark blue to purple color of bromocresol purple.

pdf:
Pure cultures of each isolate are grown
on PDA for 7–14 days at 25oC under
alternating 12 hour fluorescent light /12 hour
dark cycle to induce sporulation (Than et al.,
2008b). The conidia are harvested by placing
1–5 ml sterilized distilled water onto the
culture, which is then gently swirled and
scraped to harvest the conidia. The conidial
suspension is filtered through two layers of
muslin cloth. The spore density is adjusted to a
concentration of 1 × 106 spore/ml using a
haemocytometer (Tshering, 2006).
txt: Pure cultures of each isolate are grown on PDA for 7??4 days at 25簞C under an alternating 12-hour fluorescent light and 12-hour dark cycle to induce sporulation. The conidia are harvested by adding 1?? ml of sterilized distilled water to the culture, which is then gently swirled and scraped to collect the conidia. The conidial suspension is filtered through two layers of muslin cloth. The spore density is adjusted to a concentration of 1 ? 10^6 spores/ml using a haemocytometer.

pdf:
Freshly harvested, untreated, mature but
unripe fruits, leaves or other part plants are
washed under running tap water for 60 seconds
followed by surface sterilization by immersing
the fruits in 70% ethanol for 3 minutes, 1%
sodium hypochlorite solution for 3 minutes and
then rinsing three times in sterilised distilled
water for 2 minutes each time and drying with
sterile tissue paper and then air drying (Sanders
and Korsten, 2003; Montri et al., 2009).
txt: Freshly harvested, untreated, mature but unripe fruits, leaves, or other plant parts are washed under running tap water for 60 seconds, followed by surface sterilization. This is done by immersing the fruits in 70% ethanol for 3 minutes, then in a 1% sodium hypochlorite solution for 3 minutes. After this, they are rinsed three times in sterilized distilled water for 2 minutes each time, dried with sterile tissue paper, and then air-dried.
q1: What are the specific steps involved in the surface sterilization process?
q2: Why is it important to wash the fruits before sterilization?
q3: What are the potential benefits of using untreated, mature but unripe fruits for this process?
q4: Is 70% ethanol used in the sterilization process?
q5: Are the fruits rinsed multiple times after using sodium hypochlorite?
q6: Is air drying part of the sterilization procedure?

pdf:
The surface sterilized fruits and leaves
are placed in a plastic box that contains sterile
tissue paper soaked in sterile distilled water to
maintain around 95% relative humidity (Montri
et al., 2009). The samples are inoculated using
the wound/drop and non-wound /drop
inoculation methods (Lin et al., 2002;
Kanchana-udomkan et al., 2004; Than et al.,
2008b). Inoculation with wound/drop method
is accomplished by pin-pricking the fruits or
leaf with a sterile needle in the middle portion
of fruit or leaf and then placing 6 μl of conidia
suspension onto the wound (Freeman and
Shabi, 1996; Than et al., 2008b). Control fruits
and leaves are inoculated with 6 μl of sterile
distilled water. The inoculated samples are
incubated in containers at room temperature in
normal light regimes for 7–14 days (Figs 4–5)
(Than et al., 2008b). The non-wound/drop
method involves placing 6 μl of conidial
suspension onto the middle of each fruit or leaf
(Lin et al., 2002; Kanchana-udomkan et al.,
2004).
txt: The surface-sterilized fruits and leaves are placed in a plastic box containing sterile tissue paper soaked in sterile distilled water to maintain around 95% relative humidity. The samples are inoculated using the wound/drop and non-wound/drop inoculation methods. Inoculation with the wound/drop method is achieved by pin-pricking the fruits or leaves with a sterile needle in the middle portion and then placing 6 弮l of conidia suspension onto the wound. Control fruits and leaves are inoculated with 6 弮l of sterile distilled water. The inoculated samples are incubated in containers at room temperature under normal light regimes for 7??4 days. The non-wound/drop method involves placing 6 弮l of conidial suspension onto the middle of each fruit or leaf.
q1: What purpose does maintaining 95% relative humidity serve in the experiment?
q2: How do the wound/drop and non-wound/drop inoculation methods differ in their approach?
q3: What is the role of sterile distilled water in the control samples?
q4: Are the fruits and leaves sterilized before being placed in the plastic box?
q5: Is the inoculation performed using two different methods?
q6: Do the inoculated samples require incubation for 7??4 days?

pdf:
Evaluation of anthracnose symptoms
such as lesion appearance, lesion size, conidia
characteristics and the severity of infection is
carried out from 7 to 14 days after inoculation
(Figs 6–7). Lesion development on fruits and
leaves are assessed by the percentage of disease
area on each fruit and leaf (lesion area divided
by the total fruit/leaf area). Symptoms are
evaluated and scored on a 0-9 point scale based
on the percentage of the infected area as
outlined by Montri et al. (2009) (Table 2).
txt: Evaluation of anthracnose symptoms, such as lesion appearance, lesion size, conidia characteristics, and the severity of infection, is carried out from 7 to 14 days after inoculation. Lesion development on fruits and leaves is assessed by the percentage of disease area on each fruit and leaf (lesion area divided by the total fruit or leaf area). Symptoms are evaluated and scored on a 0-9 point scale based on the percentage of the infected area.
q1: What factors influence the severity of anthracnose symptoms?
q2: How is the lesion area calculated in relation to the total area of the fruit or leaf?
q3: What methodology is used to score the symptoms of anthracnose?
q4: Is the evaluation of anthracnose symptoms conducted within a specific time frame after inoculation?
q5: Does the scoring system for symptoms range from 0 to 9?
q6: Are the symptoms assessed based on the percentage of infected area?

Table 2. Anthracnose severity scores and the symptom description.
Score Symptom description
0 no infection.
1
1–2% of the fruit area shows necrotic lesion or a larger water soaked lesion surrounding the infection site.
3
>2–5% of the fruit area shows necrotic lesion, acervuli may be present/or water lesion up to 5% of the fruit
surface.
5 >5–15% of the fruit area shows necrotic lesion, acervuli present/or water soaked lesion up to 25% of the fruit
surface.
7 >15–25% of the fruit area shows necrotic lesion with acervuli
9 >25% of the fruit area shows necrosis, lesion often encircling the fruit, abundant acervuli.

pdf:
It is worth mentioning that artificial
inoculations are often conducted on detached
or whole plants under extreme conditions and
the success of infection appears to be
dependent on inoculum density (Bailey and
Jeger, 1992), whereas no infection may occur
under field conditions (Freeman et al., 1998).
Artificial host inoculation is, to some extent,
not reliable for determining host range or hostspecificity,
but is an indicator of infection
potential (Freeman et al., 1998). Some research
has shown that pathogenicity tests may not be
reliable on detached plant tissues because of
suppression of host defense pathways (Liu et
al., 2007).
txt: It is worth noting that artificial inoculations are often conducted on detached or whole plants under extreme conditions, and the success of infection seems to depend on inoculum density. However, no infection may occur under field conditions. While artificial host inoculation is not entirely reliable for determining host range or host specificity, it serves as an indicator of infection potential. Some research has shown that pathogenicity tests on detached plant tissues may not be reliable due to the suppression of host defense pathways.
q1: What factors influence the success of artificial inoculations in plants?
q2: How do artificial host inoculation results differ from field conditions regarding infection?
q3: Why might pathogenicity tests on detached plant tissues be unreliable?
q4: Is inoculum density a factor that affects the success of artificial inoculations?
q5: Can artificial inoculation reliably determine host specificity?
q6: Do detached plant tissues suppress host defense pathways during pathogenicity tests?

pdf:
We suggest the protocol as outlined by
Guerber and Correll (2001) and Guerber et al.
(2003). Modified Czapek-dox agar media (2 g
NaNO3, 1 g K2HPO4, 0.5 g MgSO4·H2O, 0.5 g
KCl, 0.01 g FeSO4 and 20 g agar, per liter,
pH7.8) is used. For inoculation, aseptically
punch and transfer a mycelial disc (4 mm diam.)
from the actively growing edge of a 5 day old
single conidium derived culture to the agar.
Two parental isolates are placed opposite to
each other and approximately 1 cm from the
edge of 9 cm Petri plates. Autoclaved flat
woody toothpicks are applied to serve as a
substrate for ascomata formation. Three
toothpicks are placed on the agar in an “N”
arrangement. Plates are incubated at 25ºC
under constant cool white fluorescent light.
After 20–30 days, the mating plates are
examined under a microscope for the presence
of ascomata. Successful crosses result in a
ridge of mature ascomata containing asci with
ascospores being formed at the line of contact.
Ascomata are removed from the toothpick
using fine forceps and mounted in a drop of
sterilized water and crushed under a cover slip.
A combination of a qualitative and quantitative
rating system is used to score the sexual
fertility of each cross. Fertility of cross is
scored on a scale of 0–7 (Guerber et al., 2003):
0 = no structures; 1 = small sterile structures; 2
= sterile perithecia with beaks, no asci; 3 =
sterile perithecia with asci, no ascospores; 4 =
asci with a few ascospores; 5 = fertile
perithecia with many ascospores, few asci with
eight spores; 6 = fertile perithecia with
abundant ascospores, many asci with eight
spores; 7 = perithecia exuding ascospores from
ostiole. Crosses scored 5 or higher are
considered fertile. Ascospore viability should
be assessed for crosses with a fertility score
above 4. Monoascospore cultures are obtained
by removing an individual ascomata and
placing it into drop of sterile water. The
ascospores released into the water are spread
onto PDA for growth.
txt:
We suggest following the protocol outlined by Guerber and Correll (2001) and Guerber et al. (2003). Modified Czapek-Dox agar media (2 g NaNO₃, 1 g K₂HPO₄, 0.5 g MgSO₄·H₂O, 0.5 g KCl, 0.01 g FeSO₄, and 20 g agar per liter, pH 7.8) is used. For inoculation, aseptically punch and transfer a 4 mm diameter mycelial disc from the actively growing edge of a 5-day-old single conidium-derived culture to the agar. Two parental isolates are placed opposite each other, approximately 1 cm from the edge of a 9 cm Petri plate. Autoclaved flat wooden toothpicks are used as a substrate for ascomata formation, arranged in an “N” shape on the agar. Plates are incubated at 25ºC under constant cool white fluorescent light. After 20–30 days, the mating plates are examined under a microscope for the presence of ascomata.

Successful crosses result in a ridge of mature ascomata containing asci with ascospores at the line of contact. Ascomata are removed from the toothpicks using fine forceps, mounted in a drop of sterile water, and crushed under a cover slip. A combination of qualitative and quantitative rating systems is used to score the sexual fertility of each cross, rated on a scale of 0–7:
0 = no structures
1 = small sterile structures
2 = sterile perithecia with beaks, no asci
3 = sterile perithecia with asci, no ascospores
4 = asci with a few ascospores
5 = fertile perithecia with many ascospores, few asci with eight spores
6 = fertile perithecia with abundant ascospores, many asci with eight spores
7 = perithecia exuding ascospores from the ostiole

Crosses scored 5 or higher are considered fertile. Ascospore viability should be assessed for crosses with a fertility score above 4. Monoascospore cultures are obtained by removing an individual ascoma and placing it into a drop of sterile water. The released ascospores are spread onto PDA for growth.
q1: What specific conditions are necessary for the successful incubation of the mating plates?
q2: How does the scoring system help in determining the fertility of the crosses?
q3: Why is it important to assess ascospore viability for crosses with a fertility score above 4?
q4: Is the modified Czapek-dox agar media prepared at a pH of 7.8?
q5: Are the parental isolates placed more than 1 cm apart from each other on the Petri plates?
q6: Can crosses that score below 5 be considered fertile?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Species concepts in Colletotrichum have
evolved from the use of basic morphological
data to a polyphasic scrutiny incorporating a
powerful molecular component. This has resulted
in traditional classification being less
practical, as holotypes or other types are presently
not very useful as DNA cannot usually
be extracted.
txt: Species concepts in Colletotrichum have evolved from relying on basic morphological data to a polyphasic approach that incorporates a powerful molecular component. As a result, traditional classification has become less practical, since holotypes or other types are not very useful, as DNA typically cannot be extracted from them.
q1: How has the understanding of species concepts in Colletotrichum changed over time?
q2: What challenges do traditional classification methods face in the context of molecular data?
q3: Why are holotypes and other traditional classification types becoming less practical for species identification in Colletotrichum?
q4: Has the classification of Colletotrichum species shifted from solely morphological data to include molecular analysis?
q5: Is it often difficult to extract DNA from holotypes of Colletotrichum?
q6: Are traditional classification methods still considered the most effective for identifying species in Colletotrichum?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
It is recommended that a polyphasic
approach should be adopted in future studies
before new species of Colletotrichum are
introduced or epitypes are designated, and
should incorporate molecular, morphological,
physiological, and pathogenic data. In the
following section we summarise the
recommended protocols.
txt: It is recommended that future studies adopt a polyphasic approach before introducing new species of Colletotrichum or designating epitypes. This approach should incorporate molecular, morphological, physiological, and pathogenic data. The following section summarizes the recommended protocols.
q1: What are the benefits of a polyphasic approach in studying Colletotrichum?
q2: Why is it important to consider molecular and morphological data before designating new species?
q3: What specific protocols are recommended for future studies?
q4: Is a polyphasic approach currently recommended for future studies?
q5: Should pathogenic data be included in the research?
q6: Are new species of Colletotrichum set to be introduced soon?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

pdf:
Protocols for describing new species and
epitypes
1. A detailed morphological description of
the fungus should be provided (see
Colletotrichum fructicola Prihastuti, L. Cai
& K.D. Hyde, Fungal Diversity 39: 96 and
C. anthrisci Damm, P.F. Cannon & Crous,
Fungal Diversity 39: 12 for examples).
2. In addition to any distinctive morphological
or other polyphasic characters, the
proposed new species should show sufficient
evolutionary divergence from other
closely related taxa based on a multiple
gene sequence analysis, and it is essential
that any comparisons should be made with
type specimens.
3. It is recommended that multiple gene loci
should be characterized such as ITS, TUB2,
GPDH, ACT and others. Sequences should
be deposited in a recognised international
database.
4. Media used for descriptions and comparison
should be as recommended in this
paper. Where possible a description should
also be provided from a collection on host
tissues.
5. The ex-type cultures of any new Colletotrichum
species should be deposited in at
least two internationally recognised culture
collections (preferably more), and all
information should be registered in
MycoBank.
6. Details of growth rate in a standard medium
at a standard temperature and growth
condition should be included.
7. Three basic rules should be taken into
account when considering the suitability of
a specific specimen and derived culture to
serve as epitype and ex-epitype (Mcneill et
al., 2006). The strain should be A) from
the original host, B) from the original
geographic locality and C) have well
matched morphology and other phenotypic
characters as the type which should be
examined if available and preferentially
illustrated. When an epitype is designated,
the holotype, lectotype, or neotype that the
epitype supports must be explicitly cited
(Mcneill et al., 2006).
8. Pathogenicity testing may be useful and
should be carried out where possible.
txt:
Protocols for describing new species and epitypes:

A detailed morphological description of the fungus should be provided (e.g., Colletotrichum fructicola by Prihastuti, L. Cai & K.D. Hyde, and C. anthrisci by Damm, P.F. Cannon & Crous).
In addition to any distinctive morphological or polyphasic characters, the proposed new species should show sufficient evolutionary divergence from closely related taxa based on multiple gene sequence analyses, with comparisons made to type specimens.
Multiple gene loci, such as ITS, TUB2, GPDH, and ACT, should be characterized, and sequences deposited in a recognized international database.
Media used for descriptions and comparisons should follow recommendations from this paper, and where possible, a description should be provided from a collection on host tissues.
Ex-type cultures of any new Colletotrichum species should be deposited in at least two internationally recognized culture collections, and all information registered in MycoBank.
Details of growth rate on standard media at standard temperatures and conditions should be included.
When selecting a specimen and derived culture to serve as epitype and ex-epitype, three rules should be considered (McNeill et al., 2006): A) it should come from the original host, B) from the original geographic locality, and C) have well-matched morphology and phenotypic characters to the type, which should be examined and preferably illustrated. The holotype, lectotype, or neotype the epitype supports must be explicitly cited.
Pathogenicity testing should be carried out where possible and may prove useful.
q1: What are the key characteristics that differentiate a proposed new species of fungus from closely related taxa?
q2: Why is it important to deposit sequences in an international database when describing new fungal species?
q3: What are the criteria for selecting a specimen to serve as an epitype?
q4: Should multiple gene loci be characterized when describing a new fungus species?
q5: Is it recommended to include details about the growth rate of the fungus in standard conditions?
q6: Should ex-type cultures be deposited in at least two internationally recognized culture collections?
metadata: A polyphasic approach for studying Colletotrichum.pdf

q1: What role does DNA barcoding play in the classification and identification of fungal species?
q2: How have different studies contributed to the understanding of species variability within the Colletotrichum genus?
q3: What methodologies have researchers used to differentiate between various Colletotrichum species in agricultural contexts?
q4: Does the passage include references to studies on fungal systematics?
q5: Is there a focus on the Colletotrichum genus in the listed articles?
q6: Are there any mentions of specific geographic locations in relation to the studies on fungi?

pdf:
Strawberries, perhaps the most delectable
of fruits, are grown for their attractiveness
and exquisite flavor in most temperate
and many tropical areas of the
world. Some feel the world would indeed
be a dull place without the strawberry
to perk taste buds and enliven desserts
and pastries.
txt: Strawberries, perhaps the most delectable of fruits, are grown for their attractiveness and exquisite flavor in most temperate and many tropical areas of the world. Some feel the world would indeed be a dull place without the strawberry to perk taste buds and enliven desserts and pastries.
q1: What regions are ideal for strawberry cultivation?
q2: Why do people value strawberries beyond their taste?
q3: How do strawberries enhance culinary experiences?
q4: Are strawberries grown in tropical areas?
q5: Do strawberries have an attractive appearance?
q6: Would the world be considered dull without strawberries?
metadata: Anthracnose of Strawberry Caused by.pdf

pdf:
Strawberry growing can be traced
back thousands of years. The origins of
strawberry cultivation in Europe is well
documented in literature and art (5,10,
27). Frogoria vesca L. (diploid, 2n=14
chromosomes) and F* moschara (hexaploid,
2n=42 chromosomes) were
cultured in palace and church gardens.
Strawberry culture in the New World of
North and South America is less well
documented. North American natives
appreciated the appearance of F. virginiana
Duchesne (octaploid, 2n=56
chromosomes) fruit in spring, but this
species apparently was not cultivated
until Europeans began exploring and
settling North America. However, native
inhabitants of Chile and Peru had
selected and cultured superior variants
of F. chiloenris (L.) Qucbesne (octoploid,
2n=56 chromosomes) well before
the arrival of the conquistadores in the
16th century.
txt: Strawberry growing can be traced back thousands of years. The origins of strawberry cultivation in Europe is well documented in literature and art (5,10, 27). Frogoria vesca L. (diploid, 2n=14 chromosomes) and F* moschara (hexaploid, 2n=42 chromosomes) were cultured in palace and church gardens. Strawberry culture in the New World of North and South America is less well documented. North American natives appreciated the appearance of F. virginiana Duchesne (octaploid, 2n=56 chromosomes) fruit in spring, but this species apparently was not cultivated until Europeans began exploring and settling North America. However, native inhabitants of Chile and Peru had selected and cultured superior variants of F. chiloenris (L.) Qucbesne (octoploid, 2n=56 chromosomes) well before the arrival of the conquistadores in the 16th century.
q1: How did the cultivation of strawberries in Europe influence its introduction to the New World?
q2: What factors contributed to the lack of documentation for strawberry cultivation in North America compared to Europe?
q3: How did indigenous cultures in South America contribute to the development of strawberry varieties before European contact?
q4: Was strawberry cultivation in Europe well documented?
q5: Did North American natives appreciate the appearance of strawberries before European colonization?
q6: Were superior variants of strawberries selected and cultured by native inhabitants of Chile and Peru?
metadata: Anthracnose of Strawberry Caused by.pdf

pdf:
The modern strawhr~,E ra~ariaX
ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent
origin, Not until the North American F.
virginiana and the South American F.
thiloensis were brought together and
hybridized in Europe around 1750 did
the progenitor of the strawberry we know
today come into being. The high degree
of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria spp.
has enabled the development of strawkrry
cultivars adapted to widely varying
environmental conditions and resistant
to several diseases and pests. Available
today are cultivars that can survive the
bitterly cold winters of Alaska and others
that can perform well in the long, hot
season of Pretoria, South Africa.
txt: The modern strawberry, Fragaria ? ananassa Duchesne, is of relatively recent origin. It was not until the North American F. virginiana and the South American F. thiloensis were brought together and hybridized in Europe around 1750 that the progenitor of the strawberry we know today emerged. The high degree of genetic heterozygosity in Fragaria species has facilitated the development of strawberry cultivars adapted to a wide range of environmental conditions and resistant to various diseases and pests. Today, there are cultivars that can survive the bitterly cold winters of Alaska and others that thrive in the long, hot seasons of Pretoria, South Africa.
q1: What factors contributed to the development of the modern strawberry cultivars?
q2: How does genetic heterozygosity benefit strawberry plants?
q3: In what types of climates can modern strawberry cultivars thrive?
q4: Did the modern strawberry originate from hybridization in Europe?
q5: Are there strawberry cultivars that can withstand cold winters?
q6: Is the Fragaria genus capable of adapting to different environmental conditions?
metadata: Anthracnose of Strawberry Caused by.pdf

pdf:
Although a minor crop, strawberries
provide a major source of income for
many fruit growers and nursery growers.
Strawberries were grown on nearly
20,000 ha in the United States in 1989.
Total production for fresh market and
processing use totaled 555,000 t and was
valued at $520 million, Florida is second
only to California in the production of
fresh-market strawberries. Strawberries
for U.S. winter production (December
through March) are grown on approximately
2,400 ha.
txt: Although a minor crop, strawberries provide a significant source of income for many fruit and nursery growers. In 1989, strawberries were cultivated on nearly 20,000 hectares in the United States, with total production reaching 555,000 tons and a market value of $520 million. Florida ranks second only to California in the production of fresh-market strawberries. Approximately 2,400 hectares are dedicated to U.S. winter production (December through March).

The major cultural problems for the
Florida strawberry industry are I)
ant hracnose diseases, 2) year! y infestations
of the two-spotted spider mite
(T~rranychus uriicae Koch), and 3)
variability in the quality of nursery
transplants. Commercial fields are established
on an annual basis, as in California.
Freshly dug transplants are obtained
from nurseries in Florida or in the
northern states and Canada. Use of
transplants from northern nurseries is
necessary to avoid anthracnose disease
problems and to obtain plants that have
received some natural chilling to induce
floral bud initiation.
txt: The major cultural problems for the Florida strawberry industry are 1) anthracnose diseases, 2) yearly infestations of the two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch), and 3) variability in the quality of nursery transplants. Commercial fields are established annually, similar to California. Freshly dug transplants are sourced from nurseries in Florida or from northern states and Canada. Using transplants from northern nurseries is essential to avoid anthracnose disease issues and to obtain plants that have undergone natural chilling to induce floral bud initiation.

txt: The warm, humid climate of Florida allows for year-round growth of strawberry plants in nurseries and commercial fields, creating ideal conditions for various diseases, especially anthracnose. Anthracnose diseases of strawberries have become significant in other areas of North America and globally. Given the importance of strawberry anthracnose in Florida and the increasing concern for the disease in other strawberry-producing regions, we present the history of its occurrence, symptoms caused by the Colletotrichum complex in Florida, and control measures developed for Florida strawberry growers.

txt: The term "anthracnose" was first used to describe a new disease of strawberry caused by Colletotrichum fragariae Brooks. "Strawberry anthracnose" has continued to serve as a general term for all diseases of strawberry caused by species of Colletotrichum. Strawberry anthracnose diseases have been attributed to C. acutatum J. H. Simmonds, C. gloeosporioides (Penz.) Penz. & Sacc. (the teleomorph of Glomerella cingulata (Stoneman) Spauld. & H. Schrenk), and C. dematium (Pers.) Grove. C. dematium only occasionally causes strawberry fruit rots and will not be discussed here.

pdf:
Abstract. In recent years, anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) caused by Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds, has become an
even more serious threat to strawberry plant and fruit producers in major strawberry-growing areas of North America.
This highly virulent pathogen causes fruit rot, crown rot, root rot, and lesions on petioles and stolons. In fruit-production
fields, the best way to control AFR is to prevent the introduction of the pathogen into the field by using anthracnose-free
transplants. A critical step in controlling the disease then, lies in effective nursery management practices. Participants in
this workshop outlined several key management strategies, including methods to eliminate pathogen inoculum, cultural
practices that reduce host plant susceptibility, and chemical and biological control measures. Industry members stressed
the importance of giving research priority to developing improved methods of nursery field sampling and detection of
C. acutatum in asymptomatic plants with latent infection. Being able to rapidly and economically diagnose C. acutatum in
symptomless plant material at each step in the multiyear nursery plant propagation cycle (foundation, registered, and
certified plants), will help nursery growers minimize the potential of selling C. acutatum-infected transplants to fruit
growers. A video recording of the 4-h workshop was produced by ASHS Video Workshop Series (http://ashs.org/resources/
videoworkshopseries.html).
txt: Abstract: In recent years, anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) caused by Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds has become an increasingly serious threat to strawberry producers in major growing areas of North America. This highly virulent pathogen leads to fruit rot, crown rot, root rot, and lesions on petioles and stolons. The most effective way to control AFR in production fields is to prevent the introduction of the pathogen by using anthracnose-free transplants. Therefore, effective nursery management practices are critical. Participants in this workshop outlined several key management strategies, including methods to eliminate pathogen inoculum, cultural practices that reduce host plant susceptibility, and both chemical and biological control measures. Industry members emphasized the need for research to develop improved methods for nursery field sampling and detection of C. acutatum in asymptomatic plants with latent infections. Rapid and cost-effective diagnosis of C. acutatum in symptomless plant material at each step of the multiyear nursery propagation cycle (foundation, registered, and certified plants) will help nursery growers minimize the risk of selling infected transplants to fruit growers. A video recording of the 4-hour workshop was produced by the ASHS Video Workshop Series.
q1: What are the main management strategies discussed in the workshop to combat anthracnose fruit rot?
q2: How does the introduction of C. acutatum into strawberry fields impact fruit and plant production?
q3: Why is the development of improved nursery field sampling and detection methods prioritized by industry members?
q4: Has anthracnose fruit rot become a more serious threat to strawberry producers in North America?
q5: Is using anthracnose-free transplants considered the best way to control AFR in fruit-production fields?
q6: Was a video recording of the workshop produced by the ASHS Video Workshop Series?

pdf:
On 18 July 2004, a workshop was held at
the ASHS Annual Meeting in Austin, TX, for
the purpose of considering the different
dimensions of a growing problem that commercial
nurserymen in North America are
having in controlling strawberry plant infections
by anthracnose fruit rot (AFR), caused
by Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds.
The workshop took advantage of the knowledge
and experience of nine industry, government,
and research experts from North
America (representing a geographic crosssection
of the major strawberry-production
regions in the United States and Canada),
and a researcher from Israel, Dr. Stanley
Freeman, Department of Plant Pathology,
ARO, The Volcani Center, who is internationally
recognized for his expertise of the
fungus Colletotrichum, one of the most important
genera of strawberry pathogens in
the world (Casado-Diaz et al., 2006).
txt: On 18 July 2004, a workshop was held at the ASHS Annual Meeting in Austin, TX, to address the growing problem commercial nurserymen in North America face in controlling strawberry plant infections by anthracnose fruit rot (AFR), caused by Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds. The workshop utilized the knowledge and experience of nine industry, government, and research experts from North America, representing a geographic cross-section of the major strawberry production regions in the United States and Canada, along with Dr. Stanley Freeman from Israel, a researcher in the Department of Plant Pathology at ARO, The Volcani Center, who is internationally recognized for his expertise in the fungus Colletotrichum, one of the most significant genera of strawberry pathogens worldwide.

pdf:
The idea to organize this workshop first
came from discussions among scientists and
industry members at the Centennial Conference
of ASHS in Providence, RI, where in
business meetings of the Viticulture and
Small Fruit Working Group (3 Oct. 2003),
as well as the Industry Division (5 Oct. 2003),
concerns were registered that the AFR pathogen,
Colletotrichum acutatum, was becoming
an increasingly serious disease affecting
North American strawberry nurseries and
fruit growers. Similar discussions took place
at the professional meeting of NCCC-022,
Small Fruit and Viticulture Research Group,
in late Oct. 2003, and at this meeting a
decision was made by Adam Dale, Dan
Legard, Tom Sjulin, and myself to proceed
with the organization of a workshop for the
ASHS Annual Conference in July 2004 in
Austin, TX. The 4-h workshop on 18 July
2004, was divided into two parts: 1) Etiology,
Epidemiology, and Pathology of Anthracnose
on Strawberry; and 2) Anthracnose
Management Strategies for Strawberry Nurseries,
with particular emphasis on the AFR
caused by C. acutatum J.H. Simmonds. The
workshop also received sponsorship from
the California Strawberry Commission
(CSC), Driscoll Strawberry Associates
(DSA), Arkansas Strawberry Growers Association,
North American Strawberry Growers
Association, Ontario Berry Growers Association,
and the North Carolina Strawberry
Association, Inc. The support from these
organizations made it possible for organizers
to invite Dr. Stanley Freeman to the workshop
in Austin.
txt: The idea to organize this workshop first emerged from discussions among scientists and industry members at the Centennial Conference of ASHS in Providence, RI. During business meetings of the Viticulture and Small Fruit Working Group and the Industry Division, concerns were raised that the AFR pathogen, Colletotrichum acutatum, was becoming an increasingly serious disease affecting North American strawberry nurseries and fruit growers. Similar discussions took place at the professional meeting of NCCC-022, Small Fruit and Viticulture Research Group, in late October 2003. At that meeting, a decision was made by Adam Dale, Dan Legard, Tom Sjulin, and myself to proceed with the organization of a workshop for the ASHS Annual Conference in July 2004 in Austin, TX. The 4-hour workshop on July 18, 2004, was divided into two parts: 1) Etiology, Epidemiology, and Pathology of Anthracnose on Strawberry; and 2) Anthracnose Management Strategies for Strawberry Nurseries, with particular emphasis on the AFR caused by C. acutatum. The workshop received sponsorship from the California Strawberry Commission, Driscoll Strawberry Associates, Arkansas Strawberry Growers Association, North American Strawberry Growers Association, Ontario Berry Growers Association, and the North Carolina Strawberry Association, Inc. This support enabled the organizers to invite Dr. Stanley Freeman to the workshop in Austin.

txt:
The discussions in the workshop covered several important subjects and issues, many of which are not included in the written proceedings. Therefore, the information in the video "Anthracnose on Strawberry: Management Strategies for Plant and Runner Tip Nurseries" (available through the ASHS Video Workshop Series) serves as a valuable supplement to the written materials. The oral presentations from the workshop that are not part of these proceedings include:
 "Colletotrichum acutatum in Florida Strawberry" by Jim Mertely, Dan Legard, Natalia Peres, Craig Chandler, and Teresa Seijo.
 "Special Considerations Regarding Strawberry Plugs and Colletotrichum acutatum" by E. Barclay Poling.
 "Cooperative Efforts by the California Strawberry Commission to Control Colletotrichum acutatum in Strawberry Transplants" by Dan Legard.
 "The Importance of a Certification Program for Strawberry Production" by Zvezdana Pesic-VanEsbroeck.
 "An Effort to Get the Attention of Researchers Who Work with Colletotrichum acutatum" by Curt Gaines.
 "Maintaining Plant Quality in Strawberry Propagation Nurseries: A Horticulturist? Perspective" by Kirk Larson.

pdf:
The video should be of particular interest
to researchers (especially breeders, plant
pathologists, and molecular geneticists) who
wish to ‘‘get inside’’ some of the complex
challenges that North American strawberry
nursery growers currently face in their efforts
to produce disease-free plant material for a
strawberry industry in the United States that
required an estimated 928 million plants in
2003 (Table 1). Extension educators and crop
consultants who advise commercial strawberry
nurseries and fruit growers will particularly
appreciate the information in the video
provided by Kirk Larson, UC–Davis pomologist,
who provides a practical perspective on
how to maintain plant quality in strawberrypropagation
nurseries, including hot water
dips for nursery plant material. The video
should also be useful to teachers of plant
pathology, small-fruit production courses,
as well as for extension-agent training programs.
After viewing this video, a good
follow-up exercise for agent trainers or classroom
instructors is to have the students
critique the actual production practices of
the various strawberry nurseries in the United
States and Canada that supply plant material
to commercial fruit operations in their state,
region, or province.
txt: The video should be of particular interest to researchers, especially breeders, plant pathologists, and molecular geneticists, who wish to delve into the complex challenges that North American strawberry nursery growers currently face in producing disease-free plant material for a strawberry industry in the United States that required an estimated 928 million plants in 2003. Extension educators and crop consultants advising commercial strawberry nurseries and fruit growers will appreciate the insights from Kirk Larson, a UC?avis pomologist, who offers a practical perspective on maintaining plant quality in strawberry propagation nurseries, including the use of hot water dips for nursery plant material. The video will also be beneficial for teachers of plant pathology and small-fruit production courses, as well as extension-agent training programs. After viewing, a valuable follow-up exercise for trainers or instructors could involve students critiquing the production practices of various strawberry nurseries in the United States and Canada that supply plant material to commercial fruit operations in their state, region, or province.

pdf:
To my knowledge, this was the first time
that scientists and industry leaders from
across North America had actually come
together to discuss AFR caused by C. acutatum
in the context of trying to understand
what could be done to reduce, if not eliminate,
this pathogen from North American
farms producing strawberry plants. For a
workshop that had the primary goal of identifying
management strategies to help nursery
growers minimize the potential of selling
disease-infected transplants to fruit growers,
I believe we had the correct ‘‘mix of disciplines,’’
including four ‘‘active’’ plant pathologists
(one from Israel) and two research
directors who were previously trained in
plant pathology. Among the four horticulturists
represented, there was one strawberry
breeder from Canada, two strawberry cultural
research/extension workers (from California
and North Carolina), and one nurseryman
from California. Nursery grower Curt Gaines
is a leader in the strawberry nursery industry
in California, and an important contribution
to this workshop was his candid analysis
of how C. acutatum ‘‘may be’’ making its
entrance into the nursery production system,
as well as to request that researchers give
high priority to developing improved methods
of nursery field sampling and detection
of C. acutatum in asymptomatic plants with
latent infection.
txt: To my knowledge, this was the first time that scientists and industry leaders from across North America had come together to discuss the issue of AFR caused by C. acutatum, focusing on how to reduce or eliminate this pathogen from North American strawberry farms. The workshop aimed to identify management strategies to help nursery growers minimize the risk of selling disease-infected transplants to fruit growers. We had the right mix of disciplines, including four active plant pathologists (one from Israel) and two research directors trained in plant pathology. Among the horticulturists were a strawberry breeder from Canada, two cultural research and extension workers from California and North Carolina, and a nurseryman from California. Nursery grower Curt Gaines, a leader in California's strawberry nursery industry, made significant contributions by providing a candid analysis of how C. acutatum may be entering the nursery production system, while also urging researchers to prioritize improved methods for nursery field sampling and detection of C. acutatum in asymptomatic plants with latent infections.

q2: How did Curt Gaines' insights contribute to the workshop's objectives?
q3: Why is it important to focus on asymptomatic plants with latent infections?
q4: Did the workshop include participants from multiple regions of North America?
q5: Was the primary goal of the workshop to discuss disease management for strawberry plants?
q6: Did Curt Gaines emphasize the need for improved detection methods for the pathogen?

pdf:
Many readers may be unaware that the
United States is the largest producer of
strawberries in the world, accounting for
28% of the world supply in 2004; the total
value of U.S. strawberry production was
valued at $1.5 billion USD in 2004 ($1.33
billion USD fresh; $136 million USD processed),
with California production valued at
$1.22 billion USD (83% of total) and Florida’s
contribution, mainly of winter strawberries,
accounting for 11.9% ($178 million
USD) (Boriss et al., 2006). Other significant
production states in 2004 were North Carolina
and Oregon, each worth $15.8 million
USD in 2004 (Boriss et al., 2006). Total
harvested area in the United States was
20,882 ha (51,600 acres) in 2004, a record
high over the last 25 years. California acreage
has increased consistently over the last three
and a half decades, increasing by 200% from
4452 ha (11,000 acres) in 1980 to 13,355 ha
(33,000 acres) in 2004; meanwhile, Florida
acreage has increased by 40% from 2023 ha
(5000 acres) in 1982 to 2832 ha (7000 acres)
in 2004 (Boriss, 2006). Production in California
grew from 987 million pounds in 1990
to a record 1.96 billion pounds in 2004,
and average yields were just under 67 MT/ha
(30 tons per acre); meanwhile, Florida yields
averaged 26 MT/ha (11.5 tons per acre) in
2004, which was a decrease from a high of
39MT/ha (17.5 tons per acre) in 2000 (Boriss,
2006). In the period from 2000 to 2003,
average yields per ha in North Carolina have
fluctuated between 22 MT to 30 MT (10 to
13.5 tons per acre), and for the same period
in Oregon yields have fluctuated between
22 and 29 MT/ha (10 and 13 tons per acre).
In New York, with predominantly mattedrow
production, production area fluctuated
between 567 and 648 ha (1400 and 1600
acres) in the period from 2000 to 2003, and
average yields varied from 7 to 10 MT/ha
(3.3–4.5 tons per acre) over that period.
txt: Many readers may be unaware that the United States is the largest producer of strawberries in the world, accounting for 28% of the global supply in 2004. The total value of U.S. strawberry production was $1.5 billion USD in 2004, with $1.33 billion USD from fresh strawberries and $136 million USD from processed ones. California produced strawberries valued at $1.22 billion USD, making up 83% of the total, while Florida contributed 11.9% ($178 million USD), primarily from winter strawberries. Other significant production states in 2004 included North Carolina and Oregon, each with a production value of $15.8 million USD. The total harvested area in the United States reached 20,882 hectares (51,600 acres) in 2004, a record high for the past 25 years. California's acreage has consistently increased over the last three and a half decades, rising by 200% from 4,452 hectares (11,000 acres) in 1980 to 13,355 hectares (33,000 acres) in 2004. Florida's acreage grew by 40%, from 2,023 hectares (5,000 acres) in 1982 to 2,832 hectares (7,000 acres) in 2004. California's production increased from 987 million pounds in 1990 to a record 1.96 billion pounds in 2004, with average yields just under 67 metric tons per hectare (30 tons per acre). In contrast, Florida's yields averaged 26 metric tons per hectare (11.5 tons per acre) in 2004, down from a high of 39 metric tons per hectare (17.5 tons per acre) in 2000. From 2000 to 2003, average yields in North Carolina fluctuated between 22 and 30 metric tons per hectare (10 to 13.5 tons per acre), while Oregon's yields ranged between 22 and 29 metric tons per hectare (10 and 13 tons per acre). In New York, where matted-row production predominates, the production area fluctuated between 567 and 648 hectares (1,400 and 1,600 acres) from 2000 to 2003, with average yields varying from 7 to 10 metric tons per hectare (3.3 to 4.5 tons per acre) during that period.
q1: What factors may have contributed to California being the largest producer of strawberries in the United States?
q2: How has the average yield of strawberries changed in Florida from 2000 to 2004 compared to the previous years?

yThe 700-million plant requirement for the California strawberry industry is based on information provided
by Dan Legard during the 2005 Austin workshop; it is noteworthy that about two-thirds of the total plant
supply is for short-day cultivars and one-third is for day-neutrals (cold-stored and fresh-dug). This
calculation of the day-neutral plant requirement is derived from information in Sjulin (2007)which indicates
that 65 million cold-stored day-neutral cultivars are produced by California nurseries for fruit plantings
along the southern California coast (requiring about 65,000 plants/ha, or 26,300 plants per acre), and about
160 million fresh-dug plants of day-neutral cultivars are needed to annually supply the Watsonville/Salinas
and Santa Maria districts, assuming an average of 50,000 plants/ha (20,235 plants per acre).
xProduction area in North Carolina of 809 ha (2000 acres) in 2003 is derived from the survey conducted by
S. Toth and B. Poling of annual strawberry plasticulture states participating in the Methyl Bromide Critical
Use Application to the U.S. EPA (www.smallfruits.org).
w‘‘Other states’’ with strawberry plasticulture production in 2003 include VA (111 ha), TN (71 ha), SC
(219 ha), GA (101 ha), AR (101 ha), AL (61 ha), OH (13 ha), NJ (81 ha), KY (1 ha), LA (162 ha), MD (12
ha), IL (13 ha), and MO (8 ha); data were derived from the survey conducted by S. Toth and B. Poling of
annual strawberry plasticulture states participating in the Methyl Bromide Critical Use Application to the
U.S. EPA (www.smallfruits.org).

of 0.6 m · 1.06 m (2 ft · 3.5 ft).
uAnnual planting needs in the matted-row states may be estimated by dividing the total production area by
3, as matted-row beds are commonly fruited for 3 yr (four production seasons).
tEstimate of plant usage per ha for matted row in these states is based on a spacing of 0.3 m · 1.06 m (1 ft ·
3.5 ft).

 The 700-million plant requirement for the California strawberry industry is noteworthy, as about two-thirds of the total supply is for short-day cultivars and one-third for day-neutrals. Production area in North Carolina is derived from a survey conducted by S. Toth and B. Poling. "Other states" include Virginia, Tennessee, South Carolina, Georgia, Arkansas, Alabama, Ohio, New Jersey, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Illinois, and Missouri. Estimates of plant usage per hectare for matted rows are based on standard recommended spacings, and annual planting needs in these states may be estimated by dividing total production area by three, as matted-row beds are commonly fruited for three years.

pdf:
We now know that isolates of Colletotrichum
have probably been disseminated
worldwide through international plant
exchanges (Smith, 2007) and that AFR,
caused by C. acutatum, ‘‘has over the last
20 years developed from a localized, but
serious disease of strawberry in hot humid
areas of the southern United States to one that
is worldwide in prominence’’ (Dale et al.,
2007). We are also informed in B.J. Smith’s
paper (Smith, 2007) that the greatest losses
due to anthracnose on strawberry from AFR
are caused by C. acutatum, and that anthracnose
diseases of strawberry are second only
to Botrytis in causing economic losses to
strawberry growers in North America and
worldwide (Smith, 2007). Specific accounts
of economic loss due to C. acutatum infection
are given below, along with some additional
reports by workers who did not participate
directly in the workshop.
txt: We now know that isolates of Colletotrichum have probably been disseminated worldwide through international plant exchanges. Anthracnose fruit rot (AFR), caused by C. acutatum, has developed over the last 20 years from a localized but serious disease of strawberries in hot, humid areas of the southern United States to one that is globally prominent. The greatest losses due to anthracnose on strawberries from AFR are caused by C. acutatum, and these anthracnose diseases are second only to Botrytis in causing economic losses to strawberry growers in North America and worldwide. Specific accounts of economic loss due to C. acutatum infection are provided below, along with additional reports from researchers who did not participate directly in the workshop.
q1: What factors contributed to the global dissemination of Colletotrichum isolates?
q2: How has the impact of AFR on strawberries changed over the past 20 years?
q3: Why is C. acutatum particularly significant in terms of economic losses for strawberry growers?
q4: Has AFR become a worldwide issue for strawberry cultivation?
q5: Is C. acutatum responsible for the majority of economic losses from anthracnose on strawberries?
q6: Are anthracnose diseases a major concern compared to other diseases affecting strawberries?

pdf:
Florida. Barbara Smith was able to relate
in her oral presentation (this information does
not appear in her paper) that in recent years
losses to AFR in Florida have averaged $3
million USD per year; she also noted in
1997–1998 that losses due to fruit rot in
Florida were estimated to be between $10
and $15 million USD. Assuming that AFR
losses in Florida have averaged around $3
million USD annually in recent years, this
would represent 1.7% of the value of the
Florida crop in 2004 ($178 million USD).
txt: Florida. Barbara Smith was able to share in her oral presentation (this information does not appear in her paper) that in recent years, losses to AFR in Florida have averaged $3 million USD per year. She also noted that in 1997??998, losses due to fruit rot in Florida were estimated to be between $10 million and $15 million USD. Assuming that AFR losses in Florida have averaged around $3 million USD annually in recent years, this would represent 1.7% of the value of the Florida crop in 2004 ($178 million USD).
q1: What factors contribute to the average annual losses to AFR in Florida?
q2: How do the losses from fruit rot compare to the average AFR losses?
q3: What measures might be taken to reduce the impact of AFR on Florida's crops?
q4: Did Barbara Smith mention AFR losses in her paper?
q5: Were the losses due to fruit rot higher than the average AFR losses in Florida for 1997??998?
q6: Was the value of the Florida crop in 2004 higher than $178 million USD?

pdf:
California. Anthracnose of strawberries
in California, caused by C. acutatum, is more
common in nursery areas (Strand, 1994), but
it can be a serious problem in fruit-production
areas if the pathogen is present and conditions
are favorable. In his workshop presentation,
‘‘An effort to get the attention of
researchers who work with Colletotrichum
acutatum,’’ Curt Gaines identified four significant
outbreaks of C. acutatum in California
in recent years, including an AFR
epidemic in 2002 that ‘‘Cost the fruit industry
(CA) millions of dollars, and was due to
contamination of all levels of plant production
in 2002’’ (Gaines, 2005).
txt: California. Anthracnose of strawberries in California, caused by C. acutatum, is more common in nursery areas but can also be a serious issue in fruit-production areas if the pathogen is present and conditions are favorable. In a workshop presentation titled "An Effort to Get the Attention of Researchers Who Work with Colletotrichum acutatum," Curt Gaines identified four significant outbreaks of C. acutatum in California in recent years. Notably, an AFR epidemic in 2002 cost the California fruit industry millions of dollars due to contamination at all levels of plant production.
q1: What conditions contribute to the spread of anthracnose in strawberry production areas?
q2: How has the presence of C. acutatum affected the economic viability of the strawberry industry in California?
q3: What measures are researchers and industry professionals considering to address the outbreaks of C. acutatum?
q4: Is anthracnose of strawberries primarily found in nursery areas according to the passage?
q5: Did the 2002 AFR epidemic have a significant economic impact on California's fruit industry?
q6: Are researchers working to increase awareness about C. acutatum and its effects on strawberry production?
metadata: Anthracnose on Strawberry Its Etiology, Epidemiology, and Pathology, Together with Management Strategies for Strawberry Nurseries Introduction to the Workshop.pdf

pdf:
In his presentation, ‘‘Maintaining plant
quality in strawberry propagation nurseries:
a horticulturist’s perspective,’’ Kirk Larson
identified a serious incident in Southern
California in 2003 in which plugs became
infected with C. acutatum during the misting
and rooting phase of strawberry plug propagation
(Poling and Parker, 1991), and large
quantities of expensive plant material (plugs
are about double the cost of fresh-dug or
‘‘tops-off’’ bare-root transplants) had to be
destroyed.
txt: In his presentation, ?aintaining Plant Quality in Strawberry Propagation Nurseries: A Horticulturist? Perspective,??Kirk Larson identified a serious incident in Southern California in 2003, where plugs became infected with C. acutatum during the misting and rooting phase of strawberry plug propagation. This resulted in the destruction of large quantities of expensive plant material, as plugs cost about double that of fresh-dug or ?ops-off??bare-root transplants.
q1: What measures can be taken to prevent infections like C. acutatum in strawberry propagation nurseries?
q2: How do the costs of strawberry plugs compare to other types of transplants in terms of economic impact?
q3: What were the long-term consequences of the 2003 incident on strawberry propagation practices in Southern California?
q4: Did Kirk Larson discuss a significant incident related to strawberry propagation in his presentation?
q5: Were large quantities of plant material destroyed due to the infection mentioned in the passage?
q6: Are strawberry plugs more expensive than bare-root transplants?

pdf:
North Carolina. In the same year (2003),
this pathogen was highly destructive in plug
plant propagation beds and greenhouses
across the state of North Carolina, as well
as in Virginia, South Carolina, and southern
New Jersey. I am personally affiliated with
a relatively small plasticulture industry in
North Carolina (slightly in excess of 750 ha
in 2003), by comparison with California
(11,980 ha) and Florida (2870 ha), where
C. acutatum was positively diagnosed in plug
plants being grown from Canadian runner
tips in Aug. and Sept. of 2003; as a result, an
estimated 8 million plug plants had to be
destroyed less than 1 week before planting
for most of the affected growers.
txt: North Carolina. In 2003, this pathogen was highly destructive in plug plant propagation beds and greenhouses throughout North Carolina, as well as in Virginia, South Carolina, and southern New Jersey. I am personally affiliated with a relatively small plasticulture industry in North Carolina, slightly exceeding 750 hectares in 2003, compared to California (11,980 hectares) and Florida (2,870 hectares). C. acutatum was positively diagnosed in plug plants grown from Canadian runner tips in August and September of 2003, leading to the destruction of an estimated 8 million plug plants less than one week before planting for most affected growers.
q1: What specific impact did the pathogen have on growers in North Carolina compared to those in California and Florida?
q2: How did the destruction of 8 million plug plants affect the overall plasticulture industry in the region?
q3: What measures might have been taken by growers to prevent future outbreaks of this pathogen?
q4: Was the pathogen present in North Carolina in 2003?
q5: Did the pathogen lead to the destruction of plug plants in a short timeframe?
q6: Is the plasticulture industry in North Carolina smaller than in California and Florida?

pdf:
Midwest and Northeast. By the early
1990s, epidemics of AFR began to occur in
a number of matted-row strawberry-growing
states the Northeast and Midwest (personal
communications with Mike Ellis, Ohio State
University, and Marvin Pritts, Cornell University).
Ellis (not a workshop participant)
has furnished this background statement:
‘‘Actually in 1991, the disease did not only
occur in Ohio, it was epidemic throughout the
Northeast and Midwest from the Mississippi to
the Atlantic and from Wisconsin through the
lower Midwest. It had never been seen before
that time as far as I know, and I am positive that
it was not considered as a problem that
required control. One grower in Ohio had been
growing berries for 40 years and had never
seen the disease until 1991, when he lost 2
acres of (strawberry cv.) Lateglow berries to
fruit rot. Eighty-eight percent of the fruit in
the planting was infected.’’ (M. Ellis, personal
communication)
txt: By the early 1990s, epidemics of AFR began to occur in several matted-row strawberry-growing states in the Northeast and Midwest. In 1991, the disease was not limited to Ohio; it was epidemic throughout the Northeast and Midwest, from the Mississippi to the Atlantic and from Wisconsin through the lower Midwest. It had never been seen before, and it was not considered a problem requiring control. One grower in Ohio, who had been cultivating berries for 40 years, reported never encountering the disease until 1991, when he lost 2 acres of Lateglow strawberries to fruit rot, with 88% of the fruit in the planting infected.
q1: What factors contributed to the emergence of the AFR epidemic in the Northeast and Midwest?
q2: How did the awareness of AFR change among growers after the 1991 outbreak?
q3: What specific impact did AFR have on the strawberry crop yields in Ohio?
q4: Did the AFR disease first appear in Ohio in 1991?
q5: Was the disease previously recognized as a significant problem before the early 1990s?
q6: Did the grower in Ohio experience significant crop loss due to AFR?
metadata: Anthracnose on Strawberry Its Etiology, Epidemiology, and Pathology, Together with Management Strategies for Strawberry Nurseries Introduction to the Workshop.pdf

pdf:
Marvin Pritts, horticulturist and department
chair, Cornell University, also confirmed
epidemics of AFR in commercial
strawberry fruit plantings in the Northeast,
including New York and Pennsylvania (M.
Pritts, personal communication). Because
one workshop participant directly associated
the growth in annual plasticulture production
in the United States over the last 20 years
with increased fruit losses to Colletotrichum
spp. (Smith, 2007), it is instructive to note
that C. acutatum losses have also occurred in
matted-row plantings and with matted-row
cultivars.
txt: Marvin Pritts, a horticulturist and department chair at Cornell University, confirmed epidemics of anthracnose fruit rot (AFR) in commercial strawberry plantings in the Northeast, including New York and Pennsylvania. One workshop participant directly associated the growth in annual plasticulture production in the United States over the last 20 years with increased fruit losses to Colletotrichum spp. It is important to note that losses from C. acutatum have also occurred in matted-row plantings and with matted-row cultivars.
q1: What factors might be contributing to the increased fruit losses in strawberry plantings in the Northeast?
q2: How has the practice of plasticulture affected strawberry production in the United States over the past 20 years?
q3: Are there differences in fruit loss between different planting methods, such as plasticulture and matted-row systems?
q4: Has Marvin Pritts confirmed the presence of AFR in strawberry plantings?
q5: Did a workshop participant link increased plasticulture production to higher fruit losses?
q6: Are C. acutatum losses observed in both plasticulture and matted-row strawberry plantings?
metadata: Anthracnose on Strawberry Its Etiology, Epidemiology, and Pathology, Together with Management Strategies for Strawberry Nurseries Introduction to the Workshop.pdf

pdf:
As previously noted, in the 1997–1998
winter season in Florida, AFR losses were
estimated by Smith to be as high as $10–15
million USD, and this comment served to
trigger one of the more interesting discussions
of the entire workshop which related to
the importance of having anthracnose-resistant
cultivars. Although there seems to be
little question about the long-term importance
of having disease-resistant cultivars,
as was emphasized by most presenters,
including Freeman, Sjulin, and Smith, there
seemed to be considerable question about the
short-term usefulness of current resistant
cultivars, such as the 1992 University of
Florida introduction, Sweet Charlie, which
is resistant to AFR (Chandler and Legard,
2003).
txt: As previously noted, during the 1997??998 winter season in Florida, AFR losses were estimated to be as high as $10??5 million USD. This comment triggered one of the more interesting discussions of the entire workshop, which related to the importance of having anthracnose-resistant cultivars. While there is little doubt about the long-term significance of developing disease-resistant cultivars, as emphasized by most presenters, there is considerable uncertainty regarding the short-term usefulness of current resistant cultivars, such as the 1992 University of Florida introduction, Sweet Charlie, which is resistant to AFR.
q1: What were the specific financial impacts of AFR losses in the Florida winter season of 1997-1998?
q2: Why was the discussion about anthracnose-resistant cultivars considered interesting during the workshop?
q3: What were the differing opinions regarding the effectiveness of current resistant cultivars in the short term?
q4: Did Smith estimate the AFR losses to be between $10 million and $15 million USD?
q5: Was the introduction of Sweet Charlie in 1992 associated with resistance to AFR?
q6: Did most presenters at the workshop emphasize the long-term importance of disease-resistant cultivars?
metadata: Anthracnose on Strawberry Its Etiology, Epidemiology, and Pathology, Together with Management Strategies for Strawberry Nurseries Introduction to the Workshop.pdf

pdf:
Smith stated in her presentation that
losses would have been much more severe
in the 1997–1998 Florida strawberry season
if 40% of the acreage had not been planted to
‘Sweet Charlie’. However, later in the workshop,
Dan Legard, Director of Research and
Education, California Strawberry Commission,
Watsonville, CA (who had formerly
worked in Florida as a plant pathologist),
observed that winter plantings of ‘Sweet
Charlie’ were sharply lower in the Florida
1998–1999 season, despite significant losses
to AFR in susceptible cultivars from the
previous year ($10–15 million USD). Legard
went on to say, ‘‘Growers don’t grow cultivars
for disease resistance, they grow it for
yield and marketability and other characteristics.
And, so breeding for resistance is only
usable if you actually have high productive
cultivars with good marketable qualities.’’
q1: What factors influence growers??decisions to plant specific strawberry cultivars?
q2: How did the Florida strawberry season losses in 1997??998 compare to those in 1998??999?
q3: What role does marketability play in the choice of strawberry cultivars?
q4: Did Smith claim that losses would have been worse without ?weet Charlie??
q5: Were winter plantings of ?weet Charlie??lower in 1998??999?
q6: Do growers prioritize disease resistance over yield and marketability?

pdf:
The shipping-quality issues with ‘Sweet
Charlie’ are well documented, and in a more
recent publication, The Strawberry: A Book
for Growers, Others, Florida researchers
acknowledge that ‘‘This cultivar in west
central Florida is currently in decline due to
short ‘‘shelf-life’’ in warm weather (Chandler
and Legard, 2003). In the year 2000, the
University of Florida (UF) released the cultivar
Strawberry Festival (Chandler, 2000);
this cultivar is widely credited for the Florida
industry’s healthy expansion in the early
2000s (Florida ranks second in U.S. strawberry
production). By 2006, ‘Strawberry
Festival’ occupied 60% of Florida’s 3035
ha (7500 acres) of annual hill plastic mulch
production (N. Peres, invited speaker, Southeastern
Strawberry Expo, Nov. 9, 2006,
personal communication). However, ‘Strawberry
Festival’ has resistance neither to
Colletotrichum crown rot caused by Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides nor to AFR (caused
primarily by C. acutatum). Another important
cultivar in Florida is Treasure, which was
released in 2000 by a private breeding program
(J&P Research, Naples, FL); this cultivar
is well adapted to west central Florida
and has resistance to Colletotrichum crown
rot (Chandler and Legard, 2003). Themajority
of fresh-dug bare-root green transplants
plants for the Florida market are produced
in the Canadian Provinces of Nova Scotia,
Ontario, Prince Edward Island, and Quebec,
with lesser quantities coming from western
North Carolina and northern California.
q1: What factors have contributed to the decline of the ?weet Charlie??cultivar in Florida?
q2: How did the introduction of the ?trawberry Festival??cultivar impact the strawberry industry in Florida?
q3: What are the advantages of the ?reasure??cultivar compared to the ?trawberry Festival??cultivar?
q4: Is ?weet Charlie??currently considered a successful cultivar in Florida?
q5: Did the ?trawberry Festival??cultivar contribute to the expansion of the Florida strawberry industry in the early 2000s?
q6: Are the majority of fresh-dug bare-root green transplants for Florida produced outside of the state?
