pdf:
To create concatenated matrices from the individual
datasets the Concatenator 1.1.0 software was used (Pina-
Martins and Paulo 2008). Three molecular marker combinations
were assembled for subsequent comparative purposes
and designated as: Apn-MAT dataset, comprising only
Apn2/MAT locus makers, except MAT1-2-1; traditional
dataset, combining ITS, b-tub2 and GS; and the total
concatenated dataset. MAT1-2-1 was not included in the
Apn-MAT dataset to balance the sequence length of both
Apn-MAT and traditional datasets, providing a more even
comparison. Five C. fragariae isolates were used as outgroup
taxa to root phylogenetic trees (Cai et al. 2009). Additional
outgroup taxa could not be considered because orthologous
regions to all our developed markers were unavailable
in public databases, with the exception of C. graminicola
whose sequences were too divergent for accurate and reliable
alignments. Phylogenetic trees were constructed from the
individual and combined analyses of the seven nuclear
regions with maximum likelihood (ML) and a Bayesian
framework with the Markov chain Monte Carlo (BMCMC)
algorithm. Gaps were treated asmissing data. TheML analysis
was run in PAUP* 4.0d99 (Swofford 2003) with heuristic
searches of 100 replicates with random sequence addition
and a tree-bisection-reconnection (TBR) branch swapping
algorithm. Nonparametric bootstrapping was conducted with
1000 pseudoreplicates with 10 random additions and TBR
branch swapping. ModelTest 3.7 (Posada and Crandall 1998)
was used to select the best fit model of nucleotide evolution
under the Akaike information criterion (AIC) for each
dataset. The BMCMC analysis was run in MrBayes 3.1.2
(Ronquist and Huelsenbeck 2003) with the optimal model
selected under the AIC, as implemented in MrModelTest 2.3
(Nylander 2004), specified as prior for each partition. For the
individual and combined datasets, Bayesian posterior probabilities
were generated from33107 and 13108 generations
respectively, sampling every 1000th generation. The analysis
was run three times with one cold and three incrementally
heated Metropolis-coupled Monte Carlo Markov chains,
starting from random trees. A total of 1 3 106 generations
were discarded as burn-in. Trees were combined and
summarized on a 50% majority rule consensus tree.
txt:
To create concatenated matrices from the individual datasets, the Concatenator 1.1.0 software was used. Three molecular marker combinations were assembled for comparative purposes and designated as: the Apn-MAT dataset, comprising only Apn2/MAT locus markers (excluding MAT1-2-1); the traditional dataset, combining ITS, b-tub2, and GS; and the total concatenated dataset. MAT1-2-1 was excluded from the Apn-MAT dataset to balance the sequence lengths of the Apn-MAT and traditional datasets, providing a more even comparison. Five C. fragariae isolates were used as outgroup taxa to root the phylogenetic trees. Additional outgroup taxa could not be considered because orthologous regions for all the developed markers were unavailable in public databases, except for C. graminicola, whose sequences were too divergent for accurate and reliable alignments.
Phylogenetic trees were constructed from individual and combined analyses of the seven nuclear regions using maximum likelihood (ML) and a Bayesian framework with the Markov chain Monte Carlo (BMCMC) algorithm. Gaps were treated as missing data. The ML analysis was run in PAUP* 4.0d99 with heuristic searches of 100 replicates, random sequence addition, and a tree-bisection-reconnection (TBR) branch swapping algorithm. Nonparametric bootstrapping was conducted with 1000 pseudoreplicates, 10 random additions, and TBR branch swapping. ModelTest 3.7 was used to select the best-fit model of nucleotide evolution under the Akaike information criterion (AIC) for each dataset.
The BMCMC analysis was run in MrBayes 3.1.2 with the optimal model selected under the AIC, as implemented in MrModelTest 2.3, specified as a prior for each partition. For the individual and combined datasets, Bayesian posterior probabilities were generated from 33,107 and 13,108 generations respectively, sampling every 1000th generation. The analysis was run three times with one cold and three incrementally heated Metropolis-coupled Monte Carlo Markov chains, starting from random trees. A total of 1×10^6 generations were discarded as burn-in. Trees were combined and summarized in a 50% majority rule consensus tree.
q1: What was the purpose of excluding the MAT1-2-1 marker from the Apn-MAT dataset when creating the concatenated matrices?
q2: How many total generations were discarded as burn-in during the BMCMC analysis?
q3: What software was used for constructing phylogenetic trees from the combined analyses of the seven nuclear regions?
q4: Was the Concatenator 1.1.0 software utilized to create the concatenated matrices?
q5: Did the analysis include multiple outgroup taxa for rooting the phylogenetic trees?
q6: Were gaps treated as missing data during the phylogenetic analysis?

pdf:
The total combined dataset also was analyzed with the
species-tree approach implemented in BEST (Liu 2008) to
incorporate the signals of each marker. BEST has been
shown to deal with the common issue of deep coalescence
in recently diverged species. It uses a hierarchical Bayesian
approach to estimate the joint posterior distribution of
multiple gene trees and is known to provide more accurate
estimates than the concatenation method in some multilocus
datasets (Edwards et al. 2007, Liu and Pearl 2007).
The BEST analysis was run in MrBayes 2.3, and model priors
for each partition were estimated as in the BMCMC analysis.
Priors included an inverse gamma distribution (3, 0.003) for
theta and a uniform distribution (0.2, 2) for gene mutation
and were estimated as part of the analysis. A total of 2.5 3
109 generations were sampled every 2000 generations.
Convergence and mixing were assessed for all parameters
with Tracer 1.4 (Drummond and Rambaut 2007). The
species tree was constructed from the combined runs.
txt: The total combined dataset was analyzed using the species-tree approach implemented in BEST to incorporate the signals of each marker. BEST addresses the common issue of deep coalescence in recently diverged species by employing a hierarchical Bayesian method to estimate the joint posterior distribution of multiple gene trees. It is known to provide more accurate estimates than the concatenation method in some multilocus datasets. The BEST analysis was conducted in MrBayes 2.3, with model priors for each partition estimated as in the BMCMC analysis. Priors included an inverse gamma distribution for theta and a uniform distribution for gene mutation, both estimated as part of the analysis. A total of 2.5 billion generations were sampled every 2000 generations, and convergence and mixing were assessed for all parameters using Tracer 1.4. The species tree was constructed from the combined runs.
q1: What is the purpose of using the species-tree approach in the dataset analysis?
q2: How does the BEST method address deep coalescence issues in recently diverged species?
q3: What role does the software MrBayes play in the analysis?
q4: Did the analysis incorporate multiple gene trees?
q5: Was a hierarchical Bayesian approach utilized in the BEST method?
q6: Did the researchers assess convergence and mixing using Tracer 1.4?

pdf:
Topology tests.—The current taxonomic relationship of the
studied species also was assessed through topology tests on
each relevant dataset. Alternative hypothesis were tested
against the most recent hypothesis of relationships between
our species of interest (Phoulivong et al. 2010) with the
topological test of Shimodaira and Hasegawa (SH) (Shimodaira
and Hasegawa 1999) as implemented in PAUP*
4.0d99 (Swofford 2003). Although this current taxonomy
was not formally addressed, it provided an objective starting
point for our analysis. First we tested the unconstrained
phylogenies of each dataset that revealed discordant
phylogenies to assess whether their branching order was
significantly incongruent with the current taxonomy. In
addition because C. siamense received only moderate
support in the current taxonomy we also tested the
alternative hypothesis of its monophyly to the second
closest taxa, C. asianum (i.e. {[C. siamense, C. asianum],
C. fructicola}, instead of the current taxonomy {[C. siamense,
C. fructicola}, C. asianum]) for congruent datasets. One
thousand replicates were performed by resampling the
partial likelihoods for each site (RELL model).
txt: Topology Tests?he current taxonomic relationships of the studied species were assessed through topology tests on each relevant dataset. Alternative hypotheses were tested against the most recent relationships among our species of interest using the Shimodaira-Hasegawa (SH) test, as implemented in PAUP* 4.0d99. Although this taxonomy was not formally addressed, it provided an objective starting point for our analysis. First, we tested the unconstrained phylogenies of each dataset to identify any discordant phylogenies and assess whether their branching orders were significantly incongruent with the current taxonomy. Additionally, since C. siamense received only moderate support in the current taxonomy, we tested the alternative hypothesis
q1: What was the purpose of the topology tests conducted on the species?
q2: How did the researchers assess the discordance in phylogenetic relationships?
q3: What significance did the moderate support for C. siamense have on the analysis?
q4: Did the study involve testing alternative hypotheses against a previous taxonomy?
q5: Were one thousand replicates performed during the analysis?
q6: Is the SH test used to evaluate the congruence of phylogenies with current taxonomy?

pdf:
Molecular marker analysis.—The newly developed set
of primers allowed the amplification of , 4061 bp
from the Apn2/MAT locus. Each primer pair produced
partially overlapping fragments that in combination
spanned all but the first 21 codons of Apn2,
the intergenic region between Apn2 and MAT1-2-1,
the complete MAT1-2-1 gene and a small intergenic
region adjacent to the 39 end of MAT1-2-1 (FIG. 1).
As in previous Colletotrichum studies, only one mating
type (MAT) locus idiomorph, MAT1-2-1, was identified.
Clean bands were reproducibly amplified by PCR
for all the isolates using all primer sets, generating
amplicons of , 740 bp for Apn23L, , 760 bp for
Apn2Ex3, , 840 bp for Apn25L, , 910 bp for
ApMAT and , 1040 bp for MAT1-2-1 and MAT5L.
An overview of the Apn2/MAT locus map is included
herein (FIG. 2), along with the position and length of
each developed marker, excluding overlapping segments.
The ITS, b-tub2 and GS markers generated
products of the expected size.
txt: Molecular marker analysis.?he newly developed set of primers allowed the amplification of 4061 bp from the Apn2/MAT locus. Each primer pair produced partially overlapping fragments that, in combination, spanned all but the first 21 codons of Apn2, the intergenic region between Apn2 and MAT1-2-1, the complete MAT1-2-1 gene, and a small intergenic region adjacent to the 3' end of MAT1-2-1. As in previous Colletotrichum studies, only one mating type (MAT) locus idiomorph, MAT1-2-1, was identified. Clean bands were reproducibly amplified by PCR for all isolates using all primer sets, generating amplicons of approximately 740 bp for Apn23L, 760 bp for Apn2Ex3, 840 bp for Apn25L, 910 bp for ApMAT, and 1040 bp for MAT1-2-1 and MAT5L. An overview of the Apn2/MAT locus map is included, along with the position and length of each developed marker, excluding overlapping segments. The ITS, 帣-tub2, and GS markers generated products of the expected size.

q2: How do the newly developed primers contribute to understanding the genetic structure of the organism being studied?
q3: Why might it be important that only one mating type locus idiomorph, MAT1-2-1, was identified in the isolates?
q4: Did the PCR amplification produce clean bands for all isolates?
q5: Was the complete MAT1-2-1 gene included in the amplified fragments?
q6: Were the products generated by the ITS, b-tub2, and GS markers of the expected size?

pdf:
The complete set of markers was first sequenced for
a representative sample of 10 isolates comprising the
five studied species (C. kahawae, C. gloeosporioides, C.
asianum, C. fructicola, C. siamense) plus the outgroup
(C. fragariae). This preliminary dataset was subjected
to a sliding window analysis to quantify nucleotide
polymorphisms along the sequence of each marker
and to provide a comparative exploratory analysis
between markers (FIG. 2). The commonly used ITS
region had the lowest overall nucleotide diversity (p
5 0.0077) because it was mostly invariable. The intron
rich b-tub2 (p 5 0.0436) and GS (p 5 0.0433) gene
fragments presented a greater degree of nucleotide
variation but still revealed regions of low polymorphism.
The greatest nucleotide diversity was provided
by the Apn2/MAT locus because even the most
conserved region of this locus, Apn2Ex3, was more
polymorphic (p 5 0.0467) than b-tub2 and GS. The
ApMAT intergenic region showed the highest nucleotide
diversity (p 5 0.1282), exceeding by more than
twofold the diversity of b-tub2 or GS fragments. The
MAT1-2-1 gene (p 5 0.0512) showed a considerable
diversity in its introns (p 5 0.1135), particularly the
second one in the HMG region, in contrast with exon
sequences (p 5 0.0419). In the Apn2 gene the
nucleotide diversity was highest in the Apn23L
marker region (p 5 0.0739) due to the presence of
two introns. The Apn25L region (p 5 0.0559) also
showed a considerable diversity, particularly along the
exon sequence.
txt: The complete set of markers was first sequenced for a representative sample of 10 isolates comprising the five studied species (C. kahawae, C. gloeosporioides, C. asianum, C. fructicola, and C. siamense) plus the outgroup (C. fragariae). This preliminary dataset was subjected to a sliding window analysis to quantify nucleotide polymorphisms along the sequence of each marker and to provide a comparative exploratory analysis between markers (FIG. 2). The commonly used ITS region had the lowest overall nucleotide diversity (p = 0.0077) because it was mostly invariable. The intron-rich β-tub2 (p = 0.0436) and GS (p = 0.0433) gene fragments presented a greater degree of nucleotide variation but still revealed regions of low polymorphism. The greatest nucleotide diversity was provided by the Apn2/MAT locus, as even the most conserved region of this locus, Apn2Ex3, was more polymorphic (p = 0.0467) than β-tub2 and GS. The ApMAT intergenic region showed the highest nucleotide diversity (p = 0.1282), exceeding by more than twofold the diversity of the β-tub2 or GS fragments. The MAT1-2-1 gene (p = 0.0512) exhibited considerable diversity in its introns (p = 0.1135), particularly in the second intron of the HMG region, in contrast with exon sequences (p = 0.0419). In the Apn2 gene, nucleotide diversity was highest in the Apn23L marker region (p = 0.0739) due to the presence of two introns. The Apn25L region (p = 0.0559) also showed considerable diversity, particularly along the exon sequence.
q1: What role does the sliding window analysis play in the study of nucleotide polymorphisms?
q2: How does the nucleotide diversity of the ITS region compare to that of the Apn2/MAT locus?
q3: Why might the Apn2 gene exhibit higher nucleotide diversity in certain regions compared to others?
q4: Did the study include an outgroup in the analysis?
q5: Is the ITS region characterized by high nucleotide diversity?
q6: Were introns found to contribute significantly to the nucleotide diversity in the MAT1-2-1 gene?

pdf:
Based on this assessment, two gene fragments
(Apn25L and MAT1-2-1) plus two intergenic regions
(ApMAT and MAT5L) were selected for the multilocus
phylogenetic analyses. A total of 22 sequences
were obtained for each of the seven nuclear markers
(ITS, b-tub2, GS, ApMAT, Apn25L, MAT1-2-1,
MAT5L), producing , 4676 bp of sequence data for
each studied isolate. According to the output of the
PhyDesign web application, the index of phylogenetic
power per base pair of each dataset varied widely, but
all of our developed primers generated sequences
with a superior resolution power throughout the phylogeny
(FIG. 3). After visual inspection, the ApMAT
sequence is predicted to be the most informative,
followed by MAT5L, Apn25L, MAT1-2-1, GS and
b-tub2, whose differences in phylogenetic informativeness
were less evident. The ITS sequence had the
lowest predicted resolution power. All of the newly
developed markers revealed more information than
the traditional markers, as determined with parsimony
and nucleotide diversity statistics as comparative
benchmarks (TABLE II). ApMAT, Apn25L, MAT5L
and MAT1-2-1 were 35%, 19%, 20% and 17%
parsimony informative, compared with 3%, 13% and
16% for ITS, b-tub2 and GS, respectively (TABLE II).
Regarding the combined datasets, even excluding
MAT1-2-1 to balance the sequence length of the two
partially concatenated datasets, the Apn-MAT dataset
exhibited 478 parsimony informative characters from
a total of 1886 (25%), while the traditional markers
contributed with only 232 parsimony informative
characters from a total of 1965 (12%) (TABLE II).
Altogether the total concatenated dataset presented
801 (17%) parsimony informative nucleotide characters
with parsimony criteria.
txt: Based on this assessment, two gene fragments (Apn25L and MAT1-2-1) and two intergenic regions (ApMAT and MAT5L) were selected for multilocus phylogenetic analyses. A total of 22 sequences were obtained for each of the seven nuclear markers (ITS, b-tub2, GS, ApMAT, Apn25L, MAT1-2-1, MAT5L), producing approximately 4,676 bp of sequence data for each studied isolate. According to the output of the PhyDesign web application, the index of phylogenetic power per base pair varied widely among the datasets, but all of our developed primers generated sequences with superior resolution power throughout the phylogeny. After visual inspection, the ApMAT sequence was predicted to be the most informative, followed by MAT5L, Apn25L, MAT1-2-1, GS, and b-tub2, whose differences in phylogenetic informativeness were less evident. The ITS sequence had the lowest predicted resolution power. All newly developed markers revealed more information than traditional markers, as determined by parsimony and nucleotide diversity statistics as comparative benchmarks. ApMAT, Apn25L, MAT5L, and MAT1-2-1 were 35%, 19%, 20%, and 17% parsimony informative, respectively, compared to 3%, 13%, and 16% for ITS, b-tub2, and GS. Regarding the combined datasets, even when excluding MAT1-2-1 to balance the sequence length of the two partially concatenated datasets, the Apn-MAT dataset exhibited 478 parsimony informative characters from a total of 1,886 (25%), while the traditional markers contributed only 232 parsimony informative characters from a total of 1,965 (12%). Altogether, the total concatenated dataset presented 801 (17%) parsimony informative nucleotide characters based on parsimony criteria.
q1: What is the significance of the ApMAT sequence in phylogenetic analyses?
q2: How does the phylogenetic power of newly developed markers compare to traditional markers?
q3: What criteria were used to evaluate the informativeness of the sequences?
q4: Did the study analyze seven nuclear markers?
q5: Was the ITS sequence found to have the lowest resolution power?
q6: Did the newly developed markers reveal more information than traditional markers?

pdf:
Phylogenetic analysis.—We first constructed phylogenies
from each of the individual markers (FIG. 4). The
ML and BMCMC analyses always resulted in identical
topologies for each dataset, although not all gene
trees had the same resolution. For example, ITS and
MAT5L provided such poorly resolved trees that no
discernible topology could be recovered and thus
were not analyzed individually (data not shown). In
contrast, ApMAT provided the best resolving ability in
which all species/group and even some intragroup
nodes were distinguishable with high support in both
analyses (FIG. 4a).
txt: Phylogenetic Analysis: We first constructed phylogenies from each of the individual markers. The ML and BMCMC analyses consistently resulted in identical topologies for each dataset, although not all gene trees had the same resolution. For example, ITS and MAT5L produced poorly resolved trees, making it impossible to recover a discernible topology; therefore, they were not analyzed individually. In contrast, ApMAT demonstrated the best resolving ability, allowing all species/groups and even some intragroup nodes to be distinguishable with high support in both analyses.
q1: What factors contributed to the different levels of resolution observed in the phylogenetic trees?
q2: Why were ITS and MAT5L not analyzed individually in the study?
q3: What characteristics made ApMAT the most effective marker for resolving species relationships?
q4: Did the ML and BMCMC analyses yield identical topologies for each dataset?
q5: Were the trees constructed from ITS and MAT5L well-resolved?
q6: Did ApMAT provide high support for distinguishing species and intragroup nodes?

pdf:
Most C. gloeosporioides s.l. isolates clustered with
the ex-type strains of C. siamense and C. fructicola
(TABLE I, FIG. 4). Generally species/groups were
reciprocally monophyletic, although with varying
degrees of support. An exception was the GS gene
tree in which two isolates from the C. siamense group
were part of a monophyletic group with C. fructicola.
However further incongruities were found when
comparing the relative taxonomic position of the
ingroup species. Excluding C. kahawae, which was
consistently revealed as the most basal lineage, all
other species showed different taxonomic relationships
in each of the independent loci analyzed due to
significant gene-tree discordance. For example C.
siamense was found to be part of the same monophyletic
group with either C. asianum (FIG. 4a; bootstrap:
97, posterior probability [PP]: 1.00) or C. fructicola
(FIG. 4d; bootstrap: 78, PP: 0.99). In the GS gene tree,
although there was little support for the reciprocal
monophyly of C. siamense isolates, the best ML and
BMCMC trees supported a close relationship with C.
fructicola rather than with C. asianum. The second
most basal lineage identified also was subject of
discordance because it was either C. gloeosporioides
(FIG. 4a–d; bootstrap: 82–99; PP: 0.80–1.00) or C.
asianum (FIG. 4e; bootstrap: 84; PP: 0.98). As it was
clearly shown, these discordances among loci were
well supported by both bootstrap and posterior
probability values in each loci dataset and consequently,
the phylogenetic relationships of all but one
of our species were not obvious based on the
topologies of gene trees alone.
txt: Most C. gloeosporioides s.l. isolates clustered with the ex-type strains of C. siamense and C. fructicola (TABLE I, FIG. 4). Generally, species/groups were reciprocally monophyletic, although with varying degrees of support. An exception was the GS gene tree, in which two isolates from the C. siamense group were part of a monophyletic group with C. fructicola. However, further incongruities were found when comparing the relative taxonomic positions of the ingroup species. Excluding C. kahawae, which was consistently revealed as the most basal lineage, all other species showed different taxonomic relationships in each of the independent loci analyzed due to significant gene-tree discordance. For example, C. siamense was found to be part of the same monophyletic group with either C. asianum (FIG. 4a; bootstrap: 97, posterior probability [PP]: 1.00) or C. fructicola (FIG. 4d; bootstrap: 78, PP: 0.99). In the GS gene tree, although there was little support for the reciprocal monophyly of C. siamense isolates, the best maximum likelihood (ML) and Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo (BMCMC) trees supported a close relationship with C. fructicola rather than with C. asianum. The second most basal lineage identified was also subject to discordance, as it was either C. gloeosporioides (FIG. 4a–d; bootstrap: 82–99; PP: 0.80–1.00) or C. asianum (FIG. 4e; bootstrap: 84; PP: 0.98). As clearly shown, these discordances among loci were well supported by both bootstrap and posterior probability values in each loci dataset. Consequently, the phylogenetic relationships of all but one of our species were not obvious based on the topologies of gene trees alone.
q1: What factors contributed to the varying degrees of support for the monophyly of the species groups analyzed?
q2: How did the taxonomic relationships among the species change across different loci?
q3: Why is C. kahawae considered the most basal lineage among the isolates?
q4: Did all species analyzed exhibit consistent taxonomic relationships across all loci?
q5: Were the bootstrap and posterior probability values supportive of the discordances found among the gene trees?
q6: Is C. siamense consistently grouped with C. fructicola in all analyses?

pdf:
Phylogenetic reconstructions were carried out for
the three combined datasets to assess how these
discordances affected species relationships and their
node support in multilocus datasets and to compare
degrees of resolution. Overall, both the traditional and
Apn-MAT datasets provided almost completely resolved
and highly supported trees but presented two
different topologies in which C. siamense was again
either reciprocally monophyletic with C. asianum
(FIG. 5a; bootstrap: 95; PP: 1.00) or C. fructicola
(FIG. 5b; bootstrap: 78; PP: 1.00). When all markers
were combined, the prevailing phylogenetic relationships
were congruent with the Apn-MAT dataset,
supporting the reciprocal monophyly between
C. siamense and C. fructicola (FIG. 5c; bootstrap: 97;
PP: 1.00). Of interest, both the topology and node
support of the single ApMAT marker were similar to
the seven-gene concatenated dataset.
txt: Phylogenetic reconstructions were carried out for the three combined datasets to assess how discordances affected species relationships and node support in multilocus datasets, as well as to compare degrees of resolution. Overall, both the traditional and Apn-MAT datasets provided almost completely resolved and highly supported trees but presented two different topologies in which C. siamense was either reciprocally monophyletic with C. asianum or C. fructicola. When all markers were combined, the prevailing phylogenetic relationships were congruent with the Apn-MAT dataset, supporting the reciprocal monophyly between C. siamense and C. fructicola. Notably, both the topology and node support of the single ApMAT marker were similar to the seven-gene concatenated dataset.

q3: Why is the reciprocal monophyly between C. siamense and C. fructicola significant in this study?
q4: Did the traditional datasets yield different topologies than the Apn-MAT datasets?
q5: Was the node support for the combined datasets generally high?
q6: Were the phylogenetic relationships consistent across the different markers used in the study?

pdf:
Species-tree approach and topology tests.—The current
taxonomic and evolutionary relationships of the
included species from the C. gloeosporioides complex
were further assessed by two statistical methods. First,
the species-tree approach of the BEST software was
carried out because it has the useful property of
accounting for discrepancies between gene trees and
uses the coalescent theory to combine those gene
trees to infer a species tree. The obtained tree shared
the same topology as the Apn-MAT and total
concatenated datasets, albeit with a much smaller
support for the reciprocal monophyly between
C. siamense and C. asianum (FIG. 6). Nonetheless
the remaining relationships were highly supported.
txt: Species-tree approach and topology tests.?he current taxonomic and evolutionary relationships of the included species from the C. gloeosporioides complex were further assessed using two statistical methods. First, the species-tree approach with BEST software was utilized, as it effectively accounts for discrepancies between gene trees and employs coalescent theory to infer a species tree. The resulting tree shared the same topology as the Apn-MAT and total concatenated datasets, though it exhibited much smaller support for the reciprocal monophyly between C. siamense and C. asianum. Nonetheless, the remaining relationships were highly supported.
q1: What statistical methods were used to assess the taxonomic relationships within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q2: How does the species-tree approach contribute to understanding discrepancies between gene trees?
q3: What implications does the smaller support for the reciprocal monophyly between C. siamense and C. asianum have on the overall findings?
q4: Did the species-tree approach yield a different topology compared to the Apn-MAT and total concatenated datasets?
q5: Is the support for the relationships within the species-tree analysis considered high?
q6: Does the study utilize coalescent theory in its analysis?

pdf:
For the topological tests we assumed the null
hypothesis of the most recently reported species
relationship (Phoulivong et al. 2010), which is
identical to that exhibited by the traditional dataset
(SH test, TABLE III). Except for b-tub2, all individual
datasets were discordant, but only the branching
order of ApMAT and MAT1-2-1 deviated significantly
from the current taxonomic understanding (SH test,
P 5 0.035 and P 5 0.000 respectively). Likewise, the
combined Apn-MAT topology was significantly different
(SH test, P 5 0.000) but the deviation of the total
combined dataset was only marginally significant
(SH test, P 5 0.076). We also tested whether the
traditional dataset presented a significant deviation
from the alternative scenario in which the true species
relationship is similar to that recovered in the total
dataset. Indeed, when the topology for this alternative
scenario was constrained, it was not significantly
different from the unconstrained phylogeny (SH test,
P 5 0.143).
txt: For the topological tests, we assumed the null hypothesis of the most recently reported species relationship, which is identical to that exhibited by the traditional dataset. Except for b-tub2, all individual datasets were discordant, but only the branching order of ApMAT and MAT1-2-1 deviated significantly from the current taxonomic understanding (P = 0.035 and P < 0.001, respectively). Likewise, the combined Apn-MAT topology was significantly different (P < 0.001), but the deviation of the total combined dataset was only marginally significant (P = 0.076). We also tested whether the traditional dataset presented a significant deviation from an alternative scenario in which the true species relationship resembles that recovered in the total dataset. When the topology for this alternative scenario was constrained, it was not significantly different from the unconstrained phylogeny (P = 0.143).
q1: What is the significance of the branching order of ApMAT and MAT1-2-1 in relation to species relationships?
q2: How does the combined Apn-MAT topology compare to the traditional dataset?
q3: What does the marginal significance of the total combined dataset suggest about the current taxonomic understanding?
q4: Did all individual datasets align with the traditional dataset?
q5: Was the deviation of the total combined dataset considered significant?
q6: Did the constrained topology show a significant difference from the unconstrained phylogeny?

pdf:
DISCUSSION
Resolving species complexes in Colletotrichum, particularly
the C. gloeosporioides complex, is a demanding
quest in which molecular systematic tools
are becoming of the utmost importance for taxonomists.
However, genomic regions are not equally
informative and thus it is important to select the most
useful loci to address this issue. The MAT locus has
been employed with great success in phylogenetic
studies of Colletotrichum (Du et al. 2005; Crouch et al.
2006, 2009a; Rojas et al. 2010) as well as in other
genera, such as Cochliobolus (Turgeon 1998), Fusarium
(O’Donnell et al. 2004) and Leptosphaeria (Voigt
et al. 2005). In our work a newly developed set of
primers enabled the analysis of an expanded region
of the Apn2/MAT locus in relation to other studies
exploring this locus (Du et al. 2005, Crouch et al.
2009a, Rojas et al. 2010). In fact, our primer sets were
able to generate not only orthologous sequences to
those already published (e.g. the 39 end of the Apn2
gene and intergenic region between MAT1-2-1
[Crouch et al. 2009a, Rojas et al. 2010] or the intron
in the HMG region of the MAT1-2-1 gene [Du et al.
2005]) but also the remainder of the Apn2 gene
sequence as well as the complete MAT1-2-1 gene
along with a portion of the 59 intergenic region, covering
, 2700 bp of novel sequence data from this locus.
Overall, our analyses further demonstrated the potential
of this genomic region to provide an outstanding improvement
in phylogenetic informativeness to face the
taxonomic challenges of the C. gloeosporioides complex.
txt:
DISCUSSION
 Resolving species complexes in Colletotrichum, particularly the C. gloeosporioides complex, is a demanding quest in which molecular systematic tools are becoming increasingly important for taxonomists. However, genomic regions are not equally informative, making it crucial to select the most useful loci for this purpose. The MAT locus has been employed successfully in phylogenetic studies of Colletotrichum, as well as in other genera such as Cochliobolus, Fusarium, and Leptosphaeria. In our work, a newly developed set of primers enabled the analysis of an expanded region of the Apn2/MAT locus, building on previous studies exploring this locus. Our primer sets were able to generate not only orthologous sequences to those already published (e.g., the 39 end of the Apn2 gene and the intergenic region between MAT1-2-1, or the intron in the HMG region of the MAT1-2-1 gene) but also the remainder of the Apn2 gene sequence and the complete MAT1-2-1 gene along with a portion of the 59 intergenic region, covering approximately 2,700 bp of novel sequence data from this locus. Overall, our analyses further demonstrated the potential of this genomic region to significantly improve phylogenetic informativeness in addressing the taxonomic challenges of the C. gloeosporioides complex.
q1: What challenges do taxonomists face when resolving species complexes in Colletotrichum?
q2: How does the MAT locus contribute to phylogenetic studies in fungi?
q3: What advancements have been made in the analysis of the Apn2/MAT locus compared to previous studies?
q4: Is the MAT locus considered useful for phylogenetic studies in Colletotrichum?
q5: Did the newly developed primers provide more sequence data than previously published studies?
q6: Are molecular systematic tools becoming increasingly important for taxonomists studying species complexes?

pdf:
Even though our analyses focused mostly on Coffea
spp.-inhabiting species of the C. gloeosporioides complex,
this sampling strategy proved valuable under the
current taxonomic knowledge. First, the six species
used in our study encompass relatively divergent
lineages within the complex (4.5–10.1% sequence
divergence). Therefore, despite probably not covering
all of the putatively high species richness of the
complex, they provide a wide range of sequence
diversity, which is useful to assess the robustness of
the developed primers and also enhances their
potential applicability to other species in the C.
gloeosporioides complex. Second, unlike the myriad
undescribed and poorly known lineages in this
complex, the species used here are well characterized
and recognized by multilocus phylogenetic and morphological
studies, which is paramount when investigating
the value of the newly developed molecular
tools for systematic purposes. Third, all these species
were already used simultaneously in previous and
independent phylogenetic studies, providing an objective
starting point of their taxonomic relationships
and allowing a much more meaningful comparison of
the traditional gene-tree concatenation and the recent
species-tree reconstruction methods.
txt: Even though our analyses focused mostly on Coffea spp.-inhabiting species of the C. gloeosporioides complex, this sampling strategy proved valuable given the current taxonomic knowledge. The six species used in our study encompass relatively divergent lineages within the complex (4.5??0.1% sequence divergence). Therefore, despite not covering all the putatively high species richness of the complex, they provide a wide range of sequence diversity, which is useful for assessing the robustness of the developed primers and enhances their potential applicability to other species in the C. gloeosporioides complex. Unlike the myriad undescribed and poorly known lineages in this complex, the species used here are well characterized and recognized by multilocus phylogenetic and morphological studies, which is crucial when investigating the value of the newly developed molecular tools for systematic purposes. Furthermore, all these species were previously used simultaneously in independent phylogenetic studies, providing an objective starting point for their taxonomic relationships and allowing a more meaningful comparison between traditional gene-tree concatenation and recent species-tree reconstruction methods.
q1: What advantages does the selected sampling strategy offer in studying the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q2: How does the sequence diversity among the species contribute to the robustness of the developed primers?
q3: In what ways do the well-characterized species enhance the investigation of molecular tools for systematic purposes?
q4: Did the study focus solely on the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q5: Were the species used in the study previously characterized in phylogenetic research?
q6: Is there a possibility that the sampling strategy does not cover all species richness in the complex?

pdf:
Regarding their informative potential, all newly
developed primer pairs generated sequences that
were superior to ITS and to the two commonly used
gene fragments, b-tub2 and GS, even though the
latter had been useful and regarded as fairly
informative (Talhinhas et al. 2005, Prihastuti et al.
2009, Rojas et al. 2010). The ITS sequence in
particular, which is considered one of the most
promising regions for fungal barcoding (Seifert
2009), performed poorly in our benchmark comparisons,
being unable to distinguish taxonomic groups
and recover their relationships. This also has been
observed in other studies (Cai et al. 2009, Crouch
et al. 2009b, Yang et al. 2009). As evidenced by the
sliding window analysis of polymorphism and parsimony
statistics, the intergenic region between the
Apn2 and MAT1-2-1 genes was revealed to be the
most variable segment and thus a promising marker
for both taxonomic and population genetic studies in
the complex. Intergenic regions are expected to be
much more variable because they generally are not
under functional constraints or any direct selective
pressures (O’Donnell et al. 2004, Thomson et al.
2010), but for the same reason they are unsuitable
regions for primer design over a broad range of
species. However, the ApMAT intergenic segment is
flanked by fairly conserved regions for which primers
can be designed, making it an ideal marker for the
C. gloeosporioides complex. To a lesser extent, both
the introns from MAT1-2-1 gene and the two Apn2
gene extremities were variable and should also prove
useful for systematic purposes, as reported in other
Colletotrichum studies (Du et al. 2005, Crouch et al.
2006, 2009a; Rojas et al. 2010). Nevertheless, these
markers are not barcode candidates, and attempts to
use them outside the range of the C. gloeosporioides
complex probably will fail due to their highly variable
nature even in priming sites. For example, the
markers developed by Crouch et al. (2009a) to
amplify partial fragments of the Apn2 gene and
intergenic region in the same locus for the graminicolous
Colletotrichum species could not be used in the
isolates analyzed in this study (data not shown). In
fact, after obtaining the homologous sequences from
isolates of the C. gloeosporioides complex alignments
revealed a high divergence between the two groups of
species. However, these markers are much more
suitable than barcode genes to accurately dissect
and unravel the diversity and evolutionary relationships
in a complex of closely related species.
Moreover, as Cai et al. (2009) stated, the selection
and decision of the most suitable barcode gene(s) can
be made only in the process of species delimitation
because only then we know which taxa need to be
distinguished. In other words, we first need to fully
resolve the C. gloeosporioides complex with a set of
highly informative genes to adequately search and
select a barcode gene.
txt: Regarding their informative potential, all newly developed primer pairs generated sequences that were superior to ITS and the two commonly used gene fragments, b-tub2 and GS, which had previously been useful and regarded as fairly informative. The ITS sequence, considered one of the most promising regions for fungal barcoding, performed poorly in our benchmark comparisons, failing to distinguish taxonomic groups and recover their relationships. This has also been observed in other studies. The sliding window analysis of polymorphism and parsimony statistics revealed that the intergenic region between the Apn2 and MAT1-2-1 genes was the most variable segment and thus a promising marker for both taxonomic and population genetic studies in the complex. Intergenic regions are expected to be more variable because they generally are not under functional constraints or direct selective pressures, making them unsuitable for primer design across a broad range of species. However, the ApMAT intergenic segment is flanked by fairly conserved regions for primer design, making it an ideal marker for the C. gloeosporioides complex. To a lesser extent, both the introns from the MAT1-2-1 gene and the two Apn2 gene extremities were variable and should also prove useful for systematic purposes. Nevertheless, these markers are not barcode candidates, and attempts to use them outside the range of the C. gloeosporioides complex will likely fail due to their highly variable nature, even in priming sites. For example, markers developed to amplify partial fragments of the Apn2 gene and intergenic region for the graminicolous Colletotrichum species could not be used in the isolates analyzed in this study. After obtaining homologous sequences from isolates of the C. gloeosporioides complex, alignments revealed a high divergence between the two groups of species. However, these markers are more suitable than barcode genes for accurately dissecting and unraveling the diversity and evolutionary relationships in a complex of closely related species. Moreover, the selection of the most suitable barcode gene(s) can be made only during species delimitation, as only then can we determine which taxa need to be distinguished. In other words, we first need to fully resolve the C. gloeosporioides complex with a set of highly informative genes to adequately search for and select a barcode gene.
q1: Why did the newly developed primer pairs perform better than the ITS and other commonly used gene fragments?
q2: What role do intergenic regions play in the study of taxonomic and population genetics within the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q3: How does the high variability of certain markers impact their suitability for broader species applications?
q4: Did the ITS sequence perform well in distinguishing taxonomic groups?
q5: Are the markers developed for the C. gloeosporioides complex considered suitable for other species?
q6: Is it necessary to resolve the C. gloeosporioides complex before selecting barcode genes?

pdf:
In agreement with other studies in Colletotrichum,
our study revealed the ubiquitous presence of only
one MAT gene idiomorph, MAT1-2-1 (Vaillancourt
et al. 2000, Chen et al. 2002, Rodrı´guez-Guerra et al.
2005, Garcı´a-Serrano et al. 2008). In the fungal kingdom
MAT idiomorphs are known to code for transcription
factors that regulate sexual development and
recognition (Kronstad and Staben 1997). However
their configuration in Colletotrichum species seems to
deviate from the great majority of the ascomycetes,
where a single MAT locus (MAT1) exists as two alternate
idiomorphs (MAT1-1 and MAT1-2) (Turgeon
1998). Thus the exclusive presence of a MAT1-2
homolog in all species included in this work supports
the idea that the genetic control underlying sexual
reproduction in this genus does not conform to any
known systemin the entire fungal kingdom(Rodrı´guez-
Guerra et al. 2005, Crouch and Beirn 2009).
txt: In agreement with other studies on Colletotrichum, our study revealed the ubiquitous presence of only one MAT gene idiomorph, MAT1-2-1. In the fungal kingdom, MAT idiomorphs are known to code for transcription factors that regulate sexual development and recognition. However, their configuration in Colletotrichum species seems to deviate from the majority of ascomycetes, where a single MAT locus (MAT1) exists as two alternate idiomorphs (MAT1-1 and MAT1-2). Thus, the exclusive presence of a MAT1-2 homolog in all species included in this work supports the idea that the genetic control underlying sexual reproduction in this genus does not conform to any known system in the entire fungal kingdom.
q1: How does the MAT gene idiomorph in Colletotrichum differ from that in other ascomycetes?
q2: What role do MAT idiomorphs play in the sexual development of fungi?
q3: Why is the presence of only one MAT gene idiomorph significant for understanding Colletotrichum's reproductive genetics?
q4: Is MAT1-2-1 the only MAT gene idiomorph found in Colletotrichum species?
q5: Do most ascomycetes have two alternate MAT idiomorphs?
q6: Is the genetic control of sexual reproduction in Colletotrichum consistent with other fungal systems?

pdf:
In our phylogenetic analyses of the individual gene
trees the ApMAT marker was singular in its ability to
resolve species and even intraspecific relationships.
Alone it provided essentially the same information
and support as the concatenated tree of seven genes,
a feat that was not achieved by any other single
marker. The other markers had variable degrees of
resolution and support, ranging from low to moderate,
as is normally expected for nuclear gene markers
when addressing recently diverged taxa (Thomson
et al. 2010).
txt: In our phylogenetic analyses of the individual gene trees, the ApMAT marker was unique in its ability to resolve species and even intraspecific relationships. It provided essentially the same information and support as the concatenated tree of seven genes, a feat unmatched by any other single marker. The other markers displayed variable degrees of resolution and support, ranging from low to moderate, which is typically expected for nuclear gene markers when addressing recently diverged taxa.
q1: What is the significance of the ApMAT marker in phylogenetic analyses?
q2: How does the resolution of other markers compare to the ApMAT marker?
q3: Why might nuclear gene markers show variable degrees of resolution?
q4: Does the ApMAT marker provide high resolution for species relationships?
q5: Were the other markers effective in resolving intraspecific relationships?
q6: Is the resolution of nuclear gene markers typically low when studying recently diverged taxa?
metadata: Application of the Apn2MAT locus to improve the systematics of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex.pdf

pdf:
However, gene trees are only single realizations of
the true species tree and they may not reflect the
actual pattern of lineage splitting and divergence due
to coalescent stochasticity (Degnan and Rosenberg
2009, Carstens and Dewey 2010). Therefore, it is
useful to reconstruct individual gene trees to provide
an overview of how each marker depicts species
relationships. In this way, several incongruities were
revealed by comparing the topology of each gene
tree. For example, two isolates that were consistently
shown to cluster with the C. siamense group (Mal5
and CCM5) were monophyletic with isolates from the
C. fructicola group in the GS gene tree. Moreover,
each analyzed locus provided with strong support a
discordant species branching order with each other
and the correct relationship of the studied Colletotrichum
species was not clear. In fact only one gene
tree (b-tub2) was congruent with the current taxonomic
understanding of the sampled species whereas
the ApMAT and MAT1-2-1 gene trees revealed a
significantly deviated phylogenetic signal. Even when
different combinations of genes are concatenated
these discordances remain significant, as evidenced
by the ambiguous relationship of C. siamense, C.
fructicola and C. asianum between the traditional and
Apn-MAT datasets. There are several causes for
discordance between gene trees in phylogenetic
studies, including horizontal gene transfer (Andersson
2005), hybridization (Meng and Kubatko
2009) or incomplete lineage sorting (Degnan and
Rosenberg 2009). To our knowledge this is the first
report of gene-tree discordance among species of the
C. gloeosporioides complex.
txt: However, gene trees are only single realizations of the true species tree and may not reflect the actual pattern of lineage splitting and divergence due to coalescent stochasticity. Therefore, it is useful to reconstruct individual gene trees to provide an overview of how each marker depicts species relationships. This approach revealed several incongruities by comparing the topology of each gene tree. For example, two isolates consistently clustering with the C. siamense group (Mal5 and CCM5) were monophyletic with isolates from the C. fructicola group in the GS gene tree. Moreover, each analyzed locus strongly supported discordant species branching orders, leaving the correct relationships among the studied Colletotrichum species unclear. Only one gene tree (b-tub2) was congruent with the current taxonomic understanding of the sampled species, while the ApMAT and MAT1-2-1 gene trees showed significantly deviated phylogenetic signals. Even when different combinations of genes were concatenated, these discordances remained significant, as evidenced by the ambiguous relationships among C. siamense, C. fructicola, and C. asianum between the traditional and ApMAT datasets. Several causes of discordance between gene trees in phylogenetic studies include horizontal gene transfer, hybridization, or incomplete lineage sorting. To our knowledge, this is the first report of gene-tree discordance among species of the C. gloeosporioides complex.
q1: What are the potential reasons for the discordance observed between gene trees and the true species tree?
q2: How does the reconstruction of individual gene trees contribute to understanding species relationships within the Colletotrichum genus?
q3: Why is the gene tree for b-tub2 considered significant in relation to the current taxonomic understanding of the sampled species?
q4: Is the true species tree reflected accurately by gene trees in all cases?
q5: Did the study reveal any inconsistencies in the clustering of certain isolates within the C. siamense and C. fructicola groups?
q6: Was the gene-tree discordance reported for the first time among species of the C. gloeosporioides complex in this study?
metadata: Application of the Apn2MAT locus to improve the systematics of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex.pdf

pdf:
In this study, even though the total concatenated
dataset provided a single resolved topology congruent
with that of the combined Apn-MAT and individual
ApMAT datasets, the concatenation method assumption
of no heterogeneity between the embedded gene
trees was violated. In addition, the longer and more
informative markers, such as those from the Apn2/
MAT locus, may bias tree topology toward themselves
simply because their phylogenetic signal overwhelms
the information contained in less informative markers
(Knowles and Carstens 2007). Because the evolutionary
history of species is widely considered to be mostly
a stochastic process (Kingman 1982) we have applied
a recent statistical framework that accounts for the
discrepancies of gene trees from multiple unlinked
loci and is specifically conceived to estimate the
species tree. Using a Bayesian hierarchical model, the
BEST program is able not only to accommodate gene
trees heterogeneity but also to retrieve useful information
from it and provide a more accurate estimate
of the true species tree (Edwards et al. 2007). The
resultant species-tree topology supported that of the
total concatenated dataset, except for the C. siamense
and C. asianum relationships. Although all other
nodes were highly supported, there was little support
for the reciprocal monophyly between C. siamense
and C. asianum and the relationship of these two
species plus C. fructicola was unresolved. This result
was obtained in spite of using the large and highly
informative sequence data of our analysis. Nonetheless,
it is expected that the problems and difficulties
derived from incomplete lineage sorting increase as
the time since species divergence decreases (Degnan
and Rosenberg 2009). Thus it seems likely that these
species diverged recently and consequently their
relationships may still not be easily resolved. Nonetheless,
to further understand the processes that
promote speciation and the evolution of phenotypic
traits it will be essential to recognize and delimit
nascent evolutionary lineages (Wiens 2007). In
addition, it will be interesting to assess the effects of
using different outgroup taxa in the phylogenetic
inference as the current taxonomic knowledge of
Colletotrichum increases and molecular tools improve.
txt: In this study, the total concatenated dataset provided a single resolved topology congruent with that of the combined Apn-MAT and individual ApMAT datasets; however, the assumption of no heterogeneity between the embedded gene trees was violated. Additionally, longer and more informative markers, such as those from the Apn2/MAT locus, may bias tree topology due to their phylogenetic signal overwhelming the information from less informative markers. Given that the evolutionary history of species is widely considered a stochastic process, we applied a recent statistical framework that accounts for discrepancies in gene trees from multiple unlinked loci, specifically designed to estimate the species tree. Using a Bayesian hierarchical model, the BEST program accommodates gene tree heterogeneity and retrieves useful information, providing a more accurate estimate of the true species tree. The resultant species-tree topology supported that of the total concatenated dataset, except for the relationships between C. siamense and C. asianum. While all other nodes were highly supported, there was little support for the reciprocal monophyly of these two species, and their relationship with C. fructicola remained unresolved. This result was achieved despite using a large and highly informative sequence dataset. It is anticipated that issues from incomplete lineage sorting will increase as the time since species divergence decreases, suggesting these species diverged recently and their relationships may not be easily resolved. To further understand the processes that promote speciation and the evolution of phenotypic traits, it is essential to recognize and delimit nascent evolutionary lineages. Additionally, assessing the effects of using different outgroup taxa in phylogenetic inference will be interesting as our understanding of Colletotrichum increases and molecular tools improve.
q1: What implications does gene tree heterogeneity have for estimating species trees in evolutionary studies?
q2: How does the use of longer and more informative genetic markers influence phylogenetic analysis?
q3: Why is it important to recognize nascent evolutionary lineages in understanding speciation processes?
q4: Does the study support the idea that the concatenation method may not accurately reflect gene tree relationships?
q5: Was the relationship between C. siamense and C. asianum clearly resolved in the study?
q6: Is there an expectation that incomplete lineage sorting affects the resolution of species relationships over time?
metadata: Application of the Apn2MAT locus to improve the systematics of the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex.pdf

pdf:
Altogether this study demonstrates the considerable
improvement that the Apn2/MAT locus may
provide to the molecular systematics of the C.
gloeosporioides complex. We report the development
and application of a novel set of primers as valuable,
promising tools to generate sequence data able to
dissect species and even population relationships.
Indeed, based on our data, an alternative view of the
evolutionary relationships of the studied species is
hypothesized. Because we also showed that gene tree
discordance may be a problem in recently diverged
species of this complex we stress the fact that highly
variable markers, such as the ApMAT, are much more
likely to surpass those problems and successfully discern
how species are phylogenetically related. It is
hoped that this contribution may assist and stimulate
further research on this challenging complex and
eventually lead to a more comprehensive understanding
of its structure, evolution and diversity.
txt: Altogether, this study demonstrates the considerable improvement that the Apn2/MAT locus may provide to the molecular systematics of the C. gloeosporioides complex. We report the development and application of a novel set of primers as valuable and promising tools for generating sequence data capable of dissecting species and even population relationships. Indeed, based on our data, an alternative view of the evolutionary relationships among the studied species is hypothesized. Additionally, we showed that gene tree discordance may pose a problem in recently diverged species within this complex. We emphasize that highly variable markers, such as ApMAT, are much more likely to overcome these issues and successfully discern the phylogenetic relationships among species. It is hoped that this contribution may assist and stimulate further research on this challenging complex and eventually lead to a more comprehensive understanding of its structure, evolution, and diversity.
q1: What specific improvements does the Apn2/MAT locus provide to the molecular systematics of the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q2: How do the novel primers developed in this study contribute to understanding species and population relationships?
q3: What challenges does gene tree discordance present in studying recently diverged species of the C. gloeosporioides complex?
q4: Did the study report the development of a novel set of primers?
q5: Is gene tree discordance identified as a potential problem in the research?
q6: Is there hope that this research will lead to a better understanding of the C. gloeosporioides complex?

408 MYCOLOGIA
txt: Hindorf (1970) studied Colletotrichum species isolated from Coffea arabica in Kenya. Hyde et al. (2009) discussed the current names of Colletotrichum, while also addressing the confusion surrounding the genus in another work. Johnston and Jones (1997) examined relationships among Colletotrichum isolates from fruit-rots using rDNA sequences. Katoh et al. (2009) provided methods for multiple DNA sequence alignment, and Kingman (1982) introduced the coalescent theory. Knowles and Carstens (2007) focused on delimiting species without relying on monophyletic gene trees, and Kronstad and Staben (1997) discussed mating types in filamentous fungi. Liu (2008) developed BEST for Bayesian estimation of species trees. Lopez-Giraldez and Townsend (2011) created PhyDesign for profiling phylogenetic informativeness, while Lubbe et al. (2004) characterized Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and related species associated with plant diseases. Marshall (2004) presented PerlPrimer for graphical primer design, and Meng and Kubatko (2009) modeled hybrid speciation detection amidst incomplete lineage sorting. Mills et al. (1992) used PCR for differentiation of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides isolates. Munaut et al. (1998) investigated genetic relationships among isolates from Stylosanthes in Africa and Australia. Nguyen et al. (2009) identified Colletotrichum species associated with anthracnose in coffee. Nylander (2004) distributed MrModeltest, and O'Donnell and Cigelnik (1997) studied intragenomic rDNA ITS2 types in Fusarium. Phoulivong et al. (2010) noted that Colletotrichum gloeosporioides is not a common tropical fruit pathogen. Pina-Martins and Paulo (2008) created Concatenator for sequence data matrices. Polashock et al. (2009) provided an overview of the cranberry fruit rot fungal community. Posada and Crandall (1998) developed Modeltest for testing DNA substitution models, and Prihastuti et al. (2009) characterized Colletotrichum species in Thailand. Ramos et al. (2006) molecularly and morphologically characterized Colletotrichum species in citrus anthracnose. Rodr穩guez-Guerra et al. (2005) observed heterothallic mating in Mexican isolates of Glomerella lindemuthiana, while Rojas et al. (2010) distinguished host-associated pathogens from asymptomatic endophytes using multilocus phylogenies in Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Lastly, Ronquist and Huelsenbeck (2003) advanced Bayesian phylogenetic inference with MrBayes.

q2: How do the relationships among Colletotrichum isolates contribute to our understanding of fungal diversity?
q3: What geographical regions are represented in the studies of Colletotrichum associated with coffee and other plants?
q4: Are there multiple species of Colletotrichum associated with Coffea arabica in Kenya?
q5: Is rDNA sequencing used in the studies referenced in the passage?
q6: Does the passage discuss phylogenetic analysis as a method for understanding fungal relationships?

pdf:
Seven species of Colletotrichwn known to cause ripe fruit rots in Queensland are
compared with respect to spore measurements, cultural characters, temperature reactions,
and host range determined by field collection and artificial inoculation.
The characteristic features of these organisms are discussed and on the evidence
available it is found desirable to designate a new form of C. gloeosporioides and one new
species.
txt: Seven species of Colletotrichum known to cause ripe fruit rots in Queensland are compared with respect to spore measurements, cultural characteristics, temperature reactions, and host range determined through field collection and artificial inoculation. The characteristic features of these organisms are discussed, and based on the available evidence, it is deemed desirable to designate a new form of C. gloeosporioides and one new species.
q1: What are the specific spore measurements and cultural characteristics of the Colletotrichum species studied?
q2: How do temperature reactions vary among the seven species of Colletotrichum?
q3: What criteria were used to determine the host range for these fungi?
q4: Did the study involve artificial inoculation to determine host range?
q5: Is a new form of C. gloeosporioides being proposed based on the findings?
q6: Were all seven species compared in the same environmental conditions?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
The ripe fruit rots are a common source of loss in Queensland, especially
in fruit of a tropical and subtropical nature. Of the pathogens associated, by
far the most common are species of the genus Colletotrichum. Members of
this group are particularly adapted to this form of activity. Their capacity for
maintaining a saprophytic existence on dying host parts ensures an effective source
of inoculum. In addition, by forming latent infections throughout the growing
period of the fruit the parasite is rendered largely independent of environmental
conditions at the time of ripening, not to ·mention the protection afforded from
the action of fungicides.
txt: Ripe fruit rots are a common source of loss in Queensland, especially in tropical and subtropical fruit. Among the associated pathogens, species of the genus Colletotrichum are by far the most common. Members of this group are particularly well adapted to this form of activity. Their ability to maintain a saprophytic existence on dying host parts ensures a consistent source of inoculum. Additionally, by forming latent infections throughout the growing period of the fruit, the parasite becomes largely independent of environmental conditions during ripening, not to mention the protection afforded from fungicide applications.
q1: What factors contribute to the prevalence of Colletotrichum in Queensland's tropical and subtropical fruits?
q2: How do latent infections impact the management of fruit rot?
q3: What role do environmental conditions play in the effectiveness of Colletotrichum as a pathogen?
q4: Is Colletotrichum the most common pathogen associated with ripe fruit rot in Queensland?
q5: Do members of the Colletotrichum genus rely on environmental conditions for their growth during ripening?
q6: Can fungicides effectively eliminate the protection provided by latent infections?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
A number of distinct species of Colletotrichum are associated with ripe fruit
rots in Queensland and more than one species may be responsible for similar
diseases on the one variety of fruit. The present paper is an attempt to place
these species in their correct position and at the same time summarize their main
characteristics. It is hoped that the information presented will assist future
determinations and that the importance of individual diseases will be more clearly
appreciated.
txt: A number of distinct species of Colletotrichum are associated with ripe fruit rots in Queensland, and more than one species may be responsible for similar diseases on a single variety of fruit. This paper aims to accurately classify these species while summarizing their main characteristics. It is hoped that the information presented will aid in future identifications and enhance the understanding of the significance of individual diseases.
q1: What specific species of Colletotrichum are associated with fruit rots in Queensland?
q2: How do different species of Colletotrichum affect the same variety of fruit?
q3: Why is it important to summarize the main characteristics of these species?
q4: Are there multiple species of Colletotrichum involved in fruit rots?
q5: Does the paper aim to help with future species determinations?
q6: Is the focus solely on one type of fruit in the study?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
Taxonomy within the genus Colletotrichum has long been in an unsatisfactory
position and many poorly defined species exist. Arx (1957a, 1957b) attempted
the difficult task of clarifying the position. While this work has brought about
a very useful simplification and drawn attention to the need for a drastic reduction
in the number of species, it is inevitable that within the synonyms listed by
Arx there will be species or groups of species which on further investigation will
be shown to merit separate status. This has been borne out in the present
work, where use has been made of a previously described variety to designate one
such group.
txt: Taxonomy within the genus Colletotrichum has long been unsatisfactory, with many poorly defined species. Arx attempted the difficult task of clarifying this position. While his work provided a useful simplification and highlighted the need for a drastic reduction in species, it is inevitable that some synonyms listed will, upon further investigation, merit separate status. This has been demonstrated in the present work, which utilizes a previously described variety to designate one such group.
q1: What challenges has the genus Colletotrichum faced in terms of species classification?
q2: How did Arx contribute to the understanding of taxonomy within Colletotrichum?
q3: What findings in the current work support the idea that some species should be considered separately?
q4: Did Arx attempt to clarify the taxonomy of Colletotrichum?
q5: Is there a consensus on the number of species within the genus Colletotrichum?
q6: Has the current work utilized a previously described variety for classification?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
The following species are dealt with here: Glomerella cingulata ( Stonem.)
Spauld. & Schrenk, stat. conid. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides Penz.; G. cingulata
var. minor Wr., stat. conid. C. gloeosporioides var. minor var. nov.; C. musae
(Berk. & Curt.) Arx ( Gloeosporium musarum Cke. & Mass.); Colletotrichum
atramentarium (Berk. & Br.) Taubenh.; C. dematium (Pers. ex Fr.) Grove; C.
orbiculare (Berk. & Mont.) Arx; C. acutatum sp. nov. With the introduction
of a variety the original species G. cingulata should strictly be designated G.
cingulata var. cingulata. However, in this paper reference to this species as
originally understood has been made simply by the omission of a varietal name
when confusion is unlikely to occur.
txt: The following species are discussed here: Glomerella cingulata (Stonem.) Spauld. & Schrenk, stat. conid. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides Penz.; G. cingulata var. minor Wr., stat. conid. C. gloeosporioides var. minor var. nov.; C. musae (Berk. & Curt.) Arx (Gloeosporium musarum Cke. & Mass.); Colletotrichum atramentarium (Berk. & Br.) Taubenh.; C. dematium (Pers. ex Fr.) Grove; C. orbiculare (Berk. & Mont.) Arx; C. acutatum sp. nov. With the introduction of a variety, the original species G. cingulata should strictly be designated G. cingulata var. cingulata. However, in this paper, reference to this species as originally understood is made simply by omitting the varietal name when confusion is unlikely to occur.

q2: How does the introduction of a variety affect the classification of G. cingulata?

pdf:
The characters used in describing these organisms are spore size, cultural
type, temperature relationship and host range. Reference to some physiological
reactions of a few species is given by Simmonds (1963) but no general
comparisons have been made with respect to physiology.
txt: The characters used to describe these organisms include spore size, cultural type, temperature relationship, and host range. Some physiological reactions of a few species are mentioned, but no general comparisons have been made regarding physiology.

pdf:
Imperfect stage.-For many species of Colletotrichum, reliance has to be
placed on conidial measurements, the perfect stage occurring rarely or not at
all. With spores as small and characterless as those of Colletotrichum, small differences,
although valid, are often difficult to demonstrate, and because of individual
variability, overlapping between species inevitably occurs.
txt: Imperfect Stage: For many species of Colletotrichum, reliance must be placed on conidial measurements, as the perfect stage occurs rarely or not at all. With spores as small and characterless as those of Colletotrichum, even small differences, while valid, can be difficult to demonstrate. Additionally, due to individual variability, overlapping between species inevitably occurs.
q1: Why is reliance on conidial measurements necessary for many species of Colletotrichum?
q2: What challenges are posed by the small size and characterless nature of Colletotrichum spores?
q3: How does individual variability affect the identification of different Colletotrichum species?
q4: Do the perfect stages of Colletotrichum occur frequently?
q5: Are the spores of Colletotrichum characterized by significant visual differences?
q6: Is overlapping between species a common issue due to individual variability?

pdf:
As pointed out by Wollenweber and Hochapfel ( 1949), extreme values
are of little use when comparing spore measurements of species of Colletotrichum
unless accompanied by the mean, as the coverage is usually too broad for
delimiting species. It is for this reason that many of the older descriptions are
so difficult to interpret. In Table 1 extremes have been replaced by the range
of mean values for different collections or isolations. These individual means
are based on the measurement of 15 spores in each case.
txt: Extreme values are of little use when comparing spore measurements of Colletotrichum species unless accompanied by the mean, as the coverage is usually too broad for delimiting species. This difficulty in interpretation often arises from older descriptions. In Table 1, extremes have been replaced by the range of mean values for different collections or isolations, with each individual mean based on the measurement of 15 spores.
q1: Why are extreme values not considered useful for comparing spore measurements of Colletotrichum species?
q2: How does the approach of using mean values improve the interpretation of spore measurements?
q3: What method was used to calculate the individual means for the spore measurements?
q4: Are extreme values typically too broad to effectively delimit species of Colletotrichum?
q5: Did Wollenweber and Hochapfel publish their findings in 1949?
q6: Were 15 spores measured for each case to determine the individual means?

pdf:
The general shape of the spore is often sufficiently distinctive for specific
recognition when familarity has been achieved, and the chief distinguishing features
have accordingly been included in Table 1 and illustrated in Figure 1. Confusion
can occur between the narrower strains of C. gloeosporioides and the broader strains
of C. gloeosporioides var. minor, and consideration of cultural characters is sometimes
necessary for definite placing. The restrictive host range of C. musae
prevents confusion with the above two.
txt: The general shape of the spore is often distinctive enough for specific recognition once familiarity is achieved, and the key distinguishing features are included in the accompanying table and illustrated in the figure. Confusion can arise between the narrower strains of C. gloeosporioides and the broader strains of C. gloeosporioides var. minor; therefore, consideration of cultural characters is sometimes necessary for accurate classification. The restrictive host range of C. musae helps prevent confusion with the other two.

q2: How do cultural characters aid in distinguishing between certain strains?
q3: Why is C. musae less likely to be confused with other strains?
q4: Is the shape of the spore a key factor in its identification?
q5: Can confusion occur between different strains of C. gloeosporioides?
q6: Does C. musae have a broad host range?

pdf:
The spore measurements of the two varieties of C. gloeosporioides were investigated
in some detail, since it was early considered from host range and cultural
characters that these two forms must be distinct. Mean length and breadth of
a number of collections and cultures were examined by the Chief Biometrician
(Mr. P. B. McGovern), with the results summarized in Table 2. When assigning
a particular spore collection to one or other of the two groups, cultural characters
were taken as the final criterion. Unless the cultural grouping was definite, the
particular collection was not included in the listings. Where spores were taken
direct from fruit, the group was ascertained by culturing from the same spot.
txt: The spore measurements of the two varieties of C. gloeosporioides were investigated in detail, as it was initially considered that these forms must be distinct based on host range and cultural characters. Mean length and breadth of various collections and cultures were examined by the Chief Biometrician, Mr. P. B. McGovern, with the results summarized in a table. Cultural characters were used as the final criterion when assigning a spore collection to one of the two groups. Collections without definite cultural groupings were excluded from the listings. When spores were taken directly from fruit, the group was determined by culturing from the same spot.
q1: What criteria were used to distinguish between the two varieties of C. gloeosporioides?
q2: How did the researchers ensure the accuracy of their spore measurements?
q3: What role did cultural characters play in the classification of spore collections?
q4: Were the spore measurements of C. gloeosporioides examined in detail?
q5: Did the researchers rely solely on spore size to classify the two varieties?
q6: Were cultural characters considered the final criterion for assigning spore collections to a particular group?
