pdf:
Perfect stage.-Glomerella cingulata, the perithecial stage of C. gloeosporioides,
frequently occurs both on the host plant and in culture. On the papaw,
lesions which will give rise to perithecial or conidial isolates respectively are
often recognizable macroscopically. Perithecia of G. cingulata var. minor have been
seen on rare occasions and then only in culture. The appearance of the ascospore
of the two forms is very similar except for size. Typically, both ascospores are
faintly brown with poorly staining contents. So far as possible, measurement
was restricted to this type. Ascospore measurements are given in Table 3 and
an analytical comparison in Table 4.
txt: Glomerella cingulata, the perithecial stage of C. gloeosporioides, frequently occurs both on the host plant and in culture. On papaw, lesions that give rise to perithecial or conidial isolates are often recognizable macroscopically. Perithecia of G. cingulata var. minor have been observed on rare occasions, and then only in culture. The appearance of the ascospores in both forms is very similar, except for size. Typically, both ascospores are faintly brown with poorly staining contents. Measurements were primarily focused on this type. Ascospore measurements are provided in the accompanying tables.
q1: What conditions lead to the formation of perithecial versus conidial isolates on the host plant?
q2: How do the ascospores of G. cingulata var. minor differ in size compared to the other form?
q3: Why are measurements of ascospores important in the study of G. cingulata?
q4: Are lesions on the papaw recognizable macroscopically?
q5: Have perithecia of G. cingulata var. minor been observed in nature?
q6: Is there a significant difference in appearance between the ascospores of the two forms?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
Practically all cultural work has been carried out with potato dextrose agar
medium in petri dish culture. Various other media have been tried from time to
time but these seemed to do little to reduce existing variation. Tube cultures
are often unsatisfactory for observing essential differences. Cultural characters
change considerably with time and subculturing and it is desirable to work with
fresh isolates.
txt: Practically all cultural work has been conducted using potato dextrose agar medium in petri dish cultures. While various other media have been tried, they have done little to reduce existing variation. Tube cultures are often unsatisfactory for observing essential differences. Cultural characteristics change significantly over time and with subculturing, so it is preferable to work with fresh isolates.
q1: Why is potato dextrose agar considered the preferred medium for cultural work?
q2: What challenges are associated with using tube cultures for observing differences?
q3: How does subculturing affect the observation of cultural characters?
q4: Is potato dextrose agar the most commonly used medium for cultural work?
q5: Do other media reduce variation in cultural work effectively?
q6: Is it important to work with fresh isolates in cultural studies?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
In the course of this work, hundreds of isolates have been examined. The
majority conform to the characters of specific groups with sufficient constancy
to enable them to be classified with reasonable accuracy. However, there is
always the odd isolate difficult to place, and the absence of spore formation in
many cases eliminates this means of checking identity. These unusual forms are
not included in the descriptions which follow. Examination of isolates has been
taking place at varying intervals over the past 15 years and it does appear that
in the case of C. gloeosporioides and its variety minor certain periods have been
characterized by the prevalence of a particular cultural type. It would be unwise
therefore to state any one of these to be the normal form. Both these organisms
are characteristically variable in cultural appearance and in this respect differ
from the other fruit-rotting species dealt with here.
txt: In the course of this work, hundreds of isolates have been examined. The majority conform to the characteristics of specific groups with sufficient consistency to enable accurate classification. However, there are always a few isolates that are difficult to place, and the absence of spore formation in many cases complicates the verification of identity. These unusual forms are not included in the following descriptions. Examination of isolates has been conducted at varying intervals over the past 15 years, and it appears that, in the case of C. gloeosporioides and its variety minor, certain periods have been marked by the prevalence of a particular cultural type. Therefore, it would be unwise to designate any one of these as the normal form. Both organisms are characteristically variable in cultural appearance, distinguishing them from the other fruit-rotting species discussed here.
q1: What criteria were used to classify the isolates examined in the study?
q2: Why are certain unusual forms of isolates excluded from the descriptions?
q3: How has the prevalence of cultural types for C. gloeosporioides and its variety minor changed over the years?
q4: Have hundreds of isolates been examined in this work?
q5: Is spore formation a reliable method for checking the identity of all isolates?
q6: Do C. gloeosporioides and its variety minor exhibit variability in cultural appearance?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
Glomerella cingulata, stat. conid. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
G. cingulata var. cingulata is a fast-growing species. Perithecial, conidial and
sterile cultures are obtained from field isolations.
Perithecial form.-Aerial mycelium is fine, white to light grey, of moderate
elevation and somewhat sparse and open. The substrate is light cream with or
without a grey or olive diffusion. A pinkish tinge may be present. Typically
there are produced black glomerate perithecial bodies which stand up con
spicuously from the surface and are not embedded in the mycelium as is the case
with var. minor. Smaller, scattered, sooty perithecial elements may be present
also. Mature ascospores are commonly available from these cultures (Figure 2).
txt:
Glomerella cingulata, stat. conid. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. G. cingulata var. cingulata is a fast-growing species. Perithecial, conidial, and sterile cultures are obtained from field isolations.
 Perithecial form: The aerial mycelium is fine, white to light grey, of moderate elevation, and somewhat sparse and open. The substrate is light cream, with or without a grey or olive diffusion, and may exhibit a pinkish tinge. Typically, black glomerate perithecial bodies are produced, standing out conspicuously from the surface and not embedded in the mycelium, as seen in var. minor. Smaller, scattered, sooty perithecial elements may also be present. Mature ascospores are commonly available from these cultures.
q1: What are the distinguishing features of G. cingulata var. cingulata compared to var. minor?
q2: How does the growth rate of G. cingulata var. cingulata impact its cultivation and isolation?
q3: What types of cultures can be derived from field isolations of G. cingulata?
q4: Does G. cingulata var. cingulata produce black glomerate perithecial bodies?
q5: Are mature ascospores commonly available from cultures of G. cingulata?
q6: Is the aerial mycelium of G. cingulata typically dense and dark in color?

pdf:
Conidial and sterile forms .-Aerial mycelium is fine, of low elevation and
usually fairly dense. From above, the general colour is white to light grey, or
it may appear darker corresponding to a dark substratum beneath. In the latter
case the margin is usually white or pinkish. From below, the substrate may be
light coloured or dark in the centre, with a light coloured or pinkish margin
(Figure 3).
txt: Conidial and Sterile Forms: Aerial mycelium is fine, low in elevation, and usually fairly dense. From above, it appears white to light grey, although it may look darker if there is a dark substrate beneath. In such cases, the margin is typically white or pinkish. From below, the substrate may be light-colored or dark in the center, with a light-colored or pinkish margin.

q6: Does the color of the substrate affect how the aerial mycelium appears from above?

pdf:
One characteristic type commonly isolated from passion-fruit has low, fairly
compact, white, aerial mycelium on which are scattered conspicuous black bodies.
These may have conidia associated with them and so function as sporodochia.
Apart from this particular type, conidial production in culture is usually scanty or
nil.
txt: One characteristic type commonly isolated from passion fruit has low, fairly compact, white aerial mycelium, on which conspicuous black bodies are scattered. These may have conidia associated with them and function as sporodochia. Apart from this specific type, conidial production in culture is usually scant or nonexistent.
q1: What role do the conspicuous black bodies play in the life cycle of the passion-fruit mycelium?
q2: How does the conidial production in culture compare to that of the specific type isolated from passion-fruit?
q3: What characteristics distinguish the low, compact mycelium from other types of mycelium?
q4: Is the mycelium described in the passage white and aerial?
q5: Are the black bodies mentioned in the passage associated with conidia?
q6: Does conidial production in culture vary significantly from the isolated type?

pdf:
Glomerella cingulata var. minor stat. conid. C. gloeosporioides var. minor
This is a fast-growing species with mycelium distinctly coarser in macroscopic
appearance than G. cingulata var. cingulata. Field isolations are almost
entirely restricted to conidial or sterile types. In these the aerial mycelium is
cottony or woolly and typically abundant and well elevated from the surface of the
medium, in contrast to that of the variety described above. The colour is white
or various shades of grey. From below, the colour of the substrate is white to
cream or various densities of greyish olive or olive. Forms with a less elevated
and less abundant aerial mycelium occur from time to time and these can be difficult
to distinguish from the more elevated cultural types of C. gloeosporioides
unless accompanied by conidia (Figures 2 and 3) .
The production of conidia is characteristically more common and abundant
than in C. gloeosporioides. This may take the form of conidia scattered throughout
the mycelium giving a general pinkish tinge to the culture, or they may appear
as pink masses formed in acervuli or associated with black sporodochia-like bodies.
On the few occasions when perithecia of G. cingulata var. minor appeared in
culture the latter was not of a special type, as in the case of G. cingulata, but was
similar to a grey cottony conidial or sterile form commonly obtained from field
isolations. Large glomerate bodies if present are less numerous and less conspicuous,
as they are more or less hidden in the mycelium. Small sooty perithecial
elements scattered over the mycelium may accompany the glomerate bodies or
occur alone (Figure 2) .
txt: Glomerella cingulata var. minor, also known as C. gloeosporioides var. minor, is a fast-growing species with mycelium that appears coarser than that of G. cingulata var. cingulata. Field isolations are mainly of conidial or sterile types, characterized by cottony or woolly aerial mycelium that is abundant and well elevated above the medium's surface, in contrast to the aforementioned variety. The color ranges from white to various shades of grey, while the substrate appears white to cream or different densities of greyish olive. Occasionally, forms with less elevated aerial mycelium arise, which can be hard to distinguish from the more elevated cultural types of C. gloeosporioides unless conidia are present. The production of conidia is notably more common and abundant than in C. gloeosporioides, appearing as scattered conidia giving a pinkish hue to the culture, or as pink masses in acervuli or associated with black sporodochia-like bodies. When perithecia of G. cingulata var. minor appear in culture, they resemble the grey cottony conidial or sterile forms commonly found in field isolations, with large glomerate bodies being less numerous and often hidden in the mycelium. Small sooty perithecial elements may accompany the glomerate bodies or occur alone.
q1: How does the mycelium of Glomerella cingulata var. minor differ from that of Glomerella cingulata var. cingulata in terms of appearance?
q2: What is the typical color of the aerial mycelium and substrate for Glomerella cingulata var. minor?
q3: In what conditions is the production of conidia more abundant in Glomerella cingulata var. minor compared to C. gloeosporioides?
q4: Is the aerial mycelium of Glomerella cingulata var. minor typically described as cottony or woolly?
q5: Are the conidia of Glomerella cingulata var. minor more abundant than those of C. gloeosporioides?
q6: Do small sooty perithecial elements occur alone in the mycelium of Glomerella cingulata var. minor?

pdf:
Colletotrichum musae ( Gloeosporiwn musarum)
The cultural characters of this organism were dealt with at some length by
Simmonds and Mitchell (1940). Although three cultural types are recognized,
the normal form is the one commonly obtained in field isolations. This is
characteristic and uniform for the species. Aerial mycelium is white to light
grey, loose and open and not greatly elevated. Spores are produced early and in
abundance directly on the mycelium or on acervuli developed over the surface
of the medium. This gives the colony a characteristic pink appearance.
txt:
Colletotrichum musae (Gloeosporium musarum)
The cultural characteristics of this organism were examined in detail. Although three cultural types are recognized, the normal form is the one commonly obtained in field isolations. This form is characteristic and uniform for the species. The aerial mycelium is white to light grey, loose, and open, without significant elevation. Spores are produced early and in abundance, either directly on the mycelium or on acervuli developed over the surface of the medium, giving the colony a distinctive pink appearance.
q1: What factors might influence the production of different cultural types of Colletotrichum musae?
q2: How does the appearance of the colony change as it matures, based on the characteristics described?
q3: In what environments might Colletotrichum musae be commonly isolated in the field?
q4: Is the normal form of Colletotrichum musae commonly obtained in field isolations?
q5: Do the spores of Colletotrichum musae appear early in the growth process?
q6: Is the aerial mycelium of Colletotrichum musae typically elevated?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
Colletotrichwn acutatum
C. acutatwn is a relatively slow-growing species. Aerial mycelium is moderately
dense and fairly well elevated. The surface may be finely tufted. The
advancing margin is usually abrupt. Colour is at first white but after a few days
there appears from the centre a greyish aggregated overlay, so the final colour is
grey or greyish brown. This overlay sometimes has a crystalline appearance. From
below the substrate is white or cream with sometimes a creamy pink diffusion.
Darker p~tches if present are usually irregular. More recently a series of isolates
was obtained from papaw in which the culture as a whole was a bright pink. Other
.characters apart from colour proved to be normal (Figure 3) .
The production of conidia in this species is characteristically abundant. This
appears to be distributed throughout the mycelium, although massed conidiophores
in the nature of acervuli may occur. The superficial spore masses seen in C.
gloeosporioides var. minor are met with less often. Sometimes salmon-coloured
spore masses can be seen through the media from below although not obvious from
above.
The colour of spores in mass of C. gloeosporioides var. minor and C. acutatum
differs slightly, the former tending to pink and the latter to salmon. One series
of inoculations on papaw examined with reference to Ridgway's "Colour Standards
and Nomenclature" referred the spores of C. gloeosporioides var. minor to bitter
sweet pink and those of C. acutatum to capucine orange.
txt:
Colletotrichum acutatum
 C. acutatum is a relatively slow-growing species. The aerial mycelium is moderately dense and fairly well elevated, with a finely tufted surface. The advancing margin is usually abrupt. Initially, the color is white, but after a few days, a greyish aggregated overlay develops from the center, resulting in a final color of grey or greyish brown. This overlay can sometimes have a crystalline appearance. From below, the substrate is white or cream, with occasional creamy pink diffusion. If darker patches are present, they are usually irregular. Recently, a series of isolates obtained from papaw exhibited a bright pink culture. Other characteristics, apart from color, were normal.
 The production of conidia in this species is characteristically abundant, distributed throughout the mycelium, although massed conidiophores resembling acervuli may occur. Superficial spore masses, seen in C. gloeosporioides var. minor, are encountered less frequently. Sometimes, salmon-colored spore masses can be observed through the medium from below, although they are not obvious from above.
 The color of the spores in mass differs slightly between C. gloeosporioides var. minor and C. acutatum, with the former tending toward pink and the latter toward salmon. A series of inoculations on papaw examined using Ridgway's "Colour Standards and Nomenclature" classified the spores of C. gloeosporioides var. minor as bitter sweet pink and those of C. acutatum as capucine orange.
q1: How does the growth rate of C. acutatum compare to that of other species?
q2: What visual characteristics can be used to differentiate between C. acutatum and C. gloeosporioides var. minor?
q3: What role do conidia play in the reproduction of C. acutatum?
q4: Does C. acutatum produce conidia abundantly?
q5: Is the initial color of C. acutatum's aerial mycelium white?
q6: Are the spore masses of C. acutatum more frequently seen than those of C. gloeosporioides var. minor?

pdf:
Colletotrichum orbiculare
Growth is characteristically slow (Table 5) . When first isolated aerial
mycelium is usually fine, scanty and of low elevation. Sometimes the surface is
almost powdery. Typically the colour is pinkish, usually becoming grey to dark
grey in the centre with a pinkish margin which may have a submerged edge. From
below, the substratum is dark in the centre with a fairly broad cream or pinkish
margin. With subculturing, the pink colour tends to become lost and the aerial
mycelium may increase to a grey, fairly compact growth of moderate elevation,
when the culture is no longer very distinct from types developed by other species.
Conidia are often produced by fresh isolations and these may appear as small
pink spore masses scattered over the surface.
txt: Colletotrichum orbiculare grows characteristically slow. When first isolated, the aerial mycelium is usually fine, scanty, and of low elevation, sometimes appearing almost powdery. Typically, the color is pinkish, often becoming grey to dark grey in the center with a pinkish margin that may have a submerged edge. From below, the substratum appears dark in the center with a fairly broad cream or pinkish margin. With subculturing, the pink color tends to fade, and the aerial mycelium may develop into a grey, fairly compact growth of moderate elevation, making the culture less distinct from types developed by other species. Conidia are often produced by fresh isolations and may appear as small pink spore masses scattered over the surface.
q1: What factors contribute to the slow growth of Colletotrichum orbiculare?
q2: How does the appearance of the aerial mycelium change with subculturing?
q3: What color variations are observed in the conidia produced by fresh isolations?
q4: Does Colletotrichum orbiculare typically have a pinkish margin?
q5: Is the growth of the aerial mycelium described as compact in later cultures?
q6: Are conidia produced by fresh isolations usually pink in color?

pdf:
Colletotrichum atramentarium
In fresh isolates from the tomato, aerial mycelium is fine, scanty and remains
close to the surface. The general colour is white to pale pink. From the centre
develops a well-defined black speckling due to the formation of the sclerotial bodies
characteristic of this species. From below, the substrate is speckled grey in the
centre with a pinkish margin. With subculturing, the pinkish colour tends to disappear
and sectors of a denser, more elevated, grey mycelium appear. If the
sclerotium-forming habit is completely lost there is little in the appearance of the
culture to distinguish it from some other species.
txt:
Colletotrichum atramentarium
 In fresh isolates from tomato, the aerial mycelium is fine, scanty, and remains close to the surface. The general color is white to pale pink. A well-defined black speckling develops from the center due to the formation of sclerotial bodies characteristic of this species. The substrate appears speckled grey in the center with a pinkish margin. With subculturing, the pinkish color tends to disappear, and sectors of denser, more elevated grey mycelium appear. If the sclerotium-forming habit is completely lost, the culture's appearance becomes similar to that of some other species.
q1: What environmental conditions favor the growth of Colletotrichum atramentarium in tomatoes?
q2: How does the appearance of Colletotrichum atramentarium change with subculturing?
q3: What are the key visual characteristics that differentiate Colletotrichum atramentarium from other species?
q4: Does Colletotrichum atramentarium typically display a pinkish margin when observed on a substrate?
q5: Is the formation of sclerotial bodies a characteristic feature of Colletotrichum atramentarium?
q6: Can Colletotrichum atramentarium lose its distinctive sclerotium-forming habit through subculturing?

pdf:
Colletotrichum dematium
Aerial mycelium is fine, white or grey and somewhat scanty, or in some
isolates more abundant and moderately elevated. Colour is usually dark in
the centre with a broad white margin. In a fruiting culture the setae may give
the surface a finely tufted appearance. From below,. the substratum is dark
grey or speckled grey with a white margin. Scattered dusky acervuli ate present
in fruiting cultures. Spore masses are usually straw-coloured but ,~ometimes
pale pink.
txt:
Colletotrichum dematium
 Aerial mycelium is fine, white or grey, and somewhat scanty; in some isolates, it is more abundant and moderately elevated. The color is usually dark in the center with a broad white margin. In a fruiting culture, the setae may give the surface a finely tufted appearance. From below, the substratum is dark grey or speckled grey with a white margin. Scattered dusky acervuli are present in fruiting cultures. Spore masses are usually straw-colored but sometimes pale pink.

pdf:
Cultural Types obtained from Single Ascospores
Edgerton (1914) described plus and minus strains of a Glomere/la obtained
from several different hosts. Lucas, Chilton, and Edgerton (1944) ,studied the
progeny of single ascospore isolations from an American strain of Q. cingulata,
from lpomoea, which they separated into seven or more different types. Struble
and Keitt (1950) used similar methods to investigate an isolate of G. cingulata
from apple and showed that the cultural types obtained differed somewhat from
those obtained from lpomoea.
Ascospore isolations have been made from the Queensland G. cingulata
and G. cingulata var. minor. Cultural types obtained from the former could be
correlated fairly well with those described from I pomoea, while those obtained
from the latter resembled more closely Struble and Keitt's types from apple. A
description of the Queensland types is given below. The terminology used is,
as far as correlation is possible, that of the authors cited above.
txt: Cultural types obtained from single ascospores were first described by Edgerton in 1914, who identified plus and minus strains of Glomerella from various hosts. In 1944, Lucas, Chilton, and Edgerton studied the progeny of single ascospore isolations from an American strain of Q. cingulata from Ipomoea, classifying them into seven or more different types. Struble and Keitt (1950) employed similar methods to examine an isolate of G. cingulata from apple, revealing that the cultural types differed somewhat from those derived from Ipomoea. Ascospore isolations have also been conducted on Queensland G. cingulata and G. cingulata var. minor. The cultural types from the former correlated fairly well with those from Ipomoea, while those from the latter closely resembled Struble and Keitt's types from apple. A description of the Queensland types follows, using terminology consistent with the referenced authors where possible.
q1: What methods did Struble and Keitt use to investigate the cultural types of G. cingulata from apple?
q2: How do the cultural types obtained from Queensland G. cingulata compare to those described from other hosts?
q3: What significance do the findings of Edgerton and others have for understanding the diversity of G. cingulata?
q4: Did Edgerton describe plus and minus strains of Glomere/la?
q5: Were seven or more different types identified from the progeny of single ascospore isolations of Q. cingulata?
q6: Did the cultural types obtained from Queensland G. cingulata correlate well with those from Ipomoea?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
Glomerella cingulata
(a) Plus type .-This is the same as has been described earlier for the
perithecial form of G. cingulata obtained from field isolations. It forms a definite
perithecial line with minus types (Figure 2).
(b) Minus type.-Slight to scanty amounts of open, wispy, grey or black
aerial mycelium occur over a dark background. From below, the substrate is
dark olive to black, typically mottled but not always so. Numbers of small,
globular, immature or occasionally mature perithecial elements are embedded in
the surface. Conidia are usually scarce but occasionally more plentiful. Minus
types form a definite perithecial line with plus types. When used in artificial
inoculation experiments they are characteristically non-pathogenic (Figures 2
and 3).
(c) Sterile.-Aerial mycelium is close, white and appressed to the surface,
forming a dense white mat without elevated hyphae. From below, the substrate
is white, cream or pinkish with sometimes grey or olive developing out from
the centre and imparting a darker appearance to the surface view. The name
sterile is chosen from the terms conidial and sterile used by Lucas, Chilton, and
Edgerton ( 1944), as conidia are usually rare or absent and no perithecial line
is formed with plus or minus types. It is not unusual for cultures of the sterile
type to be obtained in field isolations (Figure 3).
(d) Yellow.-Aerial mycelium is scanty and white on a background of light
yellow. The rate of growth is similar to that of other forms but pathogenicity is
reduced and spore size abnormal. This type is not obtained in field isolations.
txt:
Glomerella cingulata
 (a) Plus type. This form has been described previously for the perithecial form of G. cingulata obtained from field isolations. It forms a distinct perithecial line with minus types.
 (b) Minus type. This type exhibits slight to scanty amounts of open, wispy, grey or black aerial mycelium over a dark background. The substrate appears dark olive to black, typically mottled but not always. Small, globular, immature or occasionally mature perithecial elements are embedded in the surface. Conidia are usually scarce but may be more plentiful at times. Minus types form a definite perithecial line with plus types. In artificial inoculation experiments, they are characteristically non-pathogenic.
 (c) Sterile. Aerial mycelium is dense, white, and appressed to the surface, forming a thick white mat without elevated hyphae. The substrate appears white, cream, or pinkish, sometimes developing grey or olive from the center, giving a darker appearance to the surface. The term "sterile" is chosen because conidia are usually rare or absent, and no perithecial line is formed with plus or minus types. It is not uncommon for sterile cultures to be obtained from field isolations.
 (d) Yellow. This type features scanty white aerial mycelium on a light yellow background. The growth rate is similar to that of other forms, but pathogenicity is reduced and spore size is abnormal. This type is not obtained in field isolations.
q1: What distinguishes the plus type of Glomerella cingulata from the minus type in terms of appearance and characteristics?
q2: How do the sterile and yellow types of Glomerella cingulata differ in terms of growth and pathogenicity?
q3: In what contexts are the various types of Glomerella cingulata typically observed or isolated?
q4: Does the plus type of Glomerella cingulata form a definite perithecial line?
q5: Is the sterile type of Glomerella cingulata usually obtained from field isolations?
q6: Are conidia commonly found in the minus type of Glomerella cingulata?

pdf:
Glometella cingulata var. minor
I
447
(a) ~lus type.-Aerial mycelium is relatively coarse, cottony, grey, of
moderate elevation and density and may be slightly aggregated. From below, the
substrate is\grey in various degrees of density. The general appearance is similar
to that of \a common non-perithecial form obtained from field isolates. The
distinguishirtg feature is the presence of a few large glomerate perithecial bodies,
more or les~ embedded in the mycelium, and numerous small sooty perithecial
elements sc~ttered in patches over the surface. A dendritic perithecial line is
formed witli minus colonies. Colonies of the plus type have been obtained
only rarely :llrom field isolations (Figure 2).
(b) Minus type.-In general, this is similar to the minus type of var.
cingulata but it shows more variability. Aerial mycelium is grey or black and
is poorly developed over a dark substrate. Immature perithecial elements are
normally present but vary in numbers and are sometimes absent. In contrast
to the minus type of var. cingulata, conidia are abundant with the pinkish spore
masses showing over the surface as the culture ages. This type forms a perithecial
line with plus colonies but this has a dendritic margin and lacks the well-defined
straight outline of the one formed between var. cingulata plus and minus types.
The minus type has not been obtained from field isolations (Figure 2).
( c) Conidial and sterile .-There may also be obtained from ascospores
various types similar to those described from field isolations, including a nonperithecial
form similar to the plus type. In some of these, production of conidia
is plentiful whereas in others, similar in other respects, conidia are few or absent.
Whether these represent the conidial or sterile types of American authors is
uncertain (Figures 2 and 3).
(d) Yellow.-A yellow isolate similar to the one produced by G. cingulata
is occasionally obtained. This is not found in field isolates.
txt:
Glometella cingulata var. minor
 (a) Plus type: Aerial mycelium is relatively coarse, cottony, and grey, with moderate elevation and density, and may appear slightly aggregated. The substrate appears grey in varying densities. The overall appearance resembles a common non-perithecial form from field isolates. The distinguishing feature is the presence of a few large glomerate perithecial bodies embedded in the mycelium and numerous small sooty perithecial elements scattered in patches over the surface. A dendritic perithecial line forms with minus colonies, while colonies of the plus type are rarely obtained from field isolations.
 (b) Minus type: This type is generally similar to the minus type of var. cingulata but shows more variability. Aerial mycelium is grey or black and poorly developed over a dark substrate. Immature perithecial elements are usually present but can vary in number and may be absent. Unlike the minus type of var. cingulata, conidia are abundant, with pinkish spore masses visible on the surface as the culture ages. This type forms a perithecial line with plus colonies, but it has a dendritic margin and lacks the well-defined outline of the line formed between var. cingulata plus and minus types. The minus type has not been obtained from field isolations.
 (c) Conidial and sterile: Various types may also be obtained from ascospores, similar to those described from field isolations, including a non-perithecial form resembling the plus type. In some, conidia are plentiful, while in others, they are few or absent. It remains uncertain whether these represent the conidial or sterile types described by American authors.
 (d) Yellow: Occasionally, a yellow isolate similar to one produced by G. cingulata is obtained, though it is not found in field isolates.
q1: What are the key distinguishing features between the plus and minus types of Glometella cingulata var. minor?
q2: How does the aerial mycelium appearance vary between the different types mentioned?
q3: What role do the perithecial elements play in identifying the various types of Glometella cingulata?
q4: Is the aerial mycelium of the plus type described as grey?
q5: Are conidia abundant in the minus type of Glometella cingulata var. minor?
q6: Can a yellow isolate of Glometella cingulata be found in field isolations?

pdf:
( c) Appressoria
Some authors (Sutton 1962) have suggested using the characters of the
appressorium as one criterion for separating species of Colletotrichum. The size
and shape of the appressoria formed by the species discussed here were briefly
investigated but the differences did not appear to be sufficient to warrant a more
detailed examination. Mean length lay mostly between 8 and 9 pv and m.ean breadth
between 6 · 0 and 6 · 5μ. The appressoria of C. atranientarium were somewhat
larger, with a mean length of 11·30 , while those of C. musae were shorter, with
a mean of 7 · 7 0 . The majority examined were more or less obovate but. in all
species a varying number of individuals were definitely lobed or angular. Those
of C. acutatum were on the whole more regular and those of C. musae less so.
txt:
Appressoria
 Some authors have suggested using the characteristics of the appressorium as a criterion for separating species of Colletotrichum. The size and shape of the appressoria formed by the species discussed here were briefly investigated; however, the differences did not appear to warrant a more detailed examination. The mean length ranged mostly between 8 and 9 弮m, while the mean breadth was between 6.0 and 6.5 弮m. The appressoria of C. atranientarium were somewhat larger, with a mean length of 11.30 弮m, while those of C. musae were shorter, averaging 7.70 弮m. The majority examined were more or less obovate, but in all species, a varying number of individuals were definitely lobed or angular. The appressoria of C. acutatum were generally more regular, whereas those of C. musae were less so.
q1: What criteria do some authors propose for distinguishing species of Colletotrichum?
q2: How do the sizes of appressoria compare between different species of Colletotrichum mentioned?
q3: What general shape do the appressoria of the species discussed tend to take?
q4: Did the authors find significant differences in the appressoria that warranted a detailed examination?
q5: Are the appressoria of C. atranientarium generally larger than those of C. musae?
q6: Do most of the examined appressoria appear to be lobed or angular?

pdf:
( d) Temperature Reactions
Reaction to temperature is a useful criterion for separating some species of
Colletotrichum. This character was investigated for the species Glomerella cingulata
var. cingulata, Colletotrichum gloeosporioides var. minor, C. acutatum, C.
orbiculare and C. dematium. Three or four typical isolates were used in leach case.
The procedure consisted in inoculating potato dextrose agar slopes ih tubes or
medicine bottles with uniform circles cut from a young P.D.A. culturEJ1 of the test
fungus. These were held at room temperature overnight until growth was just
commencing to show and then incubated in the compartments of a multiple-temperature
incubator over the range 15° to 36°C. The temperature interval between
compartments was approximately 1 · 5 °. After 4 days the growth was recorded.
as diameter of colony less diameter of original inoculum (Figure J 4).
txt:
Temperature Reactions
 Reaction to temperature is a useful criterion for separating some species of Colletotrichum. This characteristic was investigated for the species Glomerella cingulata var. cingulata, Colletotrichum gloeosporioides var. minor, C. acutatum, C. orbiculare, and C. dematium. Three or four typical isolates were used in each case. The procedure involved inoculating potato dextrose agar slopes in tubes or medicine bottles with uniform circles cut from a young PDA culture of the test fungus. These were held at room temperature overnight until growth began to show, then incubated in the compartments of a multiple-temperature incubator over the range of 15簞 to 36簞C, with a temperature interval of approximately 1.5簞. After 4 days, the growth was recorded as the diameter of the colony minus the diameter of the original inoculum.
q1: What criteria are used to separate species of Colletotrichum based on temperature reactions?
q2: How does the growth of different Colletotrichum species vary with temperature?
q3: What is the significance of using multiple-temperature compartments for this study?
q4: Was potato dextrose agar used for the growth of the test fungus?
q5: Did the study involve multiple isolates for each species?
q6: Was the temperature range for incubation set between 15簞 and 36簞C?

·organism. However, the spore dimensions usually attributed to G. fructigenum
set it apart from C. acutatwn and the former is perhaps more. correctly considered
a synonym or form of C. gloeosporioides. The four isolates of C. acutatum
·employed here were from papaw. Sturgess ( 1957), using isolates from strawberry,
obtained a somewhat higher optimum for this species. Two recent isolates from
.strawberry leaves showed an optimum of 26 · 8 °C.
txt: Temperature reactions of the isolates grouped by Edgerton (1915) as G. fructigenum closely resemble those of the Queensland C. acutatum. In fact, there is nothing in Edgerton's description to indicate they are not the same organism. However, the spore dimensions usually attributed to G. fructigenum set it apart from C. acutatum, and the former is perhaps more accurately considered a synonym or form of C. gloeosporioides. The four isolates of C. acutatum used here were from papaw. Sturgess (1957), using isolates from strawberry, obtained a somewhat higher optimum for this species. Two recent isolates from strawberry leaves showed an optimum of 26.8 簞C.

pdf:
Over the years, species of Colletotrichum have been isolated on many
·occasions from fruit and vegetative parts of economic plants in Queensland. The
pathogenicity of the various species to their usual hosts is well established. In
cases where a species has been recovered from a particular host only occasionally
and no pathogenicity tests have been carried out, the nature of the lesion and the
circumstances of the isolation have been taken as evidence for or against its
presence in a pathogenic capacity.
txt: Over the years, species of Colletotrichum have been isolated multiple times from the fruit and vegetative parts of economic plants in Queensland. The pathogenicity of various species to their usual hosts is well established. In cases where a species has been recovered from a particular host only occasionally, and no pathogenicity tests have been conducted, the nature of the lesion and the circumstances of the isolation have been considered as evidence for or against its presence in a pathogenic capacity.

pdf:
In the course of this work it became evident that one species of plant may be
host for more than one species of Colletotrichum, so with this genus the identity
of the host is not necessarily sound evidence for the identity of the pathogen. However,
some fruit which are particularly prone to anthracnose are subject to attack
by only one organism. Two such are mango and banana. In contrast, papaw
and capsicum are remarkably hospitable hosts.
txt: In the course of this work, it became evident that one species of plant may host more than one species of Colletotrichum, meaning the identity of the host is not necessarily reliable evidence for the identity of the pathogen. However, some fruits particularly prone to anthracnose are attacked by only one organism, such as mango and banana. In contrast, papaw and capsicum serve as remarkably hospitable hosts.

A host list of the species of Colletotrichum affecting fruit in Queensland

characters and spore measurements. The number of collections from which the
-particular species was obtained is entered under the particular host-parasite combination

relative frequency of occurrence on the different hosts except in the case of
banana, papaw, mango, avocado and strawberry, each of which has received a
considerable amount of attention. It is hoped that the present paper will open
ihe way for an extension to this list.
txt: A host list of the species of Colletotrichum affecting fruit in Queensland is provided. Non-fruit hosts are included for a complete overview. In most cases, the specific identity of the pathogen has been determined through both cultural characters and spore measurements. The number of collections from which each particular species was obtained is noted under the relevant host-parasite combination. These figures may not accurately reflect the relative frequency of occurrence on different hosts, except for banana, papaw, mango, avocado, and strawberry, which have received significant attention. It is hoped that this paper will pave the way for an extension to this list.

pdf:
Matthews (1953, 1955a, 1955b) investigated leaf spots occurring on a
number of garden plants and weeds in the Brisbane district. In each case the
.associated organism was isolated, its cultural and morphological characters were
described and cross inoculations were carried out. As a result of this work the
.causal organism was considered to be Glomerella cingulata (Stonem.) Spauld. &
Schrenk, but no attempt was made to distinguish between varieties of this species.
However, on the basis of the information supplied by Matthews in her papers,
separation into G. cingulata and G. cingulata var. minor can be made with a fair
degree of accuracy. Isolates from azalea (Rhododendron ~ndicum Sweet), Hoya
australis R.Br. and H. carnosa R.Br., and a few from stock (Matthiola incana (L.)
R.Br.), were probably G. cingulata. The other hosts investigated yielded isolates
resembling G. cingulata var. minor or its imperfect state. These included stock,
cabbage and broccoli (Brassica oleracea L. var.), alyssum (Lobularia maritima
(L.) Desv.), wallflower ( Cheiranthus cheiri L.), oleander (Nerium oleander L.),
violet (Viola odorata L.), cestrum ( Cestrum parqui L'Herit.), and pigweed
(Portulaca oleracea L.).
txt: Matthews investigated leaf spots occurring on various garden plants and weeds in the Brisbane district. In each case, the associated organism was isolated, its cultural and morphological characteristics were described, and cross-inoculations were conducted. This research identified the causal organism as Glomerella cingulata, though no distinction was made between its varieties. However, based on Matthews's findings, separation into G. cingulata and G. cingulata var. minor can be achieved with reasonable accuracy. Isolates from azalea (Rhododendron indicum), Hoya australis, and H. carnosa, along with a few from stock (Matthiola incana), were likely G. cingulata. Other hosts investigated yielded isolates resembling G. cingulata var. minor or its imperfect state, including stock, cabbage and broccoli (Brassica oleracea), alyssum (Lobularia maritima), wallflower (Cheiranthus cheiri), oleander (Nerium oleander), violet (Viola odorata), cestrum (Cestrum parqui), and pigweed (Portulaca oleracea).
q1: What methods did Matthews use to investigate the leaf spots on garden plants and weeds?
q2: How did Matthews' findings contribute to the understanding of Glomerella cingulata and its varieties?
q3: Which specific garden plants and weeds were found to be associated with G. cingulata and its varieties?
q4: Did Matthews conduct cross inoculations as part of the investigation?
q5: Was G. cingulata identified as the causal organism for the leaf spots?
q6: Were isolates from azalea and Hoya species considered to be G. cingulata?

pdf:
The extent of lesion development even with the same organism is liable to
vary considerably with the interplay of such factors as variety and condition of the
fruit employed, ambient temperature, and the history of the culture used as inoculant.
A direct comparison of the size of lesions developed in separate series of
experiments is therefore unjustified. In the inoculations discussed here an endeavour
was made to include on each fruit an organism known to be pathogenic to the
particular host employed. Activity was measured by the diameter of the lesion
produced, and an organism was recorded as pathogenic only jf this diameter was
equal to at least half of the diameter of the largest lesion on the particular fruit
examined. This attempts to eliminate the smaller type of lesion often produced
on fruit, especially if mature, by organisms which can hardly be regarded strictly
as pathogenic. Figure 6 illustrates this method of recording.
txt: The extent of lesion development, even with the same organism, can vary considerably due to factors such as the variety and condition of the fruit, ambient temperature, and the culture history of the inoculant used. Therefore, a direct comparison of lesion sizes across separate experiments is unjustified. In the inoculations discussed, each fruit was inoculated with an organism known to be pathogenic to the specific host. Activity was measured by the diameter of the lesions produced, and an organism was recorded as pathogenic only if this diameter was at least half of the largest lesion on the fruit examined. This approach aims to exclude smaller lesions often produced by organisms that cannot be strictly considered pathogenic, especially on mature fruit. Figure 6 illustrates this method of recording.
q1: What factors influence the severity of lesion development in fruit?
q2: Why is it considered unjustified to directly compare lesion sizes across different experiments?
q3: How is the pathogenicity of an organism determined in relation to the lesions it produces?
q4: Is the ambient temperature a factor in lesion development?
q5: Does the study focus on specific types of fruit?
q6: Is an organism classified as pathogenic based solely on the size of the lesions it produces?

pdf:
The results of the artificial inoculations so far as they apply confirm the
host range determined by field collections. As a rule, a particular isolate was most
active in attacking the host from which it was originally obtained. This was
particularily noticeable in the case of banana and mango, which are less favoured
hosts except for their own normal pathogen. C. musae and the mango strain
of G. cingulata var. minor also show restricted activity towards hosts other than
the normal one. On the other hand, papaw was susceptible to most of the
organisms tested. This may be partly due to the absence of a fungi-toxic reaction
in the skin of this fruit; it is possible to demonstrate one in banana, mango and
avocado (Simmonds 1963).
txt: The results of the artificial inoculations confirm the host range determined by field collections. Generally, a particular isolate was most active in attacking the host from which it was originally obtained. This was especially noticeable in the case of banana and mango, which are less favored hosts except for their own typical pathogens. C. musae and the mango strain of G. cingulata var. minor also showed restricted activity towards hosts other than their normal ones. In contrast, papaw was susceptible to most of the organisms tested. This may be partly due to the absence of a fungi-toxic reaction in the skin of this fruit, which can be demonstrated in banana, mango, and avocado.

q2: What role do the host plants' natural pathogens play in their susceptibility to infections?
q3: Why might papaw be more susceptible to various organisms compared to banana, mango, and avocado?

pdf:
Glmnerella cingulata stat. conid. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
G. cingulata in its typical form has a restricted host range as a fruit pathogen
in Queensland. It is the cause of a common and characteristic ripe fruit rot of
the papaw and a skin blemish of passion-fruit, especially of hybrids between the
purple and yellow varieties. Spore measurements, the appearance of cultures
of the plus type and the black, somewhat corrugated, spot produced on papaw
are all characteristic. Cultures of the sterile types are apt to be somewhat
nondescript and not always readily identified.
txt:
Glomerella cingulata stat. conid. Colletotrichum gloeosporioides
G. cingulata, in its typical form, has a restricted host range as a fruit pathogen in Queensland. It causes a common and characteristic ripe fruit rot of papaw and a skin blemish on passion fruit, especially in hybrids between the purple and yellow varieties. Spore measurements, the appearance of cultures of the plus type, and the black, somewhat corrugated spots produced on papaw are all distinctive characteristics. Cultures of the sterile types tend to be somewhat nondescript and not always readily identified.
q1: What types of plants are primarily affected by Glmnerella cingulata in Queensland?
q2: How does the appearance of the cultures differ between the plus type and the sterile types of G. cingulata?
q3: What are some characteristic features used to identify G. cingulata?
q4: Does Glmnerella cingulata cause ripe fruit rot in papaw?
q5: Are the sterile types of G. cingulata easily identifiable?
q6: Is G. cingulata associated with both papaw and passion-fruit?
metadata: A STUDY OF THE SPECIES OF COLLETOTRICHUM .pdf

pdf:
This specialized form of C. gloeosporioides has a wide host range and is the
most commonly met member of the genus in Queensland. It is an important cause
of ripe fruit rotting of papaw, avocado, mango and apple and is found less
frequently injuring a number of other economic plants. C. gloeosporioides var.
niinor is quick-growing and develops an abundance of aerial mycelium in culture.
Normal spore size is characteristic, but collections in which the size approaches
the lower range for C. gloeosporioides may require cultural examination for definite
identification.
txt: This specialized form of C. gloeosporioides has a wide host range and is the most commonly encountered member of the genus in Queensland. It is an important cause of ripe fruit rot in papaw, avocado, mango, and apple, and it less frequently affects other economic plants. C. gloeosporioides var. niinor is quick-growing and develops abundant aerial mycelium in culture. While normal spore size is characteristic, collections with sizes approaching the lower range for C. gloeosporioides may require cultural examination for definitive identification.

q2: How does the growth rate of C. gloeosporioides var. niinor compare to other strains?
q3: What methods are used for the identification of C. gloeosporioides when spore size is ambiguous?
q4: Is C. gloeosporioides the most common member of its genus in Queensland?
q5: Does C. gloeosporioides primarily affect ripe fruits?
q6: Is cultural examination necessary for identifying C. gloeosporioides in some cases?

pdf:
For many years it has been apparent that two distinct forms of G. cingulata
exist in Queensland. To unite these under the same name would only serve to
obscure the many differences. Wollenweber and Hochapfel (1949) appear to have
met with a Glomerella showing the same divergence from the original G. cingulata
( Stonem.) S.pauld. & Schrenk as the one under discussion. Their nomenclature
for the perfect stage has accordingly been adopted and is the one used here.
txt: For many years, it has been apparent that two distinct forms of G. cingulata exist in Queensland. Uniting these under the same name would only obscure the many differences. Wollenweber and Hochapfel encountered a Glomerella that shows the same divergence from the original G. cingulata (Stonem.) S. paul. & Schrenk as the one under discussion. Their nomenclature for the perfect stage has been adopted and is the one used here.

pdf:
Since the perfect stage of this variety is met with only rarely in Queensland,
it is desirable for practical convenience to have a distinguishing name for the
conidial state also. Wollenweber and Hochapfel consider the imperfect state of
their G. cingulata var. minor to be Gloeosporium elasticae (Thlim.) Cke. & Mass.,
of which they list several synonyms, mainly· species occurring on fig and coffee.
Conidial measurements given by W ollenweber and Hochapfel for this species are
within the range obtained for C. gloeosporioides var. minor in Queensland. In
view of the accepted synonomy of Gloeosporium with Colletotrichum, it would be
inadvisable to perpetuate the former generic name. Unfortunately, Colletotrichum
elasticae is already occupied by C. elasticae Tassi. Apart from the fact that a
species name is not readily available, it would seem preferable to designate
the conidial state of a variety of G. cingulata as a variety of Colletotrichum
gloeosporioides. The name Colletotrichum gloeosporioides Penz. var. minor var.
nov. is therefore proposed and is used in this article. A formal description appears
later.
txt: Since the perfect stage of this variety is rarely found in Queensland, it is practical to have a distinguishing name for the conidial state as well. Wollenweber and Hochapfel consider the imperfect state of their G. cingulata var. minor to be Gloeosporium elasticae, for which they list several synonyms, primarily species occurring on fig and coffee. The conidial measurements provided by Wollenweber and Hochapfel for this species fall within the range observed for C. gloeosporioides var. minor in Queensland. Given the accepted synonymy of Gloeosporium with Colletotrichum, it would be inadvisable to continue using the former generic name. Unfortunately, Colletotrichum elasticae is already taken. Despite the lack of an available species name, it seems preferable to designate the conidial state of a variety of G. cingulata as a variety of Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Thus, the name Colletotrichum gloeosporioides var. minor var. nov. is proposed and will be used in this article, with a formal description to appear later.

It is possible that some of the references in literature to G. cingulata are
to organisms similar to var. minor. For example, some of those described by
Small (1926) as Colletotrichum coffeanum Noack appear to have characters in
common with this variety. A culture from tea in Malaya and one from avocado
in Southern Rhodesia obtained through the courtesy of the Commonwealth
Mycological Institute were similar in appearance to C. gloeosporioides var. minor
in Queensland.
txt: It is possible that some references in the literature to G. cingulata are actually referring to organisms similar to var. minor. For example, some described as Colletotrichum coffeanum by Small appear to share characteristics with this variety. A culture from tea in Malaya and another from avocado in Southern Rhodesia, obtained through the courtesy of the Commonwealth Mycological Institute, resembled C. gloeosporioides var. minor found in Queensland.

pdf:
Colletotrichum musae ( Gloeosporium musarum)
Gloeosporium musarum Cke. & Mass. was originally described from Queensland
material and the organism under discussion here is undoubtedly this species.
In the literature it has been referred to under this name up to the present time.
With the general acceptance of Colletotrichum as the correct generic name for
those organisms formerly separated under Gloeosporium and Colletotrichum, it
seems scarcely justifiable to continue to use the binominal Gloeosporium musarum
and a transfer to Colletotrichum is desirable. After examining type and other
material, Arx (1957a, 1957b) concluded that Gloeosporium musarum Cke. &
Mass. is a synonym of Colletotrichum musae (Berk. & Curt.) Arx (Myxosporium
musae Berk. & Curt.) . In this paper Colletotrichum musae has accordingly been
used as the name for the banana anthracnose organism.
txt: Colletotrichum musae (formerly Gloeosporium musarum) was originally described from Queensland material, and the organism discussed here is undoubtedly this species. It has been referred to by this name in the literature up to the present time. With the general acceptance of Colletotrichum as the correct generic name for organisms formerly classified under Gloeosporium and Colletotrichum, it is scarcely justifiable to continue using the binomial Gloeosporium musarum; thus, a transfer to Colletotrichum is desirable. After examining type and other material, Arx concluded that Gloeosporium musarum Cke. & Mass. is a synonym of Colletotrichum musae (Berk. & Curt.) Arx. In this paper, Colletotrichum musae is used as the name for the banana anthracnose organism.

pdf:
C. musae is the most host-specific of the organisms dealt with and is
moreover very constant in morphological and cultural characters. Conidial
measurements are similar to these of C. gloeosporioides, while cultural characters
resemble those of a cultural type C. gloeosporioides var minor which appears
occasionally. Arx (1957) regards the fungus as a host-specific form of C.
gloeosporioides. It is a rapid grower with a high optimum and maximum
temperature similar to this species. The host-parasite relationships of this
organism in Queensland have been investigated in some detail (Simmonds and
Mitchell 1940; Simmonds 1941, 1963).

Conidial measurements are similar to those of C. gloeosporioides, while cultural traits resemble those of the cultural type C. gloeosporioides var. minor, which appears occasionally. Arx regards the fungus as a host-specific form of C. gloeosporioides. It is a rapid grower with a high optimum and maximum temperature similar to this species. The host-parasite relationships of this organism in Queensland have been investigated in detail.

The perfect state of G. cingulata has been obtained from time to time from
banana (Ashby 1931; Hoette 1935), but these recordings have not been definitely
linked with Colletotrichum musae. It seems more likely that they represent a
separate and less frequent association with banana, such as the isolates from green
banana fruit in Queensland (Table 6).
txt: The perfect state of G. cingulata has been observed intermittently in banana, but these occurrences have not been definitively linked to Colletotrichum musae. It appears more probable that they represent a separate and less common association with banana, similar to the isolates found in green banana fruit in Queensland.

pdf:
Colletotrichum acutatwn
This organism first came to notice in association with one of the ripe fruit
rots of papaw. It was later shown to be the cause of a serious fruit rot of strawberry
(Sturgess 1957) and a less frequent pathogen of a number of other hosts. Conidia
of this species are characteristically variable in length and in the main possess
pointed ends. Some of the larger spores could be mistaken for those of C.
gloeosporioides var. minor, but smaller more typical ones usually accompany
them. Occasionally collections with abnormally long spores are found but these
·commonly revert to the normal length on sub-culturing. Cultures are characteristic
:and show little variation. They almost invariably yield an abundance of conidia
for further confirmation.
It is possible that some of the named species of Colletotrichum refer to this
·one. However the brevity of older descriptions and the custom of quoting extremes
rather than means for spore measurements render it difficult to make any accurate
comparisons. It is not one of the 11 species of Colletotrichum now recognized
by Arx (1957). With some reluctance the Queensland organism has therefore
been described as a new species. A formal description appears at the end of this
article.
txt:
Colletotrichum acutatum
 This organism first came to notice in association with ripe fruit rots of papaw. It was later shown to cause a serious fruit rot of strawberry and is a less frequent pathogen of several other hosts. Conidia of this species are characteristically variable in length, primarily possessing pointed ends. Some larger spores could be mistaken for those of C. gloeosporioides var. minor, but smaller, more typical ones usually accompany them. Occasionally, collections with abnormally long spores are found, but these commonly revert to normal length upon sub-culturing. Cultures are characteristic and show little variation, almost invariably yielding an abundance of conidia for further confirmation. It is possible that some named species of Colletotrichum refer to this one. However, the brevity of older descriptions and the custom of quoting extremes rather than means for spore measurements make accurate comparisons difficult. It is not one of the recognized species of Colletotrichum. With some reluctance, the Queensland organism has therefore been described as a new species, with a formal description appearing at the end of this article.

q4: Is Colletotrichum acutatum primarily known for causing fruit rot in strawberries?
q5: Do cultures of Colletotrichum acutatum show significant variation?
q6: Has Colletotrichum acutatum been officially recognized as one of the species by Arx?

pdf:
·Colletotrichum orbiculare
This fungus is responsible for a characteristic leaf, stem and fruit spotting
of various cucurbits. It is usually considered to be restricted in pathogenicity
to memb~rs of the Curcurbitaceae, but in Queensland the host range has been
extended to three plants outside this family. C. orbiculare is a slow-growing
species with a low optimum temperature. This and the characteristic spore and
·cultural characters make this species one of the easiest to identify. Host
specificity occurs and isolates from celery and saffiower do not rot watermelon.
txt: Colletotrichum orbiculare is a fungus responsible for characteristic leaf, stem, and fruit spotting on various cucurbits. It is typically considered pathogenic only to members of the Cucurbitaceae family, but in Queensland, its host range has expanded to three plants outside this family. C. orbiculare is a slow-growing species with a low optimum temperature, and its distinctive spore and cultural characteristics make it one of the easiest to identify. Host specificity is observed, as isolates from celery and safflower do not rot watermelon.

Colletotrichum atramentarium
 In Queensland, this species is restricted to members of the Solanaceae. It is the most common species of Colletotrichum causing ripe fruit rot in tomatoes, though it is not frequently encountered. C. atramentarium is readily identified by its long, narrow conidia and the characteristic speckled culture resulting from the formation of sclerotia.

C. dematium is the only species dealt with here which possesses a sickleshaped

is responsible for a conspicuous ripe fruit rot of papaw. It is not uncommon

Cultures are somewhat characterless unless spore production is evident. This fungus is responsible for a notable ripe fruit rot of papaw. While it is not uncommon, it is of lesser importance compared to other Colletotrichum species that affect this host.

pdf:
Colletotrichum acutatum sp. nov.
Mycelium in cultu lente crescens partim tenue hyalinum, partin crassum
fuscum septis manifestioribus. Chlamydosporae adsunt. Conidia longitudine
pervariabilia, 11·1 x 3 · lμ, (plerumque 8 · 3-14 · 4 x 2 · 5-4 · 00 ), extremitatibus
plerumque acutatis. Appressoria plerumque obovata.
Rab. in fruit of Carica papaya L., Fragaria X ananassa Duchesne,
Lycopersicon esculentum Mill. in Queensland.
Diagnostic features of the conidia are the small size, the variability in length
in the one collection, and the pointed ends.
On P.D.A. the cultural type is characteristic and relatively constant (pp.
444-5). The colony is moderately slow-growing, with an optimum temperature of
25 to 26 · 8 °C. Mycelium is slender and hyaline, with broader, stout, much
septate, dark mycelium appearing later. Terminal and intercalary chlamydospores
of various size may be present; these are hyaline or more commonly dark when
developing from the dark hyphae.
On the host, conidia are produced in acervuli. In culture they appear to
be formed throughout the mycelium, although massed conidiophores in the nature
of acervuli may occur. Spore masses are salmon-coloured and when they are
formed in culture are often more or less hidden in the mycelium. Setae have
not been observed in association with acervuli but scattered, poorly developed
setae appear occasionally in culture.
Conidiophores are slender, two to three times the length of the spore and
about half the width, or they may be shorter and stouter. Appressoria are rarely
lobed and the germ pore is often poorly defined.
The host range and other characteristics of this species have been discussed
in more detail in the foregoing pages. Representative dried cultures are deposited
in the Herbarium of the Botany Department, University of Queensland, and in
the Herbarium of the Commonwealth Mycological Institute, England.
txt:
Colletotrichum acutatum sp. nov.

Mycelium in culture grows slowly, partly thin and hyaline, partly thick and dark brown with more distinct septa. Chlamydospores are present. Conidia vary in length, measuring approximately 11.1 x 3.1 μm (generally ranging from 8.3-14.4 x 2.5-4.0 μm), with the ends mostly pointed. Appressoria are generally obovate.

It has been observed on the fruit of Carica papaya L., Fragaria × ananassa Duchesne, and Lycopersicon esculentum Mill. in Queensland. Diagnostic features of the conidia include their small size, variability in length within a single collection, and pointed ends.

On potato dextrose agar (PDA), the cultural type is characteristic and relatively constant. The colony is moderately slow-growing, with an optimum temperature of 25 to 26.8 °C. The mycelium is slender and hyaline, with broader, stout, and highly septate dark mycelium appearing later. Terminal and intercalary chlamydospores of various sizes may be present; these are hyaline or, more commonly, dark when developing from the dark hyphae.

On the host, conidia are produced in acervuli. In culture, they appear to be formed throughout the mycelium, although massed conidiophores may occur in the nature of acervuli. Spore masses are salmon-colored and are often more or less hidden within the mycelium when formed in culture. Setae have not been observed in association with acervuli, but scattered, poorly developed setae occasionally appear in culture.

Conidiophores are slender, two to three times the length of the spore and about half the width, though they may also be shorter and stouter. Appressoria are rarely lobed, and the germ pore is often poorly defined. The host range and other characteristics of this species have been discussed in more detail in preceding sections. Representative dried cultures are deposited in the Herbarium of the Botany Department, University of Queensland, and in the Herbarium of the Commonwealth Mycological Institute, England.

q2: How does the growth of Colletotrichum acutatum sp. nov. vary in culture compared to on its hosts?

q4: Is Colletotrichum acutatum sp. nov. commonly found on fruits like Carica papaya and Fragaria ananassa?
q5: Does the mycelium of Colletotrichum acutatum sp. nov. exhibit significant variability in its morphology?
q6: Are representative dried cultures of Colletotrichum acutatum sp. nov. preserved in multiple herbaria?

pdf: Strawberry anthracnose is an important disease in China that results in significant economic losses. A number of Colletotrichum species are known to be pathogens of strawberry. A survey of strawberry fields in eight provinces of China was carried out to identify the causal agents of strawberry anthracnose. The disease mainly causes crown rot, leading to plant wilt and death in the nursery stage, after transplanting in green house, which makes anthracnose a major threat to strawberry production and quality. Multi-locus sequence analysis coupled with morphological assessment revealed that the disease-associated taxa belong to two Colletotrichum species complexes: Colletotrichum nymphaeae (acutatum species complex), C. fructicola and C. changpingense sp. nov. (gloeosporioides species complex). The novel species is introduced in this paper and illustrated. The new species is closely related to C. theobromicola and pathogenicity tests proved that it is pathogenic to the strawberry crown, fruits and leaves.
txt: Strawberry anthracnose is a significant disease in China, causing substantial economic losses. Several Colletotrichum species are recognized as pathogens of strawberries. A survey of strawberry fields across eight provinces identified the causal agents of this disease. Anthracnose primarily leads to crown rot, resulting in plant wilt and death during the nursery stage and after transplanting in greenhouses, posing a major threat to strawberry production and quality. Multi-locus sequence analysis, combined with morphological assessments, revealed that the disease-associated taxa belong to two Colletotrichum species complexes: Colletotrichum nymphaeae (acutatum species complex) and C. fructicola, as well as the newly identified C. changpingense sp. nov. This paper introduces the novel species, which is closely related to C. theobromicola, and pathogenicity tests confirm its ability to affect the strawberry crown, fruits, and leaves.

pdf: Strawberry (Fragaria× ananassa) is a major crop cultivated in China (Xie et al. 2010). Strawberry production has expanded rapidly in recent years and China has become one of the world’s largest strawberry producers and exporters. Strawberry cultivation occupies 100.5 × 103 ha with a yield of 2.8 million tonnes in 2013 (The Ministry of Agriculture of the People’s Republic of China 2014). With the increase of production, many fungal diseases have become a major problem in strawberry production, reducing fruit yield and quality (Mass 1998, Smith 2008). One of the most important diseases of strawberry is anthracnose, which is caused by species of Colletotrichum.

pdf: Colletotrichum is one of the most important plant pathogenic genera worldwide (Cannon et al. 2012, Hyde et al. 2014, Nilsson et al. 2014, Yan et al. 2015), occurring predominantly in tropical and subtropical regions on a wide range of crops (Waller 1993, Hyde et al. 2009 a, b, 2014). A summary of names (Hyde et al. 2009a) and a review of the confusion with names in the genus (Hyde et al. 2009b), helped to kick start a series of studies that used molecular phylogeny and morphology, that have helped to define species in the genus (Cannon et al. 2012). Anthracnose caused by Colletotrichum species is a major disease affecting strawberry production across the world (Mass 1998). Colletotrichum species infect all plant parts causing serious crown rot, irregular leaf spots, necrotic lesions on the petioles and runners, as well as black spot on the fruits (Mass 1998). Anthracnose can cause up to 80% of plant death in nurseries and over 50% of yield losses in strawberry fields (Sreenivasaprasad & Talhinhas 2005). For successful implementation of any resistance breeding and disease management programme, accurate pathogen identification is important (Freeman et al. 1998).
txt: Colletotrichum is one of the most important plant pathogenic genera worldwide, predominantly occurring in tropical and subtropical regions on a wide range of crops. A summary of names and a review of the naming confusion within the genus helped to initiate a series of studies utilizing molecular phylogeny and morphology, which have clarified species definitions in the genus. Anthracnose, caused by Colletotrichum species, is a major disease affecting strawberry production globally. These species infect all plant parts, leading to serious crown rot, irregular leaf spots, necrotic lesions on petioles and runners, as well as black spots on the fruits. Anthracnose can result in up to 80% plant death in nurseries and over 50% yield losses in strawberry fields. For the successful implementation of any resistance breeding and disease management program, accurate pathogen identification is essential.

pdf: Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China as late as 1990 (Hu 1990). Shao (1992) reported strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai for the first time and identified the pathogen as C. acutatum (Dai et al. 2006). Zhang et al. (2007) contributed to these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (syn C. theobromicola) as the causal agents based on morphological characters. Ren et al. (2008, 2011) concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose of strawberry in China. Crown rot is the most severe disease problem in most strawberry producing areas in China (Ren et al. 2008). In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% of yield losses in strawberry fields has been recorded (Xie et al. 2010). The yield of greenhouse cultivated strawberries was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot in Donggang city in Laoning Province in 2009 (Wang 2013). The average incidence of crown rot in green houses of Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011 (Xiang et al. 2012). However, the majority of studies conducted in China regarding this disease were mainly based on morphology and single gene (mainly ITS) analysis (Dai et al. 2006, Ren et al. 2008, 2011). Due to the overlapping characters, species delimitation based on morphology alone is difficult in this genus. Use of multi-gene analysis combined with morphology can provide a better resolution (Cai et al. 2009, Hyde et al. 2014). Therefore the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens causing strawberry anthracnose in China using a morphological and multi-gene approach.
txt: Strawberry anthracnose was first reported in China in 1990. Shao reported strawberry anthracnose in Shanghai for the first time and identified the pathogen as Colletotrichum acutatum. Zhang and colleagues contributed to these findings by identifying C. gloeosporioides and C. fragariae (synonym C. theobromicola) as causal agents based on morphological characteristics. Subsequent research concluded that these three species are the main pathogens causing anthracnose in strawberries in China. Crown rot is the most severe disease affecting strawberry production in the country. In the Zhejiang region, nearly 50% of seedling deaths in nurseries and over 40% of yield losses in strawberry fields have been recorded. Additionally, the yield of greenhouse-cultivated strawberries was reduced by over 10% due to crown rot in Donggang City, Liaoning Province, in 2009. The average incidence of crown rot in greenhouses in Hubei Province was 41.7% in 2011. However, most studies on this disease in China have primarily relied on morphological and single gene (mainly ITS) analyses. Due to overlapping characteristics, species delimitation based solely on morphology is challenging in this genus. Utilizing multi-gene analysis in conjunction with morphological data can provide better resolution. Therefore, the objective of this study was to identify the pathogens causing strawberry anthracnose in China using a combined morphological and multi-gene approach.

pdf:
Sample collection, Isolation and Identification of fungi
Disease samples showing anthracnose symptoms were collected from different locations (Anhui, Hainan, Hebei, Hubei, Liaoning, Shandong Provinces and Beijing, Shanghai cities) in China during 2011–2014. To promote fungal development and facilitate isolation, samples were incubated in a clean polythene bag with sterilized tissue dipped in distilled water. Samples were surface sterilized in 3.5% Sodium hypochlorite for 1–2 minutes and then rinsed three times in sterilized water before culturing on Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) medium at 28 °C. Single germinating conidia were transferred to fresh PDA medium and incubated at 28 °C to obtain pure colonies of the fungi (Chomnunti et al. 2014). The pure isolates were maintained on PDA medium with sterilized filter paper and incubated for 7–10 days at 28 °C. Cultures on the filter papers were dried and stored at -20 °C for further study. Fungal mycelia and spores were observed and photographed using a ZEISS Imager M1 microscope and measurements were made on 40 conidia. All microscopic measurements were made with the Axio vision v 4.8 and images used for figures were processed with Adobe Photoshop CS3 Extended version 10.0 software (Adobe Systems, The United States). Facesoffungi and Index Fungorum numbers are provided (Jayasiri et al. 2015, Index Fungorum 2016).
txt:
Sample Collection, Isolation, and Identification of Fungi
 Disease samples showing anthracnose symptoms were collected from various locations in China, including Anhui, Hainan, Hebei, Hubei, Liaoning, Shandong provinces, and the cities of Beijing and Shanghai, between 2011 and 2014. To promote fungal development and facilitate isolation, samples were incubated in a clean polythene bag with sterilized tissue dipped in distilled water. The samples were surface sterilized in 3.5% sodium hypochlorite for 1 to 2 minutes and rinsed three times in sterilized water before being cultured on Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) medium at 28 簞C. Single germinating conidia were transferred to fresh PDA medium and incubated at 28 簞C to obtain pure fungal colonies. The pure isolates were maintained on PDA medium with sterilized filter paper and incubated for 7 to 10 days at 28 簞C. The cultures on the filter papers were dried and stored at -20 簞C for further study. Fungal mycelia and spores were observed and photographed using a ZEISS Imager M1 microscope, with measurements taken from 40 conidia. All microscopic measurements were conducted with Axio Vision v4.8, and the images used for figures were processed with Adobe Photoshop CS3 Extended version 10.0.
